And what kind of piece are you? To be sure, Puzzle. ìActually, now the conference is over, my time is my own. But I could use another day of rest from yesterdayís ordeal, if Jin is willing. Although I do need to report in to one fellow. Jin, if I gave you directions, do you think you could hand-carry a letter across town for me, and give it to a man?î
Jin perked up. ìSure! UhÖ maybe. What part of town?î
ìEast side.î
ìUmÖ yah, I could do that.î
Miles decided to ignore the faint tinge of doubt in his voice. ìWhere are we now, by the way?î
ìSouth side,î said Jin.
ìGo yourself,î said Suze. ìIíll give you the tube-tram fare. Just donít come back.î
ìAnd when the police ask me where Iíve been, what shall I tell them?î
Her face grew grimmer. ìTell them you were lost.î
ìI couldóif it were worth my while.î
The snort this time was savage. ìIf we had money for bribes, would we be here?î
ìYou mistake my meaning, maíam. My coin is information. Although, you know, youíre the second person on Kibou whoís tried to bribe me. Is this some sort of local custom?î
Her mouth worked. ìWho was the first?î
ìWhiteChrys.î
ìImpressive.î
ìIt impressed me, although not in the way they intended. Small gifts are for selling things. Large gifts are for hiding things. It made me very, very curious.î
ìSo did you take your large gift, Vorkosigan-san?î

He did not bother correcting it to Vorkosigan-sama, or possibly -dono; at least she had the pronunciation right. ìAt that level, a scornful no is not only shortsighted, but potentially dangerous. I think a day or two of rest here might be good for my health.î
ìAnd how do I know that letter to your friend wonít bring more trouble down on us?î
ìIt wonít if I say not. I outrank him.î
Her lips twisted. ìYah, you have that swagger, donít you?î
And Suze had undoubtedly seen a lot of upper management swagger in her time. Miles wondered if her bosses had realized how closely they were observed.
Jin had been following this exchange with anxious squeakings of his chair. ìI could take his letter, Suze! I donít mind a bit.î

Miles opened a hand to Suze, half persuasion, half plea. ìThink it through. You lose no secrecy you havenít lost alreadyîóhe cut the unless you propose to have me murderedóno point in planting suggestionsóìand you gain my gratitude.î
ìAnd whatís that worth?î
On Barrayar, quite a lot. But they were not, as Roic had several times pointed out, on Barrayar. ìIíll think of something.î

Her eyebrows signaled severe skepticism. But she spoke instead to Jin: ìDidnít Yani tell you to leave him out there? See what trouble comes of good deeds, Jin!î Miles wasnít sure if this counted for a yea or a nay, but she heaved a sigh and went on, ìTake Vorkosigan-san down to the storerooms and find him something to write with. And on.î
Jin shot eagerly to his feet. Miles made his thanks and followed him out before Suze could change her mind.

Jin watched, shifting from foot to foot, as Miles-san, as heíd decided to think of him, because that last name was a jaw-breaker, sorted through the few half-empty boxes of notepaper on the shelf in the storeroom. It was mostly the kind that old ladies used for writing formal thank-you notes, decorated with flowers and such, though Jin eyed one that bore puppies with a certain covetousness. With a quirk of his eyebrows, the little man made his selection, then turned to testing pens from the box of assorted discards. He found two that worked, stuck them in his pocket, and looked around.
ìThis place looks like a junk shop. Or the attic of Vorkosigan HouseÖî

ìWhenever anybody has findings that they donít want, they bring them down here for anybody to use,î Jin explained. ìOr else whenÖ um.î When they go downstairs to Tenbury for the last time, but he couldnít say that. He wasnít sure he was even supposed to know that.

Miles-sanís gaze caught. ìAh! Shoes!î He limped over to the pile. Jin tagged along, and helpfully also began sorting. The galacticís feet were a little smaller than his own, but then, Jin had had to find replacement shoes here just a month ago, when his toes had pushed through his last pair like spring shoots through soil. The ladiesí fancy shoes were all useless even to most of the ladies here, and tended to accumulate, but Miles found a pair of sport shoes that fit at last. They were a girly flowered print, but he didnít seem to notice as he shoved them on and fastened the straps. ìThatís better. Now I can move.î He turned, scanning the stores more closely. ìHuh. Canes!î

He went to the collection leaning in a corner and picked though it, passing up some sturdy medical ones with multiple rubber feet, and others that were too long. He made his final choice by sweeping them around like swords and thwacking them against the wall, so that Jin wasnít sure if he was looking for a prop or a weapon. But just in case it was the former, Jin led him back to his rooftop home by the inside route, up the emergency stairs and out the exchanger tower door.

Miles-san took over the table and chair, set out his paper, and frowned, face intent. The he bent and began scratching with the pen, with occasional long, thoughtful pauses. Jin had cleaned out the chickensí boxes, counted the chicks just in case any had found the parapet again, and brushed Lucky before the man finished writing, sealed the note, and looked up, squinting around.
ìDo you have a clean sharp knife? Or pin, or needle?î

ìIíll look.î Jin eventually found a little scalpel in the half-a-medicine-kit heíd once collected, and handed it over. Miles-san eyed it, shrugged, and to Jinís alarm poked his thumb with the sharp end. After squeezing out a drop of blood, he bent and pressed it over the flap, leaving a clear thumbprint across the line, which he then circled and initialed.
ìYah, wow,î said Jin. ìWhyíd you do that?î

ìDNA. Thumbprintís as good a mark as my grandfatherís seal-dagger. Better. They didnít do DNA scans in his day. After all, one couldnít expect the attaché to bestir himself for just any anonymous note off the street.î

He then proceeded to give Jin a rather complicated set of directions for after heíd reached the east side, which he made Jin recite back; the result made him sigh, and bend again to write the manís name and address on the outside of the envelope after all. ìI expect youíll get there one way or another. Donít give this into the hand of anyone but Lieutenant Johannes or Consul Vorlynkin, mind. Itís very private.î
Jin promised this, and went to find his box of coins, fishing out enough for the tube-tram fare, both ways. It didnít leave much.
ìIs that your whole bank?î Miles-san asked, peering over his shoulder. Jin nodded. ìWell, if you make my delivery, youíll get it back.î

Jin wasnít sure how much store to set by this, but he nodded anyway. In turn he gave Miles-san a set of instructions should any animal emergencies arise while he was gone, which made the man blink a little. But he recited them back flawlessly. Jin tucked the letter inside his shirt, cast one last doubtful look over his shoulder, and descended the ladder.

Jin was nervous on the tube-tram, afraid people were looking at him, but no one seized him by the arm and dragged him to Security. He almost lost himself in the big transfer station downtown, the east side routes being unfamiliar to him, but he kept his eyes rigidly on the wall maps and made an effort to not look panicked. Helpful people could be as dangerous to him as suspicious ones. He found the right tube and the right stop at last.

A six-block walk, without too many turns, brought him to his destination. The neighborhood was full not of tidy apartment buildings of the sort heíd grown up in, but of forbiddingly fine houses in walled gardens. Several bore shiny brass plaques beside their gates labeling them as planetary embassiesóEscobarís was an especially large and impressive mansion. The Barrayaran Consulate, thankfully also clearly labeled, was not so intimidating by contrastóquite a small house, really, set close to the street so Jin didnít have time to get scared going up the walk. No uniformed guards, and the decorative iron gate was so low Jin might have hopped over it, if it hadnít been left invitingly open. Jin gulped and pressed the buzzer.

The door was opened by a blond man in shirtsleeves, his slim green trousers held up by braces. He looked rumpled and tired and in need of a depilatory. He stared at Jin with lowered brows. ìNo solicitors or beggars,î he said unencouragingly.

He had the same rumbly accent as Miles-san, and Jin realized to his dismay that not all Barrayarans were short. This man was very tall. ìPlease, sir, Iím a messenger. I have a letter for Lieutenant Johannes or Consul Vor, um, Vorlynkin.î From Miles-sanís brief description of the lieutenant, Jin thought this might be him, but did lieutenants answer doors? Further, Jin thought with some outrage, Miles-san had called him a nice kid, not a scary grownup. Though he supposed lieutenants had to be grownups.
ìIím Johannes.î
Jin reached inside his shirt; the man tensed, but eased again when Jin drew out the letter. ìFrom Miles-sanófrom Mr. Vorkosigan.î Jin was careful with the pronunciation.
ìShit!î

Jin flinched. Lieutenant Johannes then terrified him further by grabbing his arm, dragging him into the front hall, and slamming the door shut. He snatched the letter, held it up to the light, then tore it open, pausing only to shout up the stairway, ìStefin!î
He began running his eyes down the neat, tightly-written lines. ìAlive, oh thank God! Weíre saved!î

A second grownup, somewhat older and even taller than the first, clattered down the stairs. He was dressed like any Northbridge businessman right down to the hakama-like trousers, except that his wide-sleeved haori coat hung open, and he looked as squinty-eyed and tired as the lieutenant. ìWhat, Trev?î
ìLook at this! A letter from Lord Vorkosiganóheís free!î
The second man looked over his shoulder, and echoed, ìThank God! But why didnít he call in?î Then, after a moment more, ìWhat? What?î
The lieutenant turned the letter over and they both read on. ìIs he insane?î
The older man cast Jin a very narrow look, stirring up all Jinís worst fears. Policemen loomed in his imagination.
ìIs this real?î the older man demanded.
Jin bent, picked up the fallen envelope, and held it out mutely. He swallowed and managed, ìHe said youíd like the thumbprint. He said it would be just like his grandfatherís seal.î
ìIs that blood?î
ìUm, yahÖ ?î
The older man handed the envelope to the lieutenant. ìTake that downstairs and check it.î
ìYes, sir.î Trev-san disappeared through the doorway at the back of the hall. After a moment, Jin heard a door slam, and feet thumping down some other stairs.

ìExcuse me, sir, are you the consul?î Jin had gained the vague notion that a consul was something like an ambassador, but smaller. Rather like his house, really. ìBecause Miles-san said, only give his letter to the lieutenant or Consul Vorlynkin.î He managed to get that last name out without stumbling over his tongue, this time. Jin would have expected an ambassador proper to be stouter and older, but this man was lean and not as old as Miles-san, or at least, he didnít have any gray in his brown hair.
ìIím Vorlynkin.î His stare at Jin intensified. His eyes were very blue, like a hot summer sky. ìWhere did you see Lord Auditor Vorkosigan?î
ìI, um, met him last night. Heíd been lost in the Cryocombs. He said.î
ìIs he all right?î
The answer seemed more complicated than the question, but Jin decided to skip all that and just reassure him: ìHeís much better this morning. I gave him eggs.î
Vorlynkin blinked, and looked at the letter some more. ìIf this wasnít a letter in his own handóif this isnít a letter in his own handóIíd have you under fast-penta soÖ eh. Where did you see him?î
ìUm, where I live.î
ìAnd whereís that?î

He was in trouble now, between Suze and this alarming stranger. He was never supposed to talk to strangers, or tell anyone about the facility, heíd been told that often enough. He wondered if he could bolt back out the door and down the walk before the consul could grab him. ìUm, my placeÖ ?î
ìWhatÖî To his surprise, Vorlynkin did not pursue this, but turned the letter over again. ìWhat did he seem to be about?î
ìUmÖ he asked a lot of questions.î Jin thought a moment, and offered, ìHeís not kidnapped any more, you know.î

ìBut why send a child as a courierÖ ?î Vorlynkin muttered. Jin wasnít sure if the question was addressed to him, so did not attempt to volunteer an answer. It didnít seem the time to explain about almost twelve, either. He was beginning to think that the less he said, the safer he would be.
The other fellowóLieutenant Johannes, Trev-san, whateveróstumped back into to the entry hall, waving the envelope at his boss. ìThis partís real. Now what, sir?î

ìWe still have to find his armsman just the sameóhe seems to think Roic was taken. No change there with respect to the locals. I suppose we have to do exactly what this says. But send a holo of the letter to ImpSec Galactic Affairs on Komarr, priority, scrambled.î
The lieutenant looked hopeful. ìMaybe theyíll have an order. Some other order. One that makes more sense.î
ìNot for some days. And think who theyíd have to go to for an override.î The two men looked at each other in mysterious perturbation. ìWeíre still on our own, here.î
Jin diffidently cleared his throat. ìMiles-san said I was to bring back a reply.î

ìYes,î said the consul. ìWait there.î He pointed to a spindly chair against the wall, one of a pair flanking a little bureau with silk flowers atop it, and a mirror above. Both men thumped downstairs again.

Jin sat. Only the firmness and brevity of that Yes gave him the courage not to run away while he had this chance. However doubtful they were of Jin, they seemed to take Miles-sanís letter seriously, which was a relief.

He was left alone for a long time. He got up once, to peer into the rooms flanking the entry hall. One was a sort of living room, very fancy; the other was more severe and officelike. No sign of pets, not even a bird in a cage or a cat. He was glad he hadnít gone poking around searching for any when another man emerged from the back hall, looked at him in surprise, and said, ìMay I help you?î
This fellow spoke in a normal Kibou accent, at least. Jin shook his head vigorously. ìLieutenant Johannes is seeing to, um, it. Me.î

The ease with which Jin spun off the lieutenantís name seemed to reassure the man. ìOh,î he said, and wandered into the office, to sit at the comconsole and begin some sort of work there. Jin stayed in his seat after that.
After a great deal more time, Vorlynkin came back. He held another sealed envelope in his hand, plain and businesslike, much bulkier than the one Jin had delivered.
ìDo you think you can give this back into the hand of Lord Vorkosiganóonly?î
Jin stood up. ìI got this far.î
ìSo you did.î With visible reluctance, the consul handed the envelope over. Jin stuffed it into his shirt once more, and lost no time in escaping.
I didnít understand any of that. Jin looked back apprehensively as he passed out the iron gate once more. But he was glad Miles-san seemed to have some friends. Of a sort.

As soon as heíd seen Jin safely over the parapet, Miles retraced his steps to the basement cafeteria, careful to make no wrong turns. He was apparently early for lunch, as only a few heads turned in suspicion to follow him. It occurred to him that he was less conspicuous here in his tattered garb than if heíd been wearing his full-on Imperial Auditor grays, a suit so severe as to signal Serious Person Here anywhere in the Nexus regardless of the vagaries of local fashion. Street Refugee Here was a much better choice for his current needs.

The scattering of tables was divided from the cooking area by a long serving counter, with metal cupboards above. He made his way around it to find a sort of large electric samovar promising tea. Next to the dispenser was a mismatched collection of mugs, with a hand-lettered sign over it, Wash your cup! He couldnít quite tell if these were personally owned or up for grabs, which gave him a perfect opening for conversation with the woman, evidently Akoís replacement, who was stirring a ten-liter pot of soup.
He addressed her, ìMay I use one of these?î
She shrugged. ìGo ahead. Wash it after, though.î She tapped her spoon on the pot rim and laid it aside. ìYou new here?î
ìVery new.î
ìRules are, cook what you want, clean up after yourself, replace what you use, contribute money to the pantry when you can. Sign up on the cleaning duty roster on the front of the fridge.î
ìThanks. Just tea for nowÖî Miles took a sip. It was stewed, cheap, bitter, and served his purposes as a prop in both senses. ìYou been here long yourself?î
ìI came with my grandmother. It wonít be much longer.î

As he was figuring out how to lead her on to parse that, a familiar, querulous voice sounded from beyond the counter: ìThat soup ready yet?î A tall, bent old man stooped to peer through the serving hatch. Impressive white mustachios drooped down, framing his frown, and wriggled as he spoke. Like an insectís palps, ah.
ìAnother half hour,î the woman called back. ìJust go sit.î
ìI believe Iíve met him,î Miles murmured to her. ìName of Yani?î
ìYah, thatís him.î
Yani shuffled in to collect a mug of tea from the dispenser. He scowled at Miles.
Miles returned a cheery smile. ìGood morning, Yani.î

ìSo, youíve sobered up. Good. Go home.î Yani clutched his mug in two hands, to average out the shakes perhaps, and shuffled back to one of the tables. Miles, undaunted, followed and slid in across from him.
ìWhy havenít you gone away?î asked Yani.
ìStill waiting for my ride. So to speak.î
ìArenít we all.î

ìJin says youíre a revive. Did you really have yourself frozen a century ago?î That would have been just about at the end of Barrayarís Time of Isolation, on the verge of a torrent of new history all of which Yani had more-or-less slept through. ìI would think the oral chroniclers around here would be all over you.î

Yani vented a bitter laugh. ìNot likely. The people here are glutted with revive interviews. I thought the journals might pay me, but there are too many of us up walking around. Nobody wants us here. Everything costs too much. The cityís too big. Settlement was supposed to be more spread out. Hell, I thought the terraforming would be halfway to the poles by now. The politics have gone all wrong, and nobody has any mannersÖî

Miles made encouraging noises. If there was one skill Miles had honed in his youth, it was how to please an old man by listening to his complaints. Yani needed no more than a nod to launch into a comprehensive denunciation of modern Kibou, a world with no need nor place for him. Some of his phrases were so practiced they came out in paragraphs, as if heíd told them over to anyone who would stop to listen. Which, by this point, was no oneóthe few other residents who drifted in gave Yaniís table a wide berth. His rheumy eye brightened at this new audience who didnít show visible signs of wanting to chew through his own leg to get away, and Milesís suspect druggie status was temporarily forgotten.

As Yani maundered on, Miles was thrown back in memory to his own grandfather. General Count Piotr Vorkosigan, planetary liberator, un-maker and re-maker of emperors, and cause of a lot of that history that Yani had missed, had sired his heir late in life, as had Milesís father, so that it was more nearly three generations between grandfather and grandson than two. Still, they had loved each other after their own peculiar fashion. How would Milesís life have altered if Piotr had been frozen when Miles was seventeen, instead of buried for real in the ground? His impending return always a promise, or a threat?

Like a great tree the old general had been, but a tree did not only give shelter from the storm. How would Barrayar be different if that towering figure had not fallen, permitting sunlight to penetrate to the forest floor and new growth to flourish? What if the only way to effect change on Barrayar had been to violently destroy what had gone before, instead of waiting for the cycle of generations to gracefully remove it?

For the first time, the notion occurred to Miles that it might not be vote-grubbing alone, nor even the lack of medical progress in reversing geriatric decay, that caused the cryocorps to freeze more patrons than they revived.

Yani had now segued into a long screed about how his cryocorp had cheated him, evidently by not delivering him into this new world physically youthful, rich, and famous, which was roughly where Miles had come in on this rant. Yani seemed a time-traveler who had found out the hard way that he did not like his destination any better than his point of departure, failed to notice the one common factor was himself, and now could not go back. So just how many like him were haunting the streets of Kibou? Miles made the emptiness of their mugs an excuse to grab both and take them for refills.
As he was washing his mug and topping up Yaniís, Miles murmured to the cook, ìIs it true Yani was rejected for being a revive?î
She snorted. ìI daresay nobody wanted him around a hundred years ago, either. I donít know why he thought that would have changed.î
Miles muffled a smile. ìI daresay.î
The half-smile caught her eye, and she looked at him more closely. ìYouíre not very old. Are you sick?î
Miles blinked. ìDo I look that hung-over?î
ìI thought that might be why you were here.î

ìWell, I have a chronic medical condition, but I donít much care to discuss it.î How had she guessed? A seizure disorder hardly showed on the outside like, say, skin lesions. Miles suspected a conversation at cross-purposes, again, and that heíd just been handed a clue. So what was it?
But before he could follow this up, she turned away and said, ìOh! Tenbury-san!î

A lot of heads swiveled at the entry of a man in threadbare coveralls, a shirt with the sleeves rolled up, and an enormous quantity of hair, but the looks were mostly followed up with brief nods or friendly waves. The greetings were returned as silently. The man trod into the kitchen area. He shoved his hand into his thatch of brown-gray beard to scratch his chin, greeted the cook with another nod, and held out a familiar carafe, which she took to rinse and refill with coffee. ìYour lunch is all ready, Tenbury-san,î she called over her shoulder. ìSackís in the fridge.î

The man grunted thanks and went to poke inside the industrial refrigerator. He was not, Miles, realized, actually of a bearlike build under all the mad hair, but lanky and pale. He pulled out a cloth sack, turned, and eyed Miles. ìYouíre new.î
ìIím a friend of Jinís,î Miles answered, not quite directly. Or at least, he collected me.
ìReally? Where is the boy?î
ìI sent him to run an errand for me.î
ìEh. Good. Time he did some work.î
ìThereís a faucet leaking in two-ten,î the cook informed him.
ìRight, right. Iíll bring my tools after dinner,î said the man. He took the carafe and trod out.
ìWho was that?î Miles asked, as the cook picked up her spoon again.
ìTenbury. Heís the custodian here.î

Miles dimly remembered that term going by a few times earlier, and wondered if its meaning was as far outside the usual as Suze the Secretaryís. But if he really wanted to know where the power came from and the sewage went to, now was his chance. Should he wait for Jin to broker an introduction? Miles didnít have infinite time to explore, hereÖ his feet were already in motion, deciding for him.

He waved his own thanks to the cook, dropped the refilled mug by Yani, rapped a friendly farewell on the tabletop, and made it to the door just in time to tail Tenburyís receding footsteps. The worn rubber soles on Milesís scavenged shoes were as silent as heíd hoped. Hinges squeaked; Miles nipped around the corner to discover a door closing again on another stairwell. He drew a breath and followed.

The steps descended into stygian blackness. His breath quickened. To his intense relief, a sudden glow reflected off the walls aheadóTenbury had unshipped a hand light. So, the man didnít see in the dark like a werewolf, good. At the fourth landing, the scrape of a heavy door being shoved open was followed by loss of the reflected light. Miles sped his steps, put out his hands, and found the handle. He opened this door more cautiously, turning sideways to slide through the gap and easing it closed with the minimum sound.

The bobbing light receded to his right; he turned after it, thinking of will-oí-the-wisps luring unwary travelers to their doom. As he followed, he became aware of tiny twinkles dancing in the corners of his vision like floating fireflies, adding to the night-swamp effect. He blinked, and they resolved into scattered indicator lights, green for allís-well, tacking randomly up the corridor walls on either side.

Reluctantly, Miles reached out and let his hand trace across the now-familiar bumps of closely-set banks of cryo-drawers. Except these were not abandoned and cleared, but working, or a portion of them were. Well insulated, the drawer faces were at room temperatureóthere was no danger of his skin freezing to the surface and trapping him in a growing cocoon of icicle-glass, really. He drew in his hands anyway, making his way down the center of the corridor by witch-light.

He stopped short as, at the end of the corridor, another door opened. Ordinary office-lab-living-quarters glare temporarily blasted his eyes, making a nimbus around a hairy head that fortunately did not turn around. The door shut, and Miles was plunged into blackness once more. As his night vision came slowly back the dense dark was relieved, if that was the word, by the scattered green specks. He could just make out his corpse-light sleeves.
So, he hadnít found the pumping station or the electrical transformers. Heíd found the deeper secret of this placeóworking cryochambers. A number of mysteries fell neatly into place.
Suze and companions were running a secret cryocorp. Noóa cryo-cooperative. And, unless he missed his guess, unlicensed, untaxed, and uninspected. Clandestine, off the books in every way.
Kibou-dainióa whole planet so obsessed with cheating death that even the street people managed to scavenge hope.

Which beat living, and dying, in a cardboard box all to flinders, Miles had to admit. He opened his mouth in what might have been a silent laugh. And I thought Iíd pulled some audacious stunts in my timeÖ How the hell Suze and whatever helpers sheíd suborned had managed to palm an entire facility, back when this place was being decommissioned and stripped, its patrons shifted to the elegant new Cryopolis on the west end, gaudy with its floodlit pyramids, was a tale Miles was suddenly dying to hear.
Bad choice of phrase, my Lord Auditor.

Less than a third of the cryo-drawers in this corridor sported those glow-worm lights, and how many other corridors might there be? Plenty of room for more customers. And, because his mind worked that way, he considered how easy murder by cryo-drawer would be. The ultimate shell game, one live body hidden among hundreds of dead ones. Asphyxiation would come quickly in the sealed black box, even without the freezing, and no one would know where to look till much too lateÖ

p.emphasis: Itís nothing I havenít undergone before.

section.p: It was curious how much that reflection didnít help.
He stepped forward to the end door, raised his hand to touch the cool metal surface, and just stood there for a minute. Then, curling his fingers into a fist, he knocked.
The creak of a chair. The door opened partway, and a hairy face thrust through. ìYah?î
ìTenbury-san?î
ìJust Tenbury. What did you want?î
ìTo ask a few questions, if I may.î
Beneath shaggy brows, dark brown eyes narrowed. ìDid you talk to Suze?î
ìJin took me to see her this morning, yes.î
Tenburyís lips pursed amid their thatch. ìOh. All right.î The door swung wide.
Miles did not correct the misperception that Suze had therefore gated him into this covert community, but slipped inside at once.

The room was part office, part control chamber for the banks of cryo-drawers, and part living space, or so the unmade bedroll by one wall and the piles of personal junk suggested. Beyond, another door stood open on what might be some sort of repairs facility. Miles glimpsed workbenches and racks of tools in its shadows. There was only one station chair, by which Miles guessed this Tenbury was less sociable than Suze, but the custodian politely gestured his guest into it and leaned against a control console. Miles would have preferred it the other way around, so as not to risk a crick in his neck, nor the embarrassment of swinging his short legs above the floor. But he dared not impede the useful exchange heíd started, so he sat and half-smiled upward.
Tenbury cocked his head, and echoed the cookís observation. ìYou look too young for us. You sick or something?î
Miles repeated the reply that had seemed to work before: ìI have an incurable seizure disorder.î
Tenbury winced in sympathy, but said, ìYouíd do better to go back to the docs. Off-planet, maybe.î
ìI have. It was costly.î Miles turned out his empty pockets as if to demonstrate.
ìThat why you ended up here? Broke, are you?î

ìIn a sense.î It wasnít as if Miles was trying to beat a fast-penta interrogation through excessive literalism, yet he found himself oddly reluctant to lie outright to this man. ìItís more complicated than that.î
ìYah, it always is.î
ìCan you show me what I might be getting into? If I stayed here, that is?î
The hairy eyebrows jerked up. ìYouíve nothing to worry about with my work. Come on, and youíll see.î

Tenbury led through his shop, which seemed half-engineeering-half-medical. Dismantled freezer parts lay strewn across a workbench. ìI keep a portion of the chambers usable by cannibalizing the others,î Tenbury explained.

Miles encouraged the tech to expand upon the arcana of his craft with much the same noises heíd used on Yani, to better effect. When Miles had absorbed as much about how cryochambers were built as he could stand, he asked, ìBut wonít you run out of parts?î

ìNot for a while yet. This facility was originally set up to serve twenty thousand patrons. In twenty years, weíve only accumulated about a ten-percent occupancy. I admit we started much smaller, back when. We can go for decades yet. Till Iím gone, for sure.î
ìAnd what then? Who are you relying on for your revivals?î
ìWe donít need anyone to do the revivals, yet. Anyway, theyíre much trickier.î
Indeed. ìWho does the cryoprep, then?î
ìPlant nurse. Youíll meet her sooner or later. Sheís real good, and she has an apprentice, Ako, too. I need to get myself a couple of youngsters like that, I guess.î

Miles didnít marvel at this. Emergency cryoprep was a common enough medical procedure that even he had learned it, at least theoretically, as part of military field-aid. Under nonemergency conditions there were doubtless more refinements, resulting in less cryo-amnesia and other unwanted side-effects, after. Less trauma to start with left less trauma to recover from, but to choose to go down to that darkness in cold blood, so to speak, while still breathingÖ ìItís still frightening to think about,î he said honestly.

ìFor most folks, itís a last choice, not a first one. We all come to it in time, though. No one wants to go of a coronary in the night and not-wake-up warm and rotting. Safer not to wait too long.î Tenburyís lips twisted. ìAlthough some of the corps are trying to increase market share these days by encouraging folks to freeze early. Iím not sure if the math works out.î
ìIt does seem an inelastic demand, yes,î agreed Miles in fascination. ìMore customers now can only mean fewer later. A short-term strategy for such a long-term enterprise.î
ìYah, except maybe for those whoíd miss their chance.î
It was Milesís turn to tilt his head in consideration. ìI suppose theyíre not up to one-hundred-percent market saturation, even now. What about the religious types?î
ìOh, yah, there are still a few refusers.î
ìRefusers?î
ìYouíre not from around here, are you? Figured from your accent, but Iíd have thought you must have been on Kibou longer. In order to end up here, I mean.î
ìIt was something of an accident. Iím glad I stumbled on you, though.î

Refusers, like revives, were another item the careful corps tours had neglected to mention, but they hardly needed even Tenburyís brief explanation, which he obligingly supplied, for Miles to figure out. Tenburyís judgment was that those who chose burial over freezing for superstitious reasons were a self-limiting phenomenon. Miles thought of those fringe utopian communities that had practiced strict celibacy and thus died out within the first couple of generations, or non-generations, and nodded provisional agreement.

Tenbury then kindly took Miles through the far door, out of the workshop and into another corridoróthankfully lit, though even with illumination the general effect was of an unsettling cross between a space station corridor and a morgue. There he opened an empty cryo-drawer, recently reconditioned, and pointed out its features, rather like a very restrained used-vehicle salesman.
ìIt seemsÖ small,î said Miles.

ìNot much head room,î Tenbury agreed. ìBut youíre past sitting up suddenly by the time you arrive in it. Iíve often wondered if folks would retain any memory of their time in these, but the revives Iíve met all say not.î He slid the drawer closed and gave it a fond thump to seat the latch.

ìYou just go to sleep, and then wake up in a future somebody else picked for you. No dreams,î Miles agreed. ìBlink out, blink back in. Like anesthesia, but longer.î An intimate preview of death, and doubtless a lot less traumatic when the blink out part wasnít accomplished by a needle-grenade blowing out oneís chest, Miles had to allow. He spread his palm on the drawer-front. ìWhat happens to all the poor frozen peopleîóor frozen poor peopleóìif this place is discovered by the authorities?î
A brief, humorless grin ruffled the beard-thatch. ìWell, they canít just let us thaw and rot, then bury us. Thatís illegal.î
ìMurder?î
ìOf a sort. One of the grades of murder, anyway.î

So this place was not as futile an effort as Miles had first guessed. Somebody was thinking ahead. How far? Who might find the future legal responsibility for these frozen souls on their hands? The municipality of Northbridge? Some unwitting entrepreneur, buying the rediscovered property for back taxes without inspecting it first? Cheating death, indeed. ìIllegal at the moment, then. What happens if the law changes?î

Tenbury shrugged. ìThen several thousand people will have died calmly and without pain, in hope and not despair. And wonít know the difference.î He added after a thoughtful pause, ìThat would be an ugly sort of world to wake up in anyway.î

ìMm, I donít suppose the authorities would go to the trouble and expense of reviving folks just to let them die again immediately. Blink out, andÖ stay blinked.î There were worse ways to arrive at an identical fate. Miles had seen many of them.
ìWell, I need to get back to work,î Tenbury hinted away his uninvited visitor. ìI hope this helped you.î
ìYes, yes it did. Thank you.î Miles let Tenbury shepherd him back through the shop to the first corridor. ìI suppose Iíd better go feed Jinís pets. I did promise the boy I would.î
ìOdd kid, that. I had hopes for a bit he might apprentice to me, but heís more interested in animals than machinery.î Tenbury sighed, whether in regret or bafflement Miles was not quite sure.
ìUmÖî said Miles, staring up the darkened corridor.

ìFirst door on your left,î said Tenbury, and thoughtfully held his office door wide to light the way till Miles had found it in the gloom. The stair rail and a careful count of the turns guided Miles after that. He emerged again in the basement near the cafeteria, and from there found his way back up to Jinís roof via the interior stairs.
Emerging into the daylight and greeted by milling chickens, he thought, Damn, but I hope the boy makes it back here soon.

The big downtown tube-tram transfer station was just as confusing going back as forward, Jin found when heíd taken his second wrong turn. The crowd made him nervous, and it was only going to get worse as the time edged toward rush hour. He needed to get out of here. Scowling, he turned around a couple of times, reoriented himself, and made his way upstream through an entry corridor, bumping a lot of folks going the other way.

What was in that big thick envelope Counsel Vorlynkin had handed to him? It crackled against his skin. Entering the second-level rotunda, he dodged out of the way of a woman with a pram, then leaned his shoulders against a pillar and fished out the letter. To his disappointment, it wasnít sealed with a bloody thumbprint, but it was certainly sealed. No peeking. He sighed and thrust it back inside his shirt.

He finally found the right escalator, and rode it up two flights to the top-level gallery. He was worried about his animals. Would Miles-san take proper care of them? You never could tell, with adults. They pretended to take you seriously, but then laughed behind your back at the things that were important to you. Or said that because you were just a kid, you would forget it all soon. But Miles-san had seemed to genuinely like Jinís rats, letting Jinni sit on his shoulder and nibble at his hair without flinching. Jin could tell when grownups didnít really appreciate how sleek and funny and friendly rats could be, and they didnít bite hard at all unless they were accidentally squeezed, and who could blame them for that?

The squeeze on Jinís shoulder made him jump and yelp. If heíd been equipped for it, he might have bitten the hand as well, but all he could do was twist and stare upward. Straight into the face of his worst nightmare.
Brown hair, a pleasant smile, the blue uniform of municipal security. Not just a tube-tram safety officer; their uniforms were green. A real policewoman, the sort whoíd come for his mother.
ìWhatís your name, child?î The voice was friendly, but the undertone steely.
Jin opened his mouth: ìJinÖî Oh, no, that wouldnít do. Lying to grownups made him scared inside, but he managed, ìJin, um, Vorkson.î
She blinked. ìWhat kind of name is that?î
ìMy Dad was a galactic. But heís dead now,î Jin added with hasty prudence. And half truth, for that matter. He tried not to think about the funeral.
ìDoes your mother let you come downtown alone? Itís school hours, you know.î
ìUm, yes. She sent me on an errand for her.î
ìLetís call her, then.î
Jin held out his skinny wrists. His stomach felt cold and quivery. ìI donít have a wristcom, maíam.î
ìThatís all right. You can come along to the security booth, and we can call her from there.î

ìNo!î In a panic now, Jin tried to wrench away. Somehow, he found his arm cranked up behind his back, hurting. His shirt tail came loose, and the envelope dropped to the pavement with a loud slap. ìNo, wait!î He tried to dive for it. Without releasing his arm, the woman scooped it up first, staring at it with a deepening frown.
She murmured to her own wristcom, ìCode Six, Dan. Level One.î
In moments, another policeman loomed. ìWhat ho, Michiko? Catch us a little shoplifter?î
ìIím not sure. Truant, maybe. This young fellow needs to come to the booth and call his mother. And get IDíd, I think.î
ìRight.î
Jinís other arm was taken in an even stronger fist. Helplessly, he let himself be marched along. He was wild for a chance to break away, but neither grip slackened.

The security booth had big glass windows overlooking the rotunda. It was cool inside, and when the door shut a wonderful silence fell, which usually would be a relief to Jin, but not now. A lot of screens were running, and Jin realized that some of them were from vidcams that looked right into peopleís faces as they went up or down on the escalators. He hadnít noticed them among the noise and confusion and hurry of the place. The woman plunked him down in a swivel chair. His feet didnít quite reach the floor.
The wide man, Dan, held up a light pen. ìLet me see your eyes, child.î

Retina scan? A red flash. Jin squeezed his eyes shut as tightly as he could, and clapped his palms over his face for good measure. But it was already too late. He heard the man moving away to his comconsole.
ìHeís scared, Dan,î said the woman. Jin peeked through his fingers to see her holding up the envelope, squeezing and rattling it like a birthday present. ìThink the reason might be in here?î
A ping from the console. ìAha. I believe we have a match. That was quick.î Officer Dan looked up and asked, ìIs your name Jin Sato?î
ìNo!î
ìIt says here heís been missing for over a year.î
Without letting go of Jinís arm, the woman edged around to look at the holoscreen. ìGood heavens! Iíll bet his family will be relieved to get him back!î
ìNo, they wonít! Let me go!î
ìWhere have you been hiding for a whole year, son?î Officer Dan asked, not unkindly.
ìAnd what is this?î Michiko asked, hefting the envelope and frowning.
ìYou canít have that! Give it back!î
ìSo whatís in it?î
ìItís just a letter. A, a very personal letter. Iím supposed to deliver it. For, for some men.î
Both officers went rigid. ìWhat sort of men?î asked Michiko.
ìJustÖ men.î
ìFriends? Relatives?î
Relatives were not a good thing, in Jinís world. ìNo. I just met them today.î
ìWhere did you meet them?î
Jinís mouth clamped shut.
ìNot addressed. Not postal-sealed. No legal reason we canít peek, is there?î said Dan.

The woman nodded and handed the envelope over. Dan popped a folding knife and slit it open from the bottom, holding it above the countertop. A thick wad of currency thumped out, followed by a fluttering note.

It was more money than Jin had seen in one place in his life. From their widening eyes, it was more money than the two security officers were used to seeing in one lump, too, certainly in the hands of a kid.
Dan riffled the wad and vented a long, amazed whistle.
Michiko said, ìDrug ring, do you think? Feelie-dream smugglers?î

ìIt could beógods, it could be anything. Congratulations, Michiko. Shouldnít wonder if thereís a promotion in this.î Staring at the envelope with more respect, Dan belatedly pulled a pair of thin plastic gloves from his pocket and donned them before he picked up the note. It seemed to be printed on half a flimsy.

Dan read aloud, ìWe must trust that you know what you are doing. Please contact us in person as soon as possible.î He turned the note in the light. ìNo address, no date, no names, no signature. Nothing. Veery suspicious.î
Michiko bent to look Jin sternly in the eyes. ìWhere did you meet these bad men, child?î
ìThey werenít bad men. They were justÖ men. Friends of a friend.î
ìWhere were you taking all this money?î
ìI didnít know it was money!î
Michikoís eyebrows rose. ìDo you believe that?î she asked her partner.
ìYah,î said Dan, ìor he might have taken off with it.î
ìGood point.î
ìI wouldnít have! Even if I had known!î
ìNo one can threaten you now, Jin,î Michiko said more gently. ìYouíre safe.î

ìNo one did threaten me!î Jin had never felt less safe in his life. And if he blabbed, Suze and Ako and Tenbury and everyone who had befriended him wouldnít be safe, either. And Lucky and the ratties and the chickens, and big, beautiful GyreÖ Lips tight as he could press them, Jin stared back at the officers.
ìCall Youth Services to pick up the boy,î said Michiko. ìThe rest of the evidence had better go to Vice, at a guess.î
ìYah,î said Dan, his gloved hands sliding Jinís precious envelope, the wad of cash, and the note into a transparent plastic bag.
ìMy animals,î Jin whispered. Such a simple task Miles-san had entrusted him with, and heíd screwed it all up. Heíd screwed everything up. Between his scrunched eyelids, tears began to leak.
With a grating noise and a puff of powder, the bolt popped out of the concrete.
ìFinally,î breathed Roic.

Roic waited for dusk to deepen, and for the occasional echo of footsteps along the gallery to fall silent for a good long time, before venturing a cautious reconnoiter. The door lock yielded to force, or rather, the flimsy doorframe splintered and gave up the mechanism whole, more loudly than he would have liked, but no one called out or came to investigate. Crouching to slip beneath any view from the windows, bare feet silent on the boards but for an occasional tiny clink from the chain swathing his ankle, he discovered that the gallery wrapped the rectangular building on three sides, with stairs down on either end. About a dozen rooms like his lined this level. There was no third storey.

Another building, with faint yellow gleams leaking from its windows, lay down the slope to the right. Obscured in the trees behind it seemed to be a parking area, but a marked lack of security lighting made the details invisibleóboth to Roic and to anyone passing overhead in a lightflyer, he guessed. Right now he was grateful for the shadows. He slipped around to the far end. A third building, vaguely shedlike, sat low and black in the gloom down at the border of the level scrubland. Roic wondered if thereíd been a fire, to so clear out the crowded conifers.
Roicís heart nearly failed him when a voice above his head hissed, ìRoic! Up here!î

He jerked his head back to see a pale smudge of a face peering over the edge of the roof. A long black braid swung forward over the figureís shoulder, triggering recognition and relief. ìDr. Durona? Raven? So they got you, too!î
ìSh! Not so loud. We were in the same lift van. You were out cold. Come up, before someone comes back.î A pair of lean arms extended downward; Raven was apparently lying prone. ìCareful of my handsÖî

With no more noise than a grunt and a scrape, Roic scrambled up to the flat rooftop. Their careful foot-slides making no thumps that could be heard through a ceiling below, they took shelter of sorts in the lee of a vent housing.

Raven Durona could have passed for a Kibou-daini nativeóa slim intellectual Eurasian in body and face, with a high-bridged nose and straight black hair to his waistótill he opened his mouth and that un-local accent came out. Delegate from the Durona Medical Group on Escobar, heíd been the only other person at the cryo-conference Roic had known, and moderately well at that, but mílord, inexplicably, had signed them away from each other. Raven had accepted the signal with the merest nod and eyebrow twitch, and steered around Roic and mílord thereafter. Leaving mílord clear, Roic realized in retrospect, to trawl for his own targets.
Roic lowered himself to sit cross-legged, the Escobaran cryo-surgeon wrapped his arms around his knees, and they put their faces close together.
In a nearly voiceless murmur, Roic said, ìSeen any guards?î
ìNo, but our captors are still awake,î Dr. Durona returned in a matching tone. ìTheyíre mostly still down in the dining hall, but some wander back up here at random. They sleep below us.î
ìHowíd you get out of your room?î
ìSurgery on my bathroom window-lock.î
An exit doubtless aided by the fact that the man was lithe as a snake; Roicís shoulders would not have fit. ìAnd the chains?î
ìChains? You had chains? Special, Roic!î
ìNever mind. How far are we from Northbridge, did you see? And where tíhell are we?î

ìAbout a hundred, hundred and fifty kilometers, Iíd guess. The one glimpse I had was all forest as far as I could see. There donít seem to be any roadsóeverything must come in by lightflyer or lift van. This place used to be some kind of lake resort for Northbridge weekenders, before the dam blew out in a storm and the lake ran down the river. The rebuild got tied up in lawsuits, so the resort has been defunct for a couple of years. One of our kidnappers owns it, turns out. Which may have been how the Legacy Liberators came up with this crazed scheme in the first place.î
ìWhat tíhell are they doingóno, wait. First, have you seen Lord Vorkosigan?î

Raven shook his dark head. ìI thought I saw them tackle him, back in the lobby when they grabbed me and you were throwing people into the lift tube and bellowing at them to keep climbingóI swear some of those poor delegates were more scared of you than of our attackersóbut I havenít seen him since. There are only six other hostages here, plus me and you. All locked in for the night. It seems the N.H.L.L. was setting up to host three times that many. Theyíre not best pleased with you for that.î
ìHow many bad guys?î
ìWhat a Barrayaran turn of phrase! About a dozen here, at a guess. Iíve not seen them all together. They take it in shifts to harass us.î
ìHuh?î
ìLecturing us, mostly. About the stern and glorious goals of the New Hope Legacy Liberators.î
ìOh. I had a sample.î
ìOnly a sample? The rest of us have endured hours of it. They marched us down to the dining hall and harangued us till they were hoarse.î
ìHow come I wasnít invited?î

ìYou have a reputation as a bold Barrayaran barbarianósay that six times really fastótoo dangerous to let loose. Chains, huh? You were fortunate to miss class. I think they might be trying to inculcate some sort of identify-with-oneís-captors syndrome in us, but are doing it wrong. Old Baron Ryoval could have eaten them all for breakfast.î

Roic had heard mílordís clone-brother Lord Mark quote the late Baron Ryoval of Jacksonís Whole only onceósome mutter about, And then we shall explore the interesting focusing effects of threatening your remaining eyeóand had not been moved to inquire further. Heíd been moved to edge away, actually, despite overtopping Lord Mark by half a meter of height. Roic only knew that the entire Durona Group, thirty-five or so cloned siblings possessing extraordinary medical talents, felt they owed their escape from Jacksonian techno-slavery to a new, free life to Lord Mark and Lord Vorkosigan. The reason for Ravenís peculiar mélange of an accent, and that of every other Durona, was that they were all refugees from Jacksonís Whole whoíd been living for over a decade on Escobar. The reason that the infamous Baron was the late was Lord Mark. The reason Roic and Raven found themselves sitting on this roof togetherÖ was still unclear.

Well, Raven had been invited to the conference to give an illustrated lecture on cryorevival techniques after death from extreme trauma, which mílord and perforce Roic had sat in on three days ago, after Raven had hinted, during a chance encounter in a hotel lift-tube, that mílord would find special interest in the very complicated case of Patient C, a messy death by needler-grenade to the chest. It was, Raven had informed his audience, one of his earliest and most memorable cases as a young assistant surgeon. Mílord had indeed been riveted. Roic had closed his eyes. But besides that.
ìYes, but why are these idiots lecturing you?î
ìPitching their cause, I think. Rather like the past several days at the cryo-conference, really, except in reverse. And with much worse food.î
ìAre they suppressed by the government, or censored by the local media?î

ìNot at all, apparently. They even have a site on the planetary net that tells everyone all they would want to know about their views. No one wants to know much, it appears, so theyíve turned to more forcible ways of getting attention. Now, robbing at gunpoint actually works. Selling at gunpointónot so good. We all started today scared to death. But by the end, it was just dreary.î Raven rubbed his nose. ìThey seem to plan to keep it up for days. Hence my escape attempt, but itís not going too well.î
ìWe both got this farÖî

ìYes, but here we are in the middle of a hundred kilometers of woodsólots more if you take a wrong turnóand even if this forest isnít stocked with people-eating predators, it would be insane to plunge off into the darkness with no shoes or gear. And all the vehicles in the parking lot are neatly locked. I just checked.î
ìHuh. Pity.î
Raven eyed Roic in speculation. ìNow, by myself I donít think I could jump someone coming out to his lightflyer and grab it after it was opened, but if we worked an ambush togetherÖî
Roic took this, resignedly, as, If you jumped him and I cheered you onÖ

Raven frowned. ìExcept this crew doesnít seem to come or go very often. All locked down tight, making no noise. Till you came along, I was starting to wonder if I should let myself back into my room and pretend this never happened, wait for some better chance.î

ìI donít think I could do that,î said Roic, remembering his ruined doorframe. He craned his neck to stare over the roof edge at that third darkened structure. If that was an old shoreline down thereÖ ìWhatís that other building?î
ìDonít know. I havenít seen anybody go in or out.î
ìIím thinking it could be a boathouse. Or a tool shedóan isolated place like this would need oneóbut likely a boathouse.î

Raven glanced wryly at the dried lake bed, and murmured, ìIíve never ridden in a boat. This doesnít seem the night to start. Tools, nowÖ do you think you could pry open a lightflyer? But then youíd still need the code keys to power it up. Crowbarís no use there. Except maybe to hit the owner on the head?î

ìMílord keeps boats. He has a place on a lake down in the Vorkosiganís District, back on Barrayar, couple hours from the capital by lightflyer.î A thought niggled in Roicís aching head. ìI say, letís go see.î
Raven gave him a dubious look, but shrugged agreement.

With painful caution, they lowered themselves from the roof and tiptoed down the far stairs. They made a straight line for the cover of the trees, then circled to come out on the shore side of the low building. The effect of the sticks, rocks, and debris on Roicís bare feet made him reluctantly agree with Ravenís negative view of any longer walk in the woods.

The window glass was unbreakable, the entry facing the ex-lake padlocked, but it gave way to the same method Roic had used on his room door. Raven winced at the rending crunch; they both froze, listening hard, but no outcry came. They edged inside.

The outer door opened onto an office; the door beyond was, thanks be, unlocked. Roic swung it open upon a garagelike space. Also very dark, butócould one smell boats? The scent of wood and oil and old bilge and dried waterweed was quite unmistakable, and strangely happy, like preserved summer. As his eyes adjusted, Roic could just make out half a dozen kayak-or-canoe shapes slung from the ceiling, and a couple of wider hulls up on sturdy cradles. Workbench on the far side of the room, mostly cleared away. Raven started for it, hands held out before him in wariness of head-cracking pillars or other shadowy obstacles, but Roic whispered him back.
ìCome over here. This big power boatóhelp me get the cover off.î
ìRoic, even if we could haul it out the doors, the lake is dry.î
ìThatís not it. Just help, all right?î

The hull was maybe five meters long and half that wide, and a stretched plastic cover protected a large open cockpit. The fastenings parted reluctantly, and Roic dragged the cover aside and climbed in. Raven followed in curiosity.

Roic felt his way to the controls, just behind a windshield, and opened what provedóyes!óto be a small vid plate cover. Now, if this comlink was independently powered, as it bloody well should beóRoicís fumbling fingers found the on-switch at last, and green and amber lights threw back the pools of darkness.
ìHey!î said Raven, in a hearteningly impressed toneómost Duronas daunted Roic. ìDid you know that would be there?î

ìI had a guess. If this place rented out boats to its customers, it wouldíve had to keep something to go rescue them in. Comlink is a pretty standard built-in for pleasure boats this size, along with the depth-finder and nav links and so on.î

The emergency channel was easy to find. Within minutes, Roic had talked his way back through the system to the Northbridge police. His years as a street guard gave him a good idea of just what to say to smoothly reach the folks with clout, and the boatís navigation aid provided a precise location. He reported, briefly, his experiences and Ravenís to the startled but pleased Northbridge detective officer in charge of theóby now highly publicized, Roic sensed in his toneókidnapping case. To Roicís intense worry, it seemed no one had found Lord Vorkosigan yet. As the Northbridge police scrambled, Roic closed the link and leaned back.
ìNow what?î asked Raven.
ìNow we wait.î
ìFor rescue? Do you think we ought to do something for the others?î

ìLying lowís better. No point in stirring up anything if our captors arenít going to miss us for a while yet. Let the Kibou fellows do their job, and hope they get here first.î Roic recalled some of mílordís cautionary lectures on local liability, a concern that mílord himself seemed to take to heart only intermittently.

Speaking of localsÖ Roic leaned forward again and searched out the number of the Barrayaran consulate in Northbridge. Unfortunately, the public net only supplied the public number, not the secured emergency link coded on his wristcom, presumably discarded back in the city by his captors for well-founded fear of tracers. A polite recorded voice told him to call back during office hours, or leave a message. The muted background music was a popular Barrayaran military march that gave Roic a twinge of homesickness. He was halfway through recording a succinct report on his current situation when, to his relief, he was interrupted by a live human.

Roic recognized Lieutenant Johannes, the young driver whoóalong with Consul Vorlynkin himself, because mílord was, after all, mílordóhad picked them up at the shuttleport nigh on a week ago and transported them to the conference hotel. Military attaché, ImpSec of sorts, and for all Roic knew, cook, gardener, and the consulís batman. He felt a dim sense of comradeship, contemplating Johannes.
ìArmsman Roic!î Johannesís voice was curt and anxious. ìAre you all right? Where are you?î
Roic began his summary once more; halfway through, the strained face of Consul Vorlynkin joined Johannesís image above the vid plate.
ìIf you follow up with the Northbridge police from your end, youíll likely know as soon and as much as we do,î Roic finished.
Vorlynkin said, ìLord Auditor Vorkosigan is not with youóright?î
ìWe havenít spotted him here. Any sign back there?î
A too-long pause. ìWe arenít quite sure.î
What tíhell did that mean?
ìWhen you get free, report in to the consulate at once,î Vorkynkin went on. ìShould I send Johannes to coordinate with the police?î
Roic scratched his head. ìIf mílordís not here, thereís no point tí get in a panic about us. Iíll get back with the others.î
ìWhat about me?î said Raven, either indignant or amused, it was hard to tell.
ìWho is that?î said Vorlynkin sharply.
ìDr. Durona. An acquaintance from Escobar, one of the delegates,î Roic replied.
Raven obligingly leaned forward into range of the vid pick-up and smiled benignly. Vorlynkin frowned back.
ìMílord would want to know he wasîósafe seemed a premature claimóìwith me,î Roic explained.
Vorlynkin said distantly, ìYou know, if you people would be more forthcoming, we could do our job of supporting you much better.î

The faint bitterness in the consulís voice was more reassuring to Roic than the man could possibly imagine. It sounded quite like Vorlynkin had undergone some recent dealing with mílord, one that he was loath to transmit over an unsecured comlink.
ìYes, sir,î said Roic, in a mollifying tone.
He cut the com.
ìNow what?î said Raven. ìJust sit here and wait for the sirens?î
ìThere had better not be sirens,î said Roic. ìBest they drop down and secure the hostages first before making any noise.î That was what heíd suggested, at least.
After a longer pause, Raven said, ìThe Liberators didnít really act like they wanted to kill us. Just convert us.î
ìPanic does odd things to people.î
Raven sighed. ìYou could stand to be more reassuring, Roic, you know?î
Huddling around the indicator lights as if at a very tiny campfire, they waited in the darkness.

Miles rattled the consulateís wrought-iron front gate, found it locked, and stared over it wearily. Beyond a dainty front garden sat a dinky house, overshadowed by its grander neighbors, although at least it looked well-kept. Maybe it had once been servantsí quarters? Kibou-daini had never been considered strategically important enough to spend much Imperial money upon, its system being in a wormhole cul-de-sac on the far side of Escobar, well outside of Barrayarís web of influence. This consulate existed mainly to ease the occasional Barrayaran or more likely Komarran trading venture through planetary regulations, aid any members of the Imperium who found themselves in local trouble, and direct and quietly vet the even rarer Kibou traveler planning to visit the Imperium. Milesís arrival was likely the most excitement the place had endured in years. Yeah, well, itís about to get more so.

The pre-dawn chill was damp and penetrating, his legs were cramped, and his back ached. He sighed and clambered awkwardly over the gate, retrieved his cane, stumped up the short walk, and leaned on the door chime.

The porch and hall lights flicked on; a face peered through the glass, and the door opened a crack. A young man Miles didnít recognize spoke in a Kibou accent: ìSir, youíll have to come back during business hours. We open in about two moreóî
Miles wedged his cane through the opening, levered it wider, put his head down, and barged in.
ìSiró!î

The minion was only saved from a shattering blast of Auditorial ire by Consul Vorklynkin strolling through an archway at the back of the hall, saying, ìWhat is it, Yuuichi?Ö Oh my God, Lord Vorkosigan!î
Showing a swift sense of self-preservation, Yuuichi fell back from between them.

Vorlynkin, tall and lean, was half-dressed in trousers, shirt, and slippers, bleary-eyed, and clutching a mug that steamed with the gentle perfume of hot green tea. Miles was so distracted by the smell that he was almost thrown off his well-rehearsed opening, but heíd had a lot of hours this past night to rehearse.
ìVorlynkin, what the hell have you done with my courier?î

Vorlynkinís spine snapped straight, unconsciously revealing a military hitch sometime in his earlier life. A look of partial, but only partial, relief lit his blue eyes. ìWe can answer that! My lord.î
ìSo Jin did make it here?î
ìUm, yes, sir.î

The problem had occurred on Jinís way back, then. Not goodÖ Miles had waited in growing anxiety till midnight, then pressed Ako into substitute pet care and taken matters unto his own hands, or feet. The hours it had cost him to make it here unobserved had not improved his mood. Neither had the rain.

The consulís brows drew down as he took in Milesís appearance in turn, a very far cry from Milesís cultivated gray-eminence-look of their brief meeting last week. Although the ragged, stained clothing, two-day growth of face stubble, general reek, and peculiar shoes might not be the whole of why he flinched. But, showing a keen eye that was well-placed in the diplomatic corps, he caught Milesís gaze tracking his waving mug, and added smoothly, ìDo you want to come to the kitchen and sit down, my Lord Auditor? We were just having breakfast.î
ìTea, yes,î said Miles, relieved from his impulse to wrench the mug out of the manís hand. Gods, yes.
Vorlynkin led through the back archway, saying, ìHow did you get here?î

ìWalked. Thirty-odd kilometers since midnight, back ways, dodging twice because I didnít want to explain myself in my current condition to the local street guards. Needless to say, this was not my original plan.î

The kitchen was a modest tidy room, with a round dining table squeezed into a sort of bay overlooking the walled back garden. The windows mostly reflected the roomís bright interior, but beyond, the nightís damp blackness was turning to bluer shadow. The blond kid, the attaché Johannes, turned from the microwave and almost dropped whatever pre-packaged bachelor fare heíd just heated. At his bossís head-jerk, he hastened to pull out a chair for the very important, if very unkempt, visitor. Miles fell into it, trying not to let his gratitude overcome his exasperation, because the latter was about all that was keeping him functional.
ìCan I get you something, my lord?î asked the lieutenant solicitously.

ìTea. Also a shower, dry clothes, food, sleep, and a secured comconsole, though Iíd settle for just the comconsole, but letís start with the tea.î Or else he risked pillowing his head on his arms and going for the sleep first, right here. ìDid you get my donít-panic message off to Barrayar, and my wife? Coded, I trust?î
Vorlynkin said, a little stiffly, ìWe notified ImpSec Galactic Affairs on Komarr that weíd heard from you, and that you were not in the hands of the kidnappers.î

ìGood enough. Iíll send my own update in a bit.î Miles trusted it would overtake any word anyone had been maladroit enough to hand on to Ekaterin, or heíd have some groveling to do when he got home. ìMeanwhile, Iíve had no news since yesterday. Have you heard more on the hostages taken from the cryo-conference? Anything on Armsman Roic?î

Vorlynkin slid into his chair a quarter-wedge around the table from Miles. ìGood news there, sir. Your Armsman managed to escape his captors long enough to reach a comlink of some sort and call the Northbridge authorities. The police rescue team reached them not long agoóweíve been up all night following developments. It seems everyone was freed alive. I donít know how long it will take him to get backóhe said he had to stay till heíd given his testimony.î

ìAh, yes. Roic has a deal more sympathy for police procedure than I do.î Miles took his first swallow of hot tea with profound relief. ìAnd the boyówait. And who might you be?î Miles eyed Yuuichi, who had taken refuge with Johannes on the far side of the kitchen.
ìThis is our consulate clerk, Yuuichi Matson,î Vorkynkin put in. ìOur most valuable employee. Heís been here about five years.î The clerk cast his boss a grateful look and slanted Miles a civil bow.

The consulateís only employee, actually. And since Vorlynkin had been here two years, and Johannes had only arrived last year, Matson was also the oldest, in time of service if not age. Who do you trust, my Lord Auditor? In a situation like this, no one but Roic, Miles supposed, but misplaced paranoia could be as great a mistake as misplaced faith. Careful, then, but not bloody paralyzed. ìSo what happened to Jin?î
ìWe dispatched him back to you exactly as you directed, my lord. We did take the precaution of placing a microscopic ping tracer in the envelope, however.î
Not exactly the donít follow him that Miles had written, but it would be hypocritical to quibble over fine points now. Results, after all.

ìBy early evening, the envelope had come to rest in what we think is the evidence room of the Northbridge central police stationóitís in that building, anyway. The boy Jin, after apparently passing through the hands of the police, ended up at the juvenile detention center, where heís been all night. With that much to go on, Lieutenant Johannes was able to access the public arrest records for yesterday, and identify him by process of elimination. It seems the boyís full name is Jin Sato, and heís a runaway whoís been missing for over a year!î
ìYes?î said Miles. ìI knew that.î
Vorlynkinís diplomatic tones grew notably strained. ìHow the devilósir!ódid you come to involve a child like that in your affairsówhatever they are?î
ìHeís eleven,î said Miles.
ìEleven! Worse and worse!î

ìWhen my father was eleven,î said Miles reasonably, ìhe became aide-de-camp to the general-my-grandfather in a full-scale civil war. By age thirteen heíd helped to bring down an emperor. I didnít figure an afternoonís jaunt across his home town and backóon a peaceful planet at thatóto be beyond Jinís capacity.î Yet apparently, heíd figured wrong. Miles winced inside. He hadnít thought through the implications of Jinís runaway status in a heavily monitored place like this, even while picking his own route to avoid notice as a matter of routine. The boy would be frantic for his animals by now, and that was the least of it. ìMy mistake to fix, then. I donít abandon my people if I can help it. Weíll just have to retrieve him.î
Vorlynkinís jaw dropped. ìHeís a minor child. How? We have no rights to him!î

ìHe was carrying all our petty cash, too,î put in Johannes. ìIíd have gone after that myself, but I had no way to prove it was ours.î He frowned at Miles, the exactly as you directed complaint implied.
Well, thereís always your ping tracer, but before Miles could voice the thought, Vorlynkin went on.
ìIf your underage courier talks, I expect the Northbridge police will be calling us. With some very hard-to-answer questions.î
Miles paused, alert. ìHave they?î
ìNo. Not yet.î
And if they didnít call, it would imply Jin had kept his mouth shut, and under conditions that had to be quite frightening to him. ìThatísÖ interesting.î
ìWhere did you pick up that boy, my lord?î said Vorlynkin.

ìActually, he found me. On the street, more or less.î Miles did some rapid internal editing. He had, after all, given Suze his tacit word not to reveal her lair in exchange for information, and he had certainly received information, even if he wasnít sure what he wanted to do with it yet. ìYou read my note to you, right?î
Vorlynkin nodded.

ìWell, as I said, the drug the kidnappers tried to sedate me with triggered manic hallucinations instead, and I ended up lost in the Cryocombs.î No need to say for how long; the situation was certainly elastic enough to cover the missing day heíd spent with Jin and company. ìWhen I came to my senses and found my way out, I was still a bit paranoid about my kidnappers finding me again, and too exhausted to go on. Jin kindly helped me, and I owe him.î
Vorlynkin stared at Miles very hard. ìAre you saying you werenít in your right mind?î
ìThat might actually be a good explanation, should one be needed. Does this consulate keep a local lawyer?î
ìOn retainer, yes.î

Standard practice. Can you trust him or her to keep our secrets? was a question Miles wasnít ready to ask out loud quite yet. ìGood. As soon as possible, contact the lawyer and find out what we can do to get Jin back.î He held out his mug for more tea; Yuuichi, the clerk, politely filled it. Milesís hand was shaking with fatigue, but he managed not to spill tea on the way to his lips. ìShowerís as good as three hours of sleep. Shower first, and then the comconsole, if you please.î
ìShouldnít you rest, my lord?î said Vorlynkin.

Miles choked back an impulse to scream, Donít argue with me! which was a pretty good indicator that, yes, he damn well should rest, but there were a few key things that he had to know, first. ìLater,î he said, then conceded, ìSoon.î

After a moment, he added reluctantly, ìYouíd better let the Northbridge police know I escaped, was lost in the Cryocombs, and came back to the consulate on my ownóI donít want them to waste their resources hunting me. You can tell them Iím uninjured but extremely fatigued, and am resting here. They can send someone to take a statement from me tomorrow, if they need one. Donít mention Jin unless they ask. If anyone else inquires after meÖ check with me.î
This won another hard stare from Vorlynkin, but he only nodded.

Johannes led Miles upstairs to the sleeping quartersóit appeared that the two Barrayaran bachelors saved on rent by living on the premisesóand the consulate personnel scored about a million points with Miles by providing his very own clothes and gear, retrieved along with Roicís from their hotel room after the kidnappings. Johannes eyed the Auditorís own secured communications equipmentóImpSecís bestówith due respect, when handing it over. The personal belongings the kidnappers had stripped from Miles were still in the hands of the police, found discarded in a downtown alley and retained as evidence, except for his Auditorís seal, which Vorlynkin had managed to pry back from them with, Miles gathered, some vigorous diplomatic persuasion.

Half an hour laterówashed, shaved, and dressed in clean clothesóMiles had Johannes lead him down to the consulateís basement communications tight-room, such as it was, and settle him before a secured comconsole. Miles stretched his back and spread his fingers, then entered his first search term: Lisa Sato.
ìWhoís that?î asked Johannes, looming over his shoulder.
ìJin Satoís mother.î
ìIs she important?î
ìSomeone thought so, Lieutenant. Someone definitely thought so.î As the vid plate flickered, Miles bent to the data stream.

A brief conversation with mílord over the comconsole at Northbridge police headquarters, once the rescued delegates arrived there, relieved Roic of his worst nightmare, that of losing the little giómílord. New curiosities thronged to take its place. Why was mílord insisting that Roic bring Dr. Durona along?
ìActually, Iíd planned to return to the conference hotel and collect my luggage,î Raven interpolated, leaning into the vid pick-up.
ìSee me first,î mílord replied.
ìIíll miss my jumpship.î
ìThereís one every day. In fact, donít reschedule your berth yet.î
Ravenís black brows flicked up. ìMy time is money.î
ìIíll keep that in mind.î
Raven shrugged amiably at mílordís very dry tone, and followed Roic, both scuffing along in the paper slippers their hosts had provided while waiting for their stolen shoes to surface.

It was midafternoon when the police at last dropped Roic and his bemused companion off at the consulate. The four-square house seemed unduly modest, in Roicís view, though he supposed that upholding the dignity of the Imperium at this distance was costly enough. It did look as though it might provide a shower and a place to nap, Roicís two biggest remaining wants since the police had provided the freed captives with a meal, or at least as many ration bars as anyone would want to eat. High in protein and vitamins, tasting like chocolate-coated putty with kitty litterósome horrors were universal, it seemed.

Roic stifled his wish for a wash-up and had Lieutenant Johannes guide them directly to mílord, already ensconced like an invasive spider in the consulateís communications tight-room. In most planetary embassies that Roic had visited in mílordís wake, the tight-room seemed the secret nerve center of the embassyís affairs, hushed and urgent. Here, it felt more like someoneís leftover basement hobby roomófor some very odd hobbiesóretrofitted in high tech.

Mílord swiveled in his station chair and waved Roic and Raven to seats, dismissing Johannes with a ìThank you, Lieutenant.î Johannes, looking as though he longed to stay and eavesdrop, nodded and dutifully withdrew, closing the door with that muffled thump that betokened a good sound seal. Roic ignored the faint serial-killer ambiance of the windowless chamber, and tried to appreciate that here at last one might enjoy a truly private conversation.
ìAre you two all right?î A perfunctory inquiry; mílord didnít even wait for Ravenís nod and Roicís grunt before continuing, ìTell me everything that happened to you. And yes, I want all the details.î

Mílord listened, brows tightening, as the full tale of the kidnapping and rescue unwound, rewarding the tellers at the end with a mere, ìHuh.î He added to Raven, ìIím glad youíre all right. I shouldnít have liked to explain your loss to your clone-siblings, or mine. Iíd actually thought the Durona Group would send your sister Rowan.î

ìNo, sheís much too busy these days for off-planet jaunts,î said Raven. ìSheís our department head for Cryonicsówe have over five hundred employees, between our clinical services, research, and administrative overhead. And she and that Escobaran medtech she married plan to pop their second kid from the uterine replicator any day now.î
ìNot cloned, eh?î
ìNo, it was all done the old-fashioned way, an egg and a sperm in a test tube. They didnít even go for any genetic mods, beyond the routine check for defects, of course.î
ìOf course,î murmured mílord, without comment. ìSo good old Lily Durona is a real grandmother, nowóor aunt, depending on how you look at it. She continues in good health for her age, I trust?î
ìVery much so.î
ìInteresting.î

Raven tugged absently on his frazzled braid, laid over his shoulder, and continued, ìAs a department head, Rowan says she misses the hands-on surgical work. She hardly gets to do two revivals a week, these days. I do two to six a day, depending on complications. Nothing as complicated as you wereóyou took Rowan, me, and two shifts of medtechs eighteen hours straight, back in the day.î
ìYou did good work.î
ìThank you.î Raven nodded in what seemed to Roic rather smug satisfaction.
ìGive Rowan my best, when you see her.î
ìOh, yeah, she said to say hi to you, too.î
This won an oddly ironic look, and a return nod.
ìI take it,î put in Roic, ìthat Dr. Durona, here, wasnít at the conference by chance?î
ìIndeed, not. Iíd asked the Durona Group to supply me with an independent technical evaluation of the cryo-conference, and whatever turned up at it.î

ìThe Group had actually received the conferenceís call for presentations well before you asked, Lord Vorkosigan. We were going to send one of our junior residentsóthis place is not without interest to us, actually.î
ìAnd have you observed anything of special note so far? Technically.î Mílord leaned back in his station chair and steepled his fingers, giving Raven a judicious stare.
ìNothing new to us on the technical side. I did notice that they seemed more interested in freezing people than thawing them.î
ìYes, the cryocorps are plainly playing numbers games with their customersíópatrons, they call íemóproxy votes.î
ìItís a game theyíve won, from the sound of things.î
Mílord nodded. ìIt was barely discussed at the conference, yet there seems to be plenty of debate on the subject outside. In the streets and elsewhere.î
Raven put in, ìThe N.H.L.L. were sure complaining vigorously.î
ìYeah, but not very effectively,î said Roic. ìLoons like that are their own worst advertisement.î
ìDoes it strike you both as a pretty free debate, as such things go? Noisy?î
ìWell, yes,î said Raven. ìNot as noisy as Escobaran politics.î
ìNoisier than Barrayar, though,î Roic said.
ìMuch noisier than Jacksonís Whole,î Raven granted, with a twisted grin.

ìThatís not politics, thatís predators versus prey,î muttered mílord. But he went on: ìWell, thanks to the N.H.L.L., I had a very useful two days. Now that youíre both back alive, I suppose I can afford to be grateful to them.î
ìNew answers?î asked Roic, with a sapient eyebrow-lift.
ìBetter. A whole raft of new questions.î

And mílord promptly toppedóof courseóRoicís tale with a hair-curling story of the appalling extent of the Cryocombs beneath the city, and of how mílord had stumbled on a bootleg freezing operation run by, apparently, Kibou street geezers. Raven seemed less impressed by the bootleg cryonicsóhe was Jacksonian, after all. As near as Roic could tell, everything on Jacksonís Whole was done illegally. Or, more precisely, lawlessly.
ìFragile and doomed,î was Ravenís succinct opinion of Madame Suzeís on-going operation. ìIím astonished sheís gotten away with so much for so long.î

ìMm, maybe not. Itís clandestine, but it doesnít really rock the cryocorpsí boat. Everyone here being in the same boat, after all.î Mílord rubbed his chin and squinted red-rimmed eyes that glinted a trifle too brightly. ìThen we come to this woman Lisa Sato, and her group.î
ìYour little zookeeperís frozen mama?î said Roic.
