ìYep. The N.H.L.L. is allowed to run its length, Suzeís operation is overlooked, but Satoís seemingly much more reasonable and legal group is broken up, at considerable trouble and expense. All that ambient noise, and yet only one voice is silenced.î Mílord gestured to the secured comconsole, now dark. ìIíve spent the past several hours doing some diggingóî
And as a former ImpSec galactic operative, this sort of digging was meat and drink to mílord, Roic reflected.

ìóand in just that time, Iíve turned up anomalies galore. Lisa Sato was not the only member of her group to come to a bad end. Two others were frozen after supposedly-unsuccessful treatments for medical conditions that should not have been fatal, another died in an accident, and yet another was ruled a suicide of the fell-or-jumped sort. Even at the time, brows were raised, and quite a few people were offended, but the aftershocks were drowned out in the news by a flood of trivial sex scandals. What does this suggest to you?î
ìThat Lisa Satoís group was getting ready to rock somebodyís boat pretty hard,î said Roic slowly.
Raven nodded concurrence. ìHow?î

ìThat, interestingly, does not turn up in the public record. Nor even in the less-public records. Somebody did a first-class job on the cleanup, there, even if they werenít able to make it completely invisible. That now heads my list of shiny new questionsójust what got cleaned up, a year and a half ago?î
Roic frowned. ìVery riveting, mílord, butÖ what has this got tí do with Barrayarís interests?î
Mílord cleared his throat. ìIt is far too early to say,î he said primly.

Roic, glumly, read that as, I havenít made up a reason yet, but give me time. Was mílord going all quixotic on account of that orphan boy? Emperor Gregor himself had warned Roic about mílordís tendency to expensive knight-errantry, in one of their rare private conversations. From the Imperial sigh that had accompanied this, it had been unclear if Gregor actually expected Roic to restrain mílord, or not.
The door hissed open, and Consul Vorlynkin stuck his head through. ìIíve heard back from the lawyer, Lord Vorkosigan.î
ìAh, good!î Mílord waved him in; he stood, seeming a bit wary. ìWhatís the word on Jin?î

ìAs I thought, there is nothing we can legally do. If he were an orphan without kin, you could apply for custody of him, but it would take some months and almost certainly be rejected by the Northbridge courts, especially if there was any hint of taking him off-planet.î
ìI didnít ask to adopt him, Vorlynkin. Just rescue him from the police.î
ìIn any case, my Lord Auditor, itís become mootóthe police have already turned the boy over to his blood-kin, an aunt who is in fact his present legal guardian.î
ìDamn!î Mílord slumped. ìDamn. I hope Ako proves a more faithful zookeeper than I did.î

ìWell, itís not as if we could kidnap him,î said Vorlynkin, with a faint smile. Mílord eyed him. Perhaps thinking better of this mild venture into humor, Vorlynkin cleared his throat and went back to looking bland. Roic wondered if he should take Vorlynkin aside later and warn him not to say things like that around mílord, and not because the Lord Auditor might take offense.

Roic rubbed sandy eyelids. ìPerhaps youíd best sleep on it, mílord,î he suggested, not without self-interest. Mílord had plainly had the advantage of a shower and fresh clothes, but still looked as if heíd been up all night, as had they all. And the shiny glitter in his eyes was a tip-off. ìHave you checked your neurotransmitter levels since you got back?î The elevation of same being early warning of an impending seizure, and signal it was time to use the medical seizure-stimulator to short-circuit the fitóin some safe and controlled place.
Mílord addressed an unrevealing mutter to his shoes.
ìRight,î said Roic, in a very firm tone.
Mílord sighed and rubbed the back of his neck. ìYeah, yeah.î
ìCan I go back to my hotel now?î asked Raven hopefully.
ìYes, but stay in touch. In factóVorlynkin, please issue Dr. Durona a secured wristcom before he goes, eh?î
Vorlynkinís brows rose, but he said only, ìYes, my lord.î

ìI need more data,î mílord growled, to no one in particular. He looked up appraisingly at the consul. ìAll right, Vorlynkin. If WhiteChrys or any of our other late hosts call to inquire after me, I want you to tell them that I am very upset by the disruption of the conference and the kidnapping of my armsman. In fact, Iím furious, and as soon as I recover from my ordeal I plan to stalk home and give a very bad report of the affair to anyone who will listen, starting with Emperor Gregor.î
ìErÖ and are you?î asked Vorlynkin, sounding nonplussed.

Mílord returned only an unreassuring grin. ìI want you to test how far theyíll go to reopen their lines of communication. Indicate youíll do your diplomatic best to calm me down, but youíre not sure it can be done. If they offer you incentives for the task, take them up.î
ìYouÖ want me to accept a bribe, sir?î A little real offense tightened Vorlynkinís jaw, as well as understandable alarm.

ìWell, at least pretend to consider it, eh? It will show us who wants what, and how badly. If they donít come through, Iíll have to think of another move, but if youíre a tolerably good fisherman, I think you can hook them for me.î

ìIíll, umÖ try my best, sir.î Vorlynkin didnít exactly stare at the Lord Auditor as if the little man had sprouted two heads, but Roic could almost see the consul scrambling to keep pace. Yeah, welcome to my world.
The debriefing broke up.

The consulate harbored two spare bedrooms upstairs fitted out for guests, not much used for the purpose and slowly filling with assorted storage. One had been hastily cleared for the Lord Auditor. Roic turned down the bed and rummaged in mílordís luggage for the seizure stimulator. Mílord stripped to his underwear, sat on the bed, and eyed the medical device with loathing.
ìKludgy thing.î
ìYes, mílord. Tell me, am I to trust the consulate fellows here, or not?î
ìIím not sure yet. Iíve been caught out before with embassy staff or even ImpSec couriers being suborned.î

ìBecause if you mean to use them for backup, which we very much need, youíre going to have to start including them in your loop. I could see Lieutenant Johannes, fír instance, didnít know what to make of you leaving him out just now.î

ìItís this Lord Auditor thing. I used to be able to get almost anyone to talk to me, damn it. In your spare minutes, try your hand at evaluating them, eh? Iíve no doubt theyíll be more willing to be frank with you, simple honest face and all that.î
ìYes, mílord.î

ìI already know that somebody out there is buying people. Question is, has the consulate been bought already, or did there seem no need to secure it before I showed up? At least neither of the Barrayarans have families here, so I donít have to worry about negative incentives.î Mílord scowled, lay back, and set the stimulator to the curve of his skull. Roic handed him the mouth guard, which he fitted around his teeth. He took a breath and squeezed his eyes shut like someone about to down a dose of some nasty-tasting medicine, and triggered the stimulator.

Roic timed the seizureóit was a long one, suggesting mílord had been pushing the limit. Roic was used to the rolled-back eyes, the weird grimace, and the shivering, but he doubted heíd ever be quite reconciled to the strange absence of that driving personality animating the face. In due course, the neural storm passed, and mílord lay slack, his eyes opening again on the universe as though his gaze recreated it.
ìGod, I hate this,î he muttered. His standard mantra at this point.
ìYes, mílord,î Roic soothed. His standard response.
ìIíll be useless for the rest of the night even if I do get slept out. And tomorrow as well.î
ìIíll bring you coffee.î
ìThanks, Roic.î Mílord rolled over and drew up the covers, surrendering at last to the demands of his depleted body. Muffled into the pillow, almost inaudibly, ìFír everythiníÖî
Roic shook his head and tiptoed off to find his own bunk.

Jin blinked open sore eyes in the semi-darkness of his sister Minakoís tiny bedroom, then bit his lip on a groan. Heíd meant to stay awake, outwait and maybe outwit his captors, but the exhaustion of the past day had betrayed him. He sat up on his elbow. A nightlight low on the wall shed a dim pink glow, but the room lacked a clock. It was still full dark outside, and the muffled rumble of Uncle Hikaruís snores sounded through the thin walls of the next room, so everyone else was asleep, but it could be any hour from midnight to near-dawn.

He swung bare legs out from under the covers of the narrow futon. Aunt Lorna had put him to bed in his underwear, since his cousin Tetsuís pajamas had been too big, and his cousin Kenís too small. His own clothes she had hauled away to wash, or maybe burn, sheíd said, since there was no telling where theyíd been. Jin sure wasnít telling, anyway.

Hopelessly, he went to the window and tried the lock. It unlatched, but the window only slid aside about three centimeters. Uncle Hikaru had climbed up on a borrowed ladder, after the argument at dinner, and blocked the window groove with a rod. Jin could just curl his fingers around the frame, but couldnít get his hand through. He wasnít going to be able to repeat his escape of last year.

Jin pressed his forehead to the cool glass and looked down at the patch of patio, one floor below. In a way, Aunt Lorna had made it easy for him, back then, by exiling all his animals out there. After heíd climbed out the window and dropped down, heíd only had to load them all up on Minakoís outgrown stroller, left in the lee of the fence earlier that day. Heíd been terrified at the time that Gyreís squawk and Luckyís meowing would alert the household, or that the glass box holding the rats and the turtle would tip and clatter, but it had been a cold night, the windows closed, and nobody but him paid attention to his creatures anyway.

Well, Tetsu had got in the habit of teasing Gyre, till Gyre had, naturally, bit him. Then thereíd been the trip to emergency care, and the surgical glue and antibiotics, and Aunt Lorna screeching more than Tetsu, though mostly about the bill. Tetsu had shown off his battle scar at school the next day pretty smugly, Jin thought.

Jin slipped over and tried the door, turning the latch as silently as he could. Still locked. There had been another big argument about whether people had to get up in the night to let Jin go to the bathroom, which Uncle Hikaru had settled, in a very practical way, by providing Jin with a bucket, which had scandalized Aunt Lorna and made Tetsu and Ken make fun of him, till Uncle had thumped them. That had been after the squabble over where Jin was to sleep, since his sister was now judged too big to share a bed with him, or maybe it was the other way around. Tetsu and Ken, already dividing a cramped room, complained about having yet a third boy shoved in atop their clutter, and had also objected to being made Jinís watchers. Jin had endured much in silence, last night and today, in anticipation of a timely escape. He hadnít expected to be locked in.
ìJust till the boy settles down,î Uncle Hikaru had saidóas if Jin would abandon his creatures. As if he would ever stay here.

Was Miles-san taking care of his charges properly? What must he think, when Jin never came back with his money? Would he think Jin had stolen it? The police had stolen it, really, but would even that extraordinary off-worlder believe Jin over the grownups? He swallowed a lump in his throat, determined not to cry again, because maybe letting go like that was why heíd fallen asleep, earlier. Although what was the point in forcing himself to stay awake when he couldnít get out? He returned to the futon and sank down in despair.

Maybe tomorrow night he could hide a screwdriver or some other tools in the room, and try to take the window or the door lock apart from the inside. Tenbury would have known how, Jin was sure. He didnít think he could pretend to be all settled down so quickly and thus lull his captors into relaxing their guard, not when he was growing more and more frantic inside. Aunt Lorna had threatened she was going to sign him right up tomorrow for Tetsu and Kenís school, because she couldnít afford to lose any more work days over him. School, he recalled, had seemed even less easy to escape from thanóJin refused to think of this narrow rented row-house as home.

The door lock clicked. Aunt Lorna, checking up on him? He could still hear Uncle Hikaruís snores. He rolled over to face the wall, hitched his covers up over his shoulder, and scrunched his eyes shut.
ìJin?î a shy voice whispered. ìAre you asleep?î
Jin rolled back, both relieved and annoyed. It was only Mina. ìYes,î he growled.
A short silence. ìNo, youíre not.î
ìWhat do you want?î Some forgotten doll or stuffed toy, he supposed, although sheíd taken a basket of them with her to her temporary bed on the couch downstairs.

The door rumbled, sliding into its slot, and small feet padded to the side of his futon. He rolled over onto his elbow again and stared up at her, staring down at him. She shared Jinís brown eyes and tousled mop of black hair, but she was taller and less chubby than he remembered from fourteen months ago. Then, she hadnít even started school yetónow she was in her second year. She seemed lessÖ bewildered-looking, somehow.
ìIf I let you out,î she said, ìwill you take me with you?î
ìHuh?î Startled, Jin sat up and hugged his knees. What, she wasnít just lost on the way to the bathroom? ìNo, of course not. Are you crazy?î
Her face fell. ìOh.î She retreated to the door and started to pull it shut behind her.
ìNo, wait!î Jin hissed, lumbering up.
Next door, the snores stopped. They both froze. After a moment, there came a creaking and a sort of gurgling-drain noise, and the snores started up again.
ìWe canít talk here,î Jin whispered. ìLetís go downstairs.î

She seemed to think this over, then nodded, waiting in the hallway while he wrapped a blanket around his shoulders and trailed after her. Jin shoved the door closed again very slowly and quietly. The stairs squeaked under their tiptoeing feet, but no one came after them.

ìDonít turn the light on,î Jin said, keeping his voice low. There was enough light leaking from what Uncle Hikaru called the one-butt kitchen, in a niche off the living-dining room, to keep from tripping on things.
Mina settled back in her twisted nest of covers on the couch. Jin sat on the edge of Uncle Hikaruís chair and stared around.
Mina asked, ìDo you remember Daddy?î
ìSort of. Some.î
ìI donít. Just his picture in the family shrine Mommy set up.î

ìYou were three.î Jin had been seven when their father had died. Four years agoóit seemed half a lifetime. He remembered his motherís extravagant grief and anger rather better, and how seldom heíd seen her after thatóas if one death had stolen both parents, even before the policewomen had come for her. ìDoesnít Aunt Lorna keep the family shrine anymore?î
ìShe let me keep it in my room for a while, but then we ran out of space when I needed a desk for school, so she boxed it up and put it away. I wasnít sure if to set your picture in it or not.î
Mina was putting on her shoes, a determined look on her face.
ìYou canít go with me,î Jin repeated uneasily. ìNot where Iím going.î
ìWhere are you going?î
ìA long walk. Too far for you. Why do you want to come anyway?î Sheíd been Aunt and Uncleís pet, he thought.
ìTetsu and Ken are horrid to me. Teasing and bedeviling. Uncle Hikaru yells at them, but he never gets up and does anything.î

Jin didnít quite see the problem with this. Well, he had a dim sense that maybe it was his job to heckle his own sister, but if somebody else wanted to take up the slack, he had no objection. ìTheyíre probably just jealous because you get all the girl stuff. Plus if you werenít here, Ken would have your room,î he added in a fair-minded fashion.
ìUncle and Aunt were talking about ídopting me, before you came back. But I donít want Tetsu and Ken for my brothers. I want my real brother.î

ìHow can they adopt you when Momís stillÖî He trailed off. Alive? The word choked in his throat, a wad of uncertainty. He swallowed it and went on: ìYou canít stay where Iím going. Ióthey wouldnít want you. Youíd just get in the way.î While Suze-san and the people at her place might be willing to treat a stray boy as casually as a stray cat, he had a queasy sense that a stray girl, and younger at that, might be another story. And while the police, not to mention Uncle Hikaru and Aunt Lorna, might be less excited about him running away a second time, would that boredom extend to Mina? ìYou couldnít keep up.î
ìYes, I could!î
ìSh! Keep your voice down!î
Her mouth went mulish. ìIf you donít take me along, Iíll set up a screech, and theyíll catch you and put you back in my room! And I wonít let you out again, so there!î

He tried to decide if she was bluffing. No, probably not. Could he hit her on the head with something and knock her out while he made his getaway? He had a feeling that worked better in holovids than in real life. And if he hit her with one of Aunt Lornaís pots or pans, the only blunt instruments immediately available, it would make a hellish bong and wake everybody up anyway, defeating his purpose.
She interrupted his hostile mulling, in a practical tone that reminded him of Uncle Hikaru: ìBesides, I have money and you donít.î
ìÖHow much?î
ìOver five hundred nuyen,î she answered proudly. ìI saved it up from my birthday and chores.î

Enough for a dozen tram fares, except that Jin had sworn off the tube system. He craned his neck for a look at the kitchen clockómaybe two hours till dawn, and everybody getting up and missing them. That wasnít very much of a headstart, compared to the last time. It was now or never. Jin surrendered to the inevitable. ìAll right, get ready. Quietly. Do you know where Aunt Lorna put my stuff?î

They found Jinís clothes in the plastic basket, along with his shoes, in the closet off the kitchen that harbored the launderizer. Mina knew which kitchen drawer hid the lunch bars, too, and stuck a dozen in a sack. Within minutes, they both edged out the sliding back door. Jin latched the patio gate as quietly as he could behind them, and led off up the alley.

The occasional streetlights made cold halos in the clammy night mist. ìIíve never been outside this late before,î said Mina, still whispering, though they were well away from the row house. ìItís weird. Are you afraid of the dark?î She made to walk closer to Jin; he strode faster.
ìThe darkís all right. Itís people you have to be afraid of.î
ìI guess so.î

A longer silence, while their feet thumped softly on the pavement. Then Mina said, ìThat thing Aunt Lorna said to you, about recidórecidivÖ I canít pronounce it. Kids who run away over and over. They donít really freeze them, do they?î
Jin pondered it uneasily. ìI never heard of it before. And it would cost a lot of money, I think.î
ìSo she was just trying to scare you into being good?î
ìYeah.î The scare part had sure worked, Jin had to allow that.
ìBut anyway, they donít freeze you the first time.î Mina seemed to take undue satisfaction from this thought.

An unwelcome memory rose in Jinís mind. It wasnít the clammy smell of the night that triggered it, because the policewomen had come for his mother in the daytime, but the clammy chill in his gut that day had felt much like this. Mom kneeling down, gripping his shoulders, saying, Jin, help look after Mina, all right? Be a good big brother, and do what Aunt Lorna tells you.

Jin had given up on that last when Aunt Lorna had insisted that he get rid of all of his pets, yes, all, a clean sweep, there was no room and they smelled and pooped too much and that bird was homicidal and to top everything, Ken was supposedly allergic to Lucky, who was too lazy to scratch anyone. Jin just figured his cousin was doing all that sniffling and blowing on purpose, to be annoying, in which he certainly succeeded. Jin had forgotten the first part of that maternal partingÖ blessing, curse, whatever it was, because, after all, nobody yelled at Mina the way theyíd yelled at him and his pets.
He wished he hadnít remembered that.

They had a good long walk ahead of them just to get out of this area, which they needed to do before they were missed. Maybe theyíd better lie up and hide during school hours. Jin selected a direction he was almost sure was south, and kept trudging.

Two days after his dawn return to the consulate, Milesís party assembled on the front walk and watched the WhiteChrys groundcar pull up to collect them. It was long, sleek, gleaming, and settled to the pavement with a sigh like a satisfied lover.
Roicís eyebrows rose. ìBetter tín that bus-thing they ferried us conference delegates around in, Iíll give it that.î
ìIndeed,î said Miles. ìGood job, Vorlynkin. It looks like WhiteChrys means to grovel in style.î

This won an uncertain head-duck from the consul, who had spent a good part of yesterday in repeated calls to and from their would-be host to set all this up, while Miles played hard-to-get. At least the delay had given him time to recover from the induced seizure.

But while it would do no harm to Milesís cause if Barrayarís own diplomat plainly found him alarming, he was not altogether sure if the man was under control. Or sure whose control heís under? He favored the consul with a brief smile. ìBy the by, Vorlynkin, please refrain from commenting on anything you hear me say or see me do today. For the duration, youíre the yes-man.î
An unreadable pause. ìYes, my Lord Auditor.î
Capable of irony, was he? Good. Probably.

ìItíll be just like watching a play,î Roic reassured him. Vorlynkinís brows quirked, albeit not in an especially reassured way. Dr. Durona, engaged in examining the variegated hostas lining the walk, straightened and turned his braided head with interest as the groundcarís rear compartment canopy rose and a woman exited.

She was as sleek as the groundcar, if considerably more delicate. Her long black hair was drawn back and bundled with enameled combs in an elegant construction that Miles was sure Raven must envy. Kibou natives wore a variety of fashions both local and galactic-inspired; Miles had been here just long enough to decode her garb as business-traditional, female version. A skin-skimming top, a fitted undercoat, and the loose cord-fastened outer coat might be worn by either men or women, but then, instead of the wide trousers tied in at the ankles adopted by men, she showed off trim calves with a short skirt and leggings. All in subtle autumnal shades that set off her deep brown eyes. The overall effect was simultaneously upper-class and sexy, like a very expensive courtesanóMiles had once had the geisha tradition explained to him on a visit to Earth itself, on its island of origin, a side-benefit of having a bride with a mania for gardens. The sense that this woman was a weapon aimed directly at him came mainly from her diminutive height, which nearly matched his own, and the fact that she wore flat sandals.

ìGood morning, ohayo gozaimasu.î She favored them all with a formal bow, but her smile zeroed in on Miles. ìLord Vorkosigan, Consul Vorlynkin, Durona-sensei, Roic-san. Wonderful, youíre all here. I am Aida, Mr. Ron Wingís personal assistant for today. I will escort you to WhiteChrysís new facility, and answer any questions you may have along the way.î

Iíll bet not mine, thought Miles, but returned appropriate greetings and allowed the pretty young lady to shepherd them all into the spacious groundcar. Miles wondered how much her boss had scrambled to find a hostess of that height on such short, as it were, notice.

Ron Wing was the man Miles had been holding out for yesterday, while Vorlynkin fielded oblique messages and visibly refrained from tearing his hair. Wingís official title was Head of Development; he was one of WhiteChrysís chief operating officers, and the man in ultimate charge of the Komarr expansion effort. It was his underlings who had spent so much effort cultivating Miles, and vice versa, during the cryonics conference. Now weíll see whatís on the other end of their string.
Roic, Aida, and Raven took the rear-facing seat; Miles and Vorlynkin settled opposite. No one even risked bumping heads with each other in the shuffle.
ìReminds me of my Daís old groundcar,î Miles murmured to Roic.
ìNah,î Roic whispered back, as the driver in the front compartment, who had not been introduced, set them smoothly in motion. ìThis isnít even half the mass. No armor plating.î

Soft-voiced Aida offered a startling variety of drinks from the carís bar, which everyone politely refused after Miles did. Miles tilted his face to the polarized canopy to get a better look at the capital from an above-ground vantage for a change. No actual mountains cradled Northbridge, but it had been long enough since the glaciers had retreated here for streams to have carved the moraines into something other than scraped-flat. The native plant species, rudimentary at best, had pretty much been displaced by urban landscaping based on Earth imports. The city was city, grown up around an infrastructure of galactic-standard transport and technology. If Miles hadnít walked through it himself, heíd have no guess of what strangeness lay below.
The view grew more interesting when they reached the west end and approached the Cryopolis proper.

ìThe Cryopolis began to be developed some forty years ago,î Aida informed them in good guide style, ìwhen further extension of cryofacilities beneath the city grew too expensive. Now Northbridge has grown out to meet it, and it has become its own municipality, named Western Hope.î
ìAnd how many representatives does Western Hope field to the Territorial Prefectureís legislature?î Miles inquired.
ìFourteen,î she replied brightly.
As many as the parent-city itself, though it occupied a fraction of the area. ìInteresting.î
Roicís head swiveled around. ìWhat tí heckÖ ?î
ìPyramids!î said Dr. Durona happily, craning too. ìDozens of íem! Is there a river around here called Denial?î
Miles reminded himself to repress Raven, too, at the earliest private opportunity.
Aidaís permanent smile grew briefly pained, but recovered at once. ìThose are the facilities of our largest cryonics services competitor, NewEgypt.î
About a kilometer of sandstone wall was pierced by a high gate, flanked by huge statues of somber seated figures sporting slim canine heads.

ìI saw those before,î said Roic, ìback at the conference. There was a fellow wandering around in a skimpy costume with a big plastic dog head, handing out flyers. Seemed more like an advertisement for a Jacksonís Whole bioengineering firm.î

Miles could fill in that one. ìThe figures are of Anubis, the Egyptian god of the dead,î he explained. ìThey had a number of other gods with animal headsóhawks, cats, cowsóthat had various figurative meanings. Thatís actually not a dog but a jackal, which was a carrion-eating scavenger in their ancient deserts. A natural association with death for a preindustrial folk, I suppose.î He glanced at Aida and refrained from expanding the parallel, though he did wonder if anyone had bothered to check the translations on those hieroglyphs decorating the walls, or whether they really read something like Ptah-hotep is a louse! or Unas owes Teti one hundred wheat sheaves and a firkin of figs.
Aida glanced at the receding figures and sniffed. ìAs you can see, theyíve taken up that era from Old Earth as their corporate theme.î
More of a theme park, Miles thought.
Aida added with reluctant admiration, ìThe pyramids are their cryo-storage facilities. NewEgypt has found that patrons will pay a premium for the more limited luxury space on the upper levels.î
ìLuxury space?î said Roic. ìIsnít it all tí same, once youíre frozen? I mean, technologically?î
He glanced at Raven, who murmured, ìOne certainly trusts soÖî

ìYes, but the cryo-contracts are selected and signed by the living people,î Aida explained. ìIt has been a very appealing and successful program for NewEgypt. Theyíve trademarked that entire historical period to block imitators.î She added in a tone of some disappointment, ìThey were giving away live sphinxes at the conference this year, but our department head was too late to get us one.î

With effort, Miles didnít blink, and so he had a good view of the next facility along their route, which featured glass towers and glittering spires wrapped with lines of colored light. The groundcar was well sound-insulated, but he could have sworn a faint bass beat penetrated the canopy. ìMusic?î

ìShinkawa Consolidated,î their guide explained. Sure enough, they passed another gate, with the cryocorpís name displayed over it in shifting rainbow hues. ìI believe they are trying to appeal to a younger crowd.î
Miles tried to digest that. It wasnít going down. ìSurely that would be the smallest market segment.î

ìPatrons are normally older when their contract is activated, yes,î said Aida. ìBut personal affordability is improved the sooner you sign on and begin your payments. Itís actually been a very effective strategy for Shinkawa. If I didnít have a cryo-contract through my own employer, as part of my benefits package, Iíd consider them myself.î She hid a giggle behind one well-manicured hand. ìThough I probably shouldnít tell you that.î

Another cryocorp campus appeared on the opposite side of the highway. It seemed to have a lot of trees, but neither walls nor gatesónor gate guardsóthough a low stone divider bore the name Northern Spring. What buildings Miles could spot through the vegetation looked blocky and utilitarian. Miles pointed. ìHow about those folks?î

ìAh, Northern Spring,î said Aida. ìThey have the distinction of being one of the oldest cryocorps in the region, and one of the first to develop a facility out here, but they are not what we would call top tier.î

Actually, according to Milesís not-always-inadequate preliminary reports on Kibou-daini, they were the sixth largest publicly-owned cryocorp presently doing business, which would certainly make them what he would call top tier. But the general look of their place was staid to the point of stodgy.

A lot of money was being spent to wooÖ not the dead, Miles supposed, but the living. Although for personal long-term cryo-sequestration, one might well want an immortal entity like a corporation left in charge. Their impressive fronts promised a number of things, but mostly continuity. If only one didnít know that at the secret heart of all such organizations, corporations and governments alike, it still came down to a finite number of fallible people talking to each otherÖ

The big groundcar slowed and turned, passing under an enormous red torii gateóWhiteChrys lost no time in asserting its chosen corporate style. The security beeped them through electronically without a pause. They rounded a stand of pine trees and pulled up before the headquarters building. An efficient tower block rose behind, but the visitor first threaded an imitation-traditional garden, all water and walkways, moss clumps, raked pebbles, and delicate red maples. The theme continued inside the big glass lobby with gnarled miniature trees and severe flower arrangements. Amid all this tasteful splendor their hosts awaited, bowing, and Miles shook off the last of his lingering seizure fatigue and gathered his wits.

Ron Wing in person proved middle-aged and trim in formal business attire: undercoat, wide-sleeved outer coat with just a hint of winged shoulders, and baggy trousers in subtle muted blues, complete right down to the split-toe socks and sandals. Style, fabric and cut all signaled status, money, and mode as surely as a Barrayaran Vor maleís quasi-military tunic, trousers, and half-boots. The calculated dress was backed up by shrewd eyes and a sober attention.

At Wingís elbow hovered the fellow who had delicately conveyed WhiteChrysís bribe to the Lord Auditor at the party the night before the terrorists/activists/idiotists had struck, so rudely interrupting their promising exchange. Hideyuki Storrs bore the title of executive vice president for development. He wore a slimmer version of his bossís garb, much like Vorlynkinís studiously local dress, tradition modified by utility; Miles had pegged him as a high-ranking minion, but not quite inner circle.

The development department plainly wanted to take up where theyíd left off, and Miles was reminded not to let himself be unruffled too soon. No point in wasting a free edge. Half of Milesís maneuvering yesterday had been to climb the chain of command up to One Who Knows. As Aida passed the party on to Storrs, who made the formal introductions to Wing, Miles thought with satisfaction, Target acquired. Locked on. By Wingís smile, Miles wondered if his opposite was thinking something similar.

p.emphasis: I am more important to you than I ought to be. Why?

section.p: ìIím so pleased,î said Wing, ìthat you have allowed us to make up for some of the inconveniences you have lately suffered, Lord Vorkosigan.î
Miles made an itís-not-your-fault wave of his free hand, undercut by a thin grimace, and returned, ìWe can only be grateful that no one was seriously injured or killed in the whole escapade.î
ìTruly,î agreed Wing. ìIn exchange, this does allow us to give you a much more detailed look at our facility than the general tour would have.î
ìSome exchange does seem due, yes.î
ìWould you care for some refreshments? Tea? Or shall we follow galactic custom and begin right away?î
ìIíd prefer to jump straight in, actually. My time here is not unlimited.î
ìRight this way, thenÖî

The whole party shuffled off after Wing at Milesís cane-pace, not altogether feigned. Between his underground ordeal and the usual after-effects of the damned seizures, his aches and pains were catching up with him. Aida stuck to his side, as if ready to catch him should he fall over. The prettiest public parts of the HQ building were quickly displayed, then they were wafted by float cart over to another building where actual intake of patrons occurred. Both the front lobby and the back loading docks seemed busy.

ìOur patrons come from two sources,î Wing explained, leading them down the medically-scented corridors. ìSome, whoíve suffered sudden and unexpected metabolic shut-downs, are actually processed by the hospitals, and then transferred to us for long-term storage. Others, who choose a less chancy mode, come in to our clinics and have us do the processing on-site.î
ìWait, they come in alive?î asked Roic.
ìThe healthier you are when frozen, the better your chances of a healthy revival,î said Storrs.
ìThatís quite true,î murmured Raven.
Roicís brows drew down, and he shot a glance at Miles, who could only say, ìAlas, yes.î

ìWould you care for a closer look at the technical processes?î said Wing. ìThat section isnít normally on the public tours, of course. We have some twenty or so freezings scheduled for today. The transfers are of course usually unscheduled.î

Miles, who had once endured the whole process far too intimately, if not consciously, waved aside the macabre treat; Roic looked relieved. Vorlynkin bore it all with a wooden expression. Raven, at Milesís thumbs-up behind his back, took the suggestion and went off with Storrs. Miles was glad to exit the processing building; the smell of the place, while not unpleasant, was doing odd jumpy things to his backbrain.

ìAnd how many cryorevivals do you do here in a day?î Miles asked Wing, once they were safely back in the float cart and in motion. He and Wing shared the front seat with the best view, Aida sat facing rearward at their backs, and Vorlynkin and Roic shared the last bench, not quite out of earshot.

Wing hesitated only slightly. ìI would have to look that figure up.î He glanced back as the cart bowled along through the well-kept grounds. ìHow did you come to know Dr. Durona?î Included in this jaunt at Milesísówell, not request; Raven had simply been announced in the seat count for the groundcar.
ìHe and my assistant Roic were rather thrown together during the kidnappings. A bonding experience, I gather.î

ìAh, that would explain it. Your Roic looks a fellow Iíd want to duck behind in a crisis, too.î It was plain Wing had no trouble translating assistant as bodyguard. No one, looking at Roic and Miles together, ever thought anything else. Miles was fairly sure Wing had not yet decoded the complexities of Armsman. Wing went on, ìI was intrigued to learn you have a relative who is a major shareholder in the Durona Group. Unless the name Vorkosigan is common on Barrayar?î

ìMark?î So, youíve finally caught up with that. Another clue, one of several, that Milesís Auditorial visit to Kibou had come as a surprise to the cryocorp, and they were still on the scramble to peg him. Miles had met deep-laid plots, years in fruition; Wingís maneuvers smelled of stop-gap, maybe only days old. ìMy younger brother, actually.î
ìReally!î Wing smiled. ìDo you think our Komarr expansion project would be of interest to him, as well?î

Yes, but not in the way you think. ìIíd prefer to keep Mark out of this. Heís a very shrewd businessman. While Iíve labored my whole life in public service for very little reward, heís piled up profits to envy, passing me by. One of the things that most excites me about your project is the chance at last to beat him at his own game.î Miles arranged his lips in a smile of vulpine sibling rivalry.
Wing got it at once, which said something about Wing. ìI quite see.î He added after a moment, ìAnd does he have anything like your influence in public affairs, Lord Vorkosigan?î
ìNo, he pretty much keeps to the shop.î
ìToo bad.î
ìNot from my point of view.î
ìAnd the rest of your famous family? Are you on warmer terms with them?î

ìOh, yes. Though a chance to show them all up doesnít come along every day.î Miles let his voice turn faintly whiny. ìIíve always had more to prove, on Barrayar.î There, let Wing digest that. A nice balance between jealous greed and the promise of an influence worth peddling. And it would stand up to surface inquiry. Thank you, Brother.
Wingís brow furrowed in doubt. ìWonít Dr. Durona report back to him?î
ìLetís just say Iím working on that.î Miles softened his voice so the hum of the cart kept it from carrying. ìYou know the old saying, Keep your friends close and your enemies closer?î
Wing nodded. ìThatís a good one.î He hesitated. ìWeíve prepared a presentation on the Komarr Project for you, next. Should we invite the good doctor to view another part of the facility during that?î
ìIt wonít be necessary. Unless you have some technical innovation you prefer not to disclose to potential rivals?î
ìNo, the Komarr installation will be based on tried and trusted technology. Our innovations are all to the business model.î

ìNo problem, then. I gather Raven is one of those techie typesóbusiness goes right over his head.î How provincial was this fellow Wing? Raven was from bloody Jacksonís Whole, where the Deal was art, science, war, and survival-till-dawn. ìHave you ever been off-world, Mr. Wing?î
ìYes, I had a trip to your Komarr last year, when we were setting up. All business, Iím afraidóI had very little time to tour. I never got outside of the Solstice Dome.î
ìAh, thatís a shame.î

Back in the headquarters building, they were all trundled off to a top-floor conference room, elegantly appointed with more gnarly potted treelets and fine art glass. Aida at last persuaded them to consume assorted beveragesóMiles and Vorlynkin stuck to green tea, Roic to coffeeóafter which they were subjected to a glossy holovid presentation all about the large WhiteChrys cryonics facility presently under construction in the Solstice Dome, Komarrís planetary capital. Try as he might, Miles could spot nothing about it that was not perfectly aboveboard. Neither, with access to far more detailed data, had ImpSec Komarr. And theyíd looked it over closely, incidentally picking up, with WhiteChrysís full cooperation and applause, two overcharging contractors, an embezzling customs clerk, and a ring of warehouse thieves, although none of that was mentioned in Wingís snazzy vid.
Raven and Storrs joined them about halfway through. The vid wound up in a burst of optimistic-yet-tasteful music.
Miles leaned back in his incredibly comfortable conference chair, steepling his fingers. ìSo, why Komarr? If you wanted to expand off-world, wouldnít Escobar have been closer?î

Wing sat up, looking happy to answer. ìWe did look into it. But Escobarís own cryonics services are far more mature, and are further shielded from competition by what I can only call highly protectionist regulation. Our analysts concluded that Komarr, despite the extra distance, offered far more scope for growth, which is, after all, where most profits lie. Profits in which we hope Barrayarans like yourself will share, of course. Indeed, Solstice Dome is sharing alreadyóall the work after the design stage was contracted locally.î

ìI expect,î said Miles judiciously, ìonce everyone on a planet has been sold a cryo-contract, thereís no place left to go but outward.î He didnít add, Though thereís one born every minute, but it was a struggle.
ìItís the hazard of a mature market, yes, Iím afraid. Although some interesting work has been done in the past year with commodifying contracts.î
ìBeg pardon?î

Wingís voice warmed with genuine enthusiasm. ìCryonics contracts have not been historically uniform, having been collected over many years by many institutions, often under different local laws. They yield on wildly varying bases, any of which might have grown or shrunk since the contract was activated. Companies themselves have split, combined, gone bankrupt or been bought out. Formerly, contracts and the responsibility for them have changed hands only along with the institutions holding them. But it was recently realized that a secondary market in individual contracts could provide considerable opportunity, either for profit-taking or to raise operating capital.î
Miles felt his brow corrugating. ìYouíre buying and selling the dead?î
ìSwapping all those frozen bodies around?î Roicís horrified expression was much less controlled.
ìNo, no!î said Wing. Storrs seconded his boss with vigorous headshake, No, no, no!

ìThat would be absurdly wasteful,î Wing went on. ìThe patrons mostly stay right where they are, unless a facility is being upgraded or decommissioned, of course. The patrons are held on a reciprocal accounting basis, company to company. Itís only their contracts that are traded.î He added piously, ìItís hoped that, over time, this will result in a more uniform and fairer contract structure industry-wide.î

Miles translated this as, When weíve squeezed the sponge dry, weíll stop. Judging by Ravenís remarkably blank smile, quite as if he hadnít understood a single word, he was making the exact same construction.
ìAnd, er, will you be applying that model to Komarr?î Miles asked.
ìUnfortunately, no. There is no one there to trade with.î Although he sighed, Wing did not seem to be especially distressed by this. Miles read that as, We plan to be a monopoly.
ìThis is all quite stunning,î Miles said honestly. ìAnd what do you think of it all, Vorlynkin?î He cast the consul a jovial wink. ìReady to sign up? I suppose itís all old hat to you, though.î

ìNotÖ really,î said Vorlynkin. ìMost of my work has dealt with the concerns of the living. I had to expedite returning the remains of one poor Barrayaran tourist who was killed glacier-diving last yearóvery dangerous sportóand sign off on the delivery of a couple of Kibou business people whoíd died of natural causes in the Empire and been shipped home. One frozen, one as ashes. There were complaints about the latter from the kin, which I forwarded to those responsible.î Vorlynkin added diplomaticallyóhow else?óìI do appreciate this behind-the-scenes view, Wing-san. Itís proving an eye-opener for me.î The glance under his lashes was at Miles, though.

They were all gathered up again and conveyed to lunch, which was served in a low building overlooking more gardens and a koi pond. The space was all paper screens and tatami mats, plus more art glass and those flower arrangements consisting of a handful of pebbles, three sticks, two buds, and a blossom. They sat on silk cushions at a couple of low lacquer tables. Miles had Wing on one side and Aida on the other, all to himself; Storrs hosted Vorkynkin, Roic, and Raven at the second table. A pair of servers brought in a succession of delicate dishes all looking like miniature sculptures, and Miles finally allowed Aida to serve him an odd-tasting clear wine in a flat ceramic cup. He wondered if the vesselís design was meant to be self-limiting; anyone too drunk must spill the contents down their front. He managed not to, barely.

Aida facilitated the conversation onto a series of pleasant, neutral topics, all the while inching nearer, her coat and undercoat loosened to strategically reveal the swell of her breasts beneath her low-cut top. Miles suspected pheromone perfumes, but the message hardly needed the boost; this young lady could be part of his bribe if he wished. Alas, Aida had shown no sign of knowing enough dirt to cultivate, and anyway he didnít need to look every kind of corruptible. There was such a thing as artistic restraint. Miles pulled out his holovid cube and showed off pictures of his magnificent wife and adorable children, and she backed off, although he also vented a few complaints about the high costs of raising a family, and Wing inched nearer, encouraging him in this vein. Miles drank more weird wine and grinned foolishly.

WhiteChrys would have kept refilling Milesís cup till he slid under the table, he was sure. He only wound up the party by repeated hints about Vorlynkin needing to get back to his duties. Aida slipped across to entertain the other group, while Wing took Miles on a turn around the pond, ìto clear our heads.î Milesís head, at least, cleared quite quickly when Wing at last got down to some very specific details about how Milesís new shares were to be secretly transferred. He supposed he shouldnít think of it as Quick work, my Lord Auditor; from foreplay to coitus in one afternoon. But who was being screwed? And why, why, why was he being bribed?

ìI truly believe in the Komarr project,î Wing told him, with apparent sincerity. And a touch of euphoria, though Miles couldnít tell if it was induced by the wine or the closing of the negotiations; to Wing, he suspected, they were interchangeable. The man harbored an almost Jacksonian passion for winning in the Deal. ìIn fact, Iíve switched all my own stock and options from WhiteChrys to WhiteChrys Solstice. Iíve even placed my own cryo-contract with the new facility, thatís how much Iím behind it. So you see Iíve put my money and my life where my mouth is.î His dark eyes almost sparkled with this revelation.
And Miles, connections boiling up at last, thought, Ye gods. I think youíve just handed me your head.

The wolf spider was perky and sharp in a black coat with white stripes and neat dots, like an aristocrat in a historical holovid dressed for a night on the town. Jin could clearly count all eight eyes in its fierce little face, two bright black buttons looking back at him, crowned by four more above, and another on each side of its head. Beneath itsóno, beneath her abdomen clung a bundle of fine white fluff, like a tiny cotton ballóan egg case? Was she going to be a mama spider? Prone on the floor of the musty garden shed, Jin stiffened with excitement, then drew slowly backwards, careful not to startle her into scuttling into the cracks in the floor or walls before he could find something to capture her in. She was a good size for her breed, over three centimeters, quite as long and wide as the end joint of Jinís thumb, so she was certainly a grownup spider. She seemed to wait patiently for him.

Jin stared around the shed in some frustration. It was taking a lot longer to walk from his aunt and uncleís outlying northwest suburb to the near south side of the city than he had imagined. It was partly from Mina lagging and complaining as soon as sheíd grown tired, just as Jin had expected, but mostly he was afraid heíd got turned around and lost during their long trudge last night. Streets curved unexpectedly, mixing him up, and the towers of the city center, glimpsed now and then from a hill or clear space, looked much the same from any direction.

This shelter had been a splendid find, early this morning. Theyíd stopped to buy half-liters of milk in a corner store of a neighborhoody area, then spent the next few blocks looking for a place to hide out during school hours. One house had a For Sale sign out front, and a peek through the windows revealed it cleared of furniture and empty of people, safe. It had been locked up tight, but the door to the shed around back proved unlatched. The garden was high-walled and full of sheltering bushes and trees, good to hide them from prying busybodies. Better yet, theyíd found an outdoor spigot with the water still turned on. Minaís lunch bars were holding out, if getting boring, but finding water had been more of a problem, though during the long march yesterday theyíd twice lucked out with city parks that offered not only drinking fountains, but bathrooms. Mina had proved very cranky about going behind a bush, even in the concealing dark.

The shelves of this shed had been cleared of likely containers, unfortunately, as well as of garden tools except for one bent and rusty trowel. Jinís eye fell on his sleeping sister, curled up with her jacket folded under her head, her zippered yellow backpack beside her, decorated with smiling but anatomically mis-drawn bees. He squatted down and began rooting through it. Ah, there!

ìHey!î mumbled Mina, sitting up and yawning. Her sleep-pale face was marked with creases from her makeshift pillow, and her hair hung every which way. What was it about sleeping in the daytime that made people so hot and rumpled? ìAre you stealing my money?î
Jim popped open the clear plastic box she kept her coins in and dumped the contents back into the pack. ìNo! I just need the box.î
ìWhat for?î asked Mina, enduring this rummage, but at least not theft, of her possessions with no more than a frown.
ìSpider house.î
ìEew! I donít like spiders. Their webs stick in your mouth.î
ìSheís a wolf spider. They donít spin webs.î

ìOh.î Mina blinked, considering this. She didnít look altogether convinced, but at least she didnít set up any stupid shrieking. She did keep her distance till Jin had snuck up on and captured his prey. But once the lady spider was safe behind the transparent barrier, Mina was at least willing to take a closer look, as Jin pointed out the manifold, if miniature, splendors of fur and eyes and mandibles, and the promising egg case.
ìShe really does have eight eyes!î said Mina, crossing her own as if trying to imagine the spiderís view of her. Emboldened by her brotherís example, she tapped on the plastic lid.
ìHey, donít. Youíll scare her.î
ìWill she be able to breathe in there?î asked Mina.
Jin regarded the box in new doubt. It was certainly secure, but it did seem rather airtight. The wolf spider scratched futilely at the walls of her prison with fine claws. ìFor a while, anyway.î
ìWhatís her name?î
ìI havenít named her yet.î
ìShe needs a name.î

Jin nodded full agreement. All right, sometimes Mina could be sensible. It was said there were thousands of wolf spider species back on old Earth, but the Kibou terraformers, stingily, had only imported half a dozen or so for their new ecosystem. But with no comlink here, he couldnít look up his new petís real scientific name. He hoped it would turn out to be something as sophisticated as the spider herself.
ìYou could call her Spinner. Except you said she doesnít spin. Wolfie?î
ìSounds like a boyís name,î Jin objected. ìIt ought to be a ladyís name, to fit her. Something from old Earth.î
Mina scowled in thought a moment, then brightened. ìLady Murasaki! Thatís the oldest ladyís name I know of.î
Jin, about to pooh-pooh her idea in brotherly reflex, paused. He eyed his spider. The name did fit. ìAll right.î
Mina grinned in triumph. ìWhat does she eat?î
ìLittler bugs. I should catch her some in the garden before we leave. Iím not sure how much longer it will take us to get, um. Home.î
Growing more interested after all this, Mina said, ìCan I help feed her?î
ìSure.î
Mina stretched, and, perhaps reminded of food, dug in her pillaged backpack for another lunch bar. ìMaybe we better split this. To make them last.î
ìGood idea,î Jin admitted. He set the spider box aside and went out to rinse and fill their milk bottles with water from the garden spigot.
When he slipped back inside the shed, closing the door with a creak, Mina asked, ìWhat time is it out there?î
ìIím not sure. Afternoon, anyway.î
ìDo you think schoolís out yet? Can we go on the streets again?î
ìPretty soon.î
They divided the lunch bar and the water.

ìMaybe you should put Lady Murasaki in one of our water bottles, instead,î said Mina, draining hers and holding it up to the light falling through the shedís one grimy window. ìWe could poke breath-holes through it.î
ìI was going to rinse those out and fill them up with water to take with us. You know how you were yammering you were so hot and thirsty yesterday afternoon.î

ìMy feet were so sweaty inside my shoes,î Mina said. ìThey felt nasty.î She looked up at him, still a bit puffy-eyed from their uncomfortable dayís sleep. ìHow much longer is it going to take to get to your place?î
ìHard to say.î Jin shrugged uneasily. ìIíve been gone way longer than Iíd planned. I sure hope Miles-san is taking care of all my creatures.î
ìThatís your galactic friend, right?î

During their winding journey, the past day and a half, Jin had slowly unburdened himself of what he suspected were far too many of his secrets to Mina, partly to shut up her incessant questions, mostly because, well, he hadnít had any other kids to talk to for so long.
ìYah.î

Jinís own abysmal failure as a courier troubled his mind. Would Miles-san believe Jin hadnít stolen his money? How was he getting along with Gyre? You had to be gentle but firm with the bird. The chickens were easier, except for the part about climbing down and carrying them back up the ladder or the stairs when they fluttered over the parapet. With that cane, could Miles-san manage both an indignant chicken and the stairs?
ìDoes Miles-san have any children?î Mina asked.

Jin frowned. ìHe didnít say. Heís pretty oldóthirty-something, he said. But heís kind of funny-looking. I donít know if he could get a girl.î Once the drug effects had worn off Miles-san had been a nice enough fellow, with that face where smiles seemed at home. Plus, he had seemed to understand Jinís creatures, which made him quite smart, for a grownup. Jin wasnít sure whether to wish him a short, understanding bride, or not.
After a long, thoughtful pause, Mina said, ìDo you think heíd like some?î
ìWhat?î
ìChildren. Like, if heís lonely.î

At Jinís baffled stare, Mina forged on: ìWe read this book for school this year, about two orphans adopted by a man from Earth. He took them there and they saw everything about where our ancestors came from.î She added enticingly, ìThey got new petsÖî

Jin vaguely remembered that one from his own second school year, otherwise made burdensome by the infliction of beginning kanji. There had been a lot of sickly stuff about the girl getting a fancy kimono, but there had also been a chapter about going to the seaside which had featured some Earth sea creaturesómuch too short an episode, but at least thereíd been picturesóand a cat whoíd capped her excellence by having kittens at the end. ìMiles-san isnít from Earth. Heís from Barrayar, he said.î
ìWhereís that?î

ìSomewhere beyond Escobar, I guess.î Escobar, Jin knew, was Kibouís closest nexus trading partner, by a shortish multi-jump route. Farther worlds didnít much come up till galactic history in high school, except for Earth. Jin had studied a lot about Earth on his own, because of the zoology. Now, if only some benefactor would come along and offer to take Jin to EarthÖ Although come to think, Barrayar as Miles-san had described it might be almost as good, with its double biota.

A sudden picture bloomed in Jinís mind of the odd little fellow living all alone in a cottage in the countryóno, better, a big rambling old house with a vast overgrown garden. Like the book with that old professor who had taken in two children from the city during wartimeóJin didnít know what war, except it was from a period before anybody got frozen. Thereíd been a horse that drew a cart, and wonderful adventures involving a cave with blind white fish. Jin had seen a horse in the Northbridge Zoo, once, on a class field trip. The braver children had all been allowed to pat its glossy neck, while one of the keepers held its lead; Jin remembered the huge beast blowing air out its soft, bellowslike nostrils in a warm whoosh across his cheek. Jin understood there were littler versions bred just for children, called ponies. Mina wouldnít be scared of one that size. The looming beast at the zoo had alarmed even Jin, but heíd been younger then, too. A great rambling house, and animals, andÖ

It was all rubbish. Miles-san wasnít a professor, or their uncle of any kind, great or regular, and for all Jin knew he lived in a cramped city apartment and wasnít lonely at all. Jin decided he didnít like that country daydream. It hurt too much when it stopped. He frowned at Mina. ìNobodyís going to adopt us and take us away from here. Thatís a stupid idea.î

Mina looked offended. She turned one shoulder to him and began pulling on her socks. They were blotched with pinkish-brown stains where her blisters had popped and bled, and Jin gulped faint guilt. They both donned their shoes, Lady Murasaki was safely lodged in Minaís backpack, where, Jin argued, she would endure less bouncing than in his pocket, and they sneaked out onto the street once more.
A winding kilometer farther on, during which Jin kept looking for, and not getting, a glimpse of the downtown towers for orientation, they came upon a busier street with a tube-tram station entry.
Minaís footsteps had grown short and gimpy already. She looked at the entrance in some longing. ìIf you want to go on the tramîóshe swallowed a bitóìIíll pay our fares.î

ìNo, the police have vidcams in the stations. Thatís how I got trapped day before yesterday. We canít go in there.î But Jinís eye was caught by a big colorful display on the outside of the entry kiosk. A map! He peered up carefully for scanning vidcams on this side, didnít spot any, and ventured nearer, Mina trailing.

The lighted You Are Here arrow horrified Jin. They were nowhere near the south side of town, as heíd hoped from how far theyíd trudged. Theyíd somehow ended up on the residential east side, instead, and still had maybe thirty kilometers left to hike before they reached the light industrial zone of the south, quite as far as theyíd already come. Well, that explained why the houses were so nice around here. Jin stepped closer, squinting.

Just two stops farther on this line was the very station heíd exited to reach the Barrayaran consulate. It was about a three-kilometer walk above ground. Jin stared, thinking. He had dimly planned to offer Minaís money to Miles-san, when they arrived at their destination, but his sister was proving pretty tight-fisted, in Jinís view. She was sure to set up a screech, even though Jin was nearly certain Miles-san would replace it as soon as he could. But if he stopped at the consulate first and explained his loss, editing his situation a bit maybe, would they give him more money for the Barrayaran? Miles-san seemed fairly important to them. And they wouldnít turn Jin in, because they were protecting their own secrets, right?

Contemplating this confession made him feel a little sick, but not as sick as going all the way back to Miles-san empty-handed as well as three days late. He stared harder at the map, trying to memorize the streets and turns.
ìI know where weíre going now,î he said to Mina, trying to sound confident and big-brotherly. ìCome on.î

After the WhiteChrys groundcar dropped them all off again at the consulate, Roic followed mílord upstairs and watched him down two headache tabs and several glasses of water. Returning to the entry hall, mílord stuck his head into the room Roic thought of as the parlor, where Raven Durona had been left to cool his heels, and said, ìDebriefing downstairs again, I think.î

Raven nodded and unfolded himself to tag along. There had been little conversation on the way home; Aida had still been escorting, mílord had settled into himself heavy-eyed, Vorlynkin had stared out the canopy with a set jaw, Roic considered himself an observer, and Raven had been disinclined to buck the obvious trend. They arrived downstairs at the door to the tight-room to discover it closed and locked.
Mílord hit the intercom. ìVorlynkin? Are you in there? Open up.î
ìJust a moment, mílord,î Vorlynkinís voice came from the speaker. The moment turned into several minutes, while mílord tapped his foot and Raven sat on the nearby step and yawned.
ìReminds me of a house with only one bathroom when the relatives have come to visit,î remarked Roic, as the wait stretched.
Mílord cast him a dry look. ìI wouldnít know. Iíve never lived in a house with only one bathroom.î Roic returned him an ironic head-tilt.

At length, the doorseal popped, the vaultlike door swung open, and the consul admitted them. His eyes seemed electric blue, and he was breathing fast, as though he had been running. ìYouíre too late,î he announced.
Mílordís brows rose. ìNot a first. What for this time?î

A muscle jumped by Vorlynkinís scowling mouth. ìI just sent a full report of what I witnessed by tight-beam to General Allegre at ImpSec HQ, Barrayar. I never thought Iíd live to see a Vorkosigan sell himself for money. My career may be slagged, but so will yours, my Lord Auditor.î
ìAh, excellent. Thatís done.î Mílord kicked the door shut; it sealed with a sigh that seemed insufficiently dramatic for Vorlynkinís mood.
ìWhat?î Vorlynkinís fists clenched.

ìNot that every man doesnít have his price,î mílord went on amiably. ìAs Iím sure Wing-san would agree. I was more afraid that if he didnít come up to scratch today, Iíd have that whole parade at the conference to do over again.î

If the consul didnít stop inhaling, he was going to pop a lung, Roic thought. He put in peaceably, ìStop baiting the poor fellow, mílord.î Now that you have what you want, anyway. Roic didnít want to have to wrestle the man to the floor if he went for mílordís throat, which he seemed on the verge of doing. Was that old phrase about being mad enough to spit nails supposed to apply to, like, roofing nails, or fingernails? Around mílord, Roic had never been sure.

Mílord added a trifle impatiently, ìMen like Wing donít go around throwing their money at potential opponents at random, Vorlynkin. First they have to figure out that the target is bribable. I did my best to help him decide. Have a seat, Consul, Doctor. Itís time we talked.î
Vorlynkinís mouth, which had opened to emit some hot remark, sagged. ìLord Vorkosiganóis this a sting?î

ìIt is now.î Mílord pulled out a station chair and plunked into it. ìWe werenít sure at first, which is why they sent meóI could be bait and trap at the same time, saving the Imperium on jumpship fares if nothing else.î
Vorlynkin sank more slowly into a chair opposite; Roic breathed easier. The consul glanced in dismay at the secured comconsole. ìMílordóI sent the report.î

ìDonít apologize. Your next official visitor might really be on the take, after all. I donít intend to apologize to you, either, if it makes you feel any better. Iíve seen our diplomatic personnel bought out before. I had to make sure.î
ìYou wereÖ testing me?î That disturbing heat in Vorlynkinís eyes, which had started to fade, flared once more.
ìWhy do you suppose I hauled you along today and let you see all this?î
Vorlynkinís hands clenched on his knees, but slowly eased again. ìI see. Very efficient.î

ìDo try to keep up.î Mílord added more kindly, ìIt wonít be easy; this case has baffled a few ImpSec analysts.î He turned to Raven. ìSo, what did you learn of interest during the time you had with Storrs?î

Ravenís mouth twisted in doubt. ìIím not sure I learned anything new. Their cryofreezing program seems perfectly legitimateónothing wrong with their procedures from a technical standpoint. I asked to see a revival, but Storrs said there werenít any scheduled today, which by then didnít surprise me. He did show me the revival facilities. They looked quite adequate. He angled to find out if I would be interested in employment with WhiteChrys, and tried to find out my current pay rate. I said my main interests lay with cryorevival, as itís more medically challenging. He said heíd pass that along, although he didnít say who to. We came back and joined your show in progress, where youíd finished the dogs and were on to the ponies. Eh.î Raven shrugged.
Vorlynkin blinked. ìLord Vorkosigan, is Dr. Durona your agent?î
ìCivilian contract consultant,î mílord clarified, ìbeing paid out of my case budget. Are you still collecting your Durona Group salary simultaneously, Raven?î
Raven smirked. ìThatís personal information.î
ìIíll take that as a yes. So donít hesitate to use Dr. Durona on double shifts, if needed.î

Raven grinned and rose to prod the automatic beverage maker, strategically positioned near the secured comconsole and its satellite console. It coughed up something coffee-ish, judging by the smell. Raven picked up the cup and gestured politely toward his chair; Roic waved him back to it and took up a position propping the wall with his arms crossed, in a pose copied from a certain former ImpSec chief.

ìTo bring you up to speed, Vorlynkin,î mílord went on. ìWhiteChrys was vetted and cleared by ImpSec when its advance teams first scouted Komarr eighteen months ago, but ImpSec was looking for connections with military espionage and the like. Their business plan passed the local Komarran commissions, and they were in. No one would have given them a second look for years, if it hadnít been for some good old-fashioned nepotism.

ìWithin the last few months, as the flagship facility we saw in Wingís vid was nearing completion, WhiteChrys began collecting contracts on future customers. Not unnaturally, they targeted Solstice upper-class elderly womenís clubs. At the same time, another sales team made some limited strategic stock offerings to certain wealthy and influential Komarrans, to give the local powers-that-be a stake in the future success of their operations. I expect the two sales teams didnít compare hit lists, nor realize that some wealthy old ladies are retired Komarran traders who can read a balance sheet to a gnatís eyebrow.

ìAnd one of those little old ladies looked at the two proposals before her and said, ëThis smells, but I donít see how,í so she took it to her beloved great-niece, who said, ëYouíre right, Auntie, this smells, but I donít see how,í who took the problem in turn to her devoted husband, better known as Emperor Gregor Vorbarra. Who handed it to his loyal Imperial Auditor, saying, and I quote, ëHere, Miles, youíre better at diving into the privy and coming up with the gold ring than anyone I know. Have a go.í And I said, ëThank you, Sire,í and took ship for Kibou-daini.î
Vorlynkin blinked again. Deeply. Roic reflected that the Imperiumís shrewd Komarran Empress served Gregor in more ways than just the joint production of their several scarily smart children.
Mílord went on blithely, ìThe other thing wealthy old Komarrans tend to have is an excess of planetary voting sharesóer, Raven, do I need to explain these to you?î
ìYes, please,î said Raven, settling back and looking fascinated.
ìThe system, as usual, is a relict of Komarrís colonization history. The planet is presently unlivableóthough undergoing long-term terraformingóall settlement is in sealed arcologies, the Domes.î
ìI knew that muchÖî

ìRight. So to encourage the development of the domes, the early Komarran colonists set up a reward system. In addition to an inalienable one-person-one-vote that every Komarran is born and dies with, the colony awarded additional votes to those taking on the work and risk of creating more living space. These were inheritable, tradable, salable, and in general accumulate-able. The basis of the Komarran oligarchy as it now stands is clan possession of blocks of these planetary voting shares. The place is putatively a democracy, but some are measurably more equal than others. You follow?î
Raven nodded.
ìSo,î said Vorlynkin, who had, after all, had two years to watch Kibou-daini in operation, ìyou think WhiteChrys plans to accumulate those votes wholesale?î

ìI do now. Mind you, Komarr has a long history of attempted chicanery with its voting system. Over time itís accumulated a huge number of rules to thwart same. Among other things, voting shares canít be held outright by corporationsóthey have to be in the hands of individuals. There are tested systems for proxies, and so on. WhiteChrysís contracts passed muster with the Komarran regulators, and, if anybody had still been looking by that point, weíd have accepted that.

ìMy two working hypotheses are either that WhiteChrys has bribed some regulatorsóa possibility I now find quite compellingóor that they have figured out some way to game the rules system to hide their true intention till too late. Or both.î
Roic couldnít help thinking that mílord oughtnít to look quite so admiring, detailing this in front of the still-gently-steaming Vorlynkin. But, well, mílord.

ìThe one thing that gave me pause was that there was no way this could be a get-rich-quick scheme, even if the Komarran system of voting shares gives it a turbo-boost compared to Kibou. The profit margin on what is arguably a service industry is razor-thin, yet WhiteChrys has been spending money like a drunken Vor lord. Why go to all this trouble for a payoff youíll never live to see? Until the last thing Wing said to me this afternoon, which was that he planned to have himself frozen on Komarr.î
Mílord looked around proudly, as if expecting the room to burst into applause, and was plainly disappointed to receive three blank looks instead.

He inhaled, visibly backing up. ìUnpack, Miles, right. What I now suspect is going on is a two-tiered scam. I think there is an inner cadre of White Chrys executives who plan to ride out the years in cryo-stasis, and all be revived in time to collect the goodies. In fact, if theyíre as smart as I think, they likely plan to take turns, so thereís always someone on the team awake to look after their interests. While they quietly, automatically, bloodlessly buy Komarr. Or maybe not so bloodlessly, depending on whether you consider early freezing to be murder or suicide, or not. The slowest, subtlest, and, I have to say, creepiest planetary conquest scheme ever devised!î
Even Vorlynkin jumped at that, his lips parting in consternation. ìConquest!î

ìI hardly know what else to call it. But I still have a hell of a lot of dots to connect before I can sign off on this investigation. As soon as we get your consulate deep data crawlers up and running, thatís the first thing I want to look foróa list of WhiteChrys personnel who have lately shifted all their investments to WhiteChrys Solstice, and are planning to follow them in person. Because, given the numbers, I also think it possible that this is could be a secret group inside WhiteChrys who are gutting their own company to feather their nests.î
ìWhew!î said Raven, with proper admiration. Mílord bestowed a pleased smile upon him.

Vorlynkin ran his hands through his hair. ìHow do you plan to nail the bastards? Bribing an Imperial Auditor may be as illegal as all hell on Barrayar, but weíre on Kibou-daini. Even if you could prove itóand Iím afraid my testimony would be suspect, hereóI doubt Wing would get more than a slap on the wrist.î

ìActually, I would prefer not to give the slightest hint to anyone on Kibou that weíve tumbled to them. The ideal revenge would be to let WhiteChrys get their hand so far into the cookie jar on Komarr that they canít get it out, then cut it off at the wrist by changing the contract rules just enough on íem to make them drop the votes. Leaving them to be exactly what they feigned to be, a marginally profitable service company. That would hurt enough to be a warning to others. Brute nationalization is a last resortóit would piss off the rest of the Komarran business community regardless of the rights of the case. Itíll take some studyóIím afraid weíre going to be up to our ears in lawyers before this is doneóbut with luck my part of the task will be over by then.î Mílord glanced up at Vorlynkin. ìSo what do you think of your Lieutenant Johannes? Heís young, which makes him both poorer and potentially more gullible. Is he reliable enough for this?î
ìIÖî Vorlynkin was given pause. ìIíve never had cause to doubt him.î
ìAnd your local clerk, Yuuichi whatís-his-name, Matson?î
ìIíve never had cause to doubt him, either. But weíve never had a situation like this before.î
ìThat you knew,î sighed mílord. ìYet routine travel visas for WhiteChrys personnel have been handled through the consulate all this time.î
ìYes, but all we ask is business or tourism? Plus a quick background check for criminal records.î
Mílordís eyes crinkled in speculation. ìI wonder if we should add a box to tick offóReason for travel: creepy planetary conquestÖ no, I suppose not.î
Vorlynkin said slowly, ìWhat if I hadnít tried to turn you in just now?î

ìThen you wouldnít be part of this debriefing, and Iíd be on the lookout for ways to nail you to the wall, too. In passing.î Mílord stretched and rolled his shoulders. Vorlynkin looked, Roic felt, properly thoughtful at last.
ìNow, the other thing,î mílord began, but was interrupted when the sealed door chimed.
Lieutenant Johannesís voice issued from the intercom. ìConsul? Lord Vorkosigan?î
ìYes?î responded mílord.
ìUmÖ Your half-sized courierís just turned up at the back door. And heís not alone.î
Mílordís brows rose; Vorlynkinís drew down. Raven cocked his head in curiosity.
ìDonít let him get away, Johannes,î mílord called back. ìWeíll be right there.î
Motioning Roic to unseal the door, mílord grabbed his cane and levered to his feet.

The kitchen of the consulate seemed homey, if spacious by Jinís standards. Maybe it was the cool dusk falling in the back garden that made it so warm and bright. Maybe it was all the dishes piled in the sink that made it look so, well, kitchen-y, as if a fellow could wander in and out to snack at will without being yelled at, even. But the noise of all the footsteps clumping up from the basement made Jin shift uneasily, and when Minaís little hand stole into his and clutched hard, he didnít shake her off.

Jinís timid knock had been answered by Lieutenant Johannes, whoíd taken one look, cried You! and hustled them both inside, though heíd looked askance at Mina; added Wait right there, donít move; and thumped downstairs before Jin could get three words into his much-rehearsed explanation of how the police had taken Miles-sanís money. So Jin was expecting the fierce-eyed Consul Vorlynkin, but behind him loomed the biggest Barrayaran Jin had seen yet, half a head taller than the tall consul. He wore clothes that reminded Jin of a military uniform, had short wavy brown hair and a firm square-jawed face, and looked older than Johannes but younger than the consul. Mina stared up at him with her mouth hanging open.

The big Barrayaran so filled up what had, till a moment before, seemed a wide doorway that it took a moment for Jin to notice the slim fellow with his hair in a neat dark braid who followed him, and another moment to spot Miles-san in their wake.

The little man shouldered past them all, coming face to face with Jin. He looked so different all cleaned up, more grownup, moreÖ daunting, that it was a couple of heartbeats before Jin, recovering from his shock, inhaled and cried, ìMy creatures! You promised youíd look after them!î

Miles-san held up a hand. ìTheyíre all right, Jin! When you didnít come back by midnight, I copied out your instructions and gave them to Ako. When I implied I was going to look for you, she was very willing to help out.î
ìBut how did you get here?î
ìWalked. Took me all that night.î
From behind Jin, Mina asked interestedly, ìDid you get lost, too?î
ìWe werenít lost, exactly,î Jin denied, harassed. ìJust turned around a little.î
ìAnd who are you, young lady?î Miles-san addressed Mina. ìI donít believe weíve been introduced.î
ìSister,î muttered Jin. ìIt wasnít my idea to bring her.î
ìI have a name,î Mina pointed out. ìItís Mina. Want to see my blisters?î
Miles-san didnít even blink. ìSure! Are they good ones? Have they popped yet?î
ìOh, yesóthey made my socks all bloody, too.î

ìWell, Miss Mina, why donít you sit down hereóî Miles-san pulled out a kitchen chair with a flourish, and half-bowed Mina into it, as if sheíd been a grownup lady, ìóand show me.î He added over his shoulder, ìJohannes. Find something for these children to eat. Cookies. Milk. Gingerbread, whatever.î
ìAre you Jinís galactic?î Mina asked, kicking off her sport shoes and picking at her splotched socks. ìHe told me all about you.î

ìDid he?î Miles-san knelt and helped her peel off her socks; she said ow, ow, as they parted stickily from her scabs. ìMy word, those are good blisters, arenít they?î He glanced up and gave Vorlynkin-san a head-jerk that sent the consul to rummage in the other end of the kitchen.
ìAunt Lorna buys all our shoes big to grow into,î Mina explained to Miles-san. ìThatís why they slip around like that.î
Lieutenant Johannes, peering doubtfully into the depths of the refrigerator, murmured, ìBeerÖ ?î

ìDo you like beer, Mina?î Miles-san asked. She shook her head, making her straight black hair swing around her chin. ìThought not, somehow. Youíll have to do better, Johannes. Arenít all you attaché fellows supposed to be ImpSec trained? Improvise!î

Johannes muttered something through his teeth that Jin couldnít quite make out. He then conducted a brief survey which determined that vat-octopus pizza, no onions, was universally acceptable, and trod out to order some. Vorlynkin came back with what turned out to be a first-aid kit, which he handed off to the slim man with the braid, who didnít look Barrayaran at all, but didnít talk like someone from Kibou, either.
Mina leaned toward Miles-san and whispered anxiously, ìThat big guy isnít a policeman, is he?î
ìUsed to be,î Miles-san whispered back gravely, ìbut now he works for me. Alas, Armsman Roic had to give up all his policemanís principles when he entered my service.î
The big man cast Mina a pious nod.

Mina settled back, looking relieved, and let the slim man, who Miles-san introduced as Raven and said was a doctor from Escobar, attend to her feet. Vorlynkin watched closely, frowning, till he seemed to be satisfied with the skills displayed, then straightened up and narrowed his eyes at Jin. The big fellow, Armsman Roic, filled two glasses with water and set them on the table; Mina seized hers and drank thirstily, and Jin followed suit more warily.
