When heíd washed down the dry lump in his throat, which actually had little to do with thirst, Jin embarked once more on his interrupted explanation of what had happened to the consulateís money. Vorlynkin winced when Jin came to the part about the drug dealers and/or smugglers, but at Miles-sanís restraining hand-gesture, the consul let Jin stumble all the way to the end before saying, ìWe know. We traced the packet to the police evidence rooms, and picked up your arrest report, too.î
So they did believe him. That was something, anyway.
ìYes,î said Miles-san, ìand Iím sure the consul thanks you for keeping mum and preserving his reputation. Donít you, Vorlynkin?î
Vorlynkinís lips compressed in an expression anything but grateful, but he choked out a, ìCertainly.î

Then, through what Jin reluctantly recognized as a skillful series of questionsósome put to Jin though many to MinaóMiles-san drew out the story of Jinís escape from the custody of his aunt and uncle. By the time Johannes returned, balancing a stack of pizza boxes, two liters of milk, and more beer, Jin was afraid there wasnít much Miles-san didnít understand about Aunt Lorna, Uncle Hikaru, and cousins Tetsu and Ken. It made Jin feel uncomfortably exposed.

Miles-san kicked a stepstool to the sink and made Jin and Mina wash their hands, following up himself as if to enforce the good example. Lieutenant Johannes watched him mount the stepstool, glanced at the impassive Roic, and bit his lip. Miles-san, the consul, Jin and Mina then sat four around the kitchen table, that being all the chairs there were; Roic and the others leaned against the counter. Setting out the boxes and a roll of disposable wipes, the lieutenant said, ìI checked the comconsole. Both these kids were reported missing yesterday. Every police officer in town must be on the lookout for them.î
Consul Vorlynkin pressed a hand to the bridge of his nose.
Jin bolted upright in alarm. ìYou canít turn us in!î
Miles-san waved him back down. ìNo one is doing anything till after we eat.î He looked over the aromatic offering. ìWhat, no vegetables? Donít you two need vegetables?î
ìNo, we donít!î said Mina. Jin shook his head vigorously in support.
Miles-san bit into his slice. ìAh, perhaps not. This does seem very healthy. And tasty.î

Mina, at least, dove readily into the first hot food theyíd had for two days. Jin, overwhelmed by the aroma, followed suit. The consulate bought good pizza, not the cheapest frozen kind that Aunt Lorna served. The consul barely sipped his beer, Miles-san had water, and big Roic, to Jinís surprise, after first pouring out for Jin and Mina, helped himself to a small glass of milk.
All this redirection might have worked to calm Jin, except Vorlynkin, after swallowing his first bite, said, ìThe consulate canít harbor runaways, Lord Vorkosigan. Their guardians must be frantic.î
ìWe donít want to stay here,î said Jin. ìI want to get back to my creatures!î
Miles-san waved his nibbled pizza slice in the air. ìAsylum?î
ìThatís not amusing even as a joke,î said Vorlynkin. ìDo you have any idea of the legal complications involved in giving political asylum to minors?î
ìIím not sure I was joking, exactly,î Miles-san said mildly. ìBut wait for the children to eat, please.î

Vorlynkinís jaw tightened, but he nodded. After Jin and Mina could eat no more, and Johannes offered more wipes and put the leftovers away in the refrigerator for breakfast, just like at home, Miles-san leaned back in his chair and said, ìI suggest we repair downstairs. The seats will be more comfortable.î

The other Barrayarans all gave Miles-san funny looks, but recalling Uncle Hikaruís daily after-dinner saying, when shifting into his big chair, of Out of the bleachers and into the box seats!, Jin saw no objection to this. Yet when theyíd all shuffled down the stairs after Miles-san, the room into which he led them only boasted four chairs, all officey-looking swivel types. Miles-san gestured Mina and Jin into a seat each, took one himself, and left the other three men to sort themselves out. Johannes parked one haunch on the long table shoved up to the wall, Raven-sensei copied him, and Vorlynkin, mouth pinched, dropped into the remaining chair.

ìThis is a funny vid room,î Mina remarked, staring around and swinging her feet, now encased in a pair of Miles-sanís socks donated to keep her bandages clean. When Roic closed the door and blandly sat cross-legged on the floor beside it, the air grew awfully hushed, and for the first time Jin wondered if this was a safe place to have brought her, and not just from the risk of being betrayed to the authorities. He kind of trusted Miles-san, or he would have been inclined to grab her and bolt. Though given Roic and that thick door, would that impulse have come too lateÖ

Miles-san laced his hands together between his knees, and said, ìSuze the Secretary told me something of the story of your mother, Jin, Mina. So when I got back here I looked up what I could about her on the planetary net. It made me very curious. I really donít understand how it was she came to be frozen, when she wasnít sick or dying, or even convicted of any crime.î
Jinís tasty dinner suddenly felt like lead in his stomach.

ìWhat do youóeither of youóremember about your mother?î Miles-san went on. ìNot personal things, but about her work, her cause. Especially anything that might have happened about the time of the riot at her rally, or just before she was arrested?î

Jin and Mina looked at each other uneasily. Jin said, ìMom didnít talk to us much about her work. When she was doing anything, she mostly left us at Aunt Lornaís unless I was in school. Then she just left Mina.î
ìAunt Lorna wasnít too happy about all the babysitting,î Mina said.
ìYah, she said she hadnít volunteered for this and didnít much like being drafted.î
ìAnd she was sorry about Daddy, but maybe if Mommy really cared that much sheíd do better to stay home and look after his kids herself.î Mina looked away, frowning.

Jin put in hastily, ìBut she only said things like that when she was feeling íspecially cranky.î Not that he was fond of Aunt Lorna, but these galactics were outsiders, after all, and it felt funny to be talking about his family like this in front of them. And Mom had said you should always try to be fair.
ìDidnít your mother ever take you along to her meetings?î
Mina shook her head. ìShe said they werenít for kids, and weíd just get bored and kick up a fuss.î

ìHuh.î Miles-san rubbed his chin. ìWhen I was a youngster Jinís age, at home, I was often permitted to sit in on my fatherís meetings with his, er, professional colleagues. My grandfather had done the same with him. I learned more just by the osmosis than I realized at the time. Of course, I had to stay quiet and make myself useful, or leave, naturally.î
Jin frowned. ìYou canít leave if youíre out somewhere. Mom would have had to break off what she was doing to take us home.î
ìCouldnít she have just tappedónever mind. Didnít she ever have meetings at your home? In the evenings, say?î
ìThere wasnít much room in our apartment.î
ìDid no one come to visit? Ever?î
Jin shook his head, but Mina, to his surprise, spoke up. ìSome people from her group did once. Late at night.î
ìWhen was this?î
Mina sucked on her lower lip. ìBefore she was arrested, anyway.î
ìClose before?î
ìYah, I think so.î
ìI donít remember this,î said Jin.
Mina tossed her head. ìYou were asleep.î
ìWhat woke you?î asked Miles-san.
ìThey were arguing in the kitchen. Kind of loud and scary. Plus, I had to go to the bathroom.î
ìCan you remember what they were arguing about? Anything at all that was said?î

Mina scrunched her face in thought. ìThey were talking about the corps, and money. They were always talking about the corps, and money, only this time they seemed more excited. George-sanís voice was really boomy, and Mommy was talking all fast and sharp, except she didnít sound mad, exactly. And the new guy yelled something about, it wasnít any tempírary setbackóthis could bring the corps to their knees, right before he came out in the hallway on the way to the bathroom and found me. And Mommy let me have an ice cream bar and put me back to bed and told me to stay there.î
ìDo you know who the people were? Had you ever seen them before?î
Mina nodded. ìThere was George-san, he was always nice to me when he came to pick up Mommy. And old Mrs. Tennoji, she always wore a lot of perfume. They called the new one Leiber-sensei.î
ìDo you remember the rest of their names? Jin?î
Headshakes. Miles-san tried, ìGeorge Suwabi, by chance?î
ìMight have been,î said Mina, though sounding a bit doubtful.

ìThe timing is interesting in the extreme. And the cast. I smell a lethal secret, oh, yes.î Miles-san rose and began to pace back and forth across the little room. He forgot his cane, left by his chair, a snazzier one than heíd scavenged from Suze-sanís. ìSuwabi and Tennoji came up in my researches. Dr. Leiber did not, I admit. Curious absence, not to be confused with an absence of curious. I wonder who the hell he was?î
Sounding as if he was being drawn into all this despite himself, Consul Vorlynkin said, ìCould you trace these people and find out more?î

ìNot Suwabi or Tennojiótheyíre dead. And rotted, buried for real. The other one, I donít know. Could be a long, cold trail, if heís run off-world or gone to ground well enough to escape the corps. It might be faster just to wake up Lisa Sato and ask her.î
Mina drew a huge breath and shot to her feet, staring wildly at Miles-san. ìYou could do that? You could get my mommy back? Really?î
Miles-san stopped short. ìEr.î
Jinís heart jumped in his chest; Minaís imploring look made him feel sick. ìNo, of course he canít,î he said angrily. ìIt was just a stupid joke.î
Miles-sanís hand went to his throat, clutching something through his shirt; some kind of pendant, Jin thought. ìDamn. If I were on Barrayar, I could just order it done.î

ìBut weíre not on Barrayar,î Armsman Roic muttered under his breath, almost the first Jin had heard the big man speak. Miles-san waved a hand as if to say, Yah, yah, though whether in agreement or protest Jin was not sure.
Mina looked crushed; her lower lip quivered. ìIt wasnítÖ wasnít a very nice thing to make a joke about it, if you didnít really mean it!î
ìNo,î said Miles-san, staring, for some reason, at Raven-sensei. ìIt wasnít. Could I, ahÖ really mean it? Technically?î
Raven-sensei scratched his chin. ìTechnically, yes. You will forgive me if I point out that the medical aspects would seem to be the least of it?î
Miles-san waved a hand in easy pardon.
ìAssuming,î Raven-sensei went on, ìthe cryoprep was done correctly in the first place, of course. Or at all.î
Miles-sanís eyes narrowed, and he resumed his pacing. ìMmÖ no reason why it shouldnít have been. Weíre not on Jacksonís Whole, either, I note. What all would you need to do the trick? Technically.î
ìA decently-equipped revival facility. This isnít something Iíd choose to do out of the consulate basementís laundry tub, if thatís what youíre thinking. Not if there were any complications.î
ìWe couldnít afford complications, no. Emphatically not.î He glanced at Jin and Mina.
Raven-sensei nodded. ìSome standard medical supplies, synthesized blood and so on.î
ìIf I secured you a facility, could you scrounge the supplies?î
Raven-sensei got a faraway look. ìLegally, or otherwise?î
A pause. ìIíve no intrinsic objection to legally, but it canít leave a data trail back to us. Otherwise, alternate suppliers would do. If their merchandise was of proper quality, of course.î
ìThat goes without saying. How would you propose to gain custody of my patient?î
Miles-sanís expression grew equally faraway. ìNow, thatís where it becomes quite interestingóî
ìLord Vorkosigan!î Vorlynkin interrupted. ìWhat the hell are you thinking?î Jin wasnít sure if he really didnít know, or knew and objected. Strenuously.

Miles-san waved that airy hand again. ìAny number of threads in my catís cradle of Kibou-daini mysteries seem to run back to Lisa Satoóand stop. Iím thinking I might be able to cut the whole knot right through if I had her to interrogate. Er, talk to. Grant you, it seems a little imaginative at first glance, but the more I think about itÖî
ìImaginative! It seems outright mad!î
Miles-san cast the consul a soulful look. ìBut Vorlynkin, it would solve all your problems with asylum for minors at a blow. Their mother being their closest possible adult next-of-kin.î
ìWhen did those become myÖ never mind.î
Miles-san grinned in a glinty way that Jin did not entirely understand. ìVery good, Vorlynkin.î
ìWhat are you all talking about?î Mina practically wailed.

Miles-san lost his glintiness at once, and dropped to one knee in front of her swivel chair. ìUnpack, right. Um. You see, Mina, I was sent here by my government to check out some sneaky, nasty things that a Kibou cryocorp is trying to do back on one of my home worlds. I think your mommy might be able to answer some of my questions, or at least give me some interesting new information. Now, it just so happens that Dr. Durona over thereîóRaven-sensei waved his long fingers kindly at Minaóìis a top cryorevival specialist, and he already works for me, which is what gives me this idea. See, there are three things that have to be in place before I could undertake to wake up your mommy. I have to be sure it would be medically safe for her, and I think Raven could see to that. I have to be able to secure her cryóI have to be able to get hold of her, get her away from the place where sheís now held without kicking up a dust, and I think I can do that. And afterward, I have to be able to protect her from being arrested and taken away again, or it will all be for nothing, and that will be Consul Vorlynkinís job.î

Vorlynkin looked startled at this news. But when Minaís anxious gaze targeted him, he returned her a flicker of a smile, the first Jin had seen lighten his face. Girls, hah. Nobody handed Jin smiles like that when he was scaredÖ he more usually got some sort of unsympathetic and bracing advice to buck up.

ìWhich reminds me, Vorlynkin,î Miles-san went on over his shoulder in a more clipped tone, ìwhat are the limits of the political and legal protection this consulate can offer, once it becomes known that Madame Sato has, er, escaped custody, as it were? Youíre not a full-scale embassyÖî

Vorlynkin said reluctantly, ìBy our budget, weíre a branch of the embassy on Escobar. But weíre legally more than a consulate, because weíre the only full-time diplomatic facility Barrayar maintains here. It would beÖ it could be an ambiguous argument.î
ìAnd ambiguous legal arguments burn lots of time, ah. That might just be good enough.î Miles-san rose to pace again.

Mina sank back into her swivel chair, her expression caught between hopeful and confused. Jin realized heíd been gripping the arms of his own chair so hard his fingernails were white, and slowly released his clutch. Minaís words whirled around and around in his head, You could get my mommy back? Really? Really? ReallyÖ ? Who did this half-sized galactic think he was? When heíd said he was a delegate to the cryo-conference, but didnít seem to be a doctor, and the others had all called him an auditor, Jin had vaguely assumed his job had something to do with insurance. Or maybe, less boringly, insurance fraud. He seemed to know a lot about fraud, anyway.
ìFirst things first. Johannes, what vehicles does the consulate maintain?î
Johannes jerked, as if heíd been a watcher of a play unexpectedly addressed by one of the characters. ìUh, the official groundcar, of course. And we have a lift van. I have a float bike, myself.î
ìLift van, perfect. Tomorrow, then, weíll take Jin and Raven and go pick up Jinís creatures, and bring them back here to the consulate, so thatíll be off his mind and my conscience.î

Jin looked up, caught between thrilled and bewildered. Didnít these Barrayarans mean to let him goÖ ? On the other hand, as long as he had his animals back, and didnít have to go back to Aunt Lorna and school, did it matter where he stayed?
ìMy consulate isnít exactly set up to host a menagerie,î said Vorlynkin.

ìNo, theyíll be fine here!î Jin assured him, panicked at the thought of being separated yet again from all his pets. ìThereís so much room. And your back garden is all walled in. They wonít bother you a bit.î
ìWhat kind ofóno, never mind. Go on, Lord Vorkosigan.î

ìAt the same time, I will take Raven to meet Suze and company, and inspect the facilities. We might avoid having to retool the consulate laundry room into a cryo revival facilityóî though he did not sound as if this proposed renovation gave him much pause ìóif, like the installation we saw today, her old place already has one. And itís still in good shape, not stripped.î
Jin said doubtfully, ìIf you want any favors from Suze-san, you better catch her early in the day. When sheís still sober.î
ìNot a problem,î Miles-san said. ìThen, if everything proves workable, we can go on to the next step.î
ìWhat is the next step?î asked Consul Vorlynkin, in fascinated tones. He looked like a man staring at a groundcar wreck. In slow motion. That he was in.
ìSecuring Madame Sato.î
ìHow?î

ìIím going to have to do a spot more research first, to devise the optimum ploy. According to the public records, sheís being kept at the NewEgypt facility out in the Cryopolis here in Northbridge, which is actually pretty convenient.î Miles-sanís lips drew back on a peculiar grin. ìIt could be just like old times.î

Armsman Roic sat up in alarm. He put in, with some urgency, ìWhat about those commodified contracts Ron Wing was going on about? Maybe you could work out a way to just, I dunno, buy her. All peaceable and aboveboard.î He added after a moment, ìOr under the table, but peaceable, anyway.î

Miles-san paused again in his pacing, as if arrested by this notion. ìShrewd idea, Roic. But sheís not just any cryo-patron. I suspect that any interest in her is likely to send up a big red flag.î He fell into motion again. ìStill, hold that thought. It might be useful later, for the retroactive tidying up.î
Roic sighed.
ìThe ideal,î Miles-san went on, ìwould be to arrange things so that she wasnít missed at all.î

ìThese commercial cryochambers are all continuously monitored,î said Raven-sensei. ìYouíd need some way to fudge the readouts.î He hesitated. ìOr go low tech, and just swap in another cryo-corpse. That way, all the readings would be naturally right. They wouldnít know the difference unless they pulled it out and unwrapped it.î

Miles-san tilted his head, like Gyre the Falcon contemplating a choice morsel of meat. ìThe old shell game, eh? ThatÖ might actually be highly feasible. I wonder if I could borrow a spare from Suze? God knows, cryo-corpses are not an item in short supply around here.î
Vorlynkin choked. ìDo you have any idea how many different crimes youíve just rattled off?î
ìNo, but it might not hurt to make up a list, should your lawyer need it. Could speed things up, in a pinch.î
ìI thought the task of an Imperial Auditor was to uphold the law!î

Miles-sanís eyebrows flew up. ìNo, whatever gave you that idea? The task of an Imperial Auditor is to solve problems for Gregor. Those greasy cryocorps bastards just tried to steal a third of his empire. Thatís a problem.î Despite his smiling lips, Miles-sanís eyes glittered, and Jin realized with a start that underneath, he was really angry about something. ìIím still considering the solution.î
Jin wondered who Gregor was. Miles-sanís insurance boss?

Mina had scrunched her chair closer and closer to where Jin rocked in his. An audible sniffle escaped her, which made both Miles-san and Vorlynkin crank their heads around. Miles-san lurched and lifted a hand toward her, stopped short, and gestured at Jin instead, who, thus compelled, gave his sister a clumsy pat on the shoulder that only made her eyes fill up and overflow for real.
ìLord Vorkosigan, for pityís sake, enough for tonight,î said Consul Vorlynkin. ìThese children have to be exhausted. Both of them.î

Jin could wish he hadnít added that last. His eyes stung in contagion with Minaís. Now he was offered it, Jin wasnít so sure he wanted sympathyóit eroded his resolve as annoying bracing remarks never did.
ìTo be sure,î said Miles-san immediately. ìBaths, I think, and we can give them both Roicís room. He can bunk in with me. I expect some clean T-shirts would do for nightclothes. Toothbrushes?î

Miles-san and Vorlynkin arguing, Jin discovered, were not nearly so daunting as the pair of them united in sudden agreement. The ordinary business of bedtime blocked further tears. Jin expected Mina found the consulate house stranger than he did. Heíd slept in parks, after all, and in all sorts of odd crannies at Suze-sanís. Vorlynkin even donated a fancy sonic toothbrush, though Jin and Mina had then to share it, with a trip through its sterilizing holder between customers.

At last they were tucked up in clean sheets in a warm, quiet room. Jin waited for the door to softly shut, and the grownupsí feet to clump away back downstairs, before wriggling up and switching on the bedside lamp. Mina threw back her covers and helped him extract Lady Murasakiís box from her backpack. She watched closely as Jin opened the lid to give their pet a breath of fresh air, and helped by tossing in one of the little powdery beige moths theyíd collected earlier, while Jinís fingers blocked the prisoner from escaping. He set the plastic box back on the table between their beds.
ìIs she going to eat it?î Mina asked, peering through the lid.
ìIím not sure. She might only go for live prey.î
Mina frowned thoughtfully. ìThey have that big garden out back. I bet we could catch more bugs tomorrow.î
A reassuring notion. Jin lay back down and pulled up his sheets, and Mina reached to turn out the lamp again before any betraying line of light showed under the bedroom door.
After a while, Minaís whisper came out of the dark: ìDo you really think your galactic can get Mommy back? No one else ever could.î

Had anyone else even tried? Jin didnít know. Miles-san, all dapper and alert and concentrated and never sitting still, was proving an alarming acquaintance. Jin wasnít sure but what heíd liked the grubby lost druggie better. Jin had a disconcerting feeling of having set a force in motion that he could not now stop, which wasnít made better by not even knowing whether he wanted to.
ìI donít know, Mina,î he said at last. ìBe quiet and go to sleep.î He rolled over and hid from it all under his covers.

Roic followed Consul Vorlynkin into the tight-room, where mílord was already deeply involved with the comconsole, Johannes at his side, Raven leaning over and kibitzing. They all seemed to be examining some engineering schematics for the NewEgypt facility, pulled up from God knew where. Roic was relieved mílord had finally decided to involve Johannes, if only by necessity. Backup at last! Inexperienced, but not untrained, and judging from his wide eyes it looked as if he was getting a tutorial in covert ops that would have done his ImpSec instructors proud.
Mílord wheeled in his station chair to take in the new arrivals. ìAh, Vorlynkin, good. Your clerk, Matsonóheíll be back to work in the morning, right?î
ìYes?î

ìI donít think we can keep those kids quiet enough to hide them from him in a house this small. Heíll have to be told they are protected witnesses, in some danger. That should be enough to settle him.î
ìIs it true?î said Vorlynkin.

ìHow did someone so reluctant to tell lies become a diplomat? By the way, I canít believe, with all your training, that you failed to admire Miss Satoís blisters. What is it about this universal female conviction that medical conditions make one interesting? Judging from my daughter Helen, it starts younger than I would have believed possible.î

ìAbout the danger,î said Vorlynkin, winning Roicís admiration by refusing to be drawn into mílordís flight of fancy. Judging from the brightness of his eyes, mílord was as over-stimulated right now as his own kids after one of his bedtime stories, right enough. ìIs it real? Because itís unconscionable to keep those children from their guardians otherwise.î

Mílord sobered. ìPerhaps. This is an investigation, which means that not all leads pan out. Or otherwise one wouldnít need to investigate. But I shouldnít think Lisa Sato would have been removed in that brutal and effective way for any trivial reason. Which means waking her up could actually increase their hazardÖî He tapped his lips, considering this. ìI suspect Jin misjudges his aunt and uncle, actually. They may not merely lack the resources to fight the good fight for their kinswoman. They may be seriously intimidated.î
ìHm,î said Vorlynkin.

Roicís own conviction was that as soon as that poor frozen woman had intersected mílordís orbit, this chain of events had become inevitable. Worse than dangling a string in front of a cat, it was. He likely shouldnít explain this to Vorlynkin; an armsman was supposed to be loyal in thought, word, and deed. But not blindÖ
ìBut if Jin and Mina were your children, would you want some off-worlder as good as kidnapping them to use for his own purposes?î Vorlynkin persisted. ìNo matter how well-intentioned?î

ìIn my defense, I must point out, they turned up here on their own, butóif I were dead, my widow frozen, my children fallen into the hands of people either unwilling or incapable of helping them? I doubt I would care where the man came from who could reunite them with Ekaterin. Iíd shower all my posthumous blessings upon him.î Mílord wheeled around and drummed his fingers on the comconsole counter. ìPoor Jin! He makes me think about my missing grandmother, actually.î
ìMissing grandmother?î said Raven, leaning back against the counter. ìI didnít know you had any.î

ìMost people have twoónot you, of course. My Betan grandmother is alive and well and opinionated to this day, in fact. If you ever meet her, youíll understand a whole lot more about my mother. No, itís a Barrayaran tale, the fate of Princess-and-Countess Olivia Vorbarra Vorkosigan.î
ìThen delightfully bloody, I daresay.î Ravenís sweeping hand gesture invited mílord to go on, not that he needed any encouragement. Johannes, too, was listening in apparent fascination.

ìVery. If youíd learned your Barrayaran history, not that you would be expected to, youíd know that once upon a timeóall the best stories start that way, you realizeóthat once upon a time, the death squads of Mad Emperor Yuri attempted to erase most of my family, thereby triggering the civil war that ended, eventually, in Yuriís dismemberment. So many people wanted a piece of him by then, they were forced to share, yísee. The death squad shot my grandmother in front of my father, messily. He was eleven at the time, which is part of why Jin keeps reminding me of it.

ìBut you seeÖ for all the horrors of that day, and of the war that followed it, nobody, Iím not sure how to put this, nobody denied my father his experience. Jinís mother was just as abruptly and unjustly taken from him, but heís not been permitted his grief. No funeral, no mourning, no protest, even. No revengeócertainly not whatever satisfaction there might be of knowing she was escorted down into death by a procession of her enemies. For Jin and Mina, thereís justÖ silence. Frozen silence.î
A rather frozen silence followed this, among the Barrayarans in the room.
Vorlynkin cleared his throat, leaned on his hand, stared into the comconsole. ìSo. Lord Auditor. And, umÖ just how are we planning to give this woman her voice backÖ ?î
ìDonít land on the chickens,î Jin said, leaning anxiously over the back of the seat between Johannes, who was flying the lift van, and Miles, occupying the passenger side.

Johannes grimaced and eased the lift van forward under the canopy of Jinís rooftop refuge, then paused again while Jin leaped out to pull the cafe table out of the way, glance underneath the van, look relieved, and motion Johannes forward. As Johannes gingerly set them down atop the roof, a woman at the back of the tent-room stood hands-on-hips, watching them in suspicion, though she smiled briefly as Jin danced up to her. The whine of the vanís engines went silent.

ìAh, Ako, good, sheís been faithful,î said Miles, and slid open his door. ìThe rest of you wait here till I signal,î he added over his shoulder. ìWe donít want to stampede the poor woman.î Or look like a clown car, he did not add aloud. Johannes and Raven nodded silently; Roicís disapproving frown at Miles seizing point-man position might as well have been audible.

Ako was evidently attempting to feed Gyre; she wore heavy oven mitts and brandished a long fork with a fragment of raw meat fluttering from it. As she gestured to Jin, the bird stretched forward and snatched the slithery morsel, twisting its head and gulping it down. Ako jumped. ìHe bites, you know,î she said to Jin, almost apologetically.
ìNot very hard,î said Jin.

ìI needed antibiotic salve and plastic bandages the first time, thank you very much. Iíll allow the bird didnít actually take off a finger.î She put her hands on her hips again and stared hard at Miles. ìSo youíre back! You gave me quite a turn, sneaking up in that van.î

Miles hoped their sneaking had been successful. Though not hidden from more sophisticated scanners, at least the tent roof concealed their activities from casual observation, in this level morning light. Discreet, if not secret.

ìI was beginning to think you werenít coming back, and was wondering what to do with all these animals. But you found Jin after all!î She had nearly decided, Miles read in her eyes, that heíd dodged off without any intention of finding Jin.
ìWe were both unavoidably delayed,î Miles said. ìJin actually found me, but in any case, weíre reunited. Thank you so much for looking after his creatures. They mean the world to him.î
She sniffed, not displeased with some recognition of her efforts. ìI know.î
Jin returned from taking a rapid inventory of his menagerie, including counting his chickens. ìMiles-san is going to take me and all my creatures away to, to his place. For a while,î he told Ako.
Her brows tightened. ìYah?î

ìYes, and I need to speak to Madame Suze about that,î Miles said. Ako looked marginally appeased at this indication of aboveboard-ness. ìTenbury told me you are something of an apprentice to the plant medtech?î Miles would be meeting her again soon, if things went as he hoped. Best to placate her.
Ako went wary. ìI help her clean and things. In the infirmary.î
ìJust so.î Miles motioned to the van; the rest of his entourage piled out.

Miles was relieved of the problem of introductions by Jin taking them over, possibly more reassuringly than Miles could have: ìThis is Raven-sensei, heís a friend from Escobar, this is Roic-san, he works for Miles-san, this is Lieutenant Johannes, heís all right.î
Ako bent and whispered, ìJin, theyíre not policemen, are they? You should know betteróî
ìNaw, theyíre Barrayarans. Galactics.î

Ako bit her lip, but seemed to accept this provisional guarantee. She watched as they sorted themselves out, Johannes and Roic to stay with the van till Jin got back to supervise loading it, Raven and Jin to accompany Miles.
ìI should come with you,î Roic muttered to Milesís ear.
ìThese people are justifiably nervous of outsiders. I wonít get what I want if we hit them en masse, and youíre en masse all by yourself.î Miles tapped his wristcom. ìIíll call you if I need you.î

Roic returned him The Sigh, familiar shorthand for the usual argument. Miles let Jin lead him and Raven off down the exchanger tower. Ako trailed as far as the kitchen, where Miles prudently detoured to grab a carafe of coffee and some cups. She stared after them as they trod away toward the stairs to Suzeís suite.
As they waited for an answer to Milesís knock, he turned his head and said to Jin, ìI had better pitch this to her in my own way. Iíll let you know when you can chime in.î
Jin, shifting from foot to foot, gulped and nodded.

A slow shuffle from within heralded the door opening a crack. Suzeís bleary eye peered out. ìYou again!î she said. ìI thought we were well rid of you.î She squinted at Jin. ìOf both of you.î The eye traveled on to Raven. ìWho the hell are you?î
ìRaven Durona, from Escobar,î Raven answered readily. ìPleased to meet you.î
ìHeís a friend,î Miles said. ìAs in, Pass, friend.î He brandished the carafe. ìMay we come in?î

ìEhÖî Reluctantly, but with her one open eye on the carafe, Suze gave way. She wore the same loose black garments as before; she probably slept in them. Her inner chamber had the same close geriatric smell. She went to her window and set the polarization to admit a grudging shade more morning, and waved Miles, and his carafe, cups, and followers, to her battered seats.
ìYou found your wallet, I see,î she said, settling across from them. At Milesís gesture, Jin hastened to distribute coffee.
ìYes, and my luggage and my friends. Iím back in business.î
ìAnd just what is your business? Thank you, Jin.î
ìIím an investigator, of a sort.î
Suzeís cup halted on its way to her lips. Her seamed face set in stiff panic.
ìNot for any authority on Kibou, however,î Miles added.
ìInsurance fraud,î Jin put in, in hasty reassurance. ìHeís not a policeman. Or a doctor or a lawyer, even though he went to that conference. Raven-senseiís the doctor.î

Milesís eyebrows went up at this description of himself. Clearly, at some point he was going to have to take the boy aside and explain Imperial Auditor to him in greater detail, but perhaps this would do for now. ìNot precisely, but close enough. As it happens, the powers-that-be on Kibou are the subject of my inquiries, not its sponsors. I have no interest whatsoever in shutting down your operation. Iíd actually like to make use of your facilities. I may be able to make it worth your time.î
Suzeís eyes narrowed over her coffee cup; she finally drank. ìWe get by here because we donít draw anyoneís attention.î
ìI donít wish to draw attention, either.î
Suze sat back, leathery lips pursing. ìYou want someone illegally frozen? Hoping you can bribe me into storing the body for you?î Her tone was remarkably neutral, neither leading nor guiding.

Her suggestion came up far too readilyóye gods, had Suze ever provided such services, perhaps for the local underworld? Did Kibou-daini have an underworld? Aside from the literal one heíd been lost in, that is. Could this be the source of some of her protection? Because crime lords would want to cheat death, too. Though youíd think they could afford their own private arrangementsóstill, they would need benefits to distribute to lesser followers. And for the discreet disposal of enemies, those ranks of anonymous drawers downstairs would certainly trump lead weights and a swim in the nearest river. It would even render murder reversible, if one had been too hasty in oneís crime-lordly commands, or otherwise made a mistake. Man, if I wanted to hide a body on KibouÖ Miles wrenched his mind from this fascinating side-path. ìHave you done such favors before?î he asked cautiously.
Suze shrugged, her alarm giving way to dry amusement in the face of his consternation. ìIf I had, would I tell you?î

ìI have no need to know,î Miles assured her. Want to know yes, but then, he wanted to know everything. ìMy need is quite the reverse. We wish to do a private cryorevival. Which requires proper facilities. And discretion. You may be able to lend us both.î

This took her aback. Her jaw worked, and she covered her confusion with another swallow of coffee, then grimaced. ìJin, fetch my medicine out of the cupboard,î she commanded. Jin leapt up, rummaged for the square bottle, and brought it to her. At her gesture, he also uncapped and pouredóscantly, both Miles and, he thought, Suze noted, but she didnít complain as the boy settled once more. ìCryorevival! How?î
ìDr. Durona, here, is a noted cryorevival specialist. If your facilities meet his specs, weíd like to, as it were, rent them.î
A long pause. ìHow much?î Suze said at last.

ìI thought Iíd offer you something your money canít buy. In exchange for letting us revive our, um, patronóand for the discretion, of courseóRaven will throw in a top-class revival for any other candidate of your choice.î
Suzeís jaw unhinged. She sank back in her chair. And after a moment breathed, ìYou devil.î
Money would have worked, Miles thought. But some things worked better.
Suze jerked her head toward Raven. ìJust how good is he?î

For answer, Miles unbuttoned his gray tunic and white shirt. ìThisîóhis hand traced the spider web of pale scarsóìwas a needle-grenade, very well aimed, at close range. Ten years ago. Raven did my revival.î Assisted at, strictly speaking, but Raven had acquired a decadeís more experience and seniority since then. ìI guarantee, as a medical challenge nothing that you have downstairs can compare.î
Suze looked away as he buttoned up again. ìOld age,î she said, ìis slower than a grenade, but a lot more thorough.î

ìThis is unfortunately true,î said Raven, ìthough I may have a few aids for that as well. What I would suggest is that Madame Suze, here, draw up a list of half a dozen or so candidates, and let me triage them for the maximum chance of medical success. This should produce the most satisfactory result all round.î
ìMm,î she said. Her hand crept up and rubbed her chest, over her heart. ìHm.î
Jin, unable to contain himself any longer, burst out, ìPlease, Suze-san! Let them!î
The caterpillar eyebrows climbed. ìWhatís it to you, boy?î
Jin pressed his lips together and looked imploringly at Miles.
ìAre you sure you want to know?î Miles inquired.
Suze was shrewd enough to hesitate a long moment before her curiosity overcame her better judgment. ìYah.î
Miles opened his hand to Jin, who cried, ìMiles-san promised to get my mother back!î
Suzeís face pinched in horror. ìOh, and you think you arenít going to draw attention, mister galactic investigator? Lisa Sato was all about attention!î

ìWe may draw some eventually, but not to you,î Miles said smoothly. ìAs soon as her recovery permits, weíll remove her to the Barrayaran consulate and reunite her with both her children. No link to this place.î
ìYou think so? Those that froze her will sure enough want to find out who unfroze her! Which will drop them right back in my lap, which isnít big enough to hold them, I promise you!î
ìYes, but the first thing theyíll run into is me. I planÖî Miles hesitated. He didnít exactly have a plan, yet. More of a stab in the dark. He still wasnít sure what his blade would connect withÖ
ìWhat?î demanded Suze.

ìI plan to give them other worries.î He glanced at Raven. ìMuch depends on Madame Sato, both on what she has to say and how soon she can say it. I had rather severe cryo-amnesia, myself. Which lingered uncomfortably.î

ìI remember that,î said Raven. ìUncomfortable it may have been, but it didnít really last that long. We were just pressed for time, back then. Madame Satoówell, I canít give any guarantees at this point.î
Miles nodded understanding, both of what was said and what was unsaid, and turned again to Suze. ìI need one more favor. Iíd like to borrow a cryo-corpse.î
ìWhat,î Suze began in a towering tone, which weakened to, ìÖkind?î
ìFemale, about fifty kilos. As young as you have available. Anything else, Raven?î
Raven shook his head. ìThat should do it.î
ìWe undertake not to damage her in any way that would compromise her future revival,î Miles went on, hoping he didnít sound too airy.
ìThat a guarantee, galactic?î
ìIt wonít be wholly under my control, but if things go my way, she should be all right.î I hope. ìIn any covert operation, peopleÖ take their chances.î
Raven wincedóah, maybe not the best parallel to draw, after the chest display.
ìWhen?î
ìSoon. Possibly tonight, no later than tomorrow night.î
Suzeís nostrils flared in a long, indrawn breath of doubt.
Miles held up a pair of fingers. ìTwo cryorevivals of your choice.î

Suze turned her head and made a throwing-away gesture. ìGo see the plant medtech. Vristi Tanaka. Jin will show you the way. If you can talk her into going along with all this nonsense, though I suppose you willÖ Talk, talk, talk. Makes me tired.î

Miles rose quickly, so as not to outwear his welcome or her decision. ìThank you, Madame Suze. I promise youÖî you wonít regret this was too big a diplomacy to push past even his teeth. ìÖit will be interesting,î he finished.
Suzeís snort sent them on their way.

The infirmary turned out to be on the second floor of the facilityís old patron intake building. Jin led Miles and Raven through double doors to a corridor with some two or three rooms apparently furbished up for action, judging from the fresh medical smell. They found Tenbury lingering outside of one of them, leaning against the wall with his arms crossed, a narrow float pallet grounded at his feet.
ìJin!î he said, looking pleased. ìThey said youíd got lost!î He looked somewhat less pleased at Miles. ìYou again.î His brow wrinkled at Raven.
ìWe came to see Tanaka-san,î Jin explained. ìItís important.î
ìSheís busy right nowîóTenbury jerked a thumb at the room beyondóìbut they should be done soon.î
Raven craned his neck to peer through a narrow glass window in the door. ìAh, cryoprep in progress? Iíd like to see that.î
ìRaven-senseiís a doctor. From Escobar,î Jin began. Tenbury looked perturbed, and began to speak. Miles cut the debate short by simply knocking.

The knock was answered by a frowning woman, brown skin like old leather, spare of build and with straight white hair where Suze was stout and frizzy, but of a like age, Miles judged, and without the alcohol fumes. Her face lightened when she saw Jin.
ìAh, youíre found, Jin! And who have your creatures savaged now, and can it wait?î
ìNo one, Tanaka-san. But itís kind of urgent. Suze-san sent us over.î

Miles let Jin run through his introductions, at which the boy was becoming nicely practiced. He picked up: ìWeíve made arrangements with Madame Suze to use your facilities for a private cryorevival, if they meet Dr. Duronaís needs. May we come in?î

ìHuh!î she said, and gave way, staring at Raven. Miles wondered if heíd rumpled Ravenís clothes, mussed his neat hair, and doused him with gin if he would have seemed less out of place, here, less alarming to these people. Too late.

On a table standing out from the far wall lay the naked body of a frail old man, detained, Miles thought, at the border crossing between life and death. A sheet draped across his middle lent him a scrap of dignity, as much as one could have when given over to plastic tubes and the will or whim of others. A cold-blanket wrapped around his skull sped the chilling of his brain. A tube from a tank above, divided partway down, ran a clear liquid into both carotid arteries. A wider tube, from a vein in his thigh, ran a dark pink color to a knee-height tub with a drain, with a trickle of water from a spout above to keep things flowing. Judging from the paleness of the skin and nails, and the color of the murky exit fluid, the old body was almost wholly perfused with cryo-solution.
Ako hovered, closely supervising the process; sheíd evidently overheard something through the doorway, because she looked up and said excitedly, ìA doctor? Weíre getting a real doctor?î
Miles waved down this hope, before it could grow big and bite. ìJust visiting. Weíll explain it all when youíre finished, here.î

Jin was staring; Miles wondered how disturbing this process was to the boy, or if heíd seen it before. It was disturbing to Miles, and heíd done it before, or had it done to him. Maybe the more unsettling for that? For the first time, he wondered how much the news of his own encounter with the needle-grenade had felt like history repeats to his father, if it had triggered unwelcome old memories of the Princess-and-Countess Oliviaís messy death. I must apologize to him for that, when next we meet.
ìIt almost seems too simple,î Miles murmured to Raven.
Raven said, ìThe complexity lies in the cryo-preservation fluid, which has a whole pharmaceutical facility behind it. Or so one trusts. Where are you getting your cryo-fluid, Madame Tanaka?î

The medtechís old mouth set in a flat smile. ìThe concentrate falls off the back of a few loading docks of hospitals here in town. They discard their outdated supplies a couple of times a year. We distill our own water to reconstitute it.î
Milesís brows rose. ìIs that, umÖ all right? Medically?î
Raven shrugged. ìIf the use-by dating is fairly conservative, yes.î

It was not, Miles supposed, a choice between discarded fluid and fresh, but between discarded and none. He was reminded again that this place was a parasite operation, clinging to the underbelly of a more functional economy, without which it could not continue to exist. Granted, if its host economy functioned rather better, it wouldnít need to exist.

Medical sensors blinked timing lights. Ako withdrew the tubes and sealed the entry and exit incisions with plastic bandage, and carefully lathered the skin with ointment. She and Medtech Tanaka horsed the body into a sort of plastic body-glove, then joined forces with Tenbury to shift it all onto the float pallet, where Tenbury covered it more corpselike with a sheet. He guided the pallet out the door. ìWant to help me, Jin?î Tenbury asked hopefully over his shoulder. Jin, planting his feet, doggedly shook his head. Tenbury sighed and trundled his burden away.

Ako turned to the clean-up process, Raven leaned against a counter, and Miles found a stool to perch upon. While the medtech folded her arms and listened dubiously, Miles embarked on much the same pitch as heíd presented to Madame Suze, heavy on the implication that Suze had sent them over here with her full blessing. Since Tanaka seemed susceptible to the boy, Miles also unleashed Jin for a judicious blast of heartfelt imploring.

As a result, her frown at the end seemed more technical than political. ìWe havenít had most of that section open for years. A lot of the equipment that wasnít stripped out when the place was decommissioned went later.î
Palmed and pawned or sold, Miles presumed.
ìBut I do maintainÖ huh. I think weíll have to go up and take a look around.î
Not a flat no, impossible, then. Good so far. ìThatís what Raven is here for,î Miles assured her. ìSuze saidóis that her first name or her last, by the way?î
ìBoth,î said the medtech. ìSusan Suzuki.î
ìHave you been working with her for long?î
ìSince the beginning. There were three of us put the scheme togetheróSuze, her sister, who was assistant to the comptroller, and me. We roped in Tenbury pretty quick, though.î
ìA younger man then, was he? You were critical for the cryoprep, obviously. Did you have any plans for the other end of things, the revivals?î

She blew out her lips in a short laugh. ìAt the time, I didnít think weíd go more than a year before we all ended up in jail. I figured it for more of a hopeless protest than anything. Then the street people started coming in, even more desperate than we were, and we found we couldnít quit. Couldnít betray them as everyone else had.î
ìThe world is made by the people who show up for the job,î Miles agreed.

Medtech Tanaka eyed Ako, who had finished cleaning up and drifted over to listen in. ìThatís a true thing. Ako and her great-aunt used to run a cook-shop. The usualóthe old woman grew ill, the medical bills bankrupted them, the shop failed, they were evictedÖ came in to us. Akoíd never finished school, but she knew how to clean and wasnít afraid of work, so I took her on.î Earnest but timid Ako, Miles guessed, would never have gained entry to, let alone graduated from, any medtech academy. This place gave a whole new dimension to the term unlicensed.
ìShouldnít we take Raven-sensei upstairs now?î Jin urged.

They mounted one floor to the corridor directly above, which had apparently once been a fully-equipped cryorevival facility, with half a dozen operating theaters, a recovery room, and some intensive care booths. Most of it was dark and dusty and, indeed, sadly stripped, but Medtech Tanaka apparently maintained one operating room for procedures more demanding than what antibiotic ointment, surgical glue, and bracing advice would cover. She and Raven fell into intense but by no means discouraged tech-speak, medical division, which ended with sending Jin downstairs to bring back Tenbury for more consultation.
ìWho is the owner-of-record for this place?î Miles asked the medtech while they were waiting. ìIf it was legally abandoned, Iíd have thought the city would have seized it for back taxes by now.î

ìThere have been a couple of supposed owners, over the years. The city wonít seize it for the same reason the current owner, poor slob, canít unload it. Legal liability for two or three thousand destitute cryo-corpses. He was a contractor, who bought it for what he thought was a song and only then discovered what came with it. Suze has him under control for now. We think the biggest current danger is that heíll try to solve his dilemma through a spot of arson, but we keep a watch.î
ìIt doesnít sound like a very stable situation.î
ìNever has been. We just try to go from day to day. Surprising where you can end up, that way.î

Raven, Miles noticed, was listening intently to all this, not in the least appalled. Well, Jacksonian-trained, after all. The Hippocratic Oath, if heíd ever heard of it, was likely only considered a guideline there.

Tenbury came back, and there followed a lot more tech-speak, then visits to other chambers with some alarming thumping and crashing. Miles sent the fretful Jin back to his roof to supervise the loading-up of his menagerie. When the noises of inventory at last died away, Raven returned.
ìWell?î said Miles. ìGo or no-go?î
ìGo,î said Raven. ìThere will have to be some prep, but I find these people are good at improvising. And the physical impediments are made up for by a delightful lack of paperwork.î

ìHow soon will you be ready for me to make my snatch? Iíll probably want you along on the insertion, by the way, in case we run into any snags that are medical rather than security-related. How do you feel about risking arrest, by the way?î
Raven shrugged. ìIím sure your brother will extract me if you canít. In any case, you can make your switch any time. Madame Sato can just as well wait here till weíre ready.î

ìMy time is not infinitely elastic.î Besides his wanting to go home, of course, there was no telling what can of worms would be emptied onto his plate with the revival of Jinís mother. Miles was getting itchy to know.
ìYou can take that kid back to the consulate. I expect Iíll be working late here,î Raven went on. ìI can get back to my hotel by public transport.î
Miles pointed to Ravenís consulate-issued wristcom. ìCheck in first. Secured channel. Iíll want a report. And it may be better to send Johannes to pick you up.î
ìActuallyÖî Raven hesitated. ìI think I will want to stop back at the consulate anyway. Can I use your secured tight-beam links to report in to my boss on Escobar?î
ìLily, or Mark?î
ìBoth. Though Iím not just sure where Lord Mark is, right now. Do you know?î
Miles shook his head. ìHis enterprises have become rather far-flung. I donít track him daily. Are you arranging bail in advance?î
ìWell, thatís a thought, but mainly because I may have found some elements of interest to the Durona group, here.î
ìIf they impinge on my investigation, I want to be fully apprised. Or even if they donít.î
ìUnderstood.î
Miles waved him back to work, and made his way back down through the basement maze and up to Jinís rooftop.

As they unloaded the van, Consul Vorlynkin came out to see what all they were dumping in his back garden. Mina danced ahead of him and pounced on Lucky with an excited cry, rubbing her face in the soft fur. ìLucky! I thought you were dead!î The old gray cat endured the hug, but wriggled free promptly. ìDo you still have your ratties, Jin?î
ìYes,î said Jin, lifting the cage he was lugging to show them off. ìJinnie and most of her children.î

ìHandsome,î said Vorlynkin, inspecting Gyre, chained to his perch, from a prudent distance. ìHow do you keep it from eating your chickens?î Galli and Twig, released from their transport box by Lieutenant Johannes, ran past his knees, flapping their wings and squawking, then slowed to stare in apparent amazement at the grass patch before them, warm and green-smelling in the noon sun.

ìWell, the big ones sort of defend themselves. I had to keep Gyre chained to his perch when the chicks were littler. Iíll have to keep him chained here anyway, till he figures out this is where he belongs.î Jin watched as Armsman Roic, with due care, unloaded a stack of terrariums onto the shelf theyíd brought from Jinís refuge. Tucked up against the back of the house and sheltered by its eaves, concealed by the house, the tall stone garden walls, and all the trees and bushes, the shelf and its contents would be almost as safe as in his tent-shelter at Suze-sanís.
ìCats and mice together as well?î Vorkynkin went on. ìWhat next, lions and lambs?î

ìRats,î Jin corrected austerely. ìThough I wish I might have a lionÖ ! Anyway, Luckyís too old and lazy to bother the big ones, and I keep the little ones in cages with tops.î He looked around with satisfaction. ìNow that I have all my creatures back, you can keep Lady Murasaki,î he told Mina generously.
She made a face. ìBut Luckyís half mine. Because she wasnít yours to start with, you know, even if you did steal her away.î
ìI saved her from Aunt Lorna,î Jin reminded her.

Lucky curled around Vorlynkinís ankles, rubbing her chin to scent-mark him as her new property and leaving a trail of hairs plastered to his formerly-tidy hakama trousers. He bent rather absently to scritch her spine, and she arched shamelessly under his hand.
Mina addressed him anxiously, ìOh sir, can we keep Lucky inside? Till she knows this is home? Cats do get lost, you know!î
Looking down into Minaís upturned face, Vorlynkin said reluctantly, ìIs she housebroken?î
Mina nodded vigorously. ìI can fix her cat pan in my room!î
ìThe washroom off the kitchen would likely do as well,î he told her. ìYou and JinÖ well, yes, I expect it will be good for you and your brother to look after her.î

Miles-san strolled past. ìAll shipshape here, Jin? Then I need Johannes back.î He added to Consul Vorlynkin, ìWeíll be in your tight-room for a time. A lot of detail-work still to do.î At his gesture, Roic rose and took up what seemed his accustomed place at his shoulder.
ìIs your scheme going to fly, then?î Vorlynkin asked. Miles-san nodded. Vorlynkin grimaced.
Miles-san returned a wry smile. ìFlexibility, Vorlynkin. Thatís the key.î He trod indoors, swinging his cane. Jin and Vorlynkin stared after him.
Vorlynkin voiced Jinís own half-formed thought: ìWas that supposed to be reassuring?î

Roic figured midnight would have been the right time for a body-snatching expedition, possibly in the middle of a thunderstorm. Among other things, an electrical storm might help account for any power-flicker anomalies they left in their wake. But there were no suitable cold fronts predicted any time soon, and so Roic found himself, Raven, and mílord, with Johannes driving the lift van again, turning in at the impressive entrance of the NewEgypt facility at high noon. It was only in Roicís imagination that the dog-headed statues flanking the main gate seemed to follow them with their painted eyes.
Johannes was armed with a couple of little floral arrangements in water tubes and a script, but he wasnít called upon to deploy either; the human gate guard waved them right through.
ìWhat tí hell,î said Roic.

ìItís visiting hours,î said mílord mildly. ìThey arenít going to harass their patronsí kin, nor their potential future customers coming in for their tour, at this time of day. This isnít a military installation. All NewEgypt security has to worry about is theftówhich is more likely to come from an employeeóvandalism, which isnít likely to occur in broad daylight, and maybe something like the N.H.L.L.ówho would probably wait for that midnight thunderstorm you wanted. Seems like their style, somehow.î
Roic settled back with a disgruntled, ìHuh.î

He shifted uncomfortably in his somewhat-too-tight hospital uniform, XL, scavenged by Raven and Medtech Tanaka, possibly from the same source as some of their medical supplies now laid in and waiting back at Madame Suzeís. Mílord wore a similar set, XS, a bit too loose, with the sleeve and trouser ends rolled up. Ravenís set fit perfectly. Johannes was dressed in what Roic had been assured were unexceptionable Kibou street clothes, tidy and middle-class.

The van slipped past both the pyramid-topped buildingís lobby, fronted by an inviting faux-Egyptian garden with stone sphinxes, and the sign pointing to the loading docks for pre-frozen patron intake, hidden on the more utilitarian backside, then on around to a discreet side entrance meant for employees.
ìAll right, this is where we unload,î mílord said. ìDonít look hurried, but donít waste time.î

Trying not to look hurried, not to mention harried, Roic helped Raven open the back of the lift van and slide out the float pallet. A stack of boxes, emptied of their medical supplies, concealed the long shape in what Roic thought of as the freezer bag beneath. The body bag, designed for short-term transport, would, if left sealed, keep its contents at cryo-temperature for a couple of days, Raven had explained to him. Roic had to grant, it was a hell of a lot less bulky and eye-catching than a portable cryochamber. Johannes drove off to find the visitor parking and wait, and mílord led the pallet and its handlers inside through automatic doors that parted for them without protest.

Mílord checked the holomap on his wristcom and led off through a succession of corridors. They encountered a trio of gossiping employees and an elderly couple, clearly visitors, on their way to the cafeteria that Roic smelled in passing, but none spared the pallet a glance. Roic carefully did not look back. Two more turns and a short ride down a freight lift tube, and they were pacing along an underground corridor that stopped at a double door, the first locked barrier theyíd encountered.

Mílord opened one of the boxes, whipped out his special tool kit, ImpSec standard issue with upgrades, and knelt to the electronic lock. He muttered unreassuringly, ìGod, itís been a while. Hope I havenít lost my touchÖî He puttered for a minute or two, while Roic jittered and kept glancing over his shoulder, and Raven looked bland. The doors parted so soundlessly, Roic was taken by surprise. Mílord looked smug. ìAh, good. Iíd hoped not to leave any evidence by damaging the lock.î He waved them through like some demented mâitre díhôtel escorting diners to the best table in the room, and closed the doors gently again when the pallet had passed through.

The new corridor was much darker. And, Roic was surprised to see, unfinished, which made him worry about encountering workmen, but he supposed a construction crew would have lights that would warn them. Beneath the pyramidal building lay three sub-levels. Around the core stack of utilities on each level, four concentric corridors extended outward in squares, with radial connecting halls at the midpoint of each side. Too regular to be called a maze, it nonetheless seemed to Roic that it would be easy to get turned around down here. So just how disturbing it had been to mílord to be lost for hours in a true maze, with no light?

They turned in at the next connecting spoke; mílordís lips moved as he counted off side branches, then set in a smile as the core stack hove into view. Another pause, while mílord weaseled his way into a locked electrical access panel, did some careful counting, and nodded. They then went out another spoke and turned right into one of the corridors, this one completed, dimly lit with utility lighting and lined with loaded cryo-drawers.
ìThis doesnít look so fancy,î Roic murmured.
ìThese are the cheap seats,î said mílord. ìIf you want to be filed away behind faux mahogany and brass fittingsóor gold, Iím toldóNewEgypt can supply, on the upper levels.î

Even down here, a lot of the drawers had small holders set in the walls beside them for odd little personal offerings, including tiny bottles of wine, wrapped snacks, or burned-down stubs of incense sticks. Most common were flowers, mostly plastic or silk but sometimes real onesósome fresh, some brown and drooping sadly from their dried-out water tubes.
ìHere,î said mílord, stopping abruptly. He craned his neck at a drawer at the top of the stack. ìRead off the number, Raven.î
Raven recited a long alphanumeric string, twice.
Mílord checked carefully against the data on his wristcom. ìThis is it.î

The disguising boxes then found another use, as mílord filched one to boost him to a convenient height to examine the drawer lock and attach his ImpSec-special door opener to it. ìAll right,î he murmured, climbing back down. ìWhen the lights go out, make the switch.î
He unshipped his own hand light and trotted off.

Raven issued Roic a pair of insulated medical gloves, donned a pair himself, and bent to unseal the long bag. The figure revealed seemed a slender little old woman, clad in a sort of plastic caul that clung to her shape. What with the translucent protective ointment heavily slathered on her skin and the frost that instantly began to form on the exposed plastic surface, her helpless nakedness had at least a decent veiling. Roic turned on his own hand light an instant before the corridor lights, and all the little green lights on the drawers, went black. There having proved no way to open a single drawer without setting off some indicator in the central control room, the next best thing had seemed to give the same flicker to five thousand or so drawers at once.
ìReady,î said Raven.
Roic tapped the button on the unlocking device; to his relief, the drawer lock opened easily. He slid the long drawer out like opening some dreadful filing cabinet.

Inside was another female figure, also in its caul, which also frosted swiftly. Roic frowned to see that the plastic wrappings werenít quite identicalóthese seemed to be browner and reinforced with some sort of netting. But, bracing himself, he slid his hands under and lifted her out. Even with the gloves, she seemed to suck the warmth from him in a swift tide. He set her gently on the floor, Raven checked the name tag attached to the outside of the wrappings, and he and Raven between them lifted her replacement into the drawer. The drawer slid shut with a smooth click.

Mílordís hand light flickered at the corridor corner, and he peered around; Roic waved allís-well, and he nodded and ducked away again. By the time Roic and Raven inserted their prize into the bag and sealed it up again, the lights flashed back on. Roic reached up and carefully unsealed the unlocking device, and hid it back in mílordís kit. He then began re-stacking concealing boxes, wondering how soon a tech crew would arrive to check out their brief power failure.

Mílord returned, and murmured, ìGo, go.î His eyes seemed as bright as any of the indicator lights, and Roic realized how much he was enjoying this caper. Iím glad one of us is. Raven seemed as amiable as ever, as if he indulged in this sort of chicanery every day, which Roic knew very well he did not. Roic swallowed and prepared to sprint as the hum of lift tube doors and the echo of voices drifted up the hall that radiated from the central stack, but they turned onto the outer ring before any shouts of Hey, you there! could find them.

A short stroll, and they were back at the underground double doors. Mílord paused to lock them again, and call Johannes on his wristcom. The lieutenant was opening the rear of the lift van as they arrived outside. The pallet-load of ìsuppliesî disappeared soundlessly within. Roic still didnít breathe easily till the van turned out the gates and joined the flow of afternoon traffic.
Mílord checked his wristcom. ìSixteen minutes,î he said, in a satisfied tone.

Raven had taken the front seat again with Johannes, which made all kinds of sense since the pair of them were by far the most normal-looking, by local standards. Johannes drove sedately but not too sedately, just as instructed. With the back seats folded down to make a cargo space, Roic crouched opposite Madame Satoís body bag from mílord, alert to reach out and prevent it shifting should Johannes make any sudden turns. Roic had been assured that the cryo-solution and protective ointments kept cryo-corpses slightly pliable, not brittle, and that despite their temperature they wouldnít shatter like an ice cube thrown to the pavement at an accidental blow. But still.

They rode in silence for a few minutes, which Roic broke at last, low-voiced: ìAll this makes me think about Sergeant Taura. All these other folks got to die in some hope for their future, why not her? We were all right there at the Durona clinic, everything was in place for it, it wouldnít have cost muchÖî

Taura was one of the mercs from mílordís old ImpSec covert ops days, before the needle-grenade and cryorevival damage had put him out of that business for good. Like Raven and the rest of the Durona cloned siblings, she was a product of Jacksonian genetic engineering; unlike them, she was a sole survivor, in her case of a failed prototype batch of supposed super-soldiers. She had escaped to mílordís merc troop, where the super-soldier part had actually worked, mílord testified. But her creators had built in a fail-safe mechanism for their genetic prototypes; Taura would have been dead of old age at twenty-standard without the medical intervention that the Dendarii medics and later the Duronas had supplied her. Roic had met her twice, desperately memorably, the first time when sheíd attended mílordís wedding, the second when mílord and Roic had traveled to Escobar to attend her last days in the Durona hospice.

Mílord sighed. ìI, you, Rowan, and Raven all tried to talk her into it. If her Dendarii insurance hadnít covered it, Iíd have popped for it out of pocket, not that the Duronas would have let me. They still figure they owed her and all the Dendarii mercs involved for their escape from Jacksonís Whole. But Taura wasnít having it at any price.î

What, wake up, still a freak, in some strange place and time, with all my friends gone? Taura had said to the protesting Roic, in that terribly-wrong-for-her thready voice. But you could make new friends! was an argument that had failed to move her, in the exhaustion of her failing metabolism.

Roic made a helpless gesture. ìYou could have overridden her. After she was too far gone to tell, ordered her cryoprepped.î God knew mílord was capable of riding over any number of other peopleís wills.

Mílord shrugged, face sobered in the shared memory. ìThat would have been for our benefit, then. Not for hers. But Taura chose fire over ice. That, at least, I had no trouble understanding. High temperature cremation leaves no DNA.î

Sheíd been indifferent to where her ashes would be scattered, except not Jacksonís Whole, so mílord had provided a burial plot for her urn in his own family cemetery at Vorkosigan Surleau, overlooking the long lake, a task mílord and Roic had seen to personally.
ìNobody,î muttered Roic, ìshould die of old age at thirty-standard.î Certainly not such a blazing spirit as Tauraís had been.
Mílord looked meditative. ìIf the Duronasí or anybody elseís anti-aging research ever succeeds, I wonder if death at three hundred or five hundred will come to seem as outrageous?î

ìOr two thousand,î said Roic, trying to imagine it. Some few Betans and Cetagandans actually made it to almost two centuries, Roic had heard, but their healths had been genetically guaranteed before conception. For random folks alive and afoot already, not a help.

ìNot two thousand, probably,î said mílord. ìSome actuarially-minded wag once calculated that if all the medical causes of death were removed, the average person would still only make it to about eight hundred-standard before encountering some fatal accident. I suppose that means that some would slab themselves at eighteen and some at eighteen hundred, but it would still be the same game in the end. Just set to a new equilibrium.î
ìMakes you wonder about the Refusers.î

ìIndeed. If the God they posit waited billions of years for them to be born, a few hundred extra years till they die should hardly make a difference to Him.î Mílord stared off into some sort of twisty mílord mind-space. ìAll the worry people expend over not existing after they die, yet nary a one ever seems to spare a moment to worry about not having existed before they were conceived. Or at all. After all, one sperm over and we would have been our sisters, and weíd never have been missed.î
Since there didnít seem an answer to this that didnít make Roicís head hurt trying to think about, he kept silent. They turned in past the sagging chain link gates of Madame Suzeís facility at last.

It took many hours to bring Lisa Satoís core temperature up from deep-cryonic to just below freezing. Miles sent Johannes back to the consulate, and, as the night wore on, took turn-about with Roic napping in a makeshift bunk in a room opposite Ravenís cobbled-together revival lab, set up on the third floor of the old patron intake building. Raven and Medtech Tanaka, too, took the night watch in shifts. Dawn of the new day brought the start of the critical procedures: the flushing of the old cryo-fluid, the swift replacement with what to Miles seemed vats of new synthetic blood. The skin of the supine figure on the procedure table went from clay gray to an encouraging warm ivory with the transfusion. The cryo-fluid gurgled away down the drain.

If theyíd had the time and equipment, not to mention a starter-sample from the patient, whole blood identical to the originalís could have been grown. The synthetic blood lacked the unique white cells the patientís own body produced, so the revived person would have to be in isolation for an indeterminate time following, till her own marrow began to refill the immunity gaps. Miles had been kept asleep through that phase, Raven told him, but then, heíd had a lot more trauma, surgical and otherwise, to heal from. Ako had spent all last evening cleaning and readying the isolation booth.

Raven was maddeningly vague about how soon his patient might be questioned, and made it clear that her children had priority as her first visitors. Miles didnít argue with that; he couldnít think of anything better to motivate the woman to fight her way to her full faculties.

Miles was anxious to offer help, but as they approached the point of no return in the procedures, Raven sat him down at a distance on a stool with a face mask across his mouth. The memorystick around the edges molded to his skin in a flexible but efficient seal, and the electropores even filtered viruses. Still, Miles wasnít entirely sure if it was only to block germs. So he bit his tongue rather than shrieking when Raven muttered, ìDamn itÖ thatís not right.î
ìWhatís not right?î Miles asked, as Raven and the medtech busied themselves about the table and didnít answer.

ìThereís no electrical latency in the brain,î Raven said, just before Miles started to repeat his question, louder. ìIt should be coming up by nowÖ Tanaka, letís try a good old-fashioned shot of shock, here.î

Lisa Satoís head bore something resembling a swimming cap, studded with electronics and sensors, tight to the dark hair plastered flat with cryo-gel. Raven did something to his control screen, and the cap made a snapping noise that made Miles jump and almost topple off his stool. Raven scowled at his readouts. His gloved hand went out, almost unconsciously it seemed to Miles, to massage his patientís limp hand.
ìClose that drain,î Raven said, abruptly and inexplicably, and the medtech hurried to comply. He stepped back a pace. ìThis isnít working.î

The bottom fell out of Milesís stomach in a sickening lurch. ìRaven, you canít stop.î My God, we canít afford to botch this one. Those poor kids are waiting for us to deliver their mother back to them. I promisedÖ

ìMiles, Iíve done over seven thousand revivals. I donít need to spend the next half hour jumping on this poor womanís corpse to know sheís gone. Her brain is slush, on a micro-level.î Raven sighed and turned away from the table, peeling down his mask and drawing off his gloves. ìI know a bad prep when I see one, and that was a bad prep. This wasnít my fault. There was nothing I could do. There was nothing I could ever have done.î Raven was far too controlled a man to throw his gloves across the room and swear, but he hardly needed to; Miles could read his emotions in his set face, the more fierce for the sharp contrast with his usual easy-going cheer.
ìMurderedÖ do you think?î
ìThings can go wrong without someone intending them, you know. In fact, thatís the statistical norm. Though not around you, I suppose.î
ìBut not, I think, in this case.î

Ravenís lips flattened. ìYeah. I can do an autopsy, in a bit, here.î When he had recovered his tone of mind, presumably. ìFind out exactly what kind of bad prep this was. There are a number of choices. I thought there was something odd about the viscosity of that return fluidÖî He paused. ìLet me rephrase that. I bloody insist on the autopsy. I want to know exactly how I was set up for this failure. Because I donít like being set up like this.î

ìAmen,î growled Miles. He slipped off his chair, jerked down his mask, and approached the table with its mute burden. The blood pump was still keeping the skin hopefully flushed, deceptive promise. Absently, Raven reached out and switched it off. The silence hurt.

How was he going to explain this to Jin and Mina? Because Miles knew that would have to be his next task. In his rush and his arrogance, he had taken away their hopeÖ no, heíd only taken away their false hope. This ending was apparently inevitable, however and whenever it was arrived at, now or later, by his hand or anotherís. The reflection didnít console him much.

I will get you justiceÖ no. He wasnít in a position to make any such pledges to them. And I will try sounded too weak, mere preamble to another adult put-off. But guilt fueled his rage against hisótheiróunknown enemy as nothing else could. How odd, how suspect. How futile.

A sharp rap fell on the operating room door. Roic, awake again? He wasnít going to greet the news of their foolís errand with any joy, either. Miles stretched his back, grabbed his cane, walked to the door, and glanced through the narrow glass. And was immediately glad he hadnít just yelled, Come in, Roic! Because standing outside was Consul Vorlynkin, looking harried, with Jin and Mina in tow, one tugging on each arm.

Miles slipped through the door and stood with his back pressed to it. ìWhat are you doing here? You were supposed to wait at the consulate till I called.î As if he couldnít tell, by the way Vorlynkin was being pulled about. He supposed it was a good thing the children seemed to have lost all fear of the man, but it would be better if he hadnít turned to putty in their hands. Yeah, like I should talk.

ìThey insisted,î Vorlynkin explained, unnecessarily. ìI told them she wouldnít be awake till tomorrowóyou told them how unappetizing you looked when you came out of cryoóbut they still insisted. Even if they could only see her through the glass. I donít think they slept all night. Woke me up three timesÖ I thought maybe if they could just see, theyíd settle down. Take naps later, something.î Vorlynkinís voice slowed as he took in Milesís grim stance. So he only mouthed, and did not voice, the words Whatís wrong?

Miles wasnít ready for this now. Hell, he wasnít ready for this ever. Heíd had the unenviable task before of informing next-of-kin or the friends who stood in that place, but theyíd always been adults. Never children, never so wide open and unarmored.

Mina and Jinís excitement was quelled, as they looked at him. Because if things had gone well, wouldnít he be puffing it off already, taking the credit? There was no way to make this better, and only one way to make it over. He wanted to kneel, to grovel, but it seemed only right to look Jin in the eye. He took a deep breath.

ìIím sorry. Iím so sorry. Something went wrong with the cryorevióno, with the cryoprep. There was nothing Raven-sensei could do. We triedÖ we think your mother died during her cryoprep eighteen months ago, or sometime soon after.î
Jin and Mina stood still in shock. But not crying, not yet. They just stared at Miles. Stared and stared.
ìBut we wanted to see her,î said Mina, in a thin little voice. ìYou said we would see her.î
Jinís voice was throaty, husky, entirely unlike himself. ìYou promisedÖî

The trio had fallen apart from each other at the blow of this news. Quite spontaneously and uncharacteristically, Jinís hand found Minaís. Minaís other hand wavered and gripped Vorlynkinís again; he looked down at her in dismay. ìNow?î he said. ìAre you sureÖ ?î His hard gaze rose as if to nail Miles to the wall.
ìThey have a right,î said Miles in reluctance. ìThough I donít know if an ugly memory is better than no memory. I justÖ donít know.î
ìNeither do I,î admitted Vorlynkin.
Minaís chin jutted out. ìI want to see. I want to see her.î
Jin gulped and nodded.
ìWait a moment, thenÖî Miles slippedófledóback through the door and said, ìRaven, we have visitors. Next of kin. Can we, ah, tidy her up a bit?î
Raven the supposed Jacksonian hard-ass looked deeply shaken at this news. ìOh gods, itís not those poor kids? What are they doing here? Must they come in?î
ìTheyíve a right,î Miles repeated, wondering why those words seemed to resonate in his mind. He ought to know, but these days he couldnít blame every memory lapse on his own ten-year-old cryorevival.

Raven, Tanaka and Miles hurried to get the silent figure decently draped, to remove the useless tangle of technology from about her, tubes and electrodes and the strange cap. Miles smoothed the short black hair back over the ears. Its slickness rendered the middle-aged female face sophisticated yet skull-like, and Miles wondered how the childrenís mother had worn her hair. Weird little things like that could matter all out of proportion. A swift and useless tidying-up, this.
Over, let it be over. Miles went to the door and held it wide.

Jin and Mina and Vorlynkin filed through. The look Vorlynkin flicked at Miles in passing had very little love in it. Jin took the consulís free hand as they came up to the tableside. Because who else was there left to hang onto, in this spinning hour?
The children stared some more. Minaís lips parted in bewilderment; Jin raised his eyes to Miles with a half-voiced Huh?
Drawing back in something between outrage and scorn, Mina said, ìBut thatís not our mommy!î

Miles just barely kept himself from blurting, idiotically, Are you sure? Neither set young face held the least doubt. ìThen who,î he choked, wheeling to stare at Raven, at the draped figure on the table, ìwas it that we justÖî Murdered was unfair, as well as inaccurate. And, he suspected, would also be deeply offensive to the upset cryorevival specialist. ìThat we justÖî Fortunately, no one here seemed to expect him to fill in the blank.
ìHer numbers were right,î said Raven. ìÖOr anyway, her numbers were the ones you gave me.î
