So either Miles had grabbed the wrong drawer code from the cryo-storage data, which he knew very well he had not, or the numbers had been fudged somewhere upstream. By somebody. For some reason. Concealment? To protect Lisa Satoís cryo-corpse from kidnapping by her supporters, or someone like the N.H.L.L.? Or by Milesóno, Miles didnít think anyone on Kibou-daini could have imagined a nosy Barrayaran Imperial Auditor taking this interest. Or might it have been a genuine error? In which caseóMiles pictured the millions of cryo-drawers in, under, or around Northbridge alone, and his heart sank. The thought that nobody might actually know where Lisa Sato had been stashed was too horrible to contemplate for more than an instant.

Oróand the notion was so arresting, Miles caught his breathósomeone else had been ahead of him, with the exact same idea. In which caseÖ No. Before his inner visions could proliferate madly, heíd better fasten them down with at least a few facts. Physical ones, not all these trailing tenuous tentacled inductions.

Miles took a deep breath, to slow his hammering heart. ìAll right. All right. Weíll start with what we can know. First is to ID that poor, um, patron. Make that a priority for your autopsy, Raven. Iíll go back to the consulate tight-room andóî Miles broke off as Vorlynkin cleared his throat, ominously.

Vorlynkin nodded to Jin and Mina, clinging together in white-faced silence. Miles wasnít sure whether to read their postures as fear, or anger, though at least they werenít weeping. In either case, Vorlynkin was probably rightóit wouldnít do to discuss the gruesome details of an autopsy in front of them just now, even if the subject wasnít their mother after all. Children, as Miles had reason to know, ranged naturally from deeply sensitive to remarkably bloody-minded; sometimes, confusingly, the same child at different times. Was dealing with women practice for dealing with children? It was likely just as well he didnít have time to follow up that thought. With a sweep of his arms, Miles shepherded Vorlynkin and his charges back out into the corridor.

ìIím so sorry about all this,î Miles repeated inanely. ìI promise youîódamn, he really needed to cull that phrase from his vocabularyóìIím still going to look for your mommy. The problem has just suddenly become a lot more interesting. Er, difficult. Itís just become a bit more difficult. I need more data, dóî Need more data, dammit, was an old mantra of his, almost comforting in its familiarity. Some setbacks were simply setbacks. Others were opportunities breaking down the door in disguise. He was reasoning ahead of his dataóremember, data?óto imagine this was the second sort. Well, that was what experience could grant oneóa high degree of certainty while making oneís mistakesÖ
Mina said, ìBut whatís going to happen to us, now?î
Jin added anxiously, ìYouíre not going to make us go back to Aunt Lorna and Uncle Hikaru, are you?î
ìNo. Or at least, not yet. Consul Vorlynkin will take you back to the consulate for the moment, until we get somewhere with all this, orÖî
ìOr?î Vorlynkin repeated, as Miles trailed off.

ìWeíll get somewhere.î I just donít know where. ìIíll stay here for the clean-up, then join you all there later. When you get back, Vorlynkin, put Lieutenant Johannes on a preliminary data sweep-search for me. I want to try to find that Dr. Leiber, the one who was associated with Lisa Satoís group here in Northbridge eighteen months ago.î Not much of a clue, but he had to go with what little was in hand. Miles wondered just how common that surname was on Kibou. Well, heíd find out shortly.

Vorlynkin nodded, and herded the kids off. Jin looked around as if regretting his lost refuge. Mina reached up and took the consulís hand, which made him twitch a little, possibly with guilt, but he manfully endured. This was clearly distressing for the children. Hell, itís distressing for me.
Roic, sleep-rumpled, stuck his head out the door of the improvised bunk room and squinted as the trio vanished around the corner. ìI heard voices. Whatís going on?î

Miles brought him up to date. His expression, when he learned that theyíd just deftly snatched the wrong body, was all that Miles had pictured. Of, course, you had to have been around Roic for a while to read all the nuances of bland his face and posture could convey. Was there some sort of secret school for armsmen to learn this, or was it all apprenticeship? Armsman-commander Pym was a master, but Roic was catching up.
ìYíknow,î said Roic, as Pym would not have, because Pym would have had an exact bland to cover it, ìif youíd quit while you were winning, right after Wing, weíd be on our way home right now.î
ìWell, I canít quit now,î said Miles tartly.
ìI can see that, mílord.î With a sigh, Roic followed him back into the lab.

Raven had tidied up and was getting ready for his next task. Medtech Tanaka was laying out an array of rather disturbing instruments on a tray next to the cryorevival table. She looked up at their entry and asked, ìWill we still get our free cryorevivals, then?î

ìYes, of course,î said Miles automatically. ìRent, after all.î He was surprised she still trusted them for the task, but was vaguely heartened that she evidently agreed with Ravenís analysis. He did not add, And we might be back; he was growing more cautious. Belatedly.
Raven tapped his fingers on the table and looked over the instruments. ìDo you want me to send any samples out to a commercial lab for analysis, or try to set up something here?î
ìWhich is faster, and which is better?î

ìIf I wanted to do a good job here in-house, Iíd need to bring some of my team from Escobar. This would likely take more time than sending samples out. Either risks drawing attention. Results ought to be the same.î

ìHm. My instinct is to keep this close till we know what weíre dealing with. Iíd say, go as far as you can on your own, and then weíll take stock. My working hypothesis is that this was a deliberate substitution, sometime in the past eighteen months. If we knew who this woman was, where she came from, it might tell us something about who could have put her in Lisa Satoís place.î Or not. ìMakes a difference if she was just swapped out, or if she was actually frozen in place of Sato from the get-go, in which caseÖî
Raven frowned. ìYou think Jin and Minaís mother might still be alive out there? In that case, why didnít she let her poor kids know?î
ìDepends entirely on how dangerous that knowledge might have been.î
Ravenís frown deepened.

ìWell, I can tell you one thing straight off,î said Medtech Tanaka, bending to retrieve a scrap of plastic caul from the waste bin and holding it up to the light. ìThis woman here wasnít frozen in place of the one youíre looking for, not in the past eighteen months at least. This is an older style of wrapping.î
Three heads turned abruptly toward her. ìHow old?î said Miles. ìAnd how do you know?î
Her wrinkled eyelids narrowed. ìOh, heavens. I havenít seen this brand with the hexagonal netting inside since my student days. At least thirty years old, maybe fifty?î
Miles groaned. ìSo this woman could have come from any time in the last two hundred and fifty years?î
ìNo, because there were other styles and brands before then. And after. This type was only on the market for about three decades.î
ìThank you, Medtech Tanaka,î said Miles. ìThatís a start.î
His mystery, it seemed, had just split into two. Mystery mitosis. It seemed a retrograde sort of progress.
Raven lifted his first instrument and bent to his patient-turned-subject.

It was very quiet in the lift van for the first part of the trip back to the consulate. Jinís throat was choked with disappointment. Mina, strapped in the middle of the next seat to the rear, was pale and withdrawn. Vorlynkin negotiated traffic by hand till they were well away from Suze-sanís, then linked to the municipal control grid and leaned back with a sigh.
He hitched around sideways to regard Jin and Mina both. ìIím really sorry about all this mix-up.î
ìIt wasnít your fault,î Jin conceded.

Vorlynkin opened his mouth to say something, evidently thought better of it, and substituted simply, ìThank you.î After a moment he added, ìAlthough if you two had been my daughter, Iíd have been furious to have you dragged into something like this.î
Before Jin could say, But I thought we dragged you in, Mina piped up eagerly, ìYou have a daughter? How old is she? Can she play with us?î
Vorlynkin grimaced. ìAnnahís six, so she probably would like to play with you, but Iím afraid not. Sheís on Escobar. With her mother.î
ìAre they coming back soon?î asked Mina.
ìNo.î Vorlynkin hesitated. ìWeíre divorced.î
Both Jin and Mina flinched a little at the scary word.
ìWhy are you divorced?î asked Mina. If theyíd been sitting together, Jin could have kicked her in the ankle to shut her up, but unfortunately she was out of reach.

Vorlynkin shrugged. ìIt wasnít anyoneís fault, really. She was an Escobaran. I met her when I was stationed at the embassy there as a junior secretary. When we first married, I thought it was understood that she would follow where my career took me. But by the time I was offered the promotion and the transfer to the Barrayaran embassy on Pol, Annah had come along. And my wife changed her mind. With a baby to look out for, she didnít want to leave the security of her family and her homeworld. Or she didnít trust me enough. Or something.î

After a silence, which Jin endured in faint embarrassment and Mina, apparently, in deep fascination, Vorlynkin added, ìMy ex-wife remarried recently. Another Escobaran. She wrote me that her new husband wants to adopt Annah. I donít know. It might be better for her than a father she sees for maybe three days every three years. Itís hard to decide. To let go.î He had been talking to his lap but, unexpectedly, he raised his shrewd blue glance to Jin and Mina. ìWhat do you think?î
Mina blinked, and blurted, ìIíd want my real daddy.î
Vorlynkin didnít look terribly cheered by this reply. Jin said more cautiously, ìIt depends, I guess. If heís a nice guy or not.î
ìI assume so. I havenít met him yet. I suppose I ought to take some time and go do that, before signing off. Maybe visiting again would just confuse Annah. Surely she canít remember much about me.î
ìDonít you send her messages and stuff?î asked Mina, frowning.
ìSometimes.î

Jin said slowly, ìCouldnít you have chosen to stay with your wife back then? Instead of going to Pol?î Wherever that was. Pretty far from Escobar, it sounded like. ìBeing a diplomat isnít like being a soldier, is it? Arenít you allowed to quit?î
Vorlynkin gave Jin an ironic salute, just a finger-touch to his forehead, and Jin felt even more uncomfortable. Maybe he shouldnít have pointed that out?
ìYes, I could have made that choice. Then. I couldnít go back now, of course. That chance has gone beyond recall.î
Minaís frown deepened to a scowl. ìIt sounds like you already picked.î
ìMy younger self did, yes. I have to wonder about him, some daysÖî The autopilot beeped as they approached the consulate, and somewhat to Jinís relief Vorlynkin turned away to re-take the controls.

Back in the consulate kitchen, Vorlynkin fixed them all a snack, then went off to the officelike front room to see about something his clerk wanted. Mina snitched Lucky and went upstairs. Jin went outside to check on all his creatures. By the time he arrived in the bedroom he shared with his sister, she was curled up on her bed around the cat, possessively. Lucky endured being clutched like a stuffed toy without protest beyond a lazy tail-twitch or two.

Jin was much too old to take a nap in the daytime, but his bed did look awfully inviting. He supposed if he tried to take Lucky away from Mina, sheíd just set up a screech. Maybe wait till she fell asleep? Her face was stiff and blotchy, her eyes red, as if sheíd been crying.
As he sat on his bed and plotted his recapture of the cat, Mina sniffed and said, ìThey lied.î
ìGrownups always lie.î Jin brooded. ìMom lied. She always said everything was going to be all right, and it wasnít.î

ìHuh.î Mina curled tighter, face scrunching, and sniffed again. In a little while, both face and grip relaxed, and Jin bent over and fished Lucky back, careful not to wake Mina. He stroked the cat till she purred in concession to the trade, then went to curl up with her on his own bed. It was a nice bed, nicer than anything heíd had at Suze-sanís, but he still wished he was back there. Maybe grouchy old Yani had been right after all to want to leave Miles-san in the streetÖ

He was wakened by Roic calling his name, big hand gently shaking his shoulder. Mina was already sitting up and rubbing the creases from her pillow out of her face. Lucky had gone off somewhere. The light on the carpet had shifted around. Jin glanced at the clock and realized that a couple of hours had slipped away.
ìSorry to wake you,î said Roic. ìMílord wants you to take a look at something on the comconsole in the tight-room.î

Roic waited patiently while both children visited the bathroom, making sure theyíd washed their hands before following him downstairs. Now that he was getting used to the big man, Jin kind of liked Roic. For Miles-san, it must be like owning your own private grownup, following you around and doing stuff for you. Except you got to tell him what to do, instead of the other way around. Jin wished he owned a Roic.

There was a crowd in the strange sealable basement room where, Jin had figured out by now, the consulate kept all the nifty secret spy stuff. Miles-san and Vorlynkin sat at one comconsole. Raven-sensei had returned, and was bent over the long table along with Johannes, attending upon a small machine.
Jin dodged over to them. ìWhatís that?î
ìDNA scanner,î said Johannes.
ìIs that what you used to check Miles-saóLord Vorkosiganís thumbprint, that first day?î
ìYes.î

ìHandy,î said Raven-sensei. ìThere should have been one at Madame Suzeís, but evidently it was sold off or broken some time ago. I was afraid I was going to have to take the tissue sample to a commercial lab for even this basic data.î
Jinís interest rose. ìCould I make scans of my creaturesí DNA on it?î
ìItís not a toy,î said Johannes. ìWe use it for making positive IDs of people wanting travel documents and so on.î He looked at Jin and weakened. ìYouíll have to ask Counsel Vorlynkin.î

Miles-san called Jin over to his comconsole, where Mina was already standing and shifting from foot to foot. Still-shots of four different men hovered in a row above the vid plate. Two had gray hair. One wore a white laboratory coat.

ìMiss Mina, Iím hoping you can help us out, here,î said Miles-san. ìAll these men are different Dr. Leibers who live around greater Northbridge. Weíve already eliminated the female Dr. Leibers, trusting none has made a trip to Beta Colony lately.î His mouth twisted up at some joke that Jin didnít understand, although Roic did, judging from his short smile. ìDo any of them look like the man you overheard talking to your mommy, that night? Or, do any of them definitely not look like him?î
Mina peered anxiously at the scans. ìIt was a long time ago. I donít really remember.î
ìDo you remember anything at all? Was your Dr. Leiber young, or old?î
ìOh, old.î
ìGray hair?î
ìNo, black. I do remember that much. Iím not too good at telling grownupsí ages. But he was real old. Thirty, maybe?î
Miles-san and Vorlynkin exchanged a look; the consulís lips twitched, but he didnít say anything.

ìSo, old but not gray.î Miles-san tapped the vid controls, and the two gray-haired men vanished. The other two looked rather alike, with similar haircuts, except oneís face was bonier and the otherís more round.
ìWhen I was a wee little kid,î remarked Roic, watching over their shoulders, ìthere was a time I thought that any skinny old man I saw was my grandfather. It was pretty confusing.î
ìNevertheless,î said Miles-san. ìJin, do you remember ever seeing either of these two men in your motherís company? Even if you werenít introduced?î
Jin shook his head.
After a long hesitation, Mina pointed at bony-face. ìThat one. Maybe. The other one seems too fat.î
ìHe might have gained weight,î Jin offered helpfully, getting into the spirit of this.
ìShow her scans of a hundred fellows,î said Roic, ìor even ten, and I doubt sheíd be able to tell, mílord. Youíre leading your witness.î

ìIf we had to look at the entire pool of elderly gents of thirty on Kibou, that would doubtless be true,î said Miles-san. ìFortunately, we have some other sorting constraints.î He pointed at round-face. ìThis Dr. Leiber is an obstetrician at a replicator clinic in a northern suburb.î His finger swung to bony-face. ìThis Dr. Leiber is a biochemist working for NewEgypt Cryonics. Given that Minaís witness does not positively eliminate him, that combination puts him at the top of my to-do list.î
ìWhat happened to your theory that the fellow must have fled?î asked Roic. ìThis Leiber doesnít look much like an activist. I meanógood salary, stock options, cryo-insurance. A company man, belike.î
Miles-san sat back and rubbed his chin. ìThat is a problem, true. Maybe I was wrong, before.î
Roic gave him a head-tilt, which induced a fleeting grin on Miles-sanís face for no reason that Jin could see.

Johannes and Raven-sensei had finished their task at the table and taken over the satellite comconsole. Now Raven-sensei said, ìAh! Is there a face scan of her? I have fingerprints and footprints for back-up, butóno, weíre not going to need them, are we.î
Miles-san shoved his chair back with his feet and swung around. ìWhat have you found over there?î

Roic bent and peered. ìAye, that does look like our woman, doesnít it? Look at her cheek bones. And her ears. And that same mole above her left eyebrow. This scan must have been taken pretty near the time she was frozen.î
ìCanít say as Iíd noticed her earsÖî Miles-san grabbed his cane and stood up to get a better view.

Jin wriggled in to look, too. Comparing the picture of the live, smiling woman with that still, alien figure theyíd seen on the treatment table made him queasy all over again. Would his mother look all strange like that if she died for real?

ìGood, this file has it all,î said Raven-sensei. ìBiographical data, medical history, date of cryoprepÖ well, her contract and her financial data would seem to be cross-referenced elsewhere. Alice Chen, poor unlucky woman. I suppose Iím glad to know her name.î
ìThat was fast work,î said Miles-san. ìGood job.î

ìThese patron data bases are pretty open to the public,î said Johannes, though he straightened a little at the praise. ìAnyone from lawyers to academics doing demographic studies to medical researchers to just genealogists scouting their family trees can get in.î He sat back, staring into the screen of data the vid plate had flung up. ìLooks like she was frozen about forty-five years ago. Thatís lucky. You get back more than about a century and the data banks tend to have holes, from one cause or another.î

ìYeah, when I was, uh, working in my prior career, this planet used to be a favored source for untraceable false IDís,î said Miles-san. ìIt was the only reason Iíd ever heard of the place, before this investigation.î He squinted and pointed to a line. ìWhat the devilís that unpronounceable polysyllable?î
Raven-sensei looked. ìDebilitating blood disease. Might have been why she chose to freeze a bit early.î
ìCause of death, do you think?î
Raven-sensei shook his head. ìNo, it shouldnít have affected her revival. She would have needed treatment later, though.î
ìCould she have had it? Effective treatment, that is?î
ìOh, yes, that oneís under control these days.î

ìSo what,î said Miles-san, ìwas a woman frozen nearly half a century ago doing in Lisa Satoís cryo-drawer with Lisa Satoís ID tag on her foot? Itís plain she didnít get there by herself. While someone could have just cooked the drawer file numbers in the data banks, that damn tag pretty much guarantees it must have been a physical switch.î

ìWhere are your Madame Chenís remains now, by the way?î said Consul Vorlynkin. ìThey really ought to be returned to her next of kin at some point. There may be an inheritance tied up, or who knows what. And her death is recent enough that someone still alive may have an emotional interest in her fate.î He hesitated. ìNot that Iím looking forward to the lawsuits.î
ìSheís tucked away downstairs at Madame Suzeís, for now,î said Raven-sensei. ìTenbury helped out.î
ìWill she keep?î asked Miles-san.
ìIndefinitely.î

Miles-san opened his hand to Vorlynkin. ìKeep she must, till Iíve untangled all this. But hold that thought. So, now we have two ends, our straying dead lady and Dr. Leiber. It remains to follow them up and see if they meet in the middle. Was she frozen by NewEgypt, by the way?î
Johannes scrolled down. ìBy one of the cryocorps that NewEgypt later took over, I think.î
ìOn that same site?î

ìI donít think it was built out there yet, forty-five years back.î Johannes bent to a flurry of searches. ìAh, here we go. The place she was originally kept seems to have been decommissioned about ten years ago. Torn down. They moved her out to the new facility at the Cryopolis then.î

ìThat would certainly have made it easy for someone to swap her out,î said Miles-san. ìEspecially if the swapper was already on the inside, like an employee. Iím thinking Madame Chen was chosen at random. Who they wanted was Lisa Sato.î
ìAre you saying somebody stole Mommy?î asked Mina, a quaver in her voice.
ìItís beginning to look that wayÖî Miles-san narrowed his eyes at the vid screen.
Vorlynkinís grip on his shoulder and exasperated head-jerk toward Mina returned Miles-sanís attention to her. She looked like she was trying not to cry.
Miles-san made quick revision. ìAlthough you have to figure, whoever took her had to care about her. You donít steal something you donít value. Suggests they would be careful with her.î
Grownup lies? On the whole, Jin liked that Miles-san didnít talk down to him and Mina, but this was all just too weird.
As Mina failed to look encouraged, Miles-san babbled on, ìAfter all, the portable cryochamber I was in was lost for a time, but it all came out right in the end.î
ìLost from your sideís point of view,î said Raven-sensei. ìFrom our point of view, it was found.î
Miles-san gave Mina a big There, see? sort of smile, which faltered at her blank stare. Vorlynkin and Johannes were gazing at him in horrified fascination.
Miles drew himself up. ìIím going to go talk to this Dr. Leiber. In person. Not at his work, I think,î he added, his voice slowing in thought.
Roicís mouth set in a grim line. ìYou will have a proper security perimeter.î
ìCertainly. Weíll even take Johannes, so you wonít have to be the perimeter all by yourself.î
ìItís a start.î

Miles-san studied Mina, who was still shifting fretfully. ìThe connection between Dr. Leiber and your mother exists nowhere in the records Iíve seen so faróonly in your witness, Miss Mina. If anything comes of it, it will be entirely due to the valuable intelligence you supplied.î
She cheered a little at this, or at least her lip stopped quivering. ìReally?î
ìReally. And valuable ImpSec informants get paid, you know. So do couriers, I am reminded,î he added with a glance at Jin.
ìBut I didnít finish the job,î said Jin.
ìCapture by the enemy rates hazard pay, actually.î
ìHow much?î asked Mina, brightening a lot more.

ìAh, I like the way you think, kid. Thereís actually an official pay schedule. In Barrayaran marks, of course. It has codes for various services. Iíll have Roic check it, and do the conversions to Kibou-daini money.î
ìYou propose to pay them adult rates?î asked Vorlynkin. Jin thought he sounded more startled than disapproving, and hoped he wouldnít try to talk Miles-san out of this wonderful idea.
ìDamn straight.î Miles-san added, ìMy case budget allows for a lot of discretion, you know.î
ìThen I wish youíd buy some,î snapped Vorlynkin. He shut his mouth abruptly, as if startled at what had fallen out of it.

Miles-san merely grinned at him. His stiff consul-face back in place, Vorlynkin shepherded Jin and Mina back up to the kitchen to feed them again. Jin glanced back over his shoulder at the four men turning intently back to their comconsoles, as that heavy door swung shut. He hoped the consulate had good spy stuff.

Dr. Seiichiro Leiber proved to live in a rented row-house in a residential district on the west side of Northbridge, not far from his work. Miles had Johannes, driving the lift van, circle the block to give him a feel for the neighborhood. On this pleasant weekend morning, not a few folks were out tending their tiny plots of greenery; a gang of children raced noisily across the lawns, got yelled at by a gardener, and vanished, giggling, around the corner. Jin and Mina might well have grown up in a place much like this.

Milesís more focused researches last night had mainly turned up Leiberís school records, with police records drawing a bland and virtuous blank. He wasnít listed on any of Lisa Satoís rosters of supporters or contributors, nor did his name appear among the arrestees at the rally riot, most of whom had been released without being charged. Charges had been made but later dropped against the two dead and the three, including Sato, whoíd been suspiciously frozen. All tidy and quiet now.

This Dr. Leiber had acquired his Ph.D. at the unprecocious age of twenty-eight, and gone directly into employment with NewEgypt for the four years subsequently. His thesis, which Miles had readówell, skimmedóhad focused on improvements in cryonics fluids, which, given that a consortium of cryocorps had funded his scholarship, seemed perfectly reasonable. Several of the larger cryocorps maintained research departments that, in addition to overseeing quality control, worked on proprietary advances in their procedures designed to lure customers from their competition. Nothing odd about that, either.

Miles had Johannes pull up at the corner. ìI think our biggest problem here is going to be nosy neighbors, not electronic surveillance. You arenít going to be able to sit or stand around without people coming out to see what youíre up to. So Iíll run an open comlink to you, JohannesîóMiles set his to record while he was at itóìand you find a place to pull in and buy coffee or something. Drop Roic around back on the way.î Miles eyed his bodyguard, dressed fairly neutrally but not quite locally. ìI wish we could disguise you as a lamp post or something.î
ìIíll manage,î said Roic.
Miles nodded, waved Raven to follow him, and descended to the sidewalk.

The door buzzer was answered by a dark-haired, blinking fellow with a tea mug in his hand, wearing a T-shirt and trousers, barefoot. Despite the weekend jaw shadow and lack of a lab coat, he was immediately recognizable as Milesís quarry.
Miles smiled. ìDr. Leiber?î Not giving the man time to answer, he continued, ìMy name is Miles Vorkosigan, and this is my associate, Dr. Raven Durona of the Durona Group.î
A flash of recognition crossed Leiberís face at the latter name, followed by puzzlement. ìDurona?î said Leiber. ìFrom the Escobar clinic?î
ìOh, youíve heard of us?î Raven smiled sunnily.
ìI read the journals.î

Miles forged on, ìWe were both in town for the inter-Nexus cryo-conference last week, and hoped to see you. May we come in?î Leaving implied that the associate was bio-research. Miles would save the insinuation of interstellar cops for after theyíd made it through the front door, and only if needed.

At this reasonable-sounding explanation, Leiber gulped down his last swallow of tea and gave way. Miles hustled gratefully inside. He let his host guide them into his little living room, and took a seat promptly, the harder to be dislodged. The others naturally followed suit. ìDid you attend the conference? I donít recall seeing you.î In fact, Miles had checkedóLeiber hadnít been there.
ìNo, but I was sorry to have missed it. Were you fellows caught up in that mess I saw on the news with the N.H.L.L.?î

ìI wasnít, but Raven here wasóî Miles gave Raven a go-ahead, and Raven supplied a few ice-breaking anecdotes about his brief adventures as a hostage, with the Barrayaran connections downplayed. Raven then went into a technical riff about the conference, drawing Leiber into questions in turn, equally divided between biochemistry and scurrilous gossip. He also touched on Leiberís thesis, which Raven had actually read all the way through last night without his eyes glazing over. By this time Leiber seemed fully at ease.
Miles decided on a direct approach. ìIím actually here this morning on behalf of the next-of-kin of Lisa Sato. I believe you had some dealings with her eighteen months ago, just before her arrest?î
Shock and dismay bloomed unconcealed on Leiberís face. Well, he was the scientist type, not a con artist, nor, probably, a very good liar. Fine by me.
ìHow do you knowówhat makes you think that?î Leiber fumbled, confirming Milesís judgment.
ìEyewitness testimony.î
ìBut no one sawóthere wasnítóbut Suwabi died.î
ìThere was one other.î
Leiber gulped and seemed to pull himself together. ìIím sorry. It was an awkward time. A frightening time.î
Miles prepared to utter something soothing, but his witness leaped to his feet. ìIím sorry, youíve rattled me a bit. Some tea. Iíll fix some more tea. Would you like some tea?î

Miles would rather not have given him time to invent lies, which they would then have to spend more time pulling apart, but he was already headed to his tiny kitchen. Miles waved an assent that Leiber didnít even look back to see.
Raven raised an eyebrow at Miles. ìCongratulations.î
ìIndeed, a hit, a palpable hit.î
Dishes rattled, water ran. A faint squeak and quiet tick of a door opening and closingÖ
ìWhoops.î Miles grabbed his cane and lurched to his feet.
The kitchen was empty, silent but for the simmering electric kettle. Only one door led out. Onto the patio, its alley gate swinging.
Miles lifted his wristcom to his lips. ìRoic? Our suspect just ran out the back.î
ìIím on him, mílord,î Roic said grimly.
The thump of big footsteps, quick gasps. A yelp, not from Roic. More footsteps. ìCrap.î
That last had been Roic. ìWhat happened?î Miles demanded.

Roic, a little breathless, returned, ìHe just dodged into a neighborís place. Gone to ground. Thereís a woman and two kids staring at me out the glass. Now sheís arguing with Leiber. Well, sheís arguing, heís wheezing.î And, after a moment, ìYou donít want me to go in there. Trespassing. Assault.î
Roicís very firm tone of voice discouraged Miles from descanting on diplomatic immunity. He continued, ìNow sheís gone off. To call the police, Iím guessing. What did you two do to the fellow?î
Nothing was plainly not the right answer. ìIím not sure,î Miles said. ìWell, withdraw for now and rendezvous with Johannes.î
ìUnderstood.î
Miles turned to Raven. ìAll right, we have maybe five minutes to go over the place here. You take downstairs, Iíll take up.î
ìWhat are we looking for?î
ìWhatever heís hiding.î

Upstairs held a bedroom, a bedroom-turned-office, and a bathroom. An endearingly tame, by galactic standards, porn collection in the bedroom was out in plain sight, suggesting Leiber did not have a girlfriend at present. The closets held clothes and shoes, and a residue of old sporting equipment. Miles was just eyeing the comconsole in the next room in frustrationóhe likely didnít have time for a stealth download before the locals arrived, and besides the ImpSec devices that made such tasks a snap were back at the consulateówhen Ravenís voice came from his wristcom.
ìMiles?î
ìWeíve got to fly, RavenóI expect the police are on their way by now.î
ìI donít think heíll have called them, actually.î An arresting remark, for all that it was delivered in an amused drawl.
ìWhat have you found down there?î
ìCome look.î
Miles made his way down the stairs with rather more care than heíd pelted up them, collecting his cane on the way.

The lowest levelóit was not quite a basementóof Leiberís townhouse was much as one might expect: a laundry area, the mechanical and electrical guts of the dwelling, a larger room left half-finished for dirty projects or whatever were the ownerís needs. Leiberís need seemed to be for a great deal of junk stowage. Raven stood between a dusty exercise machine and a long shape covered with an old bedspread.
ìTah-dah!î he cried, and whisked off the bedspread. Revealing a portable cryochamber. Plugged into the house power. Running, and apparently occupied.
ìDo we know what weíre both thinking?î asked Raven.
ìYeah,î said Miles, with proper admiration. ìAlthoughÖ could it be it normal to keep frozen people in your basement? Around here, I mean?î
ìDonít know,î said Raven, running his hands over the machine in a search for identifying marks. ìYouíd have to ask Johannes, or Vorlynkin. Or Jin. What I wonder is how he ever got it in here.î
ìDark of night, at a guess.î

ìNo, I mean how he got it down the stairs. It would never make the turn. There has to beóah, garage door. Thatís better.î Raven climbed over some junk, opened it, and stuck his head through. ìOoh, nice float bike.î

Miles checked underneath the cryochamber. It was a less expensive model, without a built-in float pallet, but it was propped up on stacks of miscellaneous bricks, concrete blocks, and a wedge of squashed flimsiesóthe top one seemed to be a scientific paperórevealing where a float pallet had been slid out from underneath. No sign of the pallet in the other piles.
He raised his wristcom. ìJohannes?î
ìI just picked up Roic, sir,î Johannes returned at once. ìShould we swing around to get you now?î
ìOne question, first. Do you still have the float pallet on board that we used the other day?î
ìYes, sorry, I havenít had time to return it to the rental place yet.î
ìExcellent. Come around to the back of the row. There will be a sunken garage entry. Weíll meet you there. I have some heavy lifting for you.î
ìOn our way.î
Raven raised his eyebrows. ìIsnít that theft? Breaking and entering?î

ìNo, the homeowner let us in. Breaking and exiting, maybe. If itís theft, Iím guessing itís the second time around for this item. And while itís not true that you canít cheat an honest man, crooked men are less likely to complain to the authorities, afterward. I donít think Leiber will tell anyone.î He went on, still peering underneath, ìDid you spot any IDs on this thing?î
ìMakerís mark. Itís a common brand. Ah, hereís a serial number. That may help.î
ìLater, yeah.î First things first. If I donít know how to recognize and seize a tactical moment by nowÖ He could be spectacularly wrong. Or spectacularly right. In any case, itíll be spectacular.

By the time Johannes and Roic arrived with the van, they had the garage door open. Leaving muscle to do what muscle did best, Miles repaired upstairs to the kitchen and searched for something to write with, and on. A half-composed grocery list and a stylus came to hand. He thought, turned the list over, bent, and scribbled.
Roic came up to find him. ìA bit awkward, but we horsed it in. Had to lean on the rear hatch to close it. What are you doing?î
ìLeaving Leiber a note.î Miles affixed it to the refrigerator door.
ìWhat tí devilÖ ?î Roic bent to read it. ìWhat kind of burglar leaves a note?î
Miles was actually rather proud of the vague wording. Call on me at my consulate at your earliest convenience. Not even an initial in signature.

ìWe never finished our conversation,î Miles explained. ìWe now have something he wants. Heíll come. Saves putting a trace on him, at least. Damn. Johannes is the only one of us he hasnít seen yet, but I need him for other tasks. Youíll be glad to know I now regret not having brought that ImpSec team you always want.î
ìCold comfort,î sighed Roic. ìWhy not just wait for Leiber to come back?î

ìHe wonít, not while weíre here. If Iíve guessed right he risked his job, maybe his life, to secure what we found in the basement. Heíll be skittish, till he has time to calm down and think it through.î And then heíll be terrified.
After considerately closing the garage door behind them, they all piled back into the lift van. ìTo Madame Suzeís,î Miles directed Johannes. ìCircuitously and sedately.î
Raven leaned over the seat back. ìYou know, if weíve just stolen that poor manís grandmother, weíre going to be very embarrassed.î
Miles grinned, exhilarated. ìThen weíll simply return her. Leave her on the lawn after dark. Or maybe ship her back anonymously. No, it would take a lot more than that to embarrass me.î
The thought was less amusing when Miles remembered yesterday morningís debacle. He wasnít sure if that noise from Roic was a sigh or a snort, but in either case, he elected to ignore it.

Back when heíd been a young municipal street guard for the town of Hassadar, Roic had undergone first-aid training. Later, after taking the solemn oath of a Countís Armsman, heíd been sent off for a much more advanced course in military field aid. It had included how to do an emergency cryoprep, with practice on a disturbingly realistic and anatomically complete model person and fake cryo-fluid. It hadnít given him nightmares. Helping shift Madame Satoís body onto the procedure table, he wasnít so sure that would remain the case.

Cutting away the protective caul and prepping the still form, Raven and Medtech Tanaka were too professional to permit much embarrassment on the helpless womanís behalf. But she didnít look like the model, she didnítóquiteólook like a corpse, and she didnít look alive, either. Maybe no one had a slot in their old ape brain for this. Yet if he ever had to perform a cryoprep for real, God forbid, Roic suspected this experience would help him do a better job, knowing what all those rote steps were aimed at. He was conscious of an odd sense of privilege.

At least mílord had made damned sure he had the right woman this time, after that unholy mess day before yesterday. Fortunately, heíd stopped short of bringing in those poor kids to ID his new prize last night, after theyíd got her to Suzeís and unwrapped her. This time around, Jin and Mina hadnít even been told she was found yet. When heíd asked mílord, But which is better? Mílord had replied simply, Neither. Which just about summed it up.

Roic tried not to flinch as Raven punched the assorted tubings through thawed skin and carefully seated them in his vessels-of-choice. Roic did start at a brief rap on the door, and turned on his heel, alert.
Consul Vorlynkin stuck his head in. ìLord Vorkosigan, a message cameóoh.î
ìYou didnít bring the kids this time, did you?î demanded mílord, alarmed.
ìNo, no. Johannes is baby-sitting. They still donít know.î
ìWhew. Though perhaps you could bring them over soon, if all goes well.î
ìAnd if it doesnít?î asked Vorlynkin grimly.
Mílord sighed. ìThen maybe I can bring them.î
ìYou can come in,î said Raven over his shoulder, ìbut you have to put on a filtering mask. You canít hang in the doorway like a cat.î
Ako hastened to hand Vorlynkin a mask, and helped him adjust it; he grimaced as the memoryseal bonded to his skin. He came cautiously up to the procedure table. ìI did wonder what this was like.î
ìAny problems so far?î mílord asked. He was perched on a tall stool, partly to oversee the procedure, but mostly, Roic suspected, to block him from pacing.

ìNot yet,î said Raven. He reached over and started the first flush of warmed, hyper-oxygenated IV fluid. His patientís skin began to turn from clay gray to an ethereal ice-pale. Someone had made an unexpected effort to preserve her long hair, treated with gel and rolled in a wrapping; it lay curled like a snail shell above her shoulder. Ms. Chenís hair had been cropped in a medically utilitarian bob.

Madame Sato was taller than Roic had expected, fully five-foot-eight. That and her dark hair gave her a slight, unsettling resemblance to mílordís wife Lady Ekaterin, actually, which Roic elected not to point out. Satoís face was a rounder shape, if also stretched over a fine symmetrical scaffolding of jaw and cheekbone, and her body was thinner in a way that suggested stress rather than athleticism. An elf-lady strung out on bad drugs and bad company.
ìSheís not whatÖî Vorlynkin stared, mesmerized. ìI thought you said sheíd look terrible. Skin flaking and bleeding, hair falling out and so on.î

ìThere wasnít a thing wrong with her when they put her in cryo-stasis,î said Raven, ìand this appears to have been first-class prep, and recent at that. When he arrived on our operating table, Lord Vorkosigan was in much worse shape than average. To put it mildly. I suppose someone has to be better, to keep the average balanced.î
ìShe looks like something out of a fairy tale.î
ìWhat,î said mílord, swinging one heel to tap upon a stool leg, ìSnow White with just one dwarf?î
Vorlynkin reddened, an I-didnít-say-that look in his eyes.
Mílord snickered at him. ìNow all we need is a prince.î
ìSo whoís tí frog?î asked Roic, secretly glad not to be alone in his fanciful impressions.
ìDifferent fairy tale,î mílord told him kindly. ìI hope.î

Raven switched tubing, and the clear fluid was replaced with dark red. The ice-woman look slowly changed, the skin tone shifting through faint pinkness like a chill spring to a warmer gold-ivory, as though she was receiving a transfusion of summer. At length, Raven closed the exit line draining from her leg, sealing vein and skin with plastic bandage. Raven and Tanaka fussed about with the leads and wires and the strange cap. ìClear,î Raven called, looking up to be sure his amateur audience had stepped back. The snap of the electrical stimulus was quieter than Roic had expected, but still made him recoil.

For the first time, the silent womanís chest rose, and her skin seemed suddenly not just pliable but alive. A few moments of uneven stuttering, while Tanaka watched their monitors and Raven stared narrow-eyed at his patient. His face was calm but his gloved hands, Roic noticed, were clenched. Then her lips parted on a longer indrawn breath, then another, and Ravenís fists relaxed. Roic remembered to exhale before he disgraced himself by passing out, but only just.
ìGot it in one,î said Raven, and shut down the external pump.
Mílordís eyes squeezed closed in gratitude. Vorlynkin, transfixed, breathed, ìThatís astounding.î
ìI just love this part,î Raven confided, to the air generally as far as Roic could tell. ìIt makes me feel quite godlike. Or at least wizardly.î
Mílordís lips twitched. ìAre you saying this is an ego-trip for you?î
ìThe best ever,î agreed Raven. ìI live for these moments.î
ìAlways glad to see a man happy in his work,î mílord murmured.

Raven circled his patientís body, tapping here and there with a stylus in a pattern Roic suspected was meaningful. And very old. ìWe have reflexes. Peripheral nerves are firing up nicely,î he reported. He returned to her head, smoothing a stray strand of hair back from her forehead in a curiously tender gesture. ìMadame Sato?î he called. ìLisa?î

The eyelids fluttered, opened, squeezed shut. The lids bore the epicanthic folds of her Earth ancestry, the eyes the classic almond shape. The irises were a rich, dark brown, further reducing her resemblance to Lady Vorkosigan, whose eyes were a striking blue-gray.
ìHearingís working,î Raven murmured. ìGrossly, at least.î And, ìLisa?î he repeated. ìAre you with us yet?î

It could hardly be reassuring to the woman to open her eyes on a circle of masked faces, like bandits. Especially if the last thing she remembered were the faces of her all-but-murderers. Had they been leering? Coolly professional? Indifferent? But bandits indeed, stealing her will, her world, her life from her.
Roic leaned in. In his best reassuring guardsmanís tones, he tried, ìMaíam, youíre all right. Safe and alive. Rescued. Your children are both safe and secure as well. Youíll get to see them soon.î
Another fluttering of lids; a moan.
ìAnd larynx,î said Raven happily. ìThat should please you, my Lord Auditor.î
ìIndeed,î said mílord.
She sighed again, the tension passing out of her.
ìSheíll sleep for some hours, after this,î said Raven. ìThe longer, the better.î
ìWeíll clean her up and move her to the isolation booth,î said Medtech Tanaka. ìAko, you can help with the skin treatment.î

Tubes and needles were pulled away, lines coiled up, machines turned off. Roic helped shift the live woman off the procedure table onto the transfer cart. Mílord slid down from his stool, stretched his back, and leaned on his cane. ìHow soon till we can move her to the consulate?î

ìDepends on her white blood count, and a few other things,î said Raven. ìBut possibly as early as the day after tomorrow. Youíll have to keep her quiet in one of those upstairs bedrooms for a few days.î
ìWe can do that,î said Vorlynkin.
Mílord turned his head toward the consul. ìWait, why are you here? Has Leiber shown up?î

ìNo, not yet. You have a sealed message from Barrayar thatís arrived in the tight-room. We canít access it, so I donít know how urgent it may be.î He added with reluctant honesty, ìAlso, I was curious how this was going. Given the need to deal with Mina and Jin.î He didnít want to be blindsided again, Roic read this. Understandable.
ìAh, all right,î said mílord. ìRaven, if youíre on top of things here, I guess I can go back.î

Raven waved assent and turned to follow the medtech and Ako, trundling his patient away. The room seemed very empty when theyíd left, disconsolate and messy like the morning after a winter solstice party.

Vorlynkin blinked and rolled his shoulders, as if trying to come back into himself from somewhere far away. ìThat was very strange. Iíve never seen anyone die, but thisóit was like watching time run backwards. Or something.î
ìI have, and yes,î said mílord.
ìWere we playing god?î Vorlynkin asked uneasily.

ìNo more so than the people who put her down in the first place. And our cause is much more just.î Mílord added in a mutter, ìI hope.î Frowning, he fished out his Auditorís seal on its chain for a slightly cross-eyed downward glance. ìSealed message, eh? You know, when I was Jinís age, Iíd have been thrilled to own a secret decoder ring. Now I have one, it feels more like a sack of bricks. Thereís something sadly out of phase about that.î

When mílord limped off to exchange one last word with Raven, Roic found himself briefly alone with the consul, who gazed in bemusement up the corridor after the short, retreating form. ìLord Vorkosigan is not exactly what I expected, when I was told the consulate should prepare for a visit from an Imperial Auditor.î

Roic, stoutly, didnít snicker. ìThe nine Imperial Auditors are actually a pretty varied lot, once you meet them. Lord Auditor Vorthys, whoís also míladyís uncle, looks like a rumpled old engineering professor because thatís exactly what he is. Thereís this crusty admiral, a retired diplomat, an industrialistÖ mílordís become more-or-less Gregorís galactic affairs expert. The Emperorís uncannily shrewd at matching his Auditors to their cases. Although I suppose weíll have to hit a dud one of these days, he hasnít sent us off-world on a foolís errand yet.î Roic actually hoped for a dud case, someday. It could be restful.
ìThatís reassuring.î Vorlynkin hesitated. ìI think.î
Roic smiled crookedly at the council. ìYeah.î

Back in the consulateís tight-room, Miles saw the address code on his message and relaxed. It looked to be the weekly report from Ekaterin, which explained why it didnít bear any of the usual urgent markers. Something nice, amid all this muddle. Reflecting on the difference between urgent and important, he leaned forward to let his Auditorís seal swing out on its chain, and unsealed the message.

His wifeís face appeared, smiling, above the vid plate, and he paused the vid just to get a good look at her. She sailed through her days under such a constant barrage of interruptions, lately, he hardly ever saw her holding still unless she was sleeping. Clear blue-gray eyes raised in a candid gaze, sleek dark hair untouched by frost although she was his age plus a couple of months. Considering that heíd stuck her with four offspring in under six years, her lack of gray hairs seemed increasingly remarkable. Theyíd all been gestated in uterine replicators, but still. Heíd been an only child himself, racked from birth by medical issues now not so much solved as exchanged for new ones. Perhapsóno, make that certainlyóheíd underestimated how much work normal healthy children would take, even with all the help his money and position could buy. For there were some tasks you didnít want to delegate, because then youíd be missing the best parts.
She was actually staring at a vid pick-up, not at him, he reminded himself, but under the weight of her faintly ironic look he set her back in motion, irrationally guilty at delaying her.

ìGreetings, my love,î she said. ìWeíve received your latest here with much relief and rejoicing, though fortunately I didnít tell the children about that first alarming message before the second had overtaken it. I shudder to think what your parents went through during your old career. Though I suppose your father kept his high-Vor upper lip suitably stiff, and your mother, well, I can scarcely imagine. Said tart Betan things, I suppose.î

Actually, heíd dodged those issues during his covert ops days by almost never sending any messages, or updates. It wasnít as if his father couldnít have demanded a report on his missions from the head of ImpSec any time he wanted one. Or nerved himself to it, he imagined his motherís voice remarking tartly.

Ekaterin swung into a crisp recounting of a few Vorkosigan District matters, before the news from his household, always first things firstóif ever she put matters the other way around, heíd know to be really alarmed for his family. He was reminded that he was neglecting duties down in the District, as well, although this week there did not seem to be anything that called for an urgent message to hisóhis fatherís, reallyóvoting proxy in the Council of Counts. But both his parents were off tending to the Emperorís business on Sergyar, viceroy and vicereine respectively, and had been for some years.

A fine tradition of neglect of oneís own in service to the Imperium, those Vorkosigans. At a cost. Miles recalled with a touch of wry pride what a District village speaker had once said to him of Ekaterin: We feel as though you belong to the Imperium, but Lady Vorkosigan belongs to us.
ìOn the home front,î Ekaterin went on, ìhereís the latest achievementÖî

The vid cut to another, less steady. ìGood job, Helen,î said Ekaterinís voice as a room spun dizzilyóthe library at Vorkosigan House, Miles recognized despite its rabbiting speed, ìbut pan more slowly or youíll give your papa vertigo.î
ìWhatís vertigo?î came a young voice from off-sideóSasha? no, Lizzie, good heavensóand Ekaterin responded at once, ìDizzy.î
ìOh.î The new word was duly accepted.

The vid steadied on Taurie, ten months old, gray eyes wide under a mop of wispy black curls, clinging grimly to the edge of a low table. Sasha, five going on six, as he and his twin, Helen, phrased it, and their sister Lizzie, three, sat on a couch in the background, Sasha watching with interest, Lizzie looking bored and kicking her feet, as if to say, Iíve already done this, whatís the fuss?
ìCome on, Taurie,î Ekaterinís voice cooed. ìCome to mama.î EffectiveóMiles undertook not to fall through the vid plate, reaching for that seductive voice.

Taurie turned, rocking, on her stout little legs, releasing one hand, which waved for balance. Then the other. Then began a bow-legged toddle toward her mamaís outstretched arms. How any child learned to walk while swaddled in a diaper, Miles didnít know, but there she went, thump-thump-thump, to fall chortling into Ekaterinís arms and be swung high in triumph.
ìLet me try her,î said Sasha, much as if his little sister were a robot car. He slid to his knees on the rug across from Ekaterin, and called encouragingly, ìCome on, Taurie, you can do it!î

Fresh from her first victory, Taurie screeched and toddled toward him even faster, promptly falling on her chin and setting up a wail, clearly more of outrage than painóMiles could discern the different timbres while still lunging up from his sleep. Sasha gathered her up, laughing. ìHey, youíre supposed to learn to walk before you run!î He got her turned around and aimed back toward her mama, and the trial was repeated more successfully.

Lizzie, who had slid down off the couch during all this, gave up spinning herself in circles singing, ìVertigo, vertigo, vertigo!î and made a grab for the vid recorder, which, judging from the way the view jerked wildly, her elder sister promptly raised out of her reach. ìNo, I wanna run the vid now,î came Lizzieís voice. ìLet me, let me! Mama, make her let meÖ !î

Too soon, the domestic drama came to an end. Miles backed it up and re-ran it, wondering if these were indeed Taurieís first steps, or a reenactment for his benefit. The vid recorder suggested the latter.
Ekaterinís face returned against the cluttered background of her third-floor office, the one on the north side overlooking her Barrayaran garden through the Earth-import treetops.

ìIím so sorry Sergeant Taura never lived to see her namesake,î she said, looking reflective, ìbut Iím glad you were at least able to tell her about Taurie, before the end. Maybe we should have given her name to Lizzie, sooner, rather than your Betan grandmotherís. Oh, speaking of names. Sasha has now announced that he is Alex, I suppose because he gave up trying to talk everyone into Xander. Lexie and A.A. appear to be permanently rejected, now, too. Same rationaleóif we donít call him Aral because of Grandda Aral, we shouldnít call him Sasha because of Grandpa Sasha, either. He seems to be sticking to this one, however, and he has Helen on his side at last, so in your next message, be sure to call him Lord Alex. That much logic and determination should be rewarded, I think.î

Indeed. Miles had been deeply alarmed, earlier in his fatherhood, by what seemed SashaísóAlexísódelay in verbal development, compared to his age-mate Helen, till Ekaterin had pointed out that the boyís sister never let him ask a question for himself or get a word in edgewise after. He wasnít delayed, merely amiable, and had caught up with complete sentences soon enough thereafter, as long as Helen wasnít in the same room translating for him.
ìCome to think of it,î Ekaterin went on, ìdidnít you once have some trouble deciding what you wanted to be called? And at a much older age. History does not so much repeat as echo, I suppose.
ìBut he loves you, whatever heís named. We all do. Take care out there, Miles, and hurry home when you can.î The vid went dark.

If only I could crawl through that vid plate and have myself beamed back to Barrayar at the speed of lightÖ Miles sighed. All his life, his home had been something he couldnít wait to escape. How had his polarity become so profoundly reversed?
Roicís remark stung: If only youíd quit while you were winningÖ Well, this tangle on Kibou-daini wasnít all of his own making.

He wished Leiber would show the hell up. Now would be a good time. Miles was surprised he was taking so long. He might have to send someone to collect the man after all. Or if Lisa Sato woke up with temporary cryo-amnesia, or simply didnít know the answers. No, she has to know whatever Leiber knows. Because Iíd bet Betan dollars to sand heís the one who told her in the first place.

Leiberís evident alarm niggled at Miles. Why should he have been so afraid of us? He didnít even know us. Leiber was obviously responding to some local threat, perhaps the very one that Miles wanted to know all about. But Miles was still having some trouble guessing what it might be.

Just as Sato was bait for Leiber, the pair of them would be bait forÖ who? Why? Miles had staked people out like goats to draw the tiger du jour in the past, but not, knowingly, when they had children in tow. Or had you just never noticed their webs of relationships, before? He couldnít remember. But if he didnít have the personnel here to chase down Leiber, he surely didnít have the personnel to put a round-the-clock guard on the consulate and the people it sheltered. Roic and Johannes between them werenít enough, even if they hadnít had other dutiesóhanding the task to them without support would be downright abusive. Raven wasnít the only one who didnít like being set up to fail.

Despite the distance it put between him and his family, Miles felt a little shiver of gratitude to Gregor for sending him so far afield on his sporadic Auditorial labors. Because it put that same distance between his family and whoever his investigations managed to piss off. Pissing off bad guys for the greater glory of Barrayar, that would be my job description, just about. Speaking of being happy in oneís work.

He bent to the comconsole and began composing an Auditorial requisition to the Barrayaran embassy on Escobar for a security team, to be dispatched immediately, with a heads-up to put an ImpSec forensic accountant and, perhaps, legal team on stand-by. He knew nothing of his invisible enemy but that they played for keeps. Five days for the squad to get here, at their best speed. Had he known enough, five days ago, to ask for this? I suppose not.
Miles called up the background data on NewEgypt Cryonics once more, and began to slog through it. Lisa Sato could not regain her voice soon enough.

By mid-morning of the day after Madame Satoís successful revival, when Dr. Leiber still hadnít contacted the consulate, mílord allowed as how he might have been mistaken, and dispatched Roic and Johannes to find the man. Roic thought it might have made his job easier if mílord had come to that conclusion earlier. He began with the two obvious first ploys, calling the manís residenceóno answeróand his work, where he learned that the researcher had called in sick the morning before, some stomach bug, heíd told his assistant, and heíd likely be out for a couple of days. Right.

Roic then had Johannes pack up some of the consulateís better surveillance equipment and drive him back out to Leiberís townhouse. A complex under construction that had caught his eye the previous trip did so again, as they passed. Roic cranked his head around to study the sign. Century Estates, it read, and Were you born between 150 and 130 years ago? See us! ìWhatís that all about?î he asked Johannes.

ìA generational cohort enclave,î said Johannes. ìYou see them here and there in the bigger cities. Revives, at least those who wake up with enough money and health for it, often find they donít like the new Kibou so much after all, and end up clustering together trying to recreate their youths.î
ìHuh,î said Roic. ìA sort of do-it-yourself historical reenactment? At least youíd have someone to talk to who gets all your jokes.î
ìI guess,î said Johannes, a little doubtfully.

Roic had Johannes pull in the van at the back of the house row while he tried Dr. Leiberís front door. No answer. After a few minutes Johannes opened it from within. ìHe left the garage unlocked. Float bikeís gone.î
ìRight. Letís take a look around, then visit his comconsole.î

No room, closet, shower, cupboard, or dustbin large enough to hold a body did so. Mílordís thoughtful burglarís note was gone from the refrigerator, which was still stocked with an assortment of bachelor rations. The kitchen was tidied, the bed upstairs more-or-less made, or at least the quilt pulled up. Clothes and shoes might have been takenóenough to fit in a duffle strapped to the back of a float bike?óbut there was still a good bit left. Toiletries were absent.
Johannes had started on Leiberís comconsole, sucking a copy of its contents through the umbilicus of the secured cable onto his ImpSec recorder, watching the progress on his holoscreen.
ìHey!î he said after a moment. ìThis thing is monitored. I wonder if Leiber knew that?î
Roic leaned in. Hey, indeed! ìThis process wonít stir up his watchers, will it?î
ìIt shouldnít,î said Johannes.
Not very reassuring. ìCan you trace the bug?î
ìPartly. I might be able to finish the job from the tight-room.î
ìGive us a look at his communications over the past two days, since our first visit.î

There were only three. Yesterday morning, Leiber had called in sick, purchased a jumpship passage to Escobar, and emptied most of his remaining savings account onto a couple of universal credit chits. There were no personal messages to relatives or friends. He might have left a door key or instructions with the folks next door, Roic supposed, but on the whole he thought not, and he was unwilling to go stir up trouble by asking around. People might remember their visit from day before yesterday. He wondered what tale Leiber had told his neighbor lady about them. Not the truth, he suspected.
ìThis jumpship doesnít leave till tomorrow evening,î Johannes pointed out.
ìYeah, I see.î
ìThink he might have gone aboard already?î

Roic frowned at the schedule. ìAh. No. That one doesnít even make inbound orbit till this afternoon.î He thought a moment. ìThe minute he passes inside shuttleport security, heís back on the grid, lit up for anyone who can look. And if we can spot him then, belike his enemies can, tooóI donít think theyíre operating on a shoestring, not if theyíre backed by one of those cryocorps. Heíll wait to the last to board. So he has to have gone to ground somewhere.î
ìWith a friend, maybe? Could be hard to find.î Johannes squinted at the comconsole. ìAlthough this could help.î
ìIf heís in as much fear for his life as this flight suggests, he might not want to endanger a friend,î said Roic slowly. ìHe didnít strike mílord as the ruthless type, he said.î
ìItís a big city,î observed Johannes.
ìSo, letís start with the obvious.î Roic climbed to his feet. ìPack up here and drive us out to the shuttleport.î

In the lift van, Roic opened itsóImpSec securedócomconsole and ran a search on lodgings around the shuttleport. Two were inside the security perimeter, half a dozen scattered in the surrounding light-industrial area. He balanced closest against cheapest, and decided to start with cheapest. As they threaded their way to it, he had time to reflect on how Nexus-wide transportation tech had shaped the cities it served, giving more sameness planet to planet than heíd expected, before heíd ever left Barrayar. This provincial boyís come a long way. In a way, he was glad no good fairy had ever endowed him with the future he would have picked for himself when younger. It would have been so much smaller.
ìNow what?î asked Johannes, as they swung into the budget hostelís lot. ìStake the place out? Ask at the front desk?î

ìNot sure anyone would remember Leiber even if they saw him,î said Roic, ìand this is one of those self-serve places.î Not as cramped as some Roic had encountered on space stations, where sleep cubicles, rented by the hour, seemed a cross between a closet and a coffin, but the buildingís utilitarian lines didnít invite lingering. It was a shadowed place even in the mid-morning, huddled down below a long concrete road abutment and some sort of manufacturing plant. ìCircle the lot. Weíll look for his float bike.î
Around the buildingís back, an open-faced shed sheltered a float bike lock-down. Roic recognized Leiberís bike nestled among half a dozen others.
ìRight the first time!î said Johannes, in a tone of admiration.

ìIíve had some practice, trailing mílord around,î said Roic modestly, leaving out the dumb luck part. Well, smart luck, perhaps. Roic would have been surprised not to have turned up something within his first three tries. They sat in the van for a few minutes while Roic tried to think it through the way mílord would. No, scratch that idea. Heíd likely do better trying to think it through like Leiber. Or better still, like Roic.

Would the enemy send cops or goons to collect their quarry? If it was a cryocorp, they could likely get all the cops they wantedócharges of employee theft would do the jobóthey had only to wait at the pinch-point inside the shuttleport and pick the man off as he scurried through. But that would leave a trail, names, security vid recordings, a whole lot of witnesses not under anyoneís direct control. A private goon squad pick-up before Leiber hit the port, that would be the quieter way to go about it. And if Roic could figure out where to look for the fellow, presumably all those smart men in the fancy trousers could, too. Roic wasnít the part of his team born with the silver tongue in his mouthócould he persuade Leiber to come to the safety of the consulate, when mílord had not? Guess Iíll have to try. He glanced up. ìWhatís that?î
A pulsing blue light was reflecting off the concrete wall, coming from the front of the building.
ìBlueís the color they use around here for emergency vehicles,î said Johannes uneasily.
ìPull around front.î

They arrived to see a pair of emergency medtechs dressed in blue scrubs yank a float pallet from the back of an unmarked van and hurry inside the sliding glass doors to the lobby. Both big fellowsóone was tall, and the other looked as though heíd had some of those traditional wrestlers in his family tree. On both sides. Didnít emergency services usually try to pair a woman in such a team? Well, not always, belike. With round the clock scheduling, as Roic knew from grappling with the guardsmenís roster for Vorkosigan House and mílordís other two official residences, you took whatever combinations you could get.

ìWait here.î Roic slid out of their own van and went to take a peek in the back of the other. The rear doors had no windows, but had been left unlocked. Careless of the techs, if it was carrying drugs and expensive equipment. Roic quietly opened a door, looked inside, and raised his wristcom to his lips. ìInteresting, Johannes. The cupboard is bare. This isnít an ambulance, just a van.î
ìUh-oh.î

ìThink Iíll just take a stroll inside and intercept those fellows coming out. You watch my back from there.î Roic still wasnít sure what was happening, here, although he was formulating some rapid guesses.
An anxious young lady desk clerk was peering up the central hallway when Roic entered the lobby.
ìWhatís going on?î he asked.
ìOne of our guests reported in very sick, apparently. He should have called the front deskówe would have assisted himÖî
ìWas he from off-world? Díyou think he might have brought in something bad?î asked Roic. ìContagious?î

ìNo, no. Some sort of sudden seizure, I gather. He was lucky he could use his wristcom.î The clerk gathered her nerve. ìI should go and lock up after them, make sure the gentlemanís property is secure.î She glanced back at Roic. ìWere you checking in, sir? Thereís only me on duty right nowÖî

ìTake your time. First things first.î Roic waved her away. She trotted off up the hall to where a loaded float pallet was already being shifted out a doorway and turned. The tall man hitched an IV to a pole, bent, and checked his patient. Roic glimpsed a blanketed male form, firmly strapped down, an oxygen mask in place across his face muffling his moans. Roic stepped forward, radiating curiosity and concern, as the pallet floated out into the lobby flanked by its two escorts.
Dr. Leiber blinked up with bleared eyes and groaned behind his plastic mask.
ìWhat happened?î Roic asked, following along out the front doors. ìIs it anything dangerous? Do you need any help?î
ìThanks, no,î the tall one told him. ìEverythingís under control.î
ìSo was it a heart attack?î
ìWe donít know, yet,î said the tall one. ìHe just collapsed.î

ìDrugs? Is this a bad area? I just landed, myself.î For once, Roicís not-from-around-here looks and accent worked in his favor. ìI was about to check in at this place and sleep off the jump-lag, but now Iím not so sure.î
The broad one scowled at him in irritation. ìNo, itís fine. Go check in.î The pair swung the van doors wide and slid the pallet aboard, both climbing inside to secure it.
Roic stuck his head in after. ìYou sure?î
ìYes, itís safe,î said the tall one, exasperated, from the windowless cargo area.
ìGood,î said Roic, pulled his stunner, and shot them both.
That would save some heavy lifting. And scuffling. Roic hated scuffles. Just because he was big didnít mean he liked getting hurt.

Johannesís breathless voice sounded from his side, not his wristcom. ìWhat the hell is going on?î When Roic had said Watch my back, he hadnít meant from this close, but he couldnít fault the lieutenant for curiosity. Johannesís eyes widened, peering into the shadows.

Roic tucked his stunner away in its shoulder holster. ìWe just rescued Dr. Leiber. Iím not sure if heíll see it that way, though.î He climbed into the cargo area, first checking both his victims for health. Stunner fire was by no means safe; it could trigger all sort of problems in people with underlying medical issues. Happily, these two seemed extremely fit. Having assured himself of their continued cooperation by the simple means of a light repeat stun to the base of each neck, he arranged them more tidily. He then turned to Leiber.

Roic was not called upon after all to trot out his encouraging Weíve saved you, be grateful, Iím taking you to a place of refuge speech, in which he had no faith; Leiber had lost consciousness. Roic hoped to hell it had just been a hypospray of knockout drugs, and not some deadly poison. Even if some bloody and secret murder was planned, if he were Leiberís enemy heíd sure want him alive to question under fast-penta first. Actually, Roic wanted to question Leiber under fast-penta on his own behalf. That decision would be up to mílord, though.
Leiberís breathing continued evenly, and his skin did not turn any alarming colors. All right so far.
ìFollow me to Madame Suzeís place,î he instructed Johannes. Dr. Durona would be there, among other useful amenities. He thought a moment. ìNo, betterólead me to Suzeís.î

He locked the back of the van, doused its flashing lights, and followed Johannes in convoy out of the parking lot. Roic wondered if mílordís approach to life, or at least to his Auditorial investigations, was rubbing off on him. Heíd never used to be this cavalier about due process. It was hard to tell, sometimes, if mílordís style was the result of single-minded dedication to duty, habits of overweening Vor privilege, or simple insanity. Roic only knew that he had an inexplicable desire to whistle cheerfully, right now.
Instead he raised his wristcom to his lips, called mílord, and gave a concise précis of his morningís mission, if mílordís laconic order of, Roic, go nail that twit could be so grandly styled.
And then, being alone in the driverís cab, he whistled all the way to Suzeís.

His imagination afire with possibilities, Jin sat at the consulateís kitchen table and counted out, again, his share of the money Roic had solemnly distributed to him and Mina at breakfast that morning. Mina had already secreted hers in her backpack upstairs, but she watched him with interest as he reshuffled his stack of currencyófive thousand nuyen, more than heíd ever had at one time in his life. Back in the good times, before his father had died, Jin had never been given more than five hundred even for his best birthday.
ìWhat are you going to do with yours?î Mina asked.

ìIím not sure yet. I could buy food for my creatures for months with this. Or get something new. I always wanted to try keeping fish, but Aunt Lorna would never let me, and there was no way at Suzeís. You canít cart fish around with you if you might have to go live on the street.î
Minaís eyebrows knit. ìDo you guess weíre going to be here that long?î
Jin hesitated. ìI donít know.î
ìDo you think I have enough for a pony?î
ìWhere would you keep a pony? You need, like, lots of terraformed ground, I think. The back garden hereís not big enough.î
ìAunt Lornaís patio sure wasnít big enough,î Mina agreed. ìAt least Consul Vorlynkin has grass.î

Jin tried to picture this. The consulateís patch of back lawn was barely larger than its living room. Nice for a chicken run, but he didnít think it would work for anything much bigger. ìAnyway,î he said bracingly, ìyou still have Lady Murasaki. Ponyís got four legs, spiderís got eight, so she has to be twice as good, right?î
Mina cast him a look of cold scorn. ìIíd like to see you try and put a saddle and bridle and stuff on her.î

Jin tried to imagine spider-sized tackóknotted thread, perhaps?óand what kind of insect could you persuade to ride a wolf spider? That the spider wouldnít eat? Riding would be a much more exciting sport, he thought, if ponies ate prey like spiders did. Did the consulate have any thread they could borrowÖ ? But before he could pursue the vision further, Consul Vorlynkin and Miles-san came through the kitchen pulling on their jackets.

ìVorlynkin is going to drive me down to Madame Suzeís to see about something,î Miles-san told them. He and Roic had been spending a lot of time there lately, Jin thought, and come back looking grim and thoughtful, though no one had said why. And Raven-sensei hadnít come back at all. ìYuuichi Matsonís here, so you wonít be alone. But if any strangers come in on consulate business, youíll need to stay out of the front rooms and hall. Upstairs should be all right, or the back garden, if you donít make too much noise.î
ìIíll be back directly,î Vorlynkin promised.
Mina looked up. ìDo you think youíll ever find Mommy?î
ìWe hope to have good news soon,î said Miles-san.
Jin wasnít sure how to interpret that soothing tone of voice. More grownup lies? By her scrunched face, he didnít think Mina was buying it, either.
But what she said was, ìLord Vorkosigan, if you had children youíd give them ponies, wouldnít you? Not spiders?î

He looked a little taken aback. ìI do and I have. Ponies, not spiders. Although I suppose they could have spiders if they wanted some. God knows we have butterbugs. Monogrammed. Didnít I ever show you my pictures?î

And then, to Jinís surprise and growing dismay, he pulled a holocube out of his pocket and proceeded to show off scans of a regular-sized, dark-haired womanóJin could tell she was regular-sized because there were some shots of the two of them together, and the top of Miles-sanís head barely reached her shoulderóand a bewildering succession of children at different ages. Jin didnít quite sort them out till they came to a group shotóa dark-haired boy and a red-haired girl a bit younger than Mina, an infant in the pretty womanís arms, and a leggy toddler in the middle of the pack. Four children. He hoped Mina would muster the wit to look interested and not distraught. He still wasnít altogether sure what Miles-san was, but he seemed to have a lot of clout. Even the consul did whatever he said.
ìAnd hereís Helen on her pony down at Vorkosigan Surleauóitís a place we have in the country, on a lakeóand hereís Sasha petting his. Xander. Alex, I mean.î

Jin wondered what kind of inattentive father Miles-san was, that he couldnít seem to remember his own sonís name. There was only the one boy, after all. It wasnít as if he needed to run down a list till he got to the one who was irritating him, the way Uncle Hikaru had with him and Tetsu and Ken sometimes.

But Jin had to admit, they were very fine-looking ponies, one dappled silvery-gray, the other a glossy dark brown with black socks and mane and tail and a white star on its forehead, both with dark, liquid, friendly gazes, seeming tolerant of their child-admirers. Mina goggled, her mouth dropping open in naked longing. Yah and double-yahóa big place in the country. With lots of animalsóthere had been dogs and cats and birds in the backgrounds of some of those shots, and who knew what creatures lurked in those wooded hills? And fish in a real lake, not just in some little glass tank, and maybe creeping and crawling native marvels living in the streams running down into itóbetter than Jin had dared to dream.
And all belonging to these other children. Children who had a live mother and father, too. What was that line of Uncle Hikaruís? Them what has, gets.

And those that didnít have, didnít get, Jin supposed was the unspoken half of that lesson. He looked at those other children, and at Miles-san, so obviously pleased and proud, and didnít doubt that Mina probably felt like crying. His own throat was tight with envy and ridiculous anger. It wasnít as if Miles-san had kept his family a secret on purpose, just to bait Jin so belatedly.

ìI wouldnít have dared not teach them to ride,î Miles-san went on. ìMy grandfatherís ghost would have haunted me if I hadnít, not that the old buzzard doesnít anyway. The Vor were a military caste, back in the Time of Isolation. Knights, of a sortóor bandits, perhaps, depending on your point of view. Horse soldiers, in any case. Itís a tradition.î He gave that last word a peculiar emphasis, as if it tasted funny in his mouth. ìA perfectly useless skill, nowadays, but we keep it up all the same.î
ìPerhaps weíd better go,î said Vorlynkin, and ìYeah,î said Miles-san. He pocketed his holocube carefully, like it was something special to him. They went off through the garden toward the big garage.
Jin and Mina stared at each other.
ìWell,î said Mina at last. ìAt least I was right about the ponies.î She blinked rapidly, and rubbed her reddened eyes.
Jin glowered down at his little stack of money, which had seemed such a big pile of possibilities just minutes ago.
ìItís no good, after all,î said Mina. ìMaybe it never was. Maybe we should just go back to Aunt Lorna and Uncle Hikaruís.î
Stop struggling? ìYou could, maybe,î Jin said bitterly. ìNot me. No, wait, you couldnít eitheróyouíd gab.î
Mina looked indignant at this accusation. With a ìHuh!î she rose to go back upstairs. At the archway into the kitchen, she flung back over her shoulder, ìTwo ponies have eight legs, so there!î
Jin couldnít think of a counter-argument to that.

As Jin was fingering his nuyen and wondering if he dared help himself to a snack, the consulate clerk wandered into the kitchen to refill his mug of green tea. He leaned against the counter and stared at Jin, who fidgeted under the cool regard.
ìYouíre Lisa Satoís children, arenít you? The cryo-rights activist?î
ìUhÖ yah?î Jin wasnít sure if that was supposed to be a secret here, but Matson-san obviously already knew.
Matson-san took a sip of tea and frowned. ìNobodyís really told me anything. But, ahÖ if you want me to call the police for you and your sister, before the Barrayarans all get back, I couldÖ ?î
Jin shot to his feet, almost knocking over his chair, and cried in horror, ìNo!î
Matson-san sloshed hot tea, swore, set the cup down, and wiped his scalded hand on his trousers.
ìIt was the police who took Mom!î said Jin.
ìCall your relatives, then?î
ìNo! Thatís even worse!î
ìEr,î said Matson-san. ìSo you two kids are not, um, notÖ prisoners, here, are you?î

ìOf course not! Miles-san is helping us!î He considered events so far, and amended that to, ìTrying to, anyway.î And then, because that sounded weak and ungrateful, ìNobody else has ever tried like him,î which was certainly true.

Matson-san scratched his head and grimaced. ìAh.î He took up his tea again. ìWell, if you change you mind, you can tell me, all right?î Jin glowered at him in a dismay that made him hold up a placating hand. ìJust trying to help, too.î
Jin wanted to cry, If thatís your idea of help, donít! but it seemed too rude a thing to say to a grownup. He settled on, ìAll right. But I wonít. Change my mind.î
