Matson-san shrugged uneasily and went back out to that front office-room. Jin gathered his money and fled upstairs to hide it away.
With three of the four people he wanted to interrogate at Suzeís place still out cold, bless Roic, Miles perforce began with Madame Sato.

Inside the glass-walled, softly-lit isolation booth, she was sitting up in her narrow bed, looking pale and exhausted but on the whole very good for a new revive. She was clean in a crisp patient gown and warmly padded robe, each extra layer of cloth providing protection from exposure both to germs and prying eyes. Miles suspectedóno, knew very wellófrom his own too-frequent hospitalizations that the latter could be more important to oneís morale than the former. Ako had washed the gel from her hair; it lay undamaged in a silky fall over her shoulder.
He eased into the booth, wondering if he seemed menacing to her or merely weird. Hard to tell from her stern glare. He adjusted his filtering mask and cleared his throat.

ìGood afternoon, Madame Sato. My name is Miles Vorkosigan.î He smiled reassuringly, then realized she couldnít see his mouth. ìSorry about the mask. But Dr. Durona says your immune systemís coming back fast. We should be able to dispense with the sterile precautions and get you out of here fairly soon.î
ìAre you a doctor?î Her voice was raspy but functional.
ìNo, your revival was done by Raven Durona, a specialist from Escobar. Who works for me,î Miles realized heíd better add. Explaining himself to her was going to be an uphill slog.

ìI saw him earlier.î She swallowedópartly nerves, partly still getting used to being back in control of her body, he expected. ìWhere is here? They said I was in Northbridge.î Her tone said she doubted this. Doubted everything, right now.

Miles glanced around. The view from booth took in only the shadowed, deserted recovery room, which had no exterior windows, not even looking out on the wall of another building. ìNorthbridge, thatís right. Youíre in an old, decommissioned cryonics facility on the south side, which has been taken over by some rather clever squatters.î
ìSomeone said you have my childrenÖî The tightening of her throat smeared that last word nearly soundless.

Miles now wished heíd brought them along, even though he was still nervy from his prior failure. ìYes, Jin and Mina are safe at the Barrayaran consulate.î He added after a moment, when she still didnít seem to know whether to parse this as a comfort or a threat, ìJin has all his creatures there, even Gyre-the-falcon and your old cat, so heís content for now. Mina is pretty much sticking with Jin.î This familiar reference to the traveling zoo would convince her of his veracity, he hoped.
ìThe Barrayaran consulate! Why?î She swallowed again. ìWho are you? Why are you here?î She didnít add, Why am I here? but Miles thought it was implied.
ìWhat do you remember?î
Her lips clamped shut.

Miles tried again. ìThe last thing Jin and Mina remember of you is your arrest by the Northbridge municipal police, eighteen months back. Two days ago, my people and I found you frozen in a portable cryochamber in Dr. Seiichiro Leiberís townhouse basement. Iím now trying to close that eighteen-month memory gap. For both of us, I suppose.î
That last plainly shocked her; her stare at him shifted from fear and misplaced anger to sheer bewilderment. ìWhat?î

Miles sighed, hitching himself up on the stool at the end of her bed. An Auditor was supposed to listen, not talkóone of Gregorís wee jokes, was that?óbut this woman had earned her briefing. Besides, it was quite likely that Lisa Sato didnít know enough about Barrayar to point to it on a wormhole map. ìI expect I had better begin at the beginning. Iím a galactic. My official job title is Imperial Auditor. Thatís a high-level government investigator for the Barrayaran Imperium. You no doubt wonder what Iím doing on Kibou-daini.î Miles wondered himself, some moments. ìI was originally sent to check out a smelly situation with a large WhiteChrys company franchise on Komarróthatís the second planet of our empireóî As succinctly as he could, he explained the WhiteChrys scam with the Komarran planetary voting shares, including his successful bribery sting. For the first time, she looked faintly cheered.
ìYes, hit them where they keep their hearts, in their wallets,î she murmured with satisfaction. ìAlthough WhiteChrys isnít even the worst of the corps.î

ìHold that thought, weíll come back to it. Now I need to explain how I met your son Jin, and found this placeÖî Necessarily, he backed up to his attendance at the cryo-conference, and the attack upon it by the N.H.L.L.
ìThose murderous idiots!î said Lisa Sato, her voice hearteningly enlivened with scorn for someone other than Miles.

ìIn their defense, they donít seem to have succeeded in killing anyone, this round. If not for lack of trying. I actually feel I owe themóthey opened up my case for me in ways Iíd have had trouble finding on my own, although I suppose the Komarr scam part would have run on rails regardless. Anyway, after I broke away from them I ended up lost in the CryocombsÖî

That part held her nicely spellbound. Miles had the mother-wit to save most of his embroidering for after Jin had joined his tale, which drew her in fully. She had less trouble following the explanation of Suzeís schemes than Miles had, first encounter.
ìBut why was Jin here?î she asked, at a loss. ìIíd left the children with my sister Lorna. I only thought Iíd be gone overnight, maybe a day or two, until I could get a lawyeróeighteen months?î
ìDo you remember being taken to be frozen? Who did it?î

Her brow furrowed in an effort of recall. ìI was in what was supposed to have been a temporary cell, more of a room, really, at the municipal police station. A man came in. I thought he might be from my lawyer. There was a hypospray, thenÖî She shook her head, then winced. Post-revival headache, no doubt. His had been a doozy.

Hypnotic or knock-out drug, it hardly mattered which she had received. Miles suspected that not even more time to overcome any lingering cryo-amnesiaóof which she showed very few signsówould recover anything after that.

ìAfter you were illegally, or in any case extra-legally, frozen, your sister and brother-in-law naturally looked after their nephew and niece. I gather that Jin ran away from your sister due to conflicts over his creatures in her crowded household. Mina stayed on. She was doing well in her second year of primary schoolîóthat seemed a safe assumptionóìuntil I inadvertently caused Jin to be returned to his aunt, and they both ran away together to, well, me.î At her Why you? look, he added, ìJin can tell you all the details when you see him.î Miles hoped Jin was enough of a Barrayaran partisan by now to convey the Lord Auditorís good intentions. Good performance was still to be tested, unfortunately.

ìBut enough about me.î Letís talk about you. It had been a very long time, thankfully, since Miles had attempted to pick up a woman in a baróand even that had been in the line of dutyóbut his sense of desperate seduction wasnít altogether misplaced. He needed to persuade Lisa Sato to trust him, and quickly. ìWhat was your connection with Seiichiro Leiber, and how did it come about?î

For a long moment he feared she was going to clam up again, but after another cool look, she began, ìSeiichiro came to usóto our political action councilówith a secret heíd discovered through his work.î
ìHow many times did he visit you?î
ìTwo or three.î
ìWho all did he tell? Did he ever meet with all of you?î
ìGeorge and Eiko and me, at first. There was one later meeting with all of us, when we planned the rallyóGeorge Suwabi and me, Seiichiro, Lee Kang, Rumi Khosla, and Eiko Tennoji.î
Those last names were all too familiar to Miles from his researches. ìLet me guess. You decided to make a public announcement of the secret at the rally, where things went so wrong.î

Her gaze flicked up from her lap to go knife-narrow at him. ìIt wasnít our people who made the trouble. We were hit by a counter-rallyóa collection of thugs from the N.H.L.L. They were supposed to have stayed at the other end of the park, that night. We couldnít afford to rent a hall, and neither could they.î
ìWas it really the N.H.L.L., or could it have been a gang hired to impersonate them?î
ìIt was really themóI recognized a couple of the fellows involved. Locals.î
ìMm, they might still have been employed for the task. Set upon you.î

Her head tilted in consideration and half-agreement. ìThe police broke up the fight. There seemed to be an awful lot of police for the size of the scuffle, and they arrived very quickly. As if theyíd already been warned. I saw several people with bleeding heads, or pushed to the ground.î The memory seemed distressing; to her, it was literally only yesterday, Miles was reminded. ìThatís not the kind of protest we ever were. I think the N.H.L.L. is like the other side of the coin, literally, from the cryocorps. The N.H.L.L. frets about the money they donít have, the cryocorps fret about money they do have, and neither one cares about anyoneís lives but their own.î
A shrewd judgment, Miles thought. ìMay we come back to Dr. Leiber?î And his secret. ìHe does seem to have been the key man, in several senses.î
She regarded him and seemed to come to a decision. ìI suppose if you are some sort of bizarre cryocorp spy, you already know. And know that I know.î So what more is there to lose? hung unspoken.
ìFor what itís worth, I already have a big pointer in the fact that Dr. Leiber researched preservation solution chemistry for NewEgypt Cryonics.î

She gave a gingerly half-nod. ìWhat Seiichiro had discovered was that a certain formulation of cryo-preservative that was on the market a generation or so ago broke down chemically after a few decades. There must be thousands, maybe millions of people who were treated with it locked up in the corps freezers who are truly dead, not revivable. Meaning their votes are void and their assets due to be returned to their heirs. There must be billions of nuyen at stake from that alone. And thatís without even getting to the vast legal costs, plus all the procedures that will have to be devised to figure out which patrons from that period are which.î

Miles blew out a soundless whistle, pieces of his puzzle slotting into place at light speed. Commodified contracts, indeed! Oh, he wanted an ImpSec meta-economics analyst to go with the forensic accountant from Escobar, and he wanted them now. With all the data-penetrating equipment they could carry, pre-keyed to the peculiarities of Kibouís planetary net.

And heíd order them the moment he was back at the consulate. But for the next few days, he was stuck with his old original organic brain. A used model, at that, sadly battered by all the wear and tear.
What he said out loud was, ìYeah, that would sure account for it all.î Including, perhaps, poor Alice Chen, whoíd been left by Leiber in Satoís placeóas a decoy, or as a clue? Or as a time-bomb?

ìWe thought this was a revelation that could truly jolt the cryocorpsí hold on Kibou,î said Lisa Sato. ìEven break their grip.î She stared around her cubicle, down at her lately-thawed hands. ìI suppose we were right.î Her brow furrowed. ìWait. You mean to say theyíve still kept this silent for the past year and a half? It wasnít a secret the corps could keep foreveróas more and more bad revives turn up from that generation, disproportionately, people are bound to notice the pattern. Thatís part of why George wanted to strike quickly, for the maximum public impact. Why didnítÖ oh.î She turned suddenly bleak eyes upon Miles, who flinched in anticipation of what was coming next. ìWhat happened to the six of us? Why didnít anyone get the word out, after I was taken away? Were we all taken away?î

ìI am sorry to be the bearer of bad tidings, Madame Sato, but thatís what it looks like. Kang, Khosla, and you were all frozen under questionable diagnoses within a few days of the rally. George Suwabi supposedly crashed his lightflyer into a lake, and Madame Tennoji fell from her apartment house balcony to her death, after excessive drinking. Needless to say, I should think it most interesting to see someone from your police homicide bureau re-open those two cases. ErÖ did she drink to excess?î
She frowned, even paler about the mouth than her revival had left her. ìWell, yes. She was in a lot of pain from her joint deterioration. But she didnít fall off of things. Oh, no, poor GeorgeÖî
ìThe odd man out in all this is Dr. Leiber. He simply went back to work for the past eighteen months.î
ìThat makes no sense.î
ìFortunately, Iím going to be able to ask him about it. When he wakes up.î
ìWas he frozen, too?î

ìAh, no. He had an encounter with a simple sedative this morning, according to my man Roic. RavenóDr. Durona, that isóconfirms. Weíve detained him here at Suzeís while he sleeps it off. He was trying to leave the planet when Roic picked him up. Somebody else was trying to prevent him, I think. Itís going to be an interesting interrogation.î Miles hesitated. This was, after all, Jin and Minaís mother. Those two had to have inherited, or perhaps learned, some part of their admirable wits and determination from her. And you couldnít demand trust without giving some in return.
ìWould you like to sit in?î

Miles was itching to get to Leiber, but was diverted by Roic to consider his other captives. Thanks to one of Ravenís potions, both now slept peacefully on the floor of an empty officeóor possibly abandoned utility closetóadjoining the underground garage of the former patient intake building. Roic had spent the time constructively going through wallets, IDs, and the lift van.

ìThis wasnít what you might call deep covert ops, here,î Roic said, sorting out the wallets to demonstrate. ìThe van is registered to NewEgypt, and the scrubs theyíre wearing are company issue. They were carrying all their own identifications. Hans Witta and Okiya Cermak. Johannes did some back-checking. Tí one is actually the senior officer for plant security, and tíother used to be a regular guard till eighteen months ago, when he got a big raise in pay and a promotion to personal assistant to his chief.î
ìInteresting,î murmured Miles.

ìAyup. Iíd say Dr. Leiberís kidnapping was something they put together in a hurry, out of resources they had to hand. If theyíd nailed him at work, or anywhere on the NewEgypt properties, they wouldnít even have had to bother with that much. Thing is, now what do we do with íem? We canít keep íem sacked out on the floor forever. I mean, you got to let a man pee sometime. And their bosses have to know by now that something went wrong. Catch and release? I figured to set them back in their van not far from Leiberís hotel, and let them wake up on their own.î
ìHm. Have you and Johannes rendered the van unlocatable?î
ìOf course, mílord,î Roic said, his prim tone adding, I do my job.
ìBut they did see you.î
ìUnavoidable, Iím afraid. I donít think they saw Johannes, though.î
ìIs kidnapping kidnappers still kidnapping?î Miles mused.
ìYes,î said Roic, unhelpfully.
ìNot that NewEgypt is likely to bring charges.î
ìNaw, theyíd do something else.î
ìI am reminded. I could have Suze freeze and store them for us, I suppose. Technically.î
Roic gave him the Look.
ìIf push came to shove. As a Kibou-daini problem-solving technique, there seems to be precedent.î
Roic said nothing, firmly.
ìAh, well,î sighed Miles. ìLock the door and let them nap, for now. Onwards.î

Working around Madame Satoís bio-isolation proved only a brief challenge. Miles set up his interrogation chamber in the empty booth next to hers, and lent her Ravenís wristcom to listen in. With his booth brightly lit, hers not, and the curtain mostly drawn on her side of the glass wall, it was as good as a one-way mirror as long as she didnít move around too much. She understood, if perhaps did not entirely approve, his plan to split the interrogation into two parts, the first with Leiber unaware of her presence, to see if the same story was extracted both ways. Miles wasnít sure when to spring her on Leiber for maximum utility. It would doubtless come to him.

Leiber was still woozy when Raven and Roic guided him into the booth and sat him in a chair. Roic took a wall-propping pose against the door. With no bed, the booth wasnít exactly crowded even with the four of them, but its slightly claustrophobic air was more of a feature than a failing, in Milesís view.
ìYou again!î Leiber said, staring at Miles.
Raven, with a benevolent air, bent to press a hypospray against Leiberís arm.
Leiber jerked. ìFast-penta?î he growled, looking helpless and angry.
ìSynergine,î Raven soothed. ìThat headache should clear right up.î
Leiber rubbed his arm and scowled, but, after pressing a suspicious hand to his forehead, blinked in surprise and, in a moment more, belief.

So, and when did you ever have fast-penta, that you can tell the difference? Miles added the question to his long list. Miles waved Raven to a chair against the wall, and took one himself at a not-too-looming distance from his subject. Although to loom properly, he supposed heíd have to stand on the chair, which just wouldnít have the same effect. Best to delegate that task to Roic.

ìSo, Dr. Leiber. We might have saved steps by having this conversation day before yesterday, but I suppose your living room might have been monitored like your comconsole. Maybe itís just as well. Here, I can assure you, we are totally private.î Miles smiled toothily. Imperial Auditor, threat or menace? You decide.
Leiberís lips moved, My comconsole! ìDammit, I thought Iíd taken care of that. So thatís how you traced me?î

ìThatís how the two gentlemen dressed in the medical kit traced you, I imagine. Armsman Roic, hereîóMiles waved his hand; Roic nodded amiablyóìIím sorry I didnít get a chance to introduce you two properly earlieróRoic followed them. More or less. And took you away from them. Did you recognize them, by the way?î
ìHans and Oki? Of course. The Gang of Fourís pet muscle.î
ìHighly paid, these coworkers of yours?î
ìOh, yah.î Leiber smiled sourly. ìAnd great job security, too.î
ìAs good as yours?î
ìNot as far as I know. Lucky for them.î Leiber squinted. ìTook me away how?î
ìStunner,î said Roic.
ìThatís illegal!î
ìNo, actually, I have a local permit. Bodyguard, yíknow.î

Official government bodyguard, in point of fact. Which was as close as Vorlynkin had been able to get to Armsman on the Prefectureís application form. Roic had acquired even odder designations in past ventures, true.
ìWho the hell are you people, anyway?î Leiber sat up indignantly; Roic tensed a trifle. ìDid you steal Lisa from me?î
ìHer cryochamber is safe,î said Miles, truthfully. It was still tucked away down the hall.
ìNot for long if NewEgyptís onto me!î
ìYouíre safe too, for the moment. Weíre holed up in an old decommissioned cryofacility on the south side of town, if you want to know. Out of sight, out of mind.î
ìNot likely,î muttered Leiber, subsiding.
ìHow about this,î said Miles. ìIíll tell you what I know, and you tell me what I donít know.î
ìWhy should I?î
ìWeíll come to that. To start with, I really was a Barrayaran delegate to the cryo-conference.î
ìYouíre no doctor. Or academic.î Leiber frowned. ìProspective patron?î

Not if I can help it. ìNo, Iím an Imperial Auditor. A high-level investigator for my government. Among my several tasks here is to study the social and legal problems Kibou-daini faces as a result of its deep engagement with cryonics. I shall inevitably be tapped as an advisor to upgrading Barrayarís admittedly-archaic legal codes, to avoid repeating your mistakes, if we can.î Granted, that wasnít his explicit task, but Gregor was bound to think of it sooner or later. Miles shuddered to foresee another few years of arm-wrestling subcommittees from the Councils of Counts and Ministers, just like his last gig about galactic reproductive and cloning technologies. On the bright side, he could go home every night; on the less bright, work would follow him thereÖ ìThe punishment for a job well done, as it were. But it didnít take long to figure out that the only troubles the conference seriously addressed were the technical ones.î
Raven waved agreement.
Miles went on, ìThe rest was pretty much cryocorps sales pitches. So I went looking on my own.î
ìFor troubles? Well, youíve found mine.î
ìIndeed, and instructive they are.î
Leiber hunched, looking offended.

ìSo far, Iíve discovered that Kibouís scheme of proxy votes for the frozen, originally devised on the assumption that people would be revived sooner and in greater numbers, has proved a fascinating demographic trap. Still thinking about that one. Also, that a certain brand of cryo-preservative from about a generation ago turned out not to be good for more than about thirty years, and that NewEgypt and presumably all the other corps are sitting on a financial time-bomb of unrevivable corpses, for which, sooner or later, someone is going to have to pony up. And NewEgypt has gone to great lengths to insure that the someone wonít be them.î
Leiber went rigid. ìHowó!î

Heíd doubtless twig to how Miles knew in a bit; Miles had no intention of hurrying his thought processes. ìI know that you figured this out, that you went to Lisa Satoís political action group for help, and that the result was a riot at their rally that ended with three of her people frozen and two murdered. Did you set them up at NewEgyptís behest?î
ìNo!î cried Leiber indignantly. But then, deflating, ìNot on purpose.î
ìBetray them for money?î
ìNo! The bribe came later, just to make it look that way.î
Miles hadnít even gone looking for evidence of bribes, yet. Ah, yes, deliver yourself into my hands, Doctor. You know you want to. ìThen what did happen? In your own words.î

Leiber clasped his hands and stared at his feet for so long that Miles began to fancy fast-penta, with or without his subjectís permission, but at last began, ìIt all started about two years ago. I was assigned the problem of figuring out the unusual number of bad revivals we were getting from that era. When Iíd narrowed it down to the decomposing cryo-fluid, I went to my boss, who went to his bosses to report. I thought theyíd do something about it, I mean, right away, but weeks went by and nothing happened.î
ìWho were these bosses? Which men were told about this?î

ìThe Gang of Four? There was my R & D supervisor, Roger Napak. And Ran Choi, the chief operating officer, and Anish Akabane, heís chief of finance, and Shirou Kim, the NewEgypt president. They clamped down and kept the information tight right away.

ìThey promised me something was going to be done about the problem. I began to figure out they didnít mean the same problem I did when Akabane unveiled his commodified contracts scheme. They werenít trying to do anything about the bad preps, just about NewEgyptís financial liabilities! When I complained to Rog, he told me to pipe down or Iíd be fired, and I pointed out that if I were fired, Iíd have no reason to pipe down, and he went real quiet, and then he promised me heíd do something. By that time, I didnít trust their ideas about problem-solving one bit.
ìIíd been following Lisa Sato on the news for a year or two by then. She seemed to me one of the few people on Kibou who wasnít just arguing about the money. I mean, moral arguments, you know?î

Her detractors had certainly been arguing about the money, though, from the bits Miles had seen. The corps claimed her schemes would just set up a rival corp run by the government for the poor, for which everyone would pay. Illogically, they also claimed her scheme would damage their business, but if they werenít taking in those poor patrons anyway, Miles didnít see how they were losing anything. The N.H.L.L. just wanted to set fire to all the metabolically disadvantaged regardless of net worth. Though they certainly wanted to start with the rich, which suggested a certain shrewd efficiency in liberating their hypothesized legacy.

ìSo I went to see Lisa Sato in person. I didnít even make an appointment over the comconsole, just went and knocked on her door one night. And she was everything Iíd hoped she would be! I went again, and gave copies of all the data I had to her and George Suwabi, poor guy, and thatís when they came up with the rally speech idea, to release it all at once in a way the corps couldnít quash. I thought it was all fixed.

ìA few days later, when I went into work, Rog called me in to his office, and suddenly I was being given a shot of fast-penta. They squeezed everything out of me.î He hesitated. ìAlmost everything. Everything about the rally plan, and then they ran off in a hurry to do something about it. Thatís where Hans and Oki first got into it, I thinkóthey did the legwork setting up the riot. I think Oki had a relative in the N.H.L.L., actually, which gave them their in.î
ìWho all was present at this interrogation?î
ìAll of them. The big four, I mean.î
ìWas that legal or illegal here? The use of fast-penta on an employee, I mean?î
ìKind of legal. I guess. I mean, theyíre allowed to use it in suspected cases of employee theft and crimes on the premises and so on. You have to sign a release when youíre first employed.î
ìI see.î

ìThere are rules about how it has to be conducted to make it admissible in court, later. But I donít think they were paying much attention to those in my case. Because the last thing theyíd want is for any of this to get to a court. Because then they locked me up in Securityís holding area.î
ìWas that also kind-of-legal?î

ìTheyíre allowed to hold suspects till the real police arrive. Except, of course, the police never did. By the time they let me out, two days later, it was all over for Lisa and her people.î He bit his lip, clenched his hands. ìI was helpless. Although not as helpless as the Gang of Four had figured, thanks to Lisa.î
ìHow was that?î

ìWhen I brought her and George the data, she told me to place a copy somewhere secretólawyer, bank vault, whereverówith instructions to simultaneously release it to a bunch of placesóthe courts, all the Prefecture departments of justice, the news, the netóin the event of my death, freezing, or disappearance. Which I did.î
ìAnd that bought you protection from your bosses?î

ìNo, they had the location out of me in no time. Thing is, Lisa and George also hid copies, and by the time NewEgypt figured this out, they were bothÖ well, Lisa was frozen and George was dead. The Gang searched, but they never found the other two copies.î
ìHow do you know?î
Leiber smiled grimly. ìIím still above room temperature and walking around.î
ìAh. Reasonable inference.î Miles rubbed his lips. ìWere Suwabi and Tennoji murdered on purpose, then? By Hans and Oki, perhaps?î

ìBy Hans and Oki, but I donít think they were told to kill anyone. I think those were attempted snatches that went wrong. They managed to get Kang and Khosla and Lisa, though.î Leiberís lips twisted. ìSpeaking of job security. Both were given bonuses and raises, after, despite the big screw-ups. I wasnít privy to the under-the-table agreements. They canít turn in their bosses without incriminating themselves, and vice versa. And I think the Four kind of liked the idea of owning their own dirty-work squad. In case they needed someone to handle people like me again.

ìAnyway, the impasse bought everyone time to calm down and think, even me. I felt so badly about it all. Especially Lisa. I mean, Iíd destroyed everything sheíd worked for, even though I was just trying to help. So when I was offered the bribe, I took it, even though I didnít believe it for a minute, because I thought it would pacify them.î He brooded. ìTheyíd bribed Rog a lot earlier, I think.î
ìWhat form did this bribe take?î

ìNothing immediately useful, they knew better than that. Itís all unvested stock options that cut in after a certain numbers of years. I always figured theyíd fire me just before they had to pay anything out, but I donít know. They did let me do some real workóI developed a noninvasive scanner test for the bad preps, which wasnít a task they could have assigned to anyone else, after all. The first payment option was due to cut in soon, though, and thatís what I set my plan on.î
ìWhat plan?î

ìTo rescue Lisa.î Leiberís eyes brightened, and he met Milesís gaze for almost the first time. ìItís whatís kept me going for the past year and a half.î His voice lowered, beseeching. ìI had to keep my job with NewEgypt in order to have access to her cryochamber, do you see? I realized it practically right away. Originally, I figured to save enough money to rescue them all, Kang and Khosla and Lisa, ship all three cryochambers secretly to Escobar for revival there. But it cost a lot more than I thought it would. Time was drawing on, I thought the Four were finally dropping their guard on me a bit, so I revised the plan to take just Lisa, alone. Take her to Escobar, make the charges against NewEgypt and the whole corrupt system from there, where weíd be safe.î
ìYouíve thought about this a lot, I see,î said Miles neutrally, and pressed his hand to his lips to prevent the escape of any premature editorials.

Leiberís expression grew almost exalted. ìIt would have worked! We could have been safe, together. We wouldnít even have had to come back to Kibou, if we didnít want. With my credentials, I could have found a job, supported us both.î
A slight, indignant disturbance of the curtain, Miles saw out of the corner of his eye. He carefully didnít turn his head that way.
Leiber cast a speculative look at Raven. ìMaybe even a place like the Durona Group.î His gaze grew more urgent. ìMaybe, if you people could help me, it still could still work outóî

Leiberís heroic visions were abruptly interrupted by the curtain being yanked back, and Madame Sato pounding on the glass and yelling something, alas made unintelligible by the barrier. Miles pointed helpfully to his wristcom.
Leiber nearly fell off his chair. ìLisa!î he cried, whether gladly or in terror Miles wasnít sure.

Madame Sato apparently didnít get the message about the wristcom, because she clenched her fists and whirled to dodge out her booth door, instead. Raven lurched up to intercept her, although only to hastily make her don a filtering mask before their own booth door slammed openóRoic had prudently moved out of the way.

ìSeiichiro Leiber, you moron!î cried Madame Sato, which was approximately what Miles had guessed sheíd been trying to say, since heíd been hard-pressed not to say it himself. ìWhat were you thinking? You were going to kidnap me, take me off-planet, and abandon my children? And trap me there, with no money to get home?î
ìNo, no!î said Leiber, rising hastily and turning his hands out in pleading. ìIt wasnít like that! Wasnít going to be like that!î

It had been going to be exactly like that, in Leiberís mind, Miles guessed. A princely rescue, with Leiber in the starring role, and the happily-ever-after, if not planned, at least much wished upon. Had Snow White in her glass coffin ever had a vote? Or a voice?
ìLisa, I know this was all my fault! I was going to make it right, I swear!î
Behind her mask, Miles thought Madame Sato was sputtering, almost beyond words. He could see her point. She snarled, ìMake it right? Make it worse!î
Raven put in, ìYou know, upsetting and stressing a new revive is not good for their immune system. Or any other system.î

Some milder exercise than towering rage was indicated, certainly. Strokes were another real possibility in the more fragile revives, Miles dimly recalled. Interested as he was in what more might be squeezed out of Leiber, it was time to intervene.

ìWell, his plan is certainly thwarted now,î Miles soothed her. ìWeíll have to see if we canít come up with something rather better.î He jumped up and dragged Ravenís chair around. ìPlease, Madame Sato, do sit down. I should be extremely glad of your input, at this point.î
Out of breath, Madame Sato sank into the seat, her brown eyes still glaring at Leiber over the top of her filtering mask. Leiber, too, sank down, or maybe his knees gave way.

Madame Sato rubbed her furrowed forehead, a gesture that made Raven frown medically. Her voice drooped in exhaustion along with her body. ìIf the corps have grown so corrupt and above the law that they can get away not just with theft, but with murder, what hope is there left for Kibou?î
ìEscape?î Leiber offered.
Her eyes shot sparks of scorn, over her mask. ìLeaving my children to be chewed up in this maw?î She drew breath. ìEveryoneís children?î

Miles said mildly, ìNewEgypt hasnít got away with murder yet. In fact, their very secrecy suggests theyíre still vulnerable on that point. A big enough stink bomb, suitably aimed, might still land on the target.î

Madame Sato shook her head. Miles wasnít sure if her spasm of despair was the result of post-revival exhaustion, perfectly understandable under the circumstances, or of an acquaintance with Kibou-dainiís troubles much deeper than his own. Ravenís glower at him suggested the former, though.

ìRoic,î he said over his shoulder, ìI want you to run a fast-penta interrogation on both those goons we have downstairs. Focus on the murders, but get as much else as you can, especially about their bosses. Shoot the recordings over to the consulate, secured link.î
ìWill such confessions be admissible to the local courts?î

ìMm, I need to think about that. The fact that weíre not the local authorities may put a wrinkle in it. Vorlynkin can ask the consulate lawyer.î Miles wondered what that as-yet-unmet woman was making of the recent stream of bizarre legal questions from her client. Well, it was doubtless time she earned her retainer. ìIn any case, I want to secure the evidence for my own purposes. Birds in the hand and all that.î
ìDo we still want to release them, after? If theyíre murderers?î

ìIt sounds as if they were amateurs, not contract killers. And bungling amateurs at that. Eh. Depends on what turns up in the interrogations. Raven can assist, but donít let them see him. No point in letting them know any more than they do already.î
ìAnd if either or both of them are allergic?î

An induced, and fatal, allergy to fast-penta was not uncommon among galactic covert operatives; Miles wasnít sure about these civilians. ìHave Raven check first. The test patches are in my kit along with the fast-penta. If so, call me.î
Roic nodded. Miles was confident in Roicís interrogation skills on criminal matters; this was one task he might safely delegate.

ìThe larger issuesÖî Milesís voice slowed. ìI donít have a handle on yet. Itís hard to see how this technology, widely adopted and combined with human nature, wouldnít run into the same traps everywhere, in due course. In a broader sense, this is Barrayarís problem, too, or will be.î Good, he had an all-purpose defense for his expense reports for this case. That had been a minor but growing concern.
Roic scratched his head. ìThing isóeveryone hereís headed for the same end. If the higher-ups allow the whole system to get too corrupt, how do they expect to assure their own future revivals?î
ìNever underestimate the human capacity for wishful thinking and willful blindness,î said Miles. Such as a whole society of people who became so wrapped up in avoiding death, they forgot to be alive?
Roic tapped his fingers on his trouser seam. ìYeah, belike.î
A motion caught Milesís eyeóthe outer door of the recovery room opening. Vorlynkin appeared, being anxiously towed by Jin and Mina.
Miles pointed. ìMadame Sato, I believe you have some visitors.î

Her head turned. She gasped, under her mask, and her eyes widened. She scrambled from her chair, Raven springing to the alert in case the sudden motion made her dangerously dizzy, but she was already banging out of the booth.
ìJin! Mina!î
ìMommy!î

The pair raced forward, but, since they did not let go of Vorlynkin, the man was pulled into a few long, unbalanced strides that brought him face to face with Madame Sato. She fell to one knee to clutch her children to her, first one, then the other, then both together, as hard as she could hug. Miles thought she might be crying. He made his way to the booth door and leaned on the jamb, watching. Even Jin, with all the austerity of his almost-twelve, didnít reject the huggy-kissy stuff now.
ìMina!î Madame Sato held her daughter a little away from herself, and stared over her mask. Her voice shook. ìYouíve grown!î
For the first time, Miles thought, those eighteen missing months and what theyíd stolen from her was brought home. Proof she could touch, not just words and more words.
She looked up at last, in some bewilderment, at Vorlynkin. ìAnd whoís this?î

Mina answered eagerly, ìItís Vorlynkin-san, Mommy. He took care of us at his house. It has a great garden! All Jinís creatures like it, too.î She grabbed Vorlynkinís hand and swung on it, without the least dismay on his part.

Vorlynkin smiled and offered Madame Sato his other hand up, which, after her first wobbling attempt to rise, she realized she needed, and took. He was tall enough that she actually had to look upósheíd been eye-to-eye with Leiber.
ìStefin Vorlynkin, Madame Sato. Iím the Barrayaran Consul to Kibou-daini. Iím very pleased to meet you at last.î

She made an abortive motion for her daughter to stop using the consul as a swing-set, but Mina had already abandoned the hand and was running around the pair in excited circles. Jin hopped up and down in a burst of explanations, most of which seemed to turn on the continued health and well-being of his creatures, with special reference to Lucky.
ìYouíve been looking after my children?î she said uncertainly.
ìOnly for the past few days, maíam. You have a couple of really good kids, there. Very bright.î
Miles thought a flicker of a smile might have turned her mouth, under the mask. It was certainly the first time heíd seen her dark eyes crinkle with pleasure.

Raven intervened at this point to run his still-new revive back to her bed, but he indulgently allowed the family reunion to go along. Miles watched through the glass, the children waving their arms and explaining their lives for the last eighteen months, Madame Sato looking dismayed as she struggled to keep up.
Vorlynkin came to watch over his shoulder. ìSo glad to see her awake and cognizant. It solves several legal conundrums for me. Now I can actually protect those kids.î
ìJust so.î Miles smiled.
Roic collected Raven and padded off about their next task. Leiber, looking confused, waved inarticulately through the glass at the Sato family and said, ìBut now what do I do?î

Miles turned to him, folding his arms and leaning against the wall. ìWell, youíre certainly not a prisoner. The only people on this planet I have the legal authority to actually arrest are other Barrayarans.î
ìUh, but what about Hans and Oki?î
ìI didnít arrest them, I kidnapped them. According to Roic. I see I shall have to explain to you the difference between permission and forgiveness, sometime.î
ìAnd what is the difference?î inquired Vorlynkin, brows rising.

ìSuccess, usually. In any case, Dr. Leiber, you are free to leave at any time. I just donít recommend it, not unless you have a better plan for hiding out than your last one. Presuming Hans and Oki are not your bossesí only resource for legwork.î
ìNo, theyíre not,î sighed Leiber.

ìYou are also free to stay. Camping here overnight would make a better hiding place than any commercial venue, to be sure. We could all use a little time to digest all this, I suspect. Although Iíd also suggest you re-think any attempt to make your orbital shuttle tomorrow afternoon. Youíd certainly not make it past the shuttleport.î
ìNo,î Leiber agreed unhappily. ìNot now.î
ìAnd what are you going to do next, my Lord Auditor?î asked Vorlynkin.
Miles rubbed his jaw and scowled in thought. ìWhat any commander does when heís outnumbered, I suppose. Look for allies.î

Roicís interrogations of their inadvertent prisoners ran as smoothly as Miles expected, though Hans and Okiís anxious self-justifications leaked through even their slap-happy fast-penta hazes. As Leiber had guessed, the two deaths had been more the result of clumsiness than malice, although the verbal picture of the pair of goons chasing the frightened old lady Tennoji around her apartment and over her balcony was sickening enough. Their attempt to force down George Suwabiís lightflyer might actually have worked, if heíd crash landed on dry ground instead of deep water. They could have pulled him out of the safety cage and whisked him off to the freezer openly feigning a quick-thinking rescue of an otherwise fatally injured man. As it was, his drowned corpse had been fished from the waters far too late for even Kibou-dainiís medics to help.

Whether the strict legal definition of their acts was murder or just manslaughter, Miles was still left with the dilemma of how, now, to be rid of his unwanted guests. Catch and release was off the table. They, and their confessions, needed to be turned over to a local police authority, but not one that could be bought by their NewEgypt bosses. Not that it would play out that way, Miles guessed. Roped together by their shared guilt, Hans and Oki would be instant sacrifices, and their bosses would purchase their own freedom through a screen of expensive lawyers. Yet Miles wanted to bring down the whole NewEgypt crew, if he could.

The meticulous Roic did get to escort his captives, individually, to the loo, and give them water. For the moment, Miles had Raven put them back into a light medicated doze, although that wasnít going to be a long-term answer either. Freezing was looking better all the time. Miles damn well wasnít packing that pair home with him. Barrayar isnít suffering a goon shortage, and anyway, ours are more competent. On the bright side, the Gang of Four must be thoroughly alarmed by now at the disappearance of their minions and Leiber, hours after they should have reported in. Yeah, it might be time to start rattling a few chains.

The recordings dispatched to the consulate, Miles was at last clear to tackle WhiteChrys, where all this had started what was beginning to seem a rather long time ago. Happily, he had no trouble bulling through to an immediate appointment with Ron Wing. Miles spent the drive out to the west end mentally rehearsing his role, so as not to crack his cover while still accomplishing his aim.

They were met in Wingís outer office by a smiling executive secretary, who rose to greet them. Also rising from a comfortable-looking chair in the corner, though with a yawn not a smile, was a startling catlike creature, with the tawny body of a miniature lion and wings not unlike Gyreís, but a disturbingly human-looking face. A colorful little striped head-cloth in the style of Egyptian statuary was tied under its feminine chin. It trotted to Roic, who froze, appalled, as it wound around his legs. It butted his kneesóit must have weighed ten kilosólooked up, and opened its mouth not to say, What goes on four legs in the morning, two legs at noon, and three legs at night? but a mere breathy half-meow.
ìStop that, Nefertiti,î scolded the secretary, and hoisted the beast to deposit it on her desk. The creature switched its tufted tail and looked offended.

Miles held out a hand for it to sniff as the secretary went on, ìItís all right, she doesnít bite or scratch. She does shed, though.î She added in cheerful explanation to the still stunned-looking Roic, ìThey were this yearís promotional give-away by our competitor and neighbor, NewEgypt.î
ìI didnít see them at the conference,î said Miles.

ìOh, they all went the first day. Very popular. They come fitted with a vocabulary of over a dozen words, and are supposed to be great with children. And good for home security.î That last was delivered in a less confident tone.
ìWhere, um, did they have them made?î Miles inquired.
ìSome bioengineering company on Jacksonís Whole, I understood,î she said.
Of course.
ìThey were shipped frozen, and NewEgypt was able to save money by reviving them in their own labs. But they prove rather tricky to maintain. Very finicky eaters.î
ìCat genesÖ mostly?î said Miles.
She looked rather doubtfully at the mini-sphinx, who stared back sphinxlike. ìI would think so. Wouldnít you? Iíll tell Mr. Wing you are here, Lord Vorkosigan.î

Wing bustled out promptly to greet his self-invited guests. Leaving Roic in the outer office to chat up the secretary, and perhaps exchange riddles with the sphinx, Miles allowed himself to be ushered into Wingís inner sanctum by the man himself and settled in a comfy and elegant gel-padded visitorís chair. Nice corner suite, windows on two sides overlooking the buildings and serene gardens of the complex; Miles was weirdly reminded of Suzeís lair.
Wing took a seat behind his big black glass comconsole desk, folding his hands and looking up in wary inquiry. ìYou say you have an emergency, Lord Vorkosigan?î
Miles picked a sphinx hair off the sleeve of his gray jacket and tried to remember what he was about. ìNo, Iíd say you do.î He sat back and scowled, wishing his feet touched the floor.
Wing seemed alert, but not alarmed. ìHow so?î

ìIíve spent a few days poking around Northbridge after the conference, and after our conference. Figuring out just what Iím getting into with my new investment. There turns out to be a hitch. Did you know?î Miles let his scowl go suspicious, in hopes of putting Wing on the defensive.
Wing merely said, ìHm?î

Miles reminded himself to keep in character while he delivered the bad news; smart enough to be believed, not so smart as to be a threat. ìThe structure of my compensation for services to be rendered depends on the value of my WhiteChrys Solstice shares rising, not falling. If they fall, I will be left holding not a profit, but a debt!î
ìThey wonít fall,î said Wing confidently.
ìI beg to differ. Your parent company, here, is about to suffer a major financial blow.î
Wing did not immediately go on soothing him, but said, ìHow so?î

ìYou know all those commodified contracts youíve bought from NewEgypt? Youíve been sold a lot of dud dead. It turns out that a particular brand of cryo-fluid on the market between fifty and thirty years ago breaks down after a couple of decades, rendering patrons nonrevivable. Brains turned to slush, as my technical consultant so vividly phrased it. Increasingly, any revivals from that period which used that product are likely to fail. Your patronsí kin are owed back millions in nuyen and all those votes.î
Wingís lips parted in genuine surprise. ìIs this true?î
ìYou can check it yourselves, as soon as you point your labs in the right direction.î
Wing sank back in his chair. ìI certainly shall.î
ìNewEgypt is your culprit. The commodified contracts scam originated from there, as I understand itógenerated by a fellow named Anish Akabane, their chief financial officer.î
Wing nodded slowly. ìI know him. Clever bastard!î He sounded more admiring than outraged.
ìIt seems to me you have a clear case against NewEgypt, you and every other cryocorp in Northbridge whoís been suckered. You might even combine forces in a joint suit.î
Wing squinted in no-doubt-rapid thought. ìOnly if it could be proved they knew.î
ìIt could be proved they knew at least eighteen months ago. You can certainly bring the bandits down.î
Wing held up a hand. ìSlow down, Lord Vorkosigan! I share your outrage, but I donít think the course you suggest will work to protect your investment.î
Leaving aside the airy nature of Milesís investment. ìSir?î
ìThis is confidential? Youíve told no one else?î
ìI started with you. Iíd planned to go on down the row of every corp in the Cryopolis, after.î
ìIím so glad you came to me first. You did the right thing.î
ìSo I hope, but what do you mean?î

ìWe have to think first of protecting the value of WhiteChrys and the interests of its shareholders, including yourself. Firstóafter checking the facts, of courseówe have this clear, if obviously limited, opportunity to unload our own liabilities. It would be the height of irresponsibility not to seize it. It would be far better for WhiteChrys to let this problem come out slowly and naturally from other sources, rather than springing it on the public all at once and creating an avoidable crisis.î
ìIím not sure I follow you.î Iím afraid I do. Damn. This dog wonít fight.

Wing shook his head. ìEvery other responsible cryocorp operating team would agree with me. This isnít something to publicize. It could be very damaging not only to WhiteChrys, but to the whole industry, even to the economy at large.î
ìSo youíre talking not a joint suit, but a, but a, a joint cover-up?î Donít sputter, Miles told himself.

ìCover-up is too strong a term.î Wing sighed as if in regret. ìThough it would certainly be preferable all around. But if this problem has come so close to the surface that even an off-worlderís casual inspection can uncover it, itís clearly far too late for concealment to be effective. The news must be about to break.î
Not so casual as all that, but Miles wasnít about to tell Wing the details.

Wing tapped his fingertips on the black glass of his desktop. ìA small head-start for us, I think. And thenóyesóI think it would be best for me to go to our competitor colleagues myself. Considering the aspects of this that threaten us all. Perhaps in a few weeks. Ah, yes! Lord Vorkosigan, your investment will be safe with us. Just leave it to me!î He sat back, smiling again, although gears plainly turned behind his eyes.
ìBut where, in all this, do those NewEgypt bastards get nailed to the wall?î Miles tried to keep his tone plaintive and not outraged.
ìHave you ever heard the phrase, Living well is the best revenge?î
ìWhere I come from, someoneís head in a bag is generally considered the best revenge.î

ìWell, ah, hm. Different cultures and all that. Well. You have delivered me a great deal to do this afternoon, none of which was on my previous schedule.î A broad hint, that, for Miles to decamp and let Wing go grapple with his damage control.
Miles could just picture it; the corps drawing together not in collision but in collusion. ìYouíve given me a lot to think about, Wing-san.î
ìAnd the reverse, Iím sure. Some tea, before you go?î Wing was clearly torn between social etiquette and getting on with this new crisis.

Cruelly, Miles said, ìWhy, yes!î Thus combining living well and revenge, he supposed, if a petty one. They repaired to the outer office, where the secretary was already engaged in filling Roic with green tea and almond cookies, and giving him admiring and grateful glances. The sphinx made plaintive noises from behind the bars of a largeÖ sphinx-carrier.

ìIím so glad youíre taking her,î said the secretary, with a nod at the cage while pouring for Miles and her boss from a delicate porcelain pot. ìSheís a very loving creature, and quite tame, but she just doesnít fit our décor.î
ìAh!î said Wing, brightening. ìHave you finally found her a home, Yuko? Good work! Iíll be so glad to get that litter box out of the executive washroom.î
Miles stared reproachfully at Roic. ìWeíre getting a sphinx?î Why? Or possibly, Why me, God?
Roic looked uncomfortable. ìI said I knew someone whoíd love tí have her.î

ìAh.î Miles trusted Roic had received some value in return. Information, hopefully. The secretary seemed a little too old for him, but whether her interest in his Barrayaran manliness was romantic or maternal hardly mattered, as long as it was friendly. And forthcoming.

Miles limited his revenge to one cup, then let himself be gently ushered out. Two underlings were produced to cart away the sphinxís food, dishes, toys, extra hats, and sanitary arrangements. Roic lugged the carrier, and oversaw it all stuffed into the back of the consulateís lift van. The sphinxís voice rose in unholy protest as they drove out under the red torii gate once more. ìAowt! Aowt!î
ìWhich way now, mílord? Any other stops?î
ìNotÖ yet, I think. My brilliant plan for fixing this mess and getting us all on our way back home just tanked. Tell you all about it on the way back to town.î
ìYes, mílord.î

Jin let himself quietly out of the isolation booth, where both his mother and Mina were napping, Mina curled on the foot of the bed like a cat. His mother looked washed-out and pale, a little scary but nothing like that other woman Miles-san and Raven-sensei had failed to revive. Jinís joy at finding her alive had crashed through him like a great wave, but now that the first flush of relief was receding, he felt all tumbled and strange. Everything was uncertain again, with the grownups back in charge. Where would they go to live now? What would happen to his creatures? Would they make him go back to school? How soon? Would he have to be stuck in with kids a year younger than him?
Could it all be taken away againÖ ?
Ako, keeping watch in the recovery room, gave him a friendly nod from her chair. Jin heard voices out in the corridor, and went to see who it was.
He shut the door behind him to find Vorlynkin-san, looking startled, confronting Raven-sensei and two new people. Jinís mouth, too, fell open as he stared at the couple.

The man was almost another Miles-sanósame height, same looksóexcept twice as wide, and with no gray in his hair. He wore a sharply-cut suit in black on black with more black that somehow made his girth look trim. The woman was even taller than Jinís mother, with bright blond hair swept back in a cool knot, and eyes almost as blue as Consul Vorlynkinís. Her suit was more flowing, in soft gray, with a silky white top and a glint of gold at her throat and ears. Her outfit reminded Jin of Miles-sanís shirt, simple yet somehow extraÖ extra-looking. Her smile down at him made him feel warm all over.
ìJin,î said Consul Vorlynkin. ìI was just coming to find you. I was about to run back to the consulate for a bit, butÖî He stared at the new not-Miles.
ìMom and Mina fell asleep,î said Jin.
ìAh, good,î said Raven-sensei. ìIíll just go check on them, and have a word with Ako, and be right with you all.î He slipped into the recovery room.
The blond ladyís eyes glinted merrily at Jin, like sunlight off a lake in summer. ìAnd whoís this, Consul?î

Vorlynkin seemed to pull himself together, though why the arrival of this pair should have scattered his wits Jin was not quite sure, well, except for the short manís surprising looks. ìThis is Jin Sato. Heís the son of the woman the Lord Auditor and Dr. Durona have just revived here. Lord Vorkosigan met him, well, Iíll let him tell it when he gets back. Jin, this is Lord Mark Vorkosigan and his partner, Miss Kareen Koudelka. From Barrayar.î

Miss Koudelka held out a slim hand for Jin to shake, just as if he were a grownup, and the man, after a beat, followed suit. Jin wondered if partner meant girlfriend or, like, coworker. The pretty woman seemed like she ought to be a corp executive, the expensive-looking bag slung over her shoulder sized for business gear, not cosmetics.

ìAre you Miles-sanís brother?î Jin asked. Like Tetsu and Ken? Jin stood, he realized, eye-to-eye with the man just as he did with Miles-san, but somehow the extra bulk made Lord Mark seem taller. And his smile didnít lurk in his eyes the way Miles-sanís did.
ìTwins, born six years apart,î the man said, sounding bored and rehearsed. ìItís a long story.î Clearly, not one he was about to tell Jin.
ìYou donít look, umÖ exactly alike,î said Jin. Lord Mark also lacked Miles-sanís cane, and he seemed to move more fluidly. Maybe he was the younger brother.
ìA distinction I go to some trouble to maintain,î said Lord Mark.
Raven-sensei let himself back out of the recovery room. ìI think you should meet Madame Suzuki first, Lord Mark.î
ìMust we deal with her? This Ted Fuwa fellow is the sole owner-of-record.î

ìOnly of the physical plant. For our purposes, the physical plant isówell, not nothing, but interchangeable. Itís the human liabilitiesóand opportunitiesóit contains that made it worth dragging you here for a closer look. And Madame Suze is unquestionably the mistress of that particular court of chaos.î
Lord Mark gave a short nodólistening, not arguing.
ìDid your brother know you were arriving, Lord Mark?î asked Vorlynkin. ìHe hadnít mentioned it to me. Nor had Dr. Durona.î His glance under his lashes at Raven-sensei was not very friendly.
ìWe caught an earlier ship than expected,î said Miss Koudelka.

ìI actually havenít any interest in impinging on whatever hornetís nest Miles is presently poking,î said Lord Mark. ìWe donít normally comment on each otherís enterprises. Think of it as the parallel-play stage of siblinghood.î
His partner-lady put in smoothly, ìActually, I understand one of the functions of the consulate is to assist Barrayaran business people on Kibou.î
Vorlynkin nodded warily. ìAlthough the Auditorial investigation naturally takes precedence, just now.î He added under his breath, ìWhatever the hell he thinks heís doingÖî
ìOf course.î Miss Koudelkaís smile grew blinding; Vorlynkin blinked. ìPerhaps, Mark, Raven, the consul should come along? Then weíll only need to explain things once.î
Vorlynkin looked nonplussed. ìJin, do you mind?î
ìOh, Jin is welcome, too,î said Raven-sensei airily. He added aside to Miss Koudelka, ìNative guide and all that.î
She nodded agreeably, and favored Jin with another sunny look.

Raven-sensei led off, Jin tagging along in silent wonder, down and under and through and up to Suze-sanís door. Lord Mark and Miss Koudelka looked all around as they walked, very keenly, the blond lady taking vid scans on the way with a tiny hand-held.

At the corner suite, Raven-sensei knocked briskly. The door was opened surprisingly soon not by Suze-san, but by Tenbury-san. ìWhatís all this?î He peered suspiciously through his hedge of hair. ìYouíve gone and brought new people in without asking!î
ìAsking is just what we came for,î said Raven-sensei. ìIím glad youíre here. May we come in and talk to Madame Suze?î
ìI suppose.î Tenbury squinted down at Lord Mark. ìGod, itís another one. How many of these sawed-off galactics do you have up your sleeve, Raven?î
Lord Markís eyebrows twitched, but Raven-sensei replied soothingly, ìJust the two,î and Tenbury gave way.

Suze-san was sitting by her window playing mah-jong and drinking something that probably wasnít tea with Medtech Tanaka; Tenbury had apparently just risen from the third seat. Their eyes opened wide at Lord Markís party.
ìNow what, Raven?î said Suze-san. ìI thought Iíd settled with you. When do I get my two revivals, eh?î
ìWeíre considering changing the Deal,î said Raven-sensei.
Suze-sanís scowl deepened.
ìInstead of two, how would you like two thousand?î

Her brows went up, though her frown still bent down; but she waved a wrinkled hand, and the whole mob filed in and pulled up seats around her. Raven-sensei first introduced Consul Vorlynkin, who, indeed, had been running in and out of her facility for the past several days, as she likely knew perfectly well. Jin cast her a nod, trying to say, This oneís all right. Tenbury half-sat on the wide windowsill, frowning and pulling on his beard.

Raven-sensei repeated his introductions: ìMadame Suzuki, may I present my employer, Lord Mark Vorkosiganóheís also Lord Auditor Miles Vorkosiganís younger brotheróand his partner, Miss Kareen Koudelka. Lord Mark is a co-owner of the Durona Group, my clinic on Escobar.î
ìWhoís the other co-owner?î Suze-san asked, staring hard at Lord Mark.

Lord Mark bowed slightly and said, ìDr. Lily Durona. Who is also founder and clone-progenitor of the original Durona Group of Jacksonís Whole. I acquired my interest a decade ago when I helped expedite the groupís removal from the ownership of Baron Fell, there, and emigration to Escobar.î
ìYou a doctor, too? Researcher?î

Lord Mark shook his head. ìEntrepreneur. My primary interest in the Durona research is to support development of an alternative to the clone-brain transplant method of life extension that will knock it out of business.î
ìThat techniqueís illegal!î said Medtech Tanaka.
ìNot on Jacksonís Whole. Unfortunately.î
Jin tugged Vorlynkinís sleeve and whispered, ìWhat are they talking about?î

He whispered back, ìSome bad rich people try to get young again by having their brains transplanted into the bodies of clones, purpose-grown to match them. Very dangerous operation, and the cloneís brain always dies.î
ìEew!î
ìI agree.î His brows drew down as he frowned anew at Lord Mark. He made a hand-down motion to Jin, Be quiet and listen, and set the example.
Lord Mark tapped his spread fingers together in a gesture very like one of his brotherís, and said, ìThe Durona Group is considering expanding its cryorevival services to Kibou-daini.î
Suze-sanís lip curled. ìThat would be a waste ofóoh, wait. Cryorevival, you say? Not cryo-storage?î

ìCryo-storage seems to be a fully mature industry here, with no room for start-ups. I think there could be far more opportunity in an arena the current cryocorps are neglecting. Raven tells me you have over two thousand unlicensed, illegal cryo-patrons stored in your lower levels. A liability that has rendered this facility unsalable by its present owner-of-record, one Theodore Fuwa.î
ìYah, when the idiot bought the place for development he didnít know we were here. He tried to get rid of his dilemma by arson, once,î said Suze-san. ìAnyway, itís closer to three thousand, by now.î
ìEven better.î
ìAnd what would you do to get rid of íem?î
ìWhy, revive them, and let them walk out on their own.î
Suze-san snorted. ìOnly if youíve found a cure for old age.î
A weird little smile turned Lord Markís lips, showing his teeth. ìJust so.î
Medtech Tanakaís head came up. In a voice of slow wonder, she said, ìWhat have you people got?î

He nodded to her. ìNot, alas, a fountain of youth. It may prove to be a fountain of middle-age, however. We donít think itíll do much for anyone under sixty, but from there up it seems to knock off about twenty years. So far. Not a single-pronged treatmentósort of a cocktail, really, as it presently standsóbut our R & D group has finished virtual and live mammal trials, and weíre almost ready to move up to clinical trials on humans.î
ìHas it been tried on any humans?î asked Tanaka-san.
ìJust one, so far,î put in Raven-sensei.
ìOne trial?î
ìOne human. Lily Durona, as it happens,î said Raven-sensei. ìYou can imagine how riveted the whole Group is by the outcome.î
ìCan you guarantee the results of this treatment?î
ìOf course not,î said Lord Mark. ìThatís why itís called a trial. But by the time we work through two or three thousand varied test cases, all the bugs should be ironed out.î
ìYouíll never get permissions,î said Suze-san.

ìOn the contrary. Escobar has reciprocal medical licensing arrangements with Kibou-daini. Any facility I might buy here would move under the Durona Groupís regulatory umbrella from the instant the purchase was registered. No need to stir things up by reapplying for, ah, anything.î Lord Mark rubbed his double chin. ìIf the trials worked out, the enterprise might become self-supporting in as little as two years.î
ìAnd after twenty years,î said Tenbury, ìwhat happens to people? Can they go around again?î
Lord Mark shrugged. ìAsk me in two decades.î
ìDamn,î said Suze-san. ìThis sounds like a license to print money, you know that, young man?î

Lord Mark made an impatient throw-away gesture. ìA side-venture, from my point of view. It will be safer than the clone-brain transplant, to be sure, but the sort of octogenarian customer who would buy a body of an eighteen-year-old is hardly going to prefer a body of sixty. We have to do better, somehow. But this could be another small step in the right direction.î
ìWill it only work on revives? Frozen folk?î asked Tenbury.
ìOh, no. I expect it will work even better on the never-frozen.î
Suze-sanís wrinkled lips drew back in a fierce smile. ìWho wouldnít choose it over a risky illegal brain transplant, hell. Who wouldnít choose it over freezing?î
ìPeople are strange,î said Lord Mark. ìI make no predictions.î
Medtech Tanaka said, ìBut what about the poor?î
Lord Mark gave her a blank look. ìWhat about íem?î

Their stares of mutual incomprehension lengthened. Miss Koudelka put in, ìIf I may offer an interpretation, Mark, I believe Madame Suzuki and her friends feel just as strongly about Kibouís poor being shut out of their chance at the future as you feel about the Jacksonian clones being shut out of their chance at a future. Or they wouldnít have been running this place as a protest for more years than youíve been running the Durona group.î She turned to Suze-san. ìMark, and Dr. Durona for that matter, were both raised on Jacksonís Whole, where one must hustle constantly to survive, and there is seldom margin to think of others. Theyíre both getting over it, slowly. I suggest we all take the chance to consider the wider aspects of this while we look around. Mark and I hoped to inspect the place before our first meeting with Mr. Fuwa.î
Suze-san sat back, looking strange and stern. ìAnd if notÖ ?î
Lord Mark shrugged. ìThen weíll just have to meet with Fuwa without your input.î
Suze-sanís eyes narrowed. ìThink you hold all the cards, do you?î
Miss Koudelka said, ìItís hardly such a zero-sum game. A cooperative venture might yield major advantages to all, according to their varied needs.î

ìYes,î said Suze-san slowly, ìI need to think.î She sat forward and jammed the cork into the top of her square bottle with a hand that shook slightly. ìTenbury, take íem around. Let them see whatever they like.î
Tenbury nodded and pushed off the wall. ìFollow me, then, folksÖî

They all shuffled out after Tenbury, except for Suze-san and the old medtech, who bent their heads together before the door even shut. Out in the corridor, Jin edged close to Consul Vorlynkin, and whispered up to him, ìWhat did they mean? I didnít understand any of that. Why was Suze-san mad?î

They trailed the group not quite out of earshot. Vorlynkin rubbed his knuckles across his lips, looked down at Jin, and lowered his voice. ìIf Lord Mark has the money, and I gather he does, he could buy this facility outright and there would be nothing Madame Suzuki could do about it. He could doówell, not anything, because heíd pick up liability for all those cryo-corpses downstairs, but in theory he could clear out all the live people here as trespassers and dump them back on the street.î
ìThatís not right!î said Jin indignantly.
Miss Koudelka cast him a glance over her shoulder, and a funny smile. Jin blushed furiously.
ìIím not sure thatís quite what he has in mind,î murmured Vorlynkin, ìbut I guess weíll have to see.î
Jin frowned, trying to sort it all out. ìHow come Miles-san is Lord Vorkosigan, and his brother is Lord Mark, if their last names are both Vorkosigan?î

ìBoth are the sons of Count Aral Vorkosigan. Your, er, friend Miles-san is Lord Vorkosigan because he is his fatherís heir. Lord Mark, as the younger brother, has a courtesy title with no direct political duties.î
ìOh.î

The consul had a very thoughtful look on his face as he followed Tenbury and the new Barrayarans. Jacksonians. Whatever. So if Lord Vorkosigan and Lord Mark were brothers, how come theyíd been raised on different planets? Did all that creepy clone history have anything to do with them? And was that five-year-old boy, the one with all the confusing names his own parent couldnít remember, lord anything?
Jin thought of Miles-sanís story about being allowed to sit in on his fatherís conferences, if he was quiet and useful, so shut his mouth and hurried to keep up.

Two hours later, Jin was yawning. He wondered if Miles-san had ever fallen asleep at any of those old meetings. Maybe his dadís business, whatever it was, had been more interesting than this. Theyíd trailed Tenbury-san all over: up and down and through parts of the facility even Jin had never seen. The talk was all boring grownup stuff about finances and drains and regulations. It never did get back to more strange stories about cloning and medical murders. Tenbury showed off his shop and tools and tricks, Lord Mark taking it all in expressionlessly, Miss Koudelka outright encouraging the custodian to drone on forever with way too many questions. Jin thought of abandoning them and going back to the recovery room to see if his mom and Mina were awake yet. He was getting hungry.
They were crossing the parking garage under the old patient intake building, when everyoneís heads turned at the sound of pounding and muffled yells coming from a door marked No Admittance.
ìHadnít someone better let that person in? Or out?î asked Miss Koudelka.
ìOut, and no,î said Raven-sensei. ìTheyíre Lord Vorkosiganís prisoners. They must have woken up. I hadnít wanted to give them too much sedative, atop the fast-penta and the stunner hangovers.î

Lord Mark held up his hands, palm out. ìNo affair of mine, then.î He didnít sound surprised that his brother went around drugging and detaining people, but merely asked, ìWhen is he thinking of removing them? I expect my deal to be moving rather quickly.î
ìDonít know.î Raven-sensei shrugged. ìTheyíre his puzzle-pieces.î As the pounding continued, he added, ìAll the same, Iíll wait till Roic comes back to go in and settle them. Theyíre a nasty pair.î
Jin tilted his head and ventured nearer to the door. ìHey! Thatís old Yaniís voice!î
ìWho?î said Raven-sensei, and ìAre you sure?î said Tenbury.
ìHey, Yani! Is that you in there?î
The pounding stopped. A quavery voice cried, ìJin? Is that you? Unlock the door and let me out!î
ìWhere are the two guys?î Jin yelled back.
ìI heard someone thumping and carrying on and went to go look,î Yani returned, muffled. ìWhat call they got to go locking people up around here?î
Raven-sensei threw up his hands and clenched his teeth. ìOh, my Lord Auditor will not love this.î He bent to the lock.

Lord Mark stood back, drawing a businesslike stunner from his black jacket. Miss Koudelka didnít get behind him, but rather, circled to cover another angle, hitching her shoulders and flexing her hands and suddenly looking very athletic.
A tense pause, and the door fell open.
Yani stumbled out, swearing. He looked rumpled and wild, with a big bruise on his forehead and dried blood around his nose.
Raven-sensei peered within. ìCrap. Gone!î

As Roic drove them into the underground garage, Miles flinched at the sight of the mob clustered around the open door of the office where theyíd left their prisoners. His eye skipped to the empty space across the concrete where the captured NewEgypt van had been parkedóand widened, when he spotted the sleek blond head bobbing above the dark ones. He didnít even need to look down to know who heíd see standing level with her shoulder.
ìWhat tí hell?î said Roic, pulling to a halt. ìWhatís Miss Kareen doing here?î
ìTrailing my brother, no doubt. What I want to know is what the hell Mark is doing here.î

They disembarked, and Miles shouldered swiftly through the gawkers to stare into the barren office. But even his best Auditorial glare couldnít make Hans and Oki magically reappear. Not that he wanted them, exactlyÖ He turned to sort out Tenbury and Raven, Mark and Kareen, Consul Vorlynkin, Jin jittering at his elbow pouring out the escape tale in a rapid high voice, and battered old Yani, looking something between irate and contrite. But no worse, thank God, and by his complaints still oblivious to his close encounter with one of Kibou-dainiís shadier death angels.
ìHow long ago did this happen?î Miles tried to cut to the essentials.
ìVery soon after you left, at a guess,î said Raven ruefully. ìIím afraid I under-medicated. SorryÖî
Miles waved a hand, in understanding if not absolution. ìSo theyíve been gone at least two hours, maybe almost three. Plenty of time to get home. Or somewhere.î

A tactical tree began to sketch itself in his mind. If the pair had bugged out intending only to save themselves, they might be anywhere, but were unlikely to come back, and certainly not with reinforcements, the police and their own bosses being equally dangerous to them in such a flight. If theyíd dutifully returned to NewEgyptÖ the possibilities grew more complex. I wonder if we passed them on the road? Too lateÖ The two goons had gained a good look at Roic, might have glimpsed Raven, had not yet seen the memorable Miles, but Roic was pretty remarkable all on his own; and once heíd been identified, the trace back to Miles could be swift, if rather baffling from NewEgyptís point of view.

And NewEgypt now knew the location of Suzeís facility, and they had to be pretty sure Leiber, their original target, had come here, though they couldnít be sure if he was still here. Had NewEgypt figured out yet that their employeeóformer employee, by now, no doubtóhad absconded with Satoís cryo-corpse? And if so, would they imagine sheíd been revived already, or would they still picture Leiber carting her about in a cryochamber like some especially awkward souvenir? Could they track back to whatever security vids they maintained from the day Miles and his strike force had liberated her unfortunate substitute Chen? And what would they make of it if they did? AndÖ ìDamn,î Miles muttered. ìI have to talk to that idiot Leiber again.î If he was to second-guess their thinking, he wanted more details on those key NewEgypt execs. He sighed and raised his voice. ìAnd hello, Mark. Why are you here? And so unexpectedly, too.î
Mark tilted his head in un-apology, smirking a bit.
Miles eyed Raven. ìI thought weíd had an understanding about such surprises.î
Looking faintly guilty, Raven shrugged and mumbled, ìEarlier ship.î
Miles abandoned the unfruitful point. ìHi, Kareen.î
She glinted back at him, reassuring in a way. Sort of. ìHi, Miles. Howís it going?î

ìNot as well as I thought, evidently.î He peered one last time into the drab little officeóstill emptyóand turned away. Tenbury, bless him, was soothing Yani and ushering him off to visit Medtech Tanaka.
A penetrating yowl rose from the back of the consulate van. ìAowt! Aowt!î

Vorlynkinís brows rose. ìHave you kidnapped someone else?î His tone seemed more resigned than disapproving. Miles thought of those tales about water wearing away stone; the consulís edges were growing more rounded, at least.
ìNot this time. Jin, Armsman Roic has a present for you. Live cargo.î
ìReally?î Jin was instantly diverted; Miles jerked his head at Roic, who led the boy out of earshot to meet his new pet. Good with kids, Wingís secretary had promised.
And you trust those people, why? Kareen, curious, followed Roic.
Miles lowered his voice to Vorlynkin and Raven. ìRaven, how soon could Madame Sato be moved out of medical isolation?î
ìTo the consulate?î said Vorlynkin.

Miles nodded. ìIf secrecy, which was our first defense, has failed, then the consulate would be a better location for fending off legal attacks. Granted it hasnít much advantage for illegal, physical attacks. I have some help on the way for that, but theyíre not here yet.î
Ravenís lips pressed together in medical reluctance. ìTomorrow? Not that her bio-isolation isnít compromised already, with those kids in and out. Little vectors that they are.î
ìWell, load her up with every immune system booster in your arsenalóî
ìI already have.î

Miles made a thumbs-up gesture. ìThen plan to decamp as early as possible tomorrow. In fact, Vorlynkin, if you could stay here tonight, and be ready to move her and her kids out at a momentís notice, that might be, um, prudent.î He added reluctantly, ìLeiber, too.î
ìDo you think NewEgypt will react that quickly?î asked Vorlynkin.

ìI truly do not know. My impression of all these cryocorp chiefs so far is that theyíd rather hunker down behind a wall of lawyers than, say, hire mercs, but this crew has already shown it can move fast at need. And, despite the lethal screw-ups, their actions eighteen months ago must have seemed successful at the time. I wish them a distraught and sleepless night figuring it all out, anyway.î
Vorlynkin frowned, taking this in.
Miles turned to his clone-brother. ìAnd you?î

ìKareen and I jumped over from Escobar to look into a real estate deal Raven spotted,î said Mark, unperturbed by the foregoing. ìThe short version is, Madame Suzeís set-up could be the perfect venue for large-scale human trials of the Durona Groupís latest life-extension treatment. If so, I mean to buy the place from the unhappy current owner-of-record, this fellow Fuwaólock, stock, and liabilities.î Mark jerked a thumb downward to indicate the frozen sleepers stacked in the hidden corridors below. ìIíd take it as a personal favor, Lord Auditor Brother, if you donít mess up my Deal.î
Milesís lips twitched. ìHappily, Vor views on nepotism remain culturally generous, even in what our late grandfather would have called this degenerate age. But donít mess up my case.î
ìHavenít the least interest in your case, thanks. Which is what, by the way?î
ìRaven didnít apprise you?î
ìNo, heís been virtuously closed-mouthed.î
Well, no one could say that a Durona didnít earn his or her pay. ìIt all started with an attempt by a Kibou cryonics company called WhiteChrys to expand onto Komarr.î
ìThat smells.î
ìOh, youíve heard of it?î

ìNot before now. But at a glance, thereís a physical, financial, and cultural distance that doesnít explain itself.î Markís lips curved slightly. ìAnd then thereís you, popping up in the middle of it. Always a tip-off.î

ìMm,î said Miles. ìWell, the WhiteChrys part is a train that has left its station, and can run on rails to its appointed end. So far. This NewEgypt involvement is a side-issue that grew complicated.î His jaw set. ìIím trying not to leave undue collateral damage upon a local kid who befriended me, at some cost to himself. Good intentions, Mark. My path is paved with them.î
ìSo glad I donít have any of those.î Markís glance grew uncomfortably shrewd. ìItís not your planet, you know. You canít fix it.î
ìNo, butÖ well, no. But.î
ìWell, try not to leave too much rubble in your wake. I can use this place.î

ìSo you said.î Miles hesitated. ìLife extension, you say. Does this one look better that the last two Durona developments you were so excited about? That, excuse the expression, died on the lab benches?î
ìMaybe. The one human trial looks hopeful so far. Lily Durona, if you were wondering.î
It was Milesís turn to raise his brows. ìAll right, Iím officially impressed, if Lily was willing to try it on herself.î
Markís smile went a little flat. ìLily,î he said, ìran out of time to wait.î
Miles drummed his fingers on his trouser seam. ìHas it been tried on an older male, yet? Speaking of running out of time.î
Miles and his clone-brother exchanged very similar looks.
Mark said, ìDo you think he could even be persuaded to try it?î
ìMm, not by me, perhaps. Our mother might give it a go. Betan, you know, anything for science.î
ìThatís one more reason Iím anxious to move these human trials along.î
ìYou might actually be more successful at persuading him if it were still billed as dodgy. Hit those old Vor service-to-the-Imperium reflexes, and all.î
ìThatís so strange.î
Miles shrugged. ìThatís the Count-our-father.î He added, ìSo, if your deal goes through, would you and Kareen be spending much time on Kibou?î

Mark shook his head. ìOnce itís set up and running, I figure to turn it over to Raven to develop. Past time he was promoted.
