So far, this is not the knock-out competition to the clone-brain transplant business I was hoping for, but itís early days yet.î Mark smiled slowly. ìOn the other hand, if it proved sufficiently profitable, maybe I could hire my own space mercs and attack the Jacksonian cloning lords directly.î
Miles grimaced. ìDo you remember the last time you tried that?î
ìVividly. Donít you?î
ìPatchily,î said Miles dryly.
Mark winced.

ìIn the event, though Iíve no doubt Admiral Quinn could do the job, I would beg you to hire a different outfit.î Just in case this wasnít quite a joke. With Mark, on this subject, it could be hard to tell. ìWhat are you two doing next? Do you have a hotel?î
ìNo, we came straight from the shuttleport. Next, weíve made arrangements to meet Fuwa here.î
ìIsnít that after local business hours?î
Mark shrugged. ìIím on system ship-time.î
ìCan I sit in?î
ìSit in, yes. Mix in, no.î

ìMm,î said Miles, but Jin, Roic and Kareen returned before he could take exception to this. Jin was bouncing with pleasure, but he paused to stare in the usual amazement at Miles and his clone-brother standing toe-to-toe. Miles still wished Mark hadnít picked weight gain as a way to differentiate himself, but Markís grim glee at his progenitor-brotherís discomfort with the choice was probably just a bonus, from his own point of view. Complicated man, Mark.
ìI want to show my sphinx to Mom and Mina!î said Jin.
ìYou mustnít take it into her booth,î said Raven, coming alert.
ìI know that,î said Jin. ìBut I can hold it up to the glass. Can Roic-san help me cart everything?î
Roic glanced at the empty office and cast Miles a tiny head-shake, bodyguard-conscious again. Vorlynkin caught it, and said smoothly, ìIíll give you a hand, Jin.î
Raven added prudently, ìIíll come along.î
ìActually,î said Miles, ìI think Leiberís still up there; weíll both come.î

Tenbury returned then, to continue the interrupted tour; with no more than an eyebrow-twitch from Mark and a farewell smile from Kareen, the three went off toward another exit. Miles followed Vorlynkin, who carried the sphinx-carrier in Jinís train. Plaintive cries of ìAowt! Hum!î drifted back through the stale shadows of the underground garage.
Out. Home. You and me both, Sphinx.
His motherís reaction to the sphinx was disappointing, Jin thought, but not surprising. Familiar, in fact, and comforting thereby.
ìJin, no!î she said, holding her hand to her lips. ìWhere would you keep it?î

Nefertiti squirmed in a disgruntled fashion under Jinís arm as he hoisted her up on his hip for his mother to see, and attempted to flap her wings, but practice handling the fiercer Gyre left Jin undismayed. ìIíll take good care of her! Donít I always? She came with a file of instructions, too, so nothing can go wrong.î
His mother rubbed her forehead, in her bed beyond the glass wall. ìThatís not the point, this time, Jin love.î

Mina, who had been lurking on the foot of the bed all day, sat up, interested. ìSheís huge! Bigger than Lucky and Gyre put together. She sort of looks like Lucky and Gyre put together, really. Oh, say yes, Mommy!î She wriggled down and exited the booth on a slight puff of positive air pressure.
ìDid Tenbury get the intercom working?î Jin asked, realizing a bit belatedly that something new had been added. ìWhen did he come by?î
ìNo, it was Consul Vorlynkin,î said Mina, bending to stare into the sphinxís slow blink. ìShe has a funny faceÖî
ìOh, how?î
ìI found the on-switch,î said Vorlynkin, leaning one shoulder against the glass wall and watching all this in some bemusement.
Raven-sensei bent to capture Minaís mask and pop it into the sterilizer box for re-use.
Nefertiti flexed her claws and growled, and Jin set her down on her four paws, where she flapped her wings with a burring noise for all the world like one of the chickens.
ìDoes she fly?î asked Mina, holding out a hand for the sphinx to sniff.
ìI donít think so,î said Jin. ìHer wings are almost the same size as Gyreís, but sheís way heavier.î
ìThese custom genetic constructs are usually made to be decorative, not functional,î advised Raven-sensei. ìDepending on what the buyer orders, of course.î
Mina frowned. ìThat seems mean, to give her wings she canít fly with.î

Jin crouched on his heels and scratched the creatureís shoulder blades, between the wings, which folded tamely again as she stretched into the caress. She could not lick her fur like a cat, nor preen her feathers like a bird, so Jin would have a lot of interesting grooming to do, according to the care instructions in the file. ìI wonder, do they lay eggs, or have live babies? One at a time, or a litter like kittens? I wonder if there are any male ones, left over?î And if he could find one, somehowÖ

ìThere may not have been any males made,î mused Raven-sensei. ìI believe sphinxes were traditionally female. But these proprietary constructs normally arenít given the ability to reproduce. Youíd likely have to clone her, and hand-raise the babies.î

Jinís imagination took fire. Home cloning of small animals wasnít that hard, if you could get the right equipment, from a pet supply place or hobbyist who was upgrading or quitting. Hardly something to be found in an alley scavenge, but there ought to be used stuff for cheap somewhereÖ
ìHum!î said the sphinx, plaintively.
ìShe talks!î cried Mina, her face breaking into a delighted smile.
ìThey come with about a twenty-word vocabulary, according to the file,î said Jin. ìI donít know if you can teach them more, like a parrot.î
ìWe can tryÖî

Beyond the glass, their mother made a noise of hopeless maternal protest, much like the halfway point of other such negotiations, so Jin took heart. But this time, she said, ìJin, we donít even have a home to take her to, right now. Oh, no, I just thought of that! Whatís happened to our apartment, and all my things? Nobody could have been paying rent for a year and a half, with no one living there. Ohóand my bank accountówhat happened to my money, after I was frozen? If I have no job, no money, no place for us to liveóî

ìAunt Lorna has some of your clothes in boxes in the attic, I know,î Mina piped up. ìAnd she took my stuff and Jinís. She had to sell the big couch, and the kitchen table, and a couple of the other big things, because she didnít have room, though.î

Consul Vorlynkin turned and spoke through the glass, earnestly. ìThese are all solvable problems, Madame Sato, but none of them need be solved today, or all at once. As part of the Lord Auditorís caseóa protected witness, more or lessóyour immediate needs will be covered by our consulate.î
ìMy committee, my friendsówhatís happened to them all, beyond the ones you say NewEgypt murdered or took away? What if theyóî Her voice shrank to silence.

ìYour first task must be your own physical recovery,î Raven-sensei put in, with a look of concern at her sudden distress. ìYour normal mental resilience will follow. In two to four weeks, not two to four daysóyou have to give yourself time.î
ìIíve never had enough time.î She pressed her hands to her temples. ìAnd that appalling creatureó!î

Vorlynkin cleared his throat. ìIím not sure the Lord Auditor was thinking it through, when he accepted the animal. Nevertheless, it may be kept in the consulateís back garden with the rest of Jinís creatures, for now. Theyíre doing no harm at all, there. Livens the place up, really. The space was underutilized.î
She sighed, folded her arms, half-laughed, quelling Jinís growing alarm. ìI suppose it just looms so absurdly large because itís closest.î But her eyes sought Jin and Mina, not the sphinx.

Since they werenít going back to the consulate tonight after all, Vorlynkin let Jin speak on his wristcom with Lieutenant Johannes, and talk him through how to care for his creatures till Jin returned tomorrow. Johannes didnít even sound sarcastic at the added chores. So that was all right, for now.

Miles-san and Roic had taken Leiber-sensei off to another room to talk, right after theyíd come in. They returned at length, toting, unexpectedly, a big stack of dinner boxes from Ayakoís Cafe. Miles-san let it be known this bounty was courtesy of Miss Kareen, who had somehow found out where to get it, how to have it delivered to the facility, and had paid for it all, too.

They all ended up having a sort of picnic in the recovery room; Raven-sensei even took in a box to Jinís mother, so that when he pulled back the curtains after his medical check, it was almost as if they were all eating a family meal together again. Jin thought she looked a bit better after she ate, sitting up less wearily, and with more color in her face. But then, Ayakoís curry was always very good.

It was funny to watch big Roic sitting cross-legged on the floor, being instructed on how to use chopsticks by Mina. Miles-san handled his pretty well, for a galactic; he claimed heíd practiced on the ship coming here, and at other times in the past. When he let slip heíd been to Old Earth itself, twice, Mina made him tell stories of his visits, though he mainly told her about his second trip, his wife, and gardens, lots of different gardens. All he said of his first trip was that it was purely business, heíd never got out of one city, and that it was the first time heíd met his brother, which last remark seemed very weird to Jinís ear. Consul Vorlynkin pulled his lip and looked thoughtful at this, but he didnít ask any helpful questions, and Miles-san didnít expand.

With frequent references to the instruction file, Jin fed tidbits to Nefertiti, who apparently could eat some kinds of people food but not others, at least not without messy digestive consequences. Unfortunately, Ako came in just as the sphinx was having an accident in the darkest corner, which was Jinís fault really because he hadnít paid enough attention to her little mutters of Poo! Pee! during her restless explorations of the recovery room. Ako was very upset, and made Jin clean it up, which was fair, but then insisted the creature couldnít spend the night in here. Raven-sensei, at least, seemed undisturbed by biological messes, and stayed out of the debate. Jin finally promised to take Nefertiti back to his rooftop hideout for overnight, which satisfied Ako, but then Mina wanted to tag along and see the place.

Miles-san and Roic had gone off by then to meet with Lord Mark and Suze-san, so Consul Vorlynkin, after a glance through the glass at Jinís worried-looking mother, volunteered to go along and help lug the sphinx carrier, and make sure that all was well. Jinís mother smiled gratefully at him, so Jin supposed that was all right, too.
They were filing down the end stairs when they met Bhavya, one of Akoís friends, panting up.
ìJin! Have you seen Ako? Tanaka-san wants her on the second flooróan emergency cryoprep. Some poor old lady collapsed in the cafeteria, all in a heap, they say.î
ìSheís up in the recovery room with my mom.î Jin pointed back up the stairs. ìRaven-senseiís there, too.î
Bhavya nodded and ran on, waving thanks without looking back.
Vorlynkin wheeled to stare after her. ìShould we go try to help?î
Jin shook his head. ìNaw, this happens all the time. Well, not all the time, but every week or so. Tanaka-san knows what to do.î
Vorlynkin looked doubtful, but followed Jin down to the tunnels.
ìThe layout down here is very confusing,î he remarked.
ìYah, the tunnels below are all offset from the buildings above, and run underneath the streets, too. And some go down four levels, and some five or six. You kind of have to memorize them.î

Jin had no trouble finding his own familiar route, even when they passed out of range of the lit section, and Vorlynkin drew a small hand light from his jacket to illuminate the steps. Mina, who had walked on her own thus far, took a prudent grip on his wide coat sleeve in the deepening shadows. They trudged upward five flights to come out at last from the exchanger tower door onto Jinís roof. Vorlynkin wasnít wheezing too badly, for a grownup, despite carting the carrier.

Jin had lost track of time in the windowless recovery room, but it seemed to have grown very late. The air was damp and chill, lit by diffuse reflections from the street lights in the area that gave everything a funny brown tinge. The city noises had quieted down the way they usually only did after midnight. But around the side of the tower, Jin found his tarps were all still up and taut, not blown loose by the weather yet. His little refuge was littered with a dreary residue of things not taken away the other dayónot needed for his creatures, or too big and awkward to fit in the lift van, or too junky to salvage. Heíd taken his own hand light down off its wire and packed it along, so it was now less-than-usefully back at the consulate, but Vorlynkin amiably shone his around while Jin explained his old life up here to Mina, and Mina made admiring and envious noises.

When they let her out of her carrier, Nefertiti did not at once take to her new environment. She stared around warily, crouching, then at last went off in a stiff-legged reconnoiter. Jin followed along, explaining to Vorlynkin about the gruesome fate of the baby chicks who couldnít fly yet. ìI canít tell, if she went over the edge, if sheíd just plummet, or flutter down like the big chickens, or even fly away.î The dense muscles Jin had felt beneath the golden fur didnít help him decide. ìMaybe Iíd better tie a line around her leg like Miles-san.î

ìHm?î said Vorlynkin, so Jin explained his first nightís safety procedures, which just made Vorlynkin go ìHm!î and set his teeth to his lower lip. But from the way his eyes crinkled, Jin didnít think he was mad or anything.

Jinís old bedding of shredded flimsies was still piled against the wall; if he slept out here, he could keep an eye on his new pet. Would Mom miss him? Sheíd have Minaóor would Mina try to stay out here with him?

Jin rose on his toes to make a grab when Nefertiti stretched her considerable length, put her front paws on the parapet, and peered over, but she drew back without any effort to launch herself fatally over the side. She visited Jinís latrine corner, and used it properlyóJin explained about the bucket-flushing to Vorlynkinóand Jin made sure to praise her, after the confusions about the corner of the recovery room. The sphinx did not quite look as if she believed him. She stretched and flapped her wings, but folded them again when she went to look over the parapet on the opposite side, toward the narrow parking lot behind the old complex.

And stiffened, growling, staring down with a predatory intensity like Lucky regarding the rats, back when Lucky had been much younger. The fur went up in a ridge along her back, and her wings spread and quivered, making a sinister rustling-rattling noise. Her tufted tail lashed.
ìFoes!î she whined. ìFoes!î
ìWhat?î said Vorlynkin, sounding startled. He stepped up to peer along with her; Jin joined him.
Mina, who was not so fond of heights, hung back a few paces and asked, ìWhat does she see?î

Jin wasnít sure what kind of night vision the sphinx had, but what he saw was a van parked in the shadowiest part of the lot, and some dark-dressed men moving about below. One swung some sort of long hammer or bat, three or four dull thumps, and Jin heard a ground-floor window pop out and fall from its frame, inward, perhaps onto a carpet, he guessed from the muffled clatter.
ìSomebodyís breaking in to the building,î he whispered back over his shoulder to Mina, who at this news overcame her nerves and joined him to stare.
ìMaybe itís robbers,î she whispered back.
ìWhat would anybody want to steal out of here?î The building had been stripped of usable furniture and equipment long ago; anything left inside was valueless or non-portable.

Two of the men lugged a big barrel-like thing from the van; they did something to it, then hoisted it through the window and let it fall and roll. A strange pungent aroma seeped up through the night mist, which made Vorlynkin jerk back and swear.
ìNot robbers,î he said through his teeth. ìArsonists!î He grabbed Minaís hand and looked frantically around.

Below, one of the men threw something through the window, and they all ran for their vehicle. Theyíd evidently left a driver waiting, because they shot out of the lot, past where the chain-link gate had been broken open, in a spray of gravel before the van doors were even all the way shut.

A flash of orange light; below Jinís feet, the building quaked as a boom echoed out across the lot and broke into mumbling thunder against the buildings across the street. A greasy boil of flame belched from the window, a licking tongue two meters long.
ìFire!î screamed the sphinx, all her fur on end, and her eyes like gilded saucers. ìFire! Foes! Fire!î
ìWe have to get out of this building, right now!î said Vorlynkin; Mina yelped as his hand tightened on hers. Vorlynkin lurched toward the towers. ìWhich stairs are farther from the fire?î
ìNot that way!î said Jin. ìThereís an outside ladder drops down to the alley on the other side.î

Vorlynkin nodded and ran, jerking Mina along with him; Jin grabbed up Nefertiti and ran after him. The sphinx struggled and hissed in his arms. Was there time to stuff her back into her carrier? Maybe not. Vorlynkin reached the opposite edge of the roof and found the steel staples.
ìI have to go first, to let down the extension!î Jin yelled to Vorlynkin.
ìMina next,î said Vorlynkin.
ìI canít reach that far!î Mina sounded like she wanted to cry.
ìIíll lower you over, and hold you till you get your grip,î said Vorlynkin. ìGo, Jin!î
ìWhoíll carry Nefertiti?î
Vorlynkin choked back something short, and said, ìI will.î

Jin dropped Nefertiti, hoping she wouldnít bolt away, vaulted over the parapet, and slapped down the rungs faster than heíd ever gone in his life. Unlatched the ladder, thumped at it, prayed it wouldnít stick or hang up. It rattled, then reached its full extension with a clang. ìAll right!î he called up.

Minaís kicking legs dangled over his head, then she found her footing and started down with no more than one scared meep. The rungs really were too far apart for her to reach comfortably. Above, Jin heard Vorlynkin swearing, and the scrunch of his footsteps, and the sphinx screaming, ìFire! Foes! Fire!î and, apparently confused in her vocabulary by the commotion, ìFood!î

Vorlynkin yelped in pain, seemingly from some greater distance, and swore some more. Jin reached the ground and stretched up to catch Mina, whose sport shoes wavered in the air when she ran out of rungs before she ran out of space. ìYouíre all right! Just let go!î She fell into him, knocking him to the ground; they both rolled, then scrambled to their feet and stared upward. At that point, Jin found out how well sphinxes could fly, when Nefertiti sailed over the parapet, wings flapping madly, and descended. She neither plummeted nor soared, but she did land right-side-up on all four paws like a cat, hard enough to grunt when her belly hit the ground, but not hard enough to break anything.

Vorlynkinís big dark shape finally swung out over the edge; he dropped the last two meters, hit with knees bending like the sphinxís, staggered, but didnít fall. Blood was running down his face from a deep triple scratch below his left eye.

ìJin!î Vorlynkinís voice was sharp and hard, brooking no debate. ìTake Mina straight to your mother, and do what Dr. Durona tells you to. If this fire spreads, they may have to evacuate all the buildings in the complex.î He raised his wristcom to his lips and began snapping connect-codes into it.
Jin dove for Nefertiti, who flapped away screeching.
ìLeave the bloody animal!î Vorlynkin snarled over his shoulder, already starting away down the alley. ìBoth of you, run!î

Ted Fuwa, the old cryofacilityís putative owner, turned out to be more or less what Miles had expectedóa big, harried man in his late forties who looked as if heíd be more at home on a construction site than in a conference chamber, even one so strange as Madame Suzeís quarters at midnight.

A less-expected presence was the consulateís local lawyer, an alert, composed, compact woman, with wiry salt-and-pepper hair, who stood barely taller than Miles himself. Kareen, Miles was unsurprised to learn, had persuaded her to come here after hours. Madame Xia stared back at him with at least as much covert interest, as the source of the increasingly bizarre stream of legal questions sheíd been fielding for the past week or so from her formerly staid and routine client. Miles trusted she was having her accumulated curiosity satisfied tonight.

Miles missed Vorlynkin, told off to stay with Sato and her children, and Suze wasnít happy that Tanaka had been called away to deal with some medical crisis, so he supposed the shifting sides, however you counted them, were still evenly matched. Suze and Tenbury versus Mark and Kareen, Miles as unruly witness with Roic his silent partner, the attorney throwing in comments and questions now and then that gave everyone pause, and Fuwa versus everyone, although Miles wasted little sympathy on him.
Madame Suze folded her arms and stared hard at Mark. ìYou still have given me no guarantees whatsoever about future provisions for the poor.î
ìIím not running a charity, you know,î Mark returned, irritably.
ìI am,î snapped Suze.

ìYes, but for how much longer?î asked Mark. ìSooner or later, and more sooner than later, I think, it would be your turn to go downstairs. And you would lose control of this place in any case. Tenbury and Tanaka might hold things together for a while, but after thatówhat?î

ìItís what I was waiting for,î put in Fuwa, a bit mournfully. Suze shot him a scornful look and sat up straighter in her big chair, as if to imply heíd be waiting for a while yet. Miles was less sure. Suzeís skin bore more than a little of that pallid slackness that was the harbinger of decline. One couldnít say she glowed with health, not even in her irate stress.

ìIf the Durona Group doesnít step in,î said Mark, ìthe inevitable end game is that this place will go to the city or the Prefecture, or to Fuwa. And in either case, patron intake stops. The life of one person isnít long enough to see this venture out.î
ìAlthough that might change in the future,î Kareen observed.
ìOr cryofreezing will become obsolete technology, and this whole demographic mess Kibou has created for itself will be naturally swept away,î said Mark.

ìIím not so sure of that,î said Miles thoughtfully. ìIf people start getting frozen at eight hundred instead of eighty, the game will still go on, just set to a new equilibrium. Although at eight hundred, itís hard to guess how people will think. At twenty, I could not have imagined myself at almost-forty. I canít imagine eighty even now.î
Suze snorted.
Mark shrugged. ìThat will be for them to decide, however many decades or centuries from now. I expect death will still be cheap and always available, doesnít take high tech.î

ìDuring the initial transition period,î Kareen said, wrenching things back from this flight of speculation to the practical present, ìtreatment actually will be free, if the subject is willing to sign up for the experimental protocols and give the legal releases. And anyone coming in can give their own permissions.î Not needing, this implied, any cooperation from Madame Suze and company. ìI expect the Group will prefer to have a few more healthy live subjects to start on, before tackling the more difficult complications from death trauma and cryorevival. Although theyíll certainly want data on those as well.î
Suze growled. Tenbury scratched his beard.

Kareen regarded her fingernails, looked up, smiled. Miles wasnít sure if anyone else caught Markís small gesture, two fingers held out and then curled once more atop his stomach. The pair had the good-cop-bad-cop routine down to an art, Miles thought with admiration, and it would be a naïve observer who concluded that all the bad-cop ideas came from Markóor the good-cop ones from his partner, for that matter. Kareen continued serenely, ìThe Durona Group will be doing a lot of local hiring, if this goes through. For example, if you, Madame Suzuki, were to sign up for the first round of protocols, and they proved to work as well as we hope, the position of Director of Community Relations could be made open for you. Which would put you in place to work on these problems on an on-going basis, right from here. This is all too complex to be solved in a night, but that doesnít mean itís too complex to be solved ever.î
ìBuy me off with an empty title? Oh, as if I havenít seen how that works before!î

ìWhat you make of it could be largely up to you,î said Mark, sounding as if he didnít care one way or another. ìBut in three years, when all those chambers below stairs are emptied out, it may be a whole new situation, here. Employment would keep you in the center of things, with real input.î

It wasnít the future Suze had set her mind to; Miles fancied he could hear her imagination creaking with the strain of change, like a gate almost rusted shut. Almost. She said querulously, ìWhat about the rest of us?î

ìTenbury, Iíd hire tonight,î said Mark readily. ìWeíll be wanting a Director of Physical Plant first thingóthe place certainly needs significant upgrades and repairs, starting from the laboratory core outward. Weíll likelyîóhe flicked a glance at Fuwaóìneed a local contractor. Medtech Tanaka as well, Raven vouches for her. The rest on a case-by-case basis. I do require competence. Certification can be arranged.î
Suze glowered in suspicion. Tenbury raised his hairy eyebrows.

The lawyer, Madame Xia, put in smoothly, ìBy the tacit contracts argument, Ms. Suzuki is the tacit proxy holder for all who have been frozen here, and can give blanket protocol permissions for all who entered here under her care. I believe I can make this argument work for the city adjudicator, since the city doesnít want the liability for several thousand destitute cryo-corpses.î
ìNot even if the city could register their votes?î asked Miles. ìSeems to me that would be enough to swing a city election, if not one on the Prefecture or planetary level.î

ìI think I could guaranteeóor at least plausibly suggestóexpensive legal challenges about that, which the adjudicator would not relish.î The lawyer smiled quietly. ìUnless disunity among the petitioners forces the matter to go before a judge, in which case I cannot guarantee the outcome, because at that point the issues will become public and political. I actually spend most of my working time keeping my clients out of court.î

ìPublic and political sounds like a job for Madame Satoís group, or something like it,î Miles said. ìI regret that we didnít snatch the other two members of her committee while we were at it. Weíd have them now.î Although an attempt to carry off three cryo-corpses from NewEgyptís coffers would certainly have taken more time, and might have gone less luckily.
ìClient confidentiality has certain limits, Lord Vorkosigan,î Xia warned him. Kindly, he thought.
ìDiplomatic immunity?î

ìWorks for you. Not for me. But in this event, with criminal charges certainly coming down on NewEgypt, there may be legal ways to wrench Mr. Kang and Ms. Khosla away from their captors. Subpoena them as witnesses, for starters.î
Miles tilted his head in appreciation. ìIf one could keep them from being destroyed by NewEgypt en route.î
ìThat would be an important consideration in designing the approach, yes.î
Mark pointed. ìKareen, put her on retainer.î
Xia smiled warily. ìMy plate at work is actually rather full. I was only able to come here tonight because itís after hours.î
ìPartner or employee?î
ìMe? Iím one of three associates in the galactic business law department of my firm. We work under a partner.î
ìThe Durona Group will certainly be needing full-time local legal advice,î murmured Kareen. ìPerhaps we should talk instead about salaryÖ later.î

Xia waved this away, provisionally. ìIn any case, Ms. Suzuki, Iíd invite you to think about what is the better long-term practical result for your patrons. You serve one community; this technology has the potential to serve the planet. If theóî
An echoing boom from outside rattled the windows. Roic shot to his feet and peered into the night. ìWhat tí hellÖ ?î
ìThat sounded awfully close,î said Xia uneasily.
ìWas that us?î said Madame Suze. ìTenburyÖî
ìCould be the plastics fabricator next door,î said Fuwa, joining Roic. ìThough I canít think what theyíd be doing over there at this hour. Or something from the streetÖ collision?î
But with the municipal traffic control net here, collisions were vanishingly rare, Miles had thought.
ìItís hard to tell the direction,î said Tenbury, craning his neck as well.
ìGo up on the roof and look,î directed Madame Suze.
Tenbury was halfway out the door when Milesís wristcom chimed, emergency secured channel. Vorlynkin. Not good. Miles found himself on his feet without remembering standing up. ìVorkosigan here.î

ìLord Auditor.î Vorlynkin sounded winded. ìAn arson teamóI counted four menójust put a fire bomb through a ground-floor window of the heat exchanger building. Asterzine, I thinkóit was a two-part liquid fire-starter, anyway.î
ìCall the local fire guards!î
ìAlready did, sir.î The cadence of Vorlynkinís language was reverting to old military training, Miles noted in passing. ìPolice, too. They should be here in moments.î
ìGood man.î
ìIím looking now to see if there are more intruders. Havenít spotted any so far. Iím fairly sure thereís no one left in the exchanger buildingócanít speak to under it.î
ìKeep this channel open.î
ìRight, sir.î
Miles wheeled to find everyone staring at Fuwa, who stared back in horror.
ìIt wasnít me!î the contractor practically wailed. ìNot this time! Why would it be me, now? Iím about to get rid of this mess!î
ìMy exchanger towers!î cried Tenbury, starting for the door again. ìIf they go down, everyoneíll start to thaw!î Suze grabbed his sleeve.
ìMy exchanger towers!î cried Fuwa. ìMy facility!î

ìTenbury.î Madame Suze shook the custodianís arm, for emphasis. ìTell everyone you see, get out of the buildings and assemble on that patch of open ground in front of the intake building. Iíll wake up and warn everyone on this floor.î

The front of the patron intake building was on the opposite side of the four-building complex from the fire-so-far, a map of the layout burning, so to speak, in Milesís mindís eye. So the arson had occurred as far as possible from the intake building, and the people now in it. This stank of diversion.
ìShould we go to Vorlynkin?î asked Roic, jittering like a horse at the start of a race.
ìNo. To Leiber. Anything interesting will turn up at Leiber.î
Roicís eyes widened as he took in the implications; Miles didnít have to spell them out. ìAh.î
ìSuze, weíll go warn them in the intake building,î Miles added.
Madame Suze, already short of breath and with her hand pressed to her heart, nodded and said, ìI know Vristi Tanaka is on the second floor. I think she just started a cryoprep.î
ìWeíll get the word to her, as well as to our people.î

She waved thanks and tottered out, Xia going with her in support and asking shrewd questions about where else all the sleeping residents were to be found at this hour. Tenbury sprinted ahead of them. Miles and Roic followed, turning in the opposite direction for the nearest stairs.

Through the office doors, Miles glimpsed Mark and Kareen braking Fuwa, one at each elbow providing a combined resistance that plainly surprised the big man, as he was yanked backward almost off his feet.
ìFuwa-san,î Mark began in his most urbane voice, ìletís talk fire sale.î

Jin staggered up the last flight of stairs, puffing, lugging Nefertiti. For no discernable reason, sheíd shied and bolted back past him in the alley below the exchanger building as Vorlynkin had disappeared around the corner, and Jin had caught her on a lucky tackle. Well, it had seemed lucky at the time. The sphinx seemed to have at least doubled in weight since then. She growled continuously, and shed fur and feathers on his shirt, but didnít try to scratch him.
ìGet the door,î Jin wheezed, and Mina nodded and swung it wide. It was labeled, on this side, Fire Door: Do Not Block. So did that mean it would stop a fire? Jin hoped they werenít about to find out.

Nefertiti wriggled some more, and finally lunged from Jinís sweaty, failing grip just as they made it down the corridor to the recovery room, so Jin was at least able to spill her into this more confined area. Leiber-sensei, who was slumped in a battered folding chair staring anxiously into space, jerked upright at their entry.
ìI thought you went to get rid of that thing!î he said, eyeing the sphinx with disfavor.
His mother sat up in her bed. ìJin? Mina? Whatís going on?î
ìIt was ninjas, mommy!î Mina declared breathlessly. ìWe saw them! They set fire to Jinís hideout!î
ìWhat?î
ìIt was not either ninjas,î said Jin impatiently. ìIt was just some stupid guys dressed in black stuff.î
ìWas that anything to do with the strange thump we heard through the walls a few minutes ago?î asked his mother.
Jin nodded. ìIt was even louder close up. Consul Vorlynkin said it was some kind of liquid fire-starter.î
His mother gasped. ìHow close were you?î
ìWe were on top of the roof, looking right down at them!î said Mina. ìThe fireball was all orange and black!î
Leiber-sensei stood up and gripped the back of his chair, looking very uneasy.
ìWhereís Raven-sensei?î said Jin. ìVorlynkin said we were supposed to tell him about the fire, and then do what he said.î
ìHe went down to the second floor to help Medtech Tanaka with a cryoprep,î said Leiber-sensei.

Jinís mother slid out of bed and came to the wall of her booth, standing with her hands pressed against the glass. ìJin, maybe youíd better run downstairs and tell them whatís going on. Was the fire spreading very fast?î
ìWe couldnít tell yet.î
ìMaybe Iíd better find a room with a window and look,î said Leiber-sensei.
ìWhereís Stefin gone?î asked their mother. ìHe was supposed to look after you two!î
ìI think he went to look for more ninjas,î said Mina.
She touched her hand to her lips. ìIsnít that the sort of thing that Armsman Roic fellow is supposed to do?î
ìHeís probably with Miles-san,î Jin called over his shoulder, heading toward the door again. ìMina, donít let Nefertiti get out!î
Leiber-sensei followed close on Jinís heels. And then cringed backward as the door was kicked open from the corridor side. Mina shrieked.
So did Nefertiti. ìFoes, foes!î she screamed, flapping madly around the room and up onto a table.
Oh, Nefertiti, youíre so right, thought Jin, backing up as Chief Hans and Sergeant Oki shouldered into the recovery room.

The pair seemed out of breath, and angry, and much, much bigger when looming vertically than when theyíd been laid out on the floor of the garage office, drooling as they snored. Theyíd changed their clothes from the rumpled blue medical smocks theyíd worn earlier, and were now dressed in uniformlike gray trousers and heavy cloth jackets, with equipment belts and big clumping boots, but without any insignia or name tags or identifying markers.
ìThere you are, you stupid turd! Finally!î growled tall Hans to Leiber-sensei, whoíd backed up against a table and turned pale.
ìWhat the hellÖ ?î said broad Oki, staring around at their audience. ìWhat are these kids doing here? That jerk Akabane didnít say anything about kids.î
ìNever mind, just grab him.î

Oki strode forward and did so, yanking Leiber-sensei around, doing something with the policemanís baton he carried in his hand, and hauling the scientistís arm up behind his back. Leiber-sensei yelped.
ìLet him go!î cried their mother through the glass.
Hansís head turned, and his eyes narrowed. ìIíll say what the hell! Itís that bitch Sato! They must have woken her up. Isnít this the jackpot! Grab her too, Oki!î

ìYouíll have to. My hands are full,î snapped his companion. Leiber-sensei tried to resist by going limp, and almost succeeded in slithering out of his captorís grip, but Oki jerked him upright once more, freed the hand with the baton, and slapped it with a loud electric pop against Leiber-senseiís thigh. Leiber-sensei yelled really loud. With a surprised gasp, Oki flinched and almost let him go, as the electric jolt evidently traveled through his victimís body and bit his gripping hand. But he renewed his clutch before the shuddering scientist could escape it.
Hans strode toward the booth and hit the lock control; the door slid back, and air puffed out.
ìNo!î said Jin, panicking so much that his vision blurred. ìSheís not supposed to come out yet! Sheíll get sick!î

ìSheís going to be a lot sicker when Akabane gets done with her,î Hans snarled. He lunged for their mother, who hopped up and across the bed, and almost made it around the end to the door and freedom before he lunged again, caught her by the arm, and swung her against the glass wall with a sickening thud. He manhandled her out of the booth, stumbling, her long hair tumbling down all over.

ìNo, you canít have my mommy!î screamed Mina. ìWe just got her back!î She grabbed the folding chair, flopped it shut, and swung it as hard as she could. She might have been trying to hit the security chief in the stomach, but Mina was pretty short, and her aim was rather blind, as she whirled around. Instead, the chair legs took him square in the crotchóbut not quite hard enough.

He bent over, saying really horrible words, but didnít let go of their motherís arm. With his other fist, he backhanded Mina, who fell on her butt, crying. Their mother tried to kick him, more accurately than Mina had, but she was barefooted and frighteningly breathless. ìHow dareÖ you touchÖ my children, youÖ horrible murderer!î

Remembering the blood running down Vorlynkinís face, Jin dodged around the table where Nefertiti stood stiff-legged, wings flapping, fur on end in a dark ridge running down her back, tail lashing, and shrieking incoherently. He grabbed her up and flung her at Oki, who was closest. The wide man yelled, waving his snapping and popping stick but only connecting with wing feathers, which scorched with a dreadful stink. Nefertiti leaped off him, shredding his jacket but only getting in one shallow bleeding scratch on his thick neck. Leiber-sensei broke from his grip, though. The scientist lurched and limped, dodging out of the way of the swinging baton.

ìOh, for Godís sake!î said Hans. ìAkabane didnít say weíd have to capture a damned tribe!î As Jin made a head-down rush with some wild idea of head-butting him in the stomach, Hans shoved their mother away hard, so she fell and skidded on the floor next to Mina, who scrambled to reach her. The tall man grabbed for Jin instead, catching him by the hair and swinging him around. Jin yelled, tears of pain starting in his eyes. He heard a strange snick by his ear, and looked down cross-eyed to glimpse a steel blade at least fifteen centimeters long glint past his face and lodge below his upraised chin.
ìEverybody, freeze!î bellowed Chief Hans.
Everybody did. Hans added impatiently, ìNot you, Oki!î
ìHans, no, heís just a kid!î
ìAfter the day weíve had, donít push me.î

The belief and terror in Okiís face convinced the others that this was no bluff as nothing else could have, Jin thought. He could feel the edge pressing into his skin, and strands of hair popping from his stretched scalp.

ìAll right,î said Hans. The big chest against which Jin was now pressed heaved for air, and maybe for balance. Could the big man actually be frightened, too? That was a weird thought, and not reassuring. ìBehave, all of you, or Iíll cut the damn kidís throat, got it? You, quit wriggling!î He shook Jinís head back and forth by the hair.
Jinís mother, still on the floor, glared up cold and furious, but said in a voice sharp with dread, ìJin, hold still!î

Jin could see Leiber-sensei swallow. The limping sphinx had taken refuge in the shadows under a table, where she crouched and mumbled piteously, ìFoes, foes, hurts, aowt, hum, hurts!î That, and people breathing, were the only sounds in the windowless room.

Hans straightened. ìThatís better. Now, you, kid, stuff your hands in your pockets.î Jin, after a glance at his mother, complied. ìYou, Sato, stand up. You too, Doctor, and put your hands on top your head. Sato, take the mini-bitch by the hand with your right hand. Now, youíre all going to march out in file, and Oki with his stick will keep you all in line. Set it on high, Oki!î
The broad man gulped, nodded, fiddled with the control in the base of the handle.
ìNow, you all follow Oki out the door and turn right. Sato first, Leiber next, then me.î

Their mother, her face utterly still and intent, grasped Minaís hand convulsively; they both stood up together. Her bare feet moved soundlessly on the floor, her padded robe flapping around her calves. Mina, sniffling and scared, trotted alongside. Leiber-sensei would have looked silly with his arms up like that, as if he were playing some toddlerís rhyming game about touching your nose and ears and head, if he werenít so grim and pale and shivering. Jin waited for the grip on his hair to slacken, the knife edge to press less deeply, so that he could twist away and run, but the big fists holding him didnít ease.
They followed the others out into the corridor, Jinís feet barely touching the floor as he was yanked along, and turned right. They took maybe three steps toward the end stairs.
A bellow from behind them, Armsman Roicís deep voice: ìHalt!î

Chief Hans whirled, still holding Jin in front of him. Up the corridor from the other end-stairs strode Roic-san, with Miles-san running at his elbow and Raven-sensei sort of dodging behind him. Roic raised his right arm, something in his fist too blurred for Jinís pain-teared eyes to make out. His expression was very strange, cool and remote, like no expression at all.
Jin felt his captor flinch. The knife edge bit harder. Hans yelled back, ìYou again! Drop that damned stuhóî

A white light flared from Roic-sanís hand, and a strange buzzing noise. The world, or maybe it was Jinís head, seemed to explode in a jagged shower of colored rain. The rain turned black, and drowned him deep.

To Roicís surprise, he was actually aided in his capture of the remaining NewEgypt security fellow by Dr. Leiber. Oki had grabbed the scientist when Roic had shouted, presumably to keep him from bolting, but then found him harder to get rid of; Leiber hung on to the thick left arm that was trying to shake him off, turning and twisting and evading what looked to be a heavy-duty shock stick, just long enough for Roic to close the distance and aim his stunner between Okiís eyes at point-blank range.
ìGive it up, Oki,î Roic advised genially. ìItís been over ever since I sent your confessions off in a bottle. Iíd have thought you people would have realized that.î

Caught and nailed by Roicís steady and implacable gaze as much as by the weapon aimed at his head, Oki reluctantly held his right arm wide and released his shock stick, which fell with a clatter. As he slumped, Leiber stood away from him, wheezing but with his spine actually straight for a change. Unasked, Oki folded his hands atop his head and stood looking downright miserable.

Madame Sato, distraught, slid to the floor to gather up her sonís limp body. The unconscious boy was pale, but Roic saw with satisfaction that the cut on his neck was a mere shallow scratch, barely bleeding.
ìIím sorry Jin was caught in my stunner nimbus, maíam,î Roic said to her. ìBut Iíve found itís usually better to resolve these hostage situations as directly as I can. Bad to let them spin out.î
ìThis is a nightmare,î she groaned.
Roic granted this with a nod, but said, ìCut short now, maíam. Raven will get Jin some synergine right awayîóRoic rolled his eye compellingly at Ravenóìand he wonít even wake up with a headache.î
Raven took the hint and scurried back to the recovery room for suitable supplies.
Mílord strolled up, possessed himself of the shock stick, and regarded their captive with a curious and thoughtful air, like a biologist planning out the dissection of a promising new specimen.
Oki regarded him back, bewildered. ìWho the hell are you people, anyway?î

ìFrom your point of view,î said mílord, ìI suppose weíre your karma delivery service. Why the devil didnít you and your buddy Hans run and keep on running when you had the chance, earlier today? Yesterday, by now, I guess. Why ever did you go back to your bosses?î
ìWe got families, you know.î
Mílordís brows rose. Had this not occurred to him before now, Roic wondered? ìIf you didnít want to be a disgrace to them, youíre about eighteen months too late, I think.î
Oki rocked a bit. ìThat, and the money.î
Mílord brows went up a bit further. Oki said defensively, ìFor the first time in my life, the money was good. We bought a house.î

Okiís was not exactly a world of riotous living, Roic suspected. If NewEgyptís plant security hiring practices were any good, heíd probably been an honest man, before heíd been sucked down into this bog by his bosses. Roic glanced at mílord, prepared to give a hint and a nudge, but mílord was on it already.
ìItís not too late even now to limit your damages. Whatís the local equivalent of turning Emperorís Witness around here, does anyone know? They must have one.î
ìPrefectureís Evidence, I believe, mílord,î said Roic.
ìI happen to have a good lawyer on retainer who can advise you, if you cooperate with me in a timely fashion,î mílord told their captive. ìThat means, instantly.î
Roic took the cue and a tighter grip on his stunner, staring along its length into Okiís eyes, for emphasis.
ìWhere were you taking Leiber and Sato just now?î asked mílord. ìNot for a walk, presumably.î
ìAkabaneís waiting for us out front in the street with the van,î mumbled Oki.
ìThe NewEgypt finance chief? Alone?î
Oki wet his lips. ìIt was just supposed to be Leiber, see.î
Mílordís eyes lit. ìThat one we want, Roicóin flagrante delicto and arrested on the premises, if possible. An enemyís mistake is a tactical gift that must never be wasted.î

Oki added, unasked, ìIt was going to be wall-to-wall lawyers for themóPresident Kim, and Choi who runs Operations, and Napak, that research head. Akabane caught us after the big meetingósaid it was plain that him and us were going to be the goats, that the other three would hand us over without a blink in the morning if nothing was done. But he knew from the last time that my brother-in-law was with the Legacy Liberators, andÖî
ìDivision and panic, ah,î said mílord, sounding quite satisfied. ìThat explains much. Hurry, Roic. Akabaneís bound to bolt as soon as the police show up in force.î

Raven was returning with a medkit. Roic passed his stunner briefly to mílord, circled Oki and fastened his wrists behind his back with his own tanglecuffs, was blandly handed back his weapon, grabbed Leiberís arm, and jogged for the end stairs.
ìWhat do you want me for?î asked Leiber, sounding a touch alarmed, as they scuffed rapidly down the steps.
ìYou can ID Akabane for me. I wouldnít want to stun the wrong fellow, after all.î
ìYouíre pretty free with that thing.î
ìItís all right. I have a license to stun.î
ìI thought that was supposed to be a license to kill.î
Roic grimaced. ìThat, too. But you would not believe all the forms that have to be filled out, afterward.î
Leiber looked as if he werenít sure if that was a joke or not, which was all right, since Roic wasnít sure either. The procedures hadnít been all that amusing at the time. Or in retrospect.

They pushed through the heavy metal doors at the intake buildingís far end, turned left, and rounded the corner onto its long front side. A short, U-shaped driveway in the center led to a covered entry space, where patients and visitors had once been dropped off, no doubt. The drive embraced what had likely been a sweep of tidy lawn and landscaping, but now was a sad stretch of weeds. There was no security lighting, but a lot of flickering hand lights revealed a herd of elderly people in all sorts of dress and undress, milling about on the drive and the ex-lawn. To Roicís relief, no orange fire-glow reflected in the night mist from the other side of the complex, but various colors of flashing emergency lights did, which helped illuminate the scene in a dance-party sort of fashion.

A double row of parking spaces ran the length of the facilityís frontóRoic could see the end of the administration building, beyond the intake building, and mentally located Madame Suzeís corner office on its top floor. Beyond the parking row, the facility was bounded by the dilapidated chain link fence.

In the street beyond, only one or two dark and distant vehicles were parked, but just past the gate with its tumbled-down old security kiosk, a familiar van lurked in the shadows. The gate, interestingly, had been forced open and left standing wide.

ìAll right,î said Roic. ìWaitíll I take cover behind that gate kiosk, then go out to the end of the lawn and mill around like the others. Make sure you can be seen from the street, but donít get within armís length of the drive.î
ìWait, what, you want to use me as bait?î said Lieber, indignant. ìI thought you wanted me to identify Akabane!î
ìThisíll do that,î said Roic reasonably. ìNobody else here is going to go grabbing for you. Plus it will lure him out of his vehicle and onto the grounds.î I hope.
ìWhy bother?î
ìFirst, I canít stun him through the side of the van, and second, if nothing else, Lord Mark can charge him with trespassing. Which will hold him for the night, and by morning itíll be too late.î
ìI thought that fellow Fuwa owned the place.î

ìIf Lord Mark doesnít own it by now, I donít know him.î Not that anyone did really know him, not even mílord. Well, maybe Miss Kareen. ìGo on.î Roic gave Lieber a little encouraging shove, then drifted away unobtrusively through the intermittent shadows to take cover on the facility side of the gate kiosk, out of sight of the street.

Leiber stumbled around quite convincingly among the weeds, albeit at a few meters farther range than Roic would have preferred, looking up and around as if in bewilderment, showing profile and full-face. For a minute, Roic wasnít sure if Akabane would rise to his bait, and was just trying to think of a next ploy, when the van eased past the kiosk. Roic crouched down in the shadows.

For a horrible instant, he wondered if heíd misjudged the situationóif Akabane just lifted the van to head-height and brought it down hard enough atop his victim, Leiber would be in no shape to confess anything to anyone again. Someone had tried to do that to mílord once, as heíd told the story to Roic, with several passes like a big stomping boot coming within centimeters of reducing him to a smear on the pavement. Roic tensed like a runner at the start of a race, getting ready to sprint to his baitís rescue.

But maybe these local vehicles had safety sensors to prevent those sorts of accidents, or maybe Akabane was inhibited by the hundred or so witnesses. In any case, as its side door slid open the van merely lurched up onto the lawn, cutting Leiber off from the sight of the old folks, who were mostly turned away craning their necks toward the source of the flashing lights.

A dark shape leaped from the van toward Leiber, who recoiled. Roic took a sweeping knee shot and brought the figure down in a muffled cry of astonishment and rage. A few swift paces, and Roic was in position to put his favorite low-stun immobilization into the back of the fellowís neck, at canít-miss range.
ìQuick, help me toss him back into his van,î Roic told Leiber, who, puffing, nodded and complied.

Chief Financial Officer Akabane proved a local-looking sortóhe might have been Ravenís middle-aged wicked uncle, if the Durona clone had owned any uncles of any description. Although Akabane did not look especially wicked at this point, just pale and limp. And, Roic hoped, defeated.

For all the days mílord had been playing against the NewEgypt cabal, this was the first direct view Roic had gained of the enemyís face, except for a few vid scans. It had all been action at a distance, like a space war. Or perhaps some bizarre mutant form of chess where the rules changed every two moves. Mílordís formidable father, whoíd once been a space admiral, might have felt at home, and mílord had scarcely been given pause, but to Roic it felt strange and bloodless and removed, though he was very grateful for the bloodless part.

And then Roic wondered how mílordís sudden trail of chaos through their affairs, erupting out of seeming-nowhere, must have felt to the confused cryocorp men, whoíd thought theyíd had it all locked down. That was a vision to make a fellow smile, though it was a smile that made Leiber draw back in unease.

From the corner of his eye, Roic saw the lights of emergency vehicles turning into the street; theyíd be through the gate in seconds. ìMelt into the crowd and meet me back at the end door,î he told Leiber, and swiftly followed his own advice. Melting into this crowd proved a bit of a trick, as he was a head taller, as well as about a century younger, than anyone else around him. But there was plenty enough else going on right now that no one spared him much attention.
Leiber arrived a few paces behind him. ìThatís it?î he asked.

Roic nodded. ìMílord will arrange the rest. Stunner tagís over.î Roic took a momentís modest satisfaction in his job performance. ìItís all words from here on. Which are not my department.î He added after a reflective pause: ìThankfully.î

Jin blinked open his eyes to discover himself staring at a ceilingóof the recovery room, he realized after turning his head. He touched his face, which was tingling, and scrunched his eyelids open and shut a few times, but he didnít feel especially sick or dizzy. He didnít feel especially good, either. Sort of blah, really. He seemed to be lying on one of the roomís several raised, narrow bed-tables, though it didnít have any sheets, and its brittle old plastic felt nasty on his skin.
ìJin, are you all right?î
He sat up on one elbow to find his mother leaning over the side of the bed-table. She was wearing her filtering mask again, her robe all belted up tight, and her eyes searched him anxiously.
ìI guess so.î He rubbed his face some more, then scrubbed his scalp where it still hurt from the hair-pulling.
Mina skipped to their motherís side and looked up at him with great interest. ìArmsman Roic shot you. Iíd never seen anyone get shot for real before.î

Neither had Jin. It felt very strange to have been shot. For the first time, he wondered what it had really been like for Miles-san when heíd been shot with that needle-grenade. Of course, that was nothing like being merely stunned, Jin supposed, but that weird moment of looking into Armsman Roicís unyielding face, and feeling so helpless and too late and that his world was being taken away from him by people he didnít, couldnít, controlÖ He scowled, not liking that feeling much.
ìItís not broken,î came Raven-senseiís voice, and, ìYou couldnít prove it by me,î Vorlynkinís voice returned.

Jin twisted around to find the pair of them at the next table over. Vorlynkin was sitting up with his legs dangling. His wide-sleeved coat was off, tossed aside, along with his undercoat, and his shirtsleeves were rolled up. Raven-sensei stood in front of him, poking at his left arm, which Vorlynkin was holding rather defensively.

Vorlynkinís face was all washed, and Nefertitiís claw marks were now three thin red lines beneath a shiny layer of transparent plastic bandage. There was a lot of drying blood soaked on his shirt collar, though, and spattered elsewhere on his clothes, and Jin cringed in guilt for his new pet.
ìYou will have some magnificent bruises,î Raven-sensei continued.
ìA crowbar will do that. Iím lucky I didnít get my face bashed in.î
ìVorlynkin-san found more ninjas,î Mina confided to Jin. ìThey had a fight. Vorlynkin-san won.î

Vorlynkin looked over and smiled rather ruefully at her. ìFortunately for me, not ninjas. They were just a couple of borrowed thugs from the local chapter of the N.H.L.L. Finally trying to carry out their slogan, I suppose.î
ìI thought they were all arrested after the conference kidnappings,î said Raven-sensei.

ìThat was an especially radical splinter group, apparently. Their organization is not very unified at the best of times, I gather.î Vorlynkin added to Jin, ìI found the pair of them around the far end of the next building over from your hideout, trying to pry the door open and get down into the tunnels with more fire-starter. If theyíd succeeded it would have been a major mess.î
Raven-senseiís eyebrows lifted. ìWould the arsonists even have gotten themselves out alive?î

ìHard to say. It seems awfully easy to get turned around down there. But the department was able to get the fire in the exchanger building under control quickly, once Iíd told them it was asterzine. Ugly product, asterzine. You donít want to put water on it, and it would have been a horrible surprise for the firefighters if they had. You can believe theyíll be going after the N.H.L.L. in the morning.î
Jinís brow wrinkled. ìWhy a crowbar? The door around the next side after that is always left unlocked.î

Vorlynkin blinked, then laughed, then winced, touching his scratched face. ìJust as well that none of us knew that, I suppose. After I confiscated the crowbar, I was able to hold them till the police arrived. Some of the firemen were more than eager to help. The pair fingered the NewEgypt security guards as having engaged them, evidently just to create a diversion for Dr. Leiberís re-kidnapping, though I gather that some of the Liberators grew over-eager and exceeded their instructions. But it should lead back nicely to the senior men Lord Auditor Vorkosigan wished to target.î
Their mother rubbed her forehead, frown-lines deepening around her eyes. ìIf they donít manage to suppress it all, again.î
ìNot this time, I suspect,î said Vorlynkin, smiling at her in reassurance.
ìWhereís Nefertiti?î asked Jin in sudden alarm.

Mina pointed at the desk built into the far wall, along with a lot of cupboards. From the shadows beneath came a mumbling sort of growl. ìSheís hiding. Maybe you can get her to come out after she calms down. I tried some food, but I donít think sheís hungry right now.î
Raven-sensei stepped around the tables to smile at Jin, peer into his eyes, thumb back his eyelids, and feel his pulse. ìHeadache? Nausea?î
ìNot really.î Jin felt down his tingling face to find a strip of plastic bandage across his neck.
ìJust a nick,î Raven-sensei assured him.
ìMy face is a little numb.î

ìThatís normal. Itíll pass in another hour. If it doesnít, let me know.î Raven-sensei paused and cleared his throat. ìLord Vorkosigan said to tell you when you woke up, those few minutes of delay you and Mina caused with those NewEgypt thugs made all the difference to us. The rescue party, as it turned out.î
ìOh,î said Mina, sounding pleased.

Raven-sensei nodded. ìIf theyíd hustled you out of the building before we arrived, he said, it would have been a long stern chaseóone of his military turns of phrase, thatómeaning, weíd have had a hell of a time catching up with you. Although I imagine he would have, somehow. He, ahÖ tends to be persistent.î

For the first time, Jin sat all the way up. In the glass booth next to his motherís, the two big NewEgypt guys were penned, and Jin flinched in fear, till he saw that Hans was still out cold on the floor, and Oki was sitting with his hands fastened behind his back and his shoulders slumped, not paying attention to anything.

Jin pictured itóall of them dragged away in some windowless van to who-knew-where, and Mom taken away againÖ He gulped, which made the bandage tug on his skin. His desperate struggle with those big men hadnít seemed to do much good at the time, had seemed utterly futile in fact, but maybeÖ
Miles-san himself blew in then, his step brisk, with Armsman Roic in tow. Oki still didnít look up, and Jin was reminded that you couldnít hear anything in those booths.
ìAh,î said Roic, smiling at Jin and giving him a friendly wave. ìYouíre awake. Good.î

Jin scowled back, not quite able to get that new picture out of his mindís eye of Roic looking through him like he wasnít there while he aimed the stunner. Roicís face fell, a little, though he then tried his smile on Mina to better effect. Was it all a fake, that smile? Which was the real Roic, the big smiling man or that cold, intent, scary one?

ìYouíre all here, excellent,î said Miles-san to the room at large. He hopped up on a chair like a teacher about to give a lecture, commanding everyoneís attention, and making himself quite as tall as Roic. It should have looked silly, and Jin wasnít sure why it didnít.

ìThe Northbridge police will be here in minutes to start recording statements, and to take delivery of our NewEgypt guests,î Miles-san went on, with a wave at the jail-booth. ìWe should be getting a couple of sleepy lawyers by then, too. Madame Xia has categorically insisted she has no expertise in criminal law, but weíve woken up a couple of associates from her firmís criminal department. Weíll have the senior partner in later today, when weíre all back at the consulate and have rested up a bit.î
Jinís mother stiffened. ìWe never had good luck with lawyers before.î
ìThis time, theyíll be on your side,î Miles-san promised. ìMeanwhile, Raven, Dr. Leiber, Consul Vorlynkin, we have just time to get our stories straight.î
Raven-sensei looked interested, Leiber-sensei alarmed, and Consul Vorlynkin resigned.

Miles-san went on, ìThis whole chain of events is too complex and interlocking to adjust much, but on the whole Iíd prefer to be less prominent in it, for reasons having to do with the other half of my investigations on Kibou. Which do not concern and should not impinge on your affairs, Madame Sato, so donít be alarmed. Fortunately, Raven and Dr. Leiber, here, are well positioned to be the local heroes.î
Raven-senseiís brows rose. Leiberís stare at Miles-san grew glumly suspicious.

ìShort version is, when Raven and I visited you that first day, Dr. Leiber, it was because Raven was head-hunting a top cryo-preservatives chemist for the Durona Groupís proposed new expansion to this Northbridge facility. Which is a position you will in fact be offered, by the way, assuming we can keep you out of jail.î
ìOh!î said Leiber-sensei, sitting up, his sudden smile surprised but gratified.

ìAt that time, Dr. Leiber explained his renewed plans to blow the whistle on NewEgypt for the decomposed cryo-solution and commodified contracts scandal, and that he had abstracted Madame Satoís cryo-corpse to assure her safety as a future witness. Seizing his opportunity, he engaged Dr. Durona to revive her, as part of his price for employment, and Dr. Durona, anxious to secure his services, agreed.î
ìAnd carried her stolen cryochamber off to my secret laboratory on the spot?î inquired Raven-sensei, a bit dryly.
ìPrecisely.î Miles-san smiled cheerfully at him. ìThough letís not use the term stolen in your statements, should the issue arise. Rescued would be all right, or secured.î
Raven-sensei waved assent. ìAnd then what?î

ìDr. Leiberís attempt to leave Kibou for Escobar was a feint, to draw NewEgypt off, and out, till Madame Sato was revived and ready to testify. Unfortunately, it worked a little too well. But his rescue by Roic, at Ravenís request, was allowed by me as a nepotistic favor to my brotherís company.

ìI was along for the ride tonight merely to keep an eye on Mark, whose movements are of on-going interest to Barrayaran Imperial Security for purely Barrayaran political reasons. Which also happens to be true, by the way. Having concluded that there is no current threat to the Imperium from Markís new enterprise, I shall be withdrawing from Kibou-daini shortly to tend to my own urgent affairs.î
Jin blinked at this news. Yah, wellÖ of course it had to be that way. People always left. Nothing was ever really secure, or safe. He bit his lip.

ìI suggest we not volunteer any information on the late Alice Chen tonight, and I think her existence is unlikely to come up as yet, but if it does, Raven abstracted her at Dr. Leiberís request as well, as independent physical evidence for the effects of the bad cryo-solution. Raven being enough of both a scientist and a businessman not to put his company at risk on mere hearsay.î
Raven tilted his head and grinned at this. ìThat works for me.î

Miles-san rolled his shoulders and stretched. He did look a little gray-faced, a very four-oíclock-in-the-morning look, if no more tired than anyone else here. His eyes were bright, though. He turned to Jinís mother. ìI have an experienced forensic economics analyst already en route from the Barrayaran embassy on Escobar. As it happens, my need for him has been largely short-circuited the events of the last day, but to justify the expenses of his journey I will make you a loan of him for a few days. I expect he could be of considerable help in strategizing your next moves, should you decide to try to revive your political action committee. Or even if you donít.î
Jinís mother rubbed her forehead. In a rather thick voice, she said, ìBut what if the police try to take Jin and Mina?î
It was a horrible thought, one that Jin had been trying not to think ever since Miles-san had announced the imminent arrival of the authorities.

ìI think they are unlikely to question minors when abundant adult witnesses are ready-to-hand. You are next-of-kin; theyíll have to request your permission to interrogate your children, which I suggest you deny for now on the grounds that the pair are too traumatized by the recent fright of their thwarted kidnapping.î
Mina made a faint indignant noise at this. Jin wasnít so sure.

ìThe lawyer will support you,î Miles-san went on. ìIf it becomes an issue, which I doubt it will in this immediate aftermath, tell the police to come see them later at the consulate if neededówhich, by then, I suspect it wonít be, and in any case weíll be on home ground there.î
Vorlynkin nodded reassurance at her. She shook her head in doubt, but Jin thought some of the strain eased around her eyes.
Jin glanced up to find Armsman Roic eyeing him closely. Jin shrugged uncomfortably and turned his head away.
ìMadame Sato,î came Roicís slow, deep voice, ìcan Jin and Mina come out in the corridor with me for a moment? Iíd like to show them something.î

Jin looked back, about to decline, but Mina was already hopping up and down in agreement, readily prevailing over their mother who seemed to want to say something to the consul anyway, so Jin ended up letting himself be shepherded out with his sister. Roic closed the door firmly behind them.
To Jinís surprise, Roic went down on one knee, which made him, well, not much shorter than Jin and still taller than Mina.
ìI thought,î said Roic, ìthat you might like to try firing my stunner.î He drew the weapon that had hurt so shockingly out of the holster under his jacket, and Jin flinched.
ìOoh, ooh!î said Mina. ìWow, can we?î
Which made it impossible for Jin to say No. He nodded warily.

ìYou must never point a weapon at a person unless you intend to fire,î Roic began a short tutorial. ìNo matter if you think itís uncharged, or the safety lock is on, or what. Make it an absolute habit, and it will never be a question.î He pointed out the various features of the device, including a sensor in the grip that was keyed to his own palm, and which he turned off with a code. Then he let Jin take it, making sure it was pointed up the empty corridor.

The grip was still warm from Roicís hand, like a chair youíd sat down in too soon after someone else got out of it. The stunner was lighter than Jin expected, but solid enough. The power pack in the grip gave it the most of its heft. It didnít feel like a toy.
Jin stared down the sight the way Roic told him too, and squeezed the trigger. The buzz in his hand startled him, but there was no recoil, and he managed not to drop it.

Encouraged, Jin let Roic show him how the automatic laser sight worked, and fired again. This time, he didnít jump. And again. The charge hit the wall pretty nearly just where heíd intended, this time. Jin didnít exactly smile, but he felt his jaw ease.

Mina was by this time eager to try, Let me! Let me! so Jin reluctantly gave the device up to her. Roic went through his instructions once more, prudently kneeling behind Mina and keeping a hand hovering to help steady heróshe had to hold the thing up in both fistsóand the drill was repeated.
Roic stood up, reset the code, and holstered the weapon. ìBetter?î he asked Jin.
ìYah,î said Jin, in some wonder. ìItís like a tool. Itís just a tool.î
ìThatís right.î
This time, when Roic smiled down at him, Jin smiled up. He let the armsman lead them back into the recovery room.

Miles leaned forward and spoke earnestly into the secure holovid recorder. ìI just want you to know, Gregor, that if the planet melts down over all this, it wasnít my fault. The trip-wire was laid long before I stumbled across it.î

He considered the opening remark of his report cover for a moment, then reached out and deleted it. The one good thing about the very asynchronous vid communication entailed by Nexus info-squirts, moving at light speed between jump points and ship-carried through them, was that if you didnít think before you spoke, you could at least think before you hit send. Not that he hadnít generated some of his best ideas as his brain raced to catch up with his moving mouth. Also, some of my worst. He wondered which kind his recent examples would ultimately prove to be.

He glanced around the consulateís tight-room, which he had all to himself, having run out the exhausted Johannes before embarking on this private and personal recording. Since Johannes was the closest thing to an ImpSec analyst the out-of-the-way consulate boasted, Miles had spent much of the past two days in training him in just what information, out of the uproar of the local planetary feeds, to screen and forward to Galactic Affairs on Komarr. Multitasking, always a good thing. Johannes proved a diligent enough student. If the attaché had been one of the Imperial Serviceís brighter stars, heíd have been sent to some hotter posting, but if heíd been less responsible, he wouldnít have been sent to such an autonomous one.

Miles added a note commending the lieutenantís conscientiousness, while he was thinking of it, which reminded him in turn of his early suspicions of the clerk, Yuuichi Matson. Heíd caught the tail end of a short conversation between Matson and his boss Vorlynkin in the kitchen, day-before-yesterday, when the media siege of the consulate was just beginning.

ìPeople told me Iíd be able to pocket a tidy amount of baksheesh in this job,î the clerk complained, ìbut in five years nobody offered me anything. And when they finally do, itís because they want dirt on Sato-san. Sato-san. As if I would! Agh!î
Vorlynkinís blue eyes crinkled. ìYou were doing it wrong, Yuuichi. Youíre not supposed to wait for offers, youíre supposed to ask. Or at least hint. You should ask the Lord Auditor for pointers.î
Matson just shook his head and stalked off, nursing his green tea and his umbrage. Miles grinned and bent to add a kind word for the overworked clerk, as well.

Trying to bring his mind back into focus, Miles scanned down the long index of attachments, both raw data and his synopses, that heíd generated for HQ, a tedious but necessary chore. This should suffice to keep some unfortunate team of ImpSec Galactic Affairs analysts busy and happy for a week or three, till he caught up with them in person. Well, busy, anyway. The Imperial Councilor, as the Barrayaran viceroy on Komarr was dubbed, would be invited into the loop as well when this arrived by coded tight-beam. A full analysis of the planetary voting shares scam should be awaiting the Lord Auditor by the time he made Komarr orbit, and a plan for suitable countermeasures for the vote-theft, as well.

Miles indulged himself with a brief fantasy of Ron Wing and friends waking up from cryo-stasis, expecting to have stolen a planet, as destitute and distraught as old Yani. Alas, the affair would doubtless be wound up before matters progressed that far. Cosmic justice was very appealing, but the regular kind would also do.

Putting together his Auditorial report had also sufficed to keep Miles out of the way of the consulate upstairs, and out of sight of its visitors, as the consequences had spun out from that very useful night at Madame Suzeís. The NewEgypt execs were under arrest for conspiracy, and, possibly, murder, and as the degenerated-cryopreservatives-and-commodified-contracts scandal hit the newsfeeds in force, it was likely that enough other charges would be thrown in atop to keep them from wriggling out. The attempted kidnapping involving real kids looked to prove especially damaging to their cause, score another point for Jin and Mina, which Miles must remember to tell them. Lawsuits on behalf of Madame Sato and her group were in preparation, and sheíd given her first interview, under the watchful protection of Vorlynkin and with the shrewd advice of her new attorney, who was working, very enthusiastically, on contingency.

WhiteChrys and a number of other cryocorps, shoved into premature responses by these breaking events, were making noises like outraged victims after all, and Miles, smirking, wished Ron Wing all the luck he deserved in his damage control. Asterzine was all very well for setting a building on fire, but if one wanted to set a world alightÖ well.

Miles hardly needed, he reminded himself for the nth time, to mix in further, above-stairs. Consul Vorlynkin was doing a fine job of looking out for Barrayarís interests, not to mention those of the Sato family, and Mark was atop affairs from the Durona Clinic end. Miles had danced uncomfortably close to jeopardizing his primary mission with WhiteChrys on these fascinating side-issues with NewEgypt, but given Markís new enterprise, they might not prove so sidewise after all. Miles was not above taking credit for accidental foresight; really, none of this would have come to pass if he hadnít gone on poking just a little farther than heíd needed to. He must be sure to point that out to Gregor.

Ah. Gregor. The cover message would go to the Emperorís eyes and ears only. For inspiration, Miles called up a still vid of Gregor in full uniform and his sternest glower, the official pose that Gregor had dubbed the rod up my Imperial butt look. Alas, it only inspired Miles to want to clown till he made that grave face crack a smile. No, Gregor had clowns enough in his life. Starting with about half of the Council of Counts, though they seldom made him smile.
Miles hit record once more, and began with crisp efficiency.

ìGood day, Gregor. As my follow-up note to Vorlynkinís little misguided emergency message last week indicated, suspicions of WhiteChrys chicanery on Komarr have proven correct. The raw data and my summations are in the main body of my report. Iím not sure what to do with the bribe. Iím not going to give it back, but itís not going to be worth what Ron Wing promised, either, which makes dumping it directly onto the Imperial Service Veteransí Hospice a questionable proposition. But we can deal with that later. Iíll stop at Solstice on my return trip if ImpSec Komarr and the Imperial Councilor want to ask further questions, though really, this should be enough to get them started.

ìOh, and with respect to Vorlynkin, I want a suitable Auditorial commendation to go on his diplomatic department record for exemplary assistance during my visit, or, ah, visitation. And after, as Iím running away tomorrow and dumping all of the cleanup on the poor fellow.î Better him than me.

ìMeanwhile, I suppose Iíd better give you a quick synopsis of the erupting NewEgypt scandal, as it has impinged on my investigation. It all started when the local loony party broke into the cryo-conference and failed to carry me off, which I described in brief in my last report, but after thatÖî

As succinctly as he could, Miles summarized the events of the past days, from Jinís arrival at the consulateís back door through the successful arrest of the NewEgypt crew. He was a little out of breath by the time he finished. Miles tried not to wince as he imagined the look on Gregorís face as he heard all this out. Nonplussed? Pained? Bland? Gregor could out-bland Pym.
ìSo far, no criminal charges have been leveled against me, and I trust Iíll be long gone from Kibou-daini before anyone on the other side thinks of it,î he concluded in cheerful reassurance.

He sought for an upbeat note on which to end. ìIn the department of only on Kibou, we actually got to summon the dead to testify against the bad guys, which is a moment of cosmic justice if ever there was one.î

What was that creepy old quoteÖ ? Something read in his Academy days, or more likely on one of his Academy leaves, an ancient tale from Old Earth. Before cryonics was invented or even imagined, so seeming strangely prescient. The words were branded in his brain, though their literary source was long forgotten, buried under the chaos of his intervening decades and possibly a touch of lingering cryo-amnesia. I will break the door of hell and smash the bolts; I will summon the dead to take food with the living, and the living shall be outnumbered by the host of themÖ

Ah, not something he cared to share with Gregor, that. Gregor, as Miles had reason to know, already had enough creepy crap stuffed into his Imperial head that it was a wonder his skull hadnít exploded. But it did bring Miles to his finale.

ìI shouldnít wonder if Markís rejuvenation research here doesnít turn out to be more important, in the long run, than my mission. Too early to judge, but the Durona Group will be something to keep an eye on, and not just ImpSecís spy-eyes, either. A private word in the ear of Laisaís great-aunt, if sheís looking for a better investment than WhiteChrys Solstice, might be a suitable reward for her first bringing the affair to our attention, come to think.
ìI missed todayís commercial jumpship to Escobar, but Iíve snagged berths on tomorrowís. Iím eager to get home.
ìAnd oh, tell Laisa from meóGood catch.î
Miles closed the recording, security-sealed it, attached it to his coded report, and sent it on its way.

The afternoon sun warmed the consulateís back garden, murmurous with creatures. Gyre preened and muttered on his perch. The chickens scratched in the grass or dozed in their nest boxes. The sphinx nosed and mumbled among the flower beds, occasionally sneezing just like Jinís mom. Gracing the tabletop, the turtle slowly crunched a piece of lettuce, donated from Minaís lunch salad. Lucky sat in Jinís motherís lap and purred, unsheathing her claws whenever the stroking hand stopped, apparently demanding to be petted bald. Granted that the rats, let out for a run earlier and then fed special tidbits, just curled up and slept in their cages, but then they never made much noise in the first place. It was all very alive out here, Jin thought with satisfaction.

They had brought out a table to eat lunch under a tree, Mom and Jin and Mina and Consul Vorlynkin, and Aunt Lorna, invited for the first time to visit her revived sister.
